webTitle: The making of the Millennium Star

fields.headline: The making of the Millennium Star
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The centrepiece of the dome's display of diamonds is the De Beers Millennium Star, widely regarded as one of the purest and most beautiful in the world.
fields.body:
The centrepiece of the dome's display of diamonds is the De Beers Millennium Star, widely regarded as one of the purest and most beautiful in the world.

The 2in long pear-shaped stone, which took three years to cut and polish, was bought in the early 1990s in the former Zaire, now the Democratic Republic of Congo.

Five craftsmen worked on it in Europe, America and South Africa, shaping it from one of the biggest diamonds discovered, a stone said to have been dug from a field by a Congolese miner.

Rumour has it that he sold it to a de Beers buyer for £400,000, but the company would not confirm this.

On the dome's opening night, a laser was shone through the Millennium Star, throwing shafts of light around the building.

The other 11 stones are rare blue diamonds, gathered at the De Beers Premier mine in South Africa - which yields one significant blue stone a year - and set aside for the millennium.

The largest and most stunning is the 27-carat Heart of Eternity, which sparkles in an intense blue found rarely in diamonds of its size, which often bear grey flecks of impurity.

Some reports claimed the set of 12 spectacular gems was insured for £150m, and could be worth £350m, but De Beers would not speak of their value. A spokeswoman described the Millennium Star as virtually priceless because it is so unique.

When the collection was unveiled last September, De Beers' chairman, Nicky Oppenheimer, said: "To be able to unveil not only one diamond but a collection of such rarity that most of us will not see its like again is, I think, the only adequate way to mark the passage of 2,000 years of man's history."

De Beers provided £2m in sponsorship for the dome, most of which went on security for the collection.

webTitle: America's emptiest double act

fields.headline: America's emptiest double act
fields.standfirst: As the winner is nominated of the two-horse race for the presidency Geoffrey Wheatcroft is gloomy
fields.trailText: As the winner is nominated of the two-horse race for the presidency Geoffrey Wheatcroft is gloomy
fields.body:
As the polls closed, the American election left behind an undercurrent of bitterness in the Democratic party towards Ralph Nader. The veteran environmentalist, running as a Green candidate, has been denounced in intemperate terms, at best as what New York Times calls an "ego run amok", at worst as a spoiler who has betrayed the liberal cause. There are Gore loyalists who have come to hate Nader more than George W Bush, and will never forgive him.

It is hard to see the logic of this. For a variety of good reasons, plenty of Democrats already felt betrayed by Gore, as well as by Bill Clinton, and there is something odd about telling them that they had a moral duty to vote for a candidate they dislike and despise. Richard Cohen of the Washington Post was surely right in saying that "If Al Gore loses any of the eight states where Nader has become a factor, the fault will not be Nader's. It will be Gore's." Nader has said the same himself: were the Democrat to lose, it wouldn't be Nader who had taken the election from Gore, "Al Gore will have taken the election from Al Gore."

Critics are found denouncing Nader in London as well as Washington and New York, but they don't seem to have thought it through. They can scarcely claim it is inherently wicked for a third party to run at all. Is Nader doing anything different in kind from the disillusioned Labour defectors who created the SDP in 1981 (and sharply affected the 1983 election by winning 11.6% of the vote); or for that matter from the Labour representation committee when it broke free of "Lib-Lab" subjection and set up shop 100 years ago this year, six years before it formally became a Labour party destined to supplant the Liberals?

Perhaps these traditionalist critics deplore anyone challenging the sclerotic American two-party system. In fact, what's striking about third-party interventions in presidential elections is how rare they have been - and how ineffectual they have been in disrupting that system. Occasionally they have decided the outcome. The strangest case was in 1912 when Theodore Roosevelt bolted from the Republicans, for whom he had won the presidency eight years earlier, to run as a Progressive against President Taft, Roosevelt's own chosen successor when he stepped down after his first term in the White House. That intervention handed the election to the Democrat, Woodrow Wilson, just as, eight years ago, the astonishing 19% of the vote won by Ross Perot handed the election to Clinton.

But in other cases, the effect of out side candidates has been more ambiguous. In 1968, the candidature of the racist George Wallace, evidently taking votes on the right, didn't stop Nixon winning. The 1948 election was still more complex. It saw the only genuine four-horse race of the century, with two men bolting from the Democrats under President Harry Truman. Strom Thurmond ran under the banner of States Rights (as Southern segregationists euphemistically had it) and Henry Wallace ran as a Progressive, the same name as Roosevelt's 36 years earlier but a very different kind of party, a leftwing popular front supported by the communists.

If anything, that election showed how unpredictable such interventions could be. Coming from Truman's own party, Thurmond and Wallace both looked as if they must damage him, and indeed, right up to election day, almost every politician and pundit expected Truman to be beaten by the Republican, Thomas Dewey. In the event, the two bolters both picked up far from insignificant tallies, Thurmond winning 1.17m votes (and carrying four states), Wallace 1.15m.

But Truman won the election, and it seems at least possible that those two may actually have helped him. Thurmond showed that a Democrat could win without the embarassment of the racist "Solid South". As for Wallace, by drawing anti-communist fire as the cold war got into its stride, he allowed Truman to denounce Russian aggression and those who would appease it, while visibly moving his campaign to the left on domestic issues, backing labour and attacking business in a way which would terrify Gore. In the same indirect way, Patrick Buchanan's campaign on a xenophobic radical-right platform this year almost certainly helped Bush.

In a new book, The Last Campaign: How Harry Truman Won the 1948 Election, the American writer Zachary Karabell suggests something more. Flawed as those two were, Thurmond's campaign stained by racism, Wallace's by Stalinism, they were also authentic populist attempts to break free of the Tweedledum and Tweedledee two-party duopoly. It is this that strikes a visitor to America as the truly quaint thing about its political culture. The G & S line about "either a little Liberal or a little Conservative" doesn't apply here any more, if it ever did. But for almost 150 years, every American boy and gal that's born into the world alive has been either a Republican or a Democrat.

In no European country has the shape of party politics been frozen in this way, a sclerosis no one has been able to cure. There is no American Tory or Labour party, no Social Democrats or Christian Democrats, still less any serious parties to further right or left. And the truth is that the differences between Democrats and Republicans - even supposedly liberal Democrats and supposedly conservative Republicans - have often been slight by European political standards.

In Seattle last Thursday, Nader repeated his central themes: "Don't go for the lesser of two evils, because at the end of the day, you end up with evil." And, "Bush and Gore don't matter. They're just battling over who's going to go into the White House to take marching orders from their corporate paymasters." From whatever political position American politics are viewed, that was near the knuckle. The great issue in this election was campaign finance. Or it should have been: raised by mavericks like John McCain on the right and Nader on the left, it was studiously ignored by both Bush and Gore.

Whatever he says on particular issues, Nader surely ought to be applauded in principle as one more, all too rare authentic populist attack on the American political culture, with its empty double act, and its inability to tune into the real wishes of the people outside a narrow waveband controlled by a solipsistic political elite. Quite apart from those voting for Nader, there was another eloquent block of voters yesterday, the 50-something per cent who didn't vote at all. What does their abstention say about the system? Are they "spoilers" too?

Jonathan Freedland's column will appear tomorrow. wheaty@compuserve.com

webTitle: The Dome diamond robbery attempt

fields.headline: How fact drew on fiction
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The audacity of the raid on the Millennium Dome and the subterfuge employed by the Flying Squad to foil it could have been lifted straight from the pages of an Ian Fleming novel.
fields.body:
The audacity of the raid on the Millennium Dome and the subterfuge employed by the Flying Squad to foil it could have been lifted straight from the pages of an Ian Fleming novel.

Seven weeks after the rocket attack on MI6, it seemed that life was imitating art once again as the attempt to pull off the world's biggest jewel heist evoked scenes from the latest 007 cinema blockbuster, The World Is Not Enough.

In the film, a spectacular action sequence begins with an explosion at the secret service's Vauxhall Bridge headquarters.

A speedboat chase along the Thames follows, culminating in a showdown at the dome.

Bond, played by Pierce Brosnan, crashes through a pier as he arrives and corners a female assassin as she is about to make her getaway in a hot air balloon.

She blows herself up rather than surrender, and Bond jumps from the balloon to land on the roof of the dome.

Sophie Marceau, who plays the film's chief villain, Elektra, was invited to the dome and posed for pictures with the Millennium Star, the biggest of the diamonds, when the De Beers gem collection was unveiled last year.

webTitle: Coup for the new-look Sweeney Todd

fields.headline: Coup for the new-look Sweeney Todd
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The success of Operation Magician could not have come at a better time for Scotland Yard's Flying Squad.
fields.body:
The success of Operation Magician could not have come at a better time for Scotland Yard's Flying Squad.

Once, being a member of the unit was the most coveted job in the force. But a series of scandals exposed widespread corruption by officers, shaming its reputation and bringing ignominy on the Met.

Cases against officers from the Flying Squad are still going through the courts following a purge started by Sir Paul Condon, the former commissioner, who estimated that up to 200 officers in the force were corrupt.

Allegations have included claims that detectives brokered financial deals with criminals or tipped them off about investigations. Some became involved with drug dealers.

The Flying Squad was organised by Det Insp David Goodwillie in 1918 to deal with an influx of American and continental crooks.

Criminals dubbed it "the heavy mob", and later the Sweeney Todd - rhyming slang - as it handled some of the Met's most high-profile cases, concentrating on armed robberies.

The macho image of fast cars and guns was reinforced by John Thaw's portrayal of Jack Regan in The Sweeney, the successful 1970s television drama based on the unit, which also starred Dennis Waterman.

In 1977, the then head of the unit, Commander Ken Drury, was arrested and jailed for corruption.

Last year Scotland Yard announced plans to tone down the Flying Squad's macho image and moved to tackle its reputation for chauvinism by encouraging more women, particularly those with families, to join.

webTitle: Tax crackdown ahead on internet betting

fields.headline: Tax crackdown ahead on internet betting
fields.standfirst:
Net news

Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: A crackdown on the booming business of tax-free telephone and internet betting is to be announced by Gordon Brown in the next budget.
fields.body:
A crackdown on the booming business of tax-free telephone and internet betting is to be announced by Gordon Brown in the next budget.

It comes as the Commons public accounts committee warns that unless prompt action is taken to change the way tax is collected, tens of millions of pounds in revenue will be lost every year to the exchequer.

Ministers' favourite option is putting a new "stealth tax" on betting by means of a levy on every bet made in Britain, which would have to be collected by bookmakers. At present punters have a choice of paying 9p in the pound when they place a bet or paying the tax on the winnings. The indications are that ministers would replace this with a standard levy.

Ministers are aware that betting is a popular working class pursuit, and do not fancy further alienating voters who are already behind the fuel protesters. Many firms are also promoting tax-free betting from overseas branches.

On telephone betting alone, the MPs estimate that if all business moved offshore the government would lose £50m every year.

Richard Broadbent, chairman of customs and excise, told MPs earlier this year that he wants a reform of the betting tax implemented next April, when the government presents a new finance bill.

At the moment the only offence in Britain that internet bookmakers are committing is if they advertise their website. But there is little police can do to stop flyers promoting websites being handed out near betting shops or at racetracks.

Ministers are also warned by MPs today that they need to crack down on illegal bookmakers in the UK. Illegal betting is estimated to cost a further £100m a year and customs is proposing to reduce its scrutiny of gambling.

webTitle: Sketch

fields.headline: Britney socks it to Tory women
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: To the Conservative Women's national conference to catch Ann Widdecombe's speech. It was nice to be at a gathering where every single person was older than me.
fields.body:
To the Conservative Women's national conference to catch Ann Widdecombe's speech. It was nice to be at a gathering where every single person was older than me.

These gals make no concession to the feminist zeitgeist. There were fundraising books of recipes to tempt hubby's jaded palate, all the chairwomen were addressed as "chairman", and the only clothes stall sold cut-price neckties. You couldn't get near it for elderly women buying cheap presents for their husbands.

There was not a dungaree to be seen; instead they were dressed in the kind of sensible clothes advertised near the back of the Daily Mail, the newspaper for old women of both sexes.

At the bookstall, where you could still buy jigsaws of John Major, Ms Widdecombe had installed herself in front of a pile of her best-selling novel, The Clematis Tree. "Get your copies of The Cannabis Tree!" she shouted merrily.

"Sorry, I mean The Clematis Tree. Roll up, roll up, no sex and violence in The Clematis Tree!"

As the lines of women queued up (the book has sold a remarkable 20,000 copies in hardback) I reflected that, surprising as it might seem, Ms Widdecombe has become the Britney Spears of the Conservative party.

Consider: she is not so much an object of desire for the opposite sex as a role model for her own. She has hordes of admirers who would love to dress like her but don't quite dare. Like the American diva, she makes much of her chastity.

Similarly she is not a person blessed with a huge talent, but she makes up for it by giving it everything she's got on stage - indeed the main difference is that at the Ann Widdecombe show it's the performer who does the screaming.

The debate on home affairs began. Delegates were asked to support a motion which "deplores a culture which favours the offender and not the victim". I wondered anxiously how many people would demand more consideration for the offender and less for the victim.

Amazingly there was one. Councillor Carol Cohen made a passionate speech in favour of giving young offenders a second chance. "The huge majority of young offenders are victims themselves - those who ran out of luck before they grew up."

I thought she'd be lynched, or at least pelted with recipe books. But times have changed. She received a polite sprinkling of applause. Suddenly the top of the bill act arrived. She stood up without notes. "The chairman said to me, 'Do you want me to stop you?' I said I wanted her to stop me!" Cries of "No!" from the hall.

As with all Widdecombe rants, the rage and the fury contains some good, liberal common sense. "Let young offenders out early, if they mend their ways" was the gist of one section. "We will wipe the slate clean and let them enter adult life without a criminal record!" Just as Britney's fans would continue to cheer madly if she launched into the more difficult Mahler lieder, so the Tory ladies were unfazed by this proposal to flood our streets with hoodlums.

Finally her great encore, the fans' fave, the fabulous socks number. Apparently prisoners, instead of training for life outside, spend their time knitting socks for other prisoners.

Last year they made 1.2m pairs "for a prison population never more than 67,000! Where are these socks? What are they doing with the socks? There are limits to sock-knitting opportunities outside prison!"

The Joy Of Socks is her showstopper, like Britney's Whoops I Did It Again; she couldn't have left without performing it. At the end they cheered and clapped, and those who were physically capable - around half - gave her a standing ovation.

webTitle: Rail chaos blamed on 'wrong trains'

fields.headline: Rail chaos blamed on 'wrong trains'
fields.standfirst:
Track showing dangerous cracks only a year old, admits Corbett

Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: Gerald Corbett, the Railtrack chief executive, yesterday blamed the wrong trains on the wrong tracks for the chaos and disruption on Britain's rail network that is likely to last well into the new year.
fields.byline: David Gow, Larry Elliott  and Keith Harper
fields.body:
Gerald Corbett, the Railtrack chief executive, yesterday blamed the wrong trains on the wrong tracks for the chaos and disruption on Britain's rail network that is likely to last well into the new year.

He admitted his embattled company had discovered that rails with the hair's breadth cracks known as gauge corner cracking, seen as the most likely cause of last month's Hatfield crash which killed four passengers, were only one year old.

But he warned the Confederation of British Industry's national conference in Birmingham that government plans to introduce laws on corporate manslaughter would decrease safety on the railways and create a "buck-passing, secretive culture".

Mr Corbett's comments came as the head of a leading train operating company refused to back a vote of confidence in the Railtrack chief.

Moir Lockhead, chief executive of FirstGroup which operates three rail franchises, batted away the question, saying he was confident Railtrack was working hard to get the railway back into working order "and that's all you're going to get from me".

Mr Corbett told delegates Railtrack had been forced to call in academic experts to help provide a quick solution to the problem of gauge corner cracking, but the initial view was that this "is all to do with the wheel-rail relationship" - code for the pressure that fast-running trains exert on the track.

In a remarkable display of openness about Railtrack's difficulties, he revealed that during the recent "re-railing" of 50 miles of track after inspection of 2,800 sites the company had found many year-old rails with cracks.

"We dug up a whole load of rails north of Rugby at the weekend [which] we put in last year as part of the broken rail recovery programme and found they suffered from gauge corner cracking," he said. Similar defects had been found in track near Wimbledon, south-west London.

Mr Corbett said the problem would be resolved in most areas by the new year, but in some places it would continue into January. But he indicated a more deep-rooted problem was that the wrong trains were running on the tracks.

"There are trains on the track in which we - who own the track - have no say in their design or specification and that can't be right for optimising the wheel-rail relationship," he said. The problem was particularly acute with freight trains "thundering" over tracks - a 24-tonne train exerts 14 times more pressure on the rails than a 14-tonne two-carriage "sprinter".

Mr Corbett held out the prospect of dedicated tracks for freight trains, ending the practice which causes slow-moving goods trains to be sent to sidings to allow passenger trains priority.

His offer to resign immediately after the Hatfield crash was rejected by the Railtrack board, but yesterday he was unrepentant about the network's performance since privatisation, claiming that the number of broken rails had dropped by 30% and signals passed at danger by 13% in the first seven months of this year.

Train delays, he added, were down by 44% in the same period, even with a sharp increase in traffic. "Before Hatfield we had the best four months for the railway ever."

But Mr Corbett said legislation on corporate manslaughter following the Hatfield, Ladbroke Grove and Southall rail crashes would create a culture in which "everybody is interested in protecting themselves because of the likelihood of criminal proceedings".

Digby Jones, the CBI director-general, praised Mr Corbett's "determination to deliver", but argued that corporate manslaughter laws would enhance safety as a company's top priority.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText:
Where there is Discord ...
No wonder young people thought the election was someone else's problem. The Bush campaign selected a couple of hoary singalongs to poke fun at his opponent. At his last campaign stop, devotees were treated to Fleetwood Mac's Don't Stop - the Clinton-Gore theme eight years ago - followed by The Who's Won't Get Fooled Again.
fields.body:
Where there is Discord ...
No wonder young people thought the election was someone else's problem. The Bush campaign selected a couple of hoary singalongs to poke fun at his opponent. At his last campaign stop, devotees were treated to Fleetwood Mac's Don't Stop - the Clinton-Gore theme eight years ago - followed by The Who's Won't Get Fooled Again.

Secret ballot for the Senate
The precise result of Hillary Clinton's attempt to win a seat in the Senate will not be known until tomorrow at the earliest. A judge has ruled that absentee ballots in New York state must remain sealed until then to prevent anyone tampering with them.

Delayed reaction
The extraordinarily high number of absentee ballots in California, a record 3.2m, could conceivably delay results in both the congressional and presidential elections, officials in Sacramento were warning last night. The final tally of late postal votes could take some time. If both candidates had to wait until the most populous state, with its 54 electoral college votes, declared, the suspense could go on for days.

Loaded magazines
Time and Newsweek publish special election issues today. Time prepared two covers, one for President Bush, one for President Gore; Newsweek was considering a third, in case one took the popular vote and the other the electoral vote.

Cheney loses it in Vegas
Dick Cheney, George Bush's running mate, tried his best to energise likely Republican voters by hitting the phones in Las Vegas. "Okay, sorry about that. Thank you," he said after placing the first call. "Wrong number."

Short and sweet
The average length of the candidates' soundbites on the evening news programmes was seven seconds, said the Centre for Media and Public Affairs.

How the voters were bought
Altogether $3bn was spent on the presidential and congressional races. That works out at roughtly $30 for every vote cast.

webTitle: Dead man proves tricky opponent in tight senate race

fields.headline: Dead man proves tricky opponent in tight senate race
fields.standfirst:
Issues Fatality gives Missouri Republicans little to attack

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Debbie O'Connor, a former university secretary, is a lifelong Democrat with strong   views on education and other issues. Her choice of Mel Carnahan for the Senate was not unusual in Missouri, where the former governor was popular. The election itself, however, was among the most unusual ever held.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson in St Louis, Missouri
fields.body:
Debbie O'Connor, a former university secretary, is a lifelong Democrat with strong views on education and other issues. Her choice of Mel Carnahan for the Senate was not unusual in Missouri, where the former governor was popular. The election itself, however, was among the most unusual ever held.

Carnahan was killed in a plane crash three weeks ago. But his death came too late in the electoral process for the Democrats to put another candidate on the ballot papers. Carnahan's name remained and - in accordance with local electoral law -his widow was chosen to take the seat should he win it.

Opinion polls as the race entered its final phase suggested the Carnahans held a slim lead over the sitting Republican senator, John Ashcroft.

The contest raised questions about whether issues, personality or pity alone would dominate. Missouri was also important for the presidential race as a key swing state that had chosen the winner in every contest since 1960.

In the drizzle yesterday in St Louis, Ms O'Connor made it clear that she was voting for the causes espoused by the candidate. "I was really disappointed when he was killed," she said. "But now I can vote for everything he stood for." She described Jean Carnahan as a "great choice" to replace her husband. "I'm sure they shared the same values as husband and wife for 40-odd years."

Her views echoed the local Democrat campaign strategy, which urged electors to vote for the dead man's policies. At a rally in the state on Monday, Al Gore spoke of continuing Carnahan's work while wearing a black ribbon inscribed with "Keep the Fire Burning", a favourite Carnahan phrase.

For others in Missouri, the choice of a Democrat for the Senate was not simply a matter of party loyalty. Sharon Whalen, Ms O'Connor's sister, voted for the dead man and his widow in the Senate race while choosing George W Bush for president. "I liked Mel Carnahan," she said simply.

Local Republicans were not happy. Sheri Kelly, a spa owner, said: "It's unfair to the other guy. How can you fight against a dead person?"

There were whispers that the Republicans would use national election laws to invalidate a win for Mrs Carnahan. Local campaign officials, who had studiously avoided public criticism of the dead man's campaign team, denied this. Privately, they admitted that any attempt to benefit from a tragedy would not help their campaign efforts. Devoid of an opponent to abuse, the campaign focused on stressing the track record of their man.

Underlining the difficult nature of the election, Mrs Carnahan hardly campaigned, limiting her involvement to a television advertisement urging a "vote for Mel" and an interview on Sunday morning television.

The unusual nature of the campaign led to an unprecedented level of debate and predictions of an unusually high turnout. Rick Hardy, professor of political science at the University of Missouri at Columbia, said: "We have a dead person on the ballot. This has generated enormous support. It's made people who otherwise would not be paying attention talk about it."

webTitle: Mowlam trips on cannabis claims

fields.headline: Mowlam trips on cannabis claims
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: The Cabinet Office minister, Mo Mowlam, was yesterday forced to backtrack on claims that cannabis could be legalised for medicinal use as early as next year after Downing Street indicated such a measure could not go ahead until 2004.
fields.body:
The Cabinet Office minister, Mo Mowlam, was yesterday forced to backtrack on claims that cannabis could be legalised for medicinal use as early as next year after Downing Street indicated such a measure could not go ahead until 2004.

Speaking as the government published its second annual report into its anti-drugs strategy, Ms Mowlam said that, with a number of scientific trials on the soft drug drawing to a close, official backing for the legalisation of cannaboids - a derivative which is not smoked and which could help sufferers of MS and spina bifida - could be given from the end of 2001.

But Downing Street and the Department of Health swiftly insisted the current trials would have to be assessed by the Committee of Safety of Medicines before being given approval - which would take at least another four years.

Questioned on the fact that her comments on BBC Radio 4's Today programme appeared at odds with government policy, Ms Mowlam, the minister in charge of coordinating drugs policy and the only cabinet minister to admit to having smoked the drug, was forced, just three hours later, to admit she had made a mistake.

"I probably underestimated the time it would take to get through all the different phases," she added. "I was going on the results of a visit to a scientific centre where the research was being done but ... if that's what No 10 are saying, obviously it's right. ,If they feel it can't be done quicker ... he's the prime minister."

Her implied frustration with the government's timescale reflects her belief that there should be a more open debate on the legalisation of the drug.

While the home secretary, Jack Straw, and Mr Blair take a tougher line, public support for the legalisation of cannabis in general, and for medicinal use in particular, grows.

Only this year, two MS sufferers who used cannabis to alleviate their suffering were cleared of possession by juries, while, last month, a Mori poll found nearly nine out of 10 people believe it should be allowed for medicinal purposes.

The confusion over conflicting policies was compounded when Ms Mowlam found herself at odds with the drugs czar Keith Hellawell over whether cannabis is a "gateway" to hard drugs. Mr Hellawell insisted new research from New Zealand, which showed young people who smoked a joint once a week were 50 times more likely to progress to harder drugs, had finally convinced him of a connection, but the Ms Mowlam claimed on Sunday there was no such evidence.

The contradiction threatened to cloud the publication of the second report by Mr Hellawell into the government's 10-year anti-drug strategy. The report reveals most of the government's targets into preventing and treating drug abuse are "broadly" being met.

The government's drug testing and treatment orders (DTTOs) - a scheme which enables criminals to undertake drug treatment as an alternative to a prison sentence - was also heralded as a success, despite a third of such orders, in an ongoing pilot scheme, being revoked. While a large proportion revert to using some illicit drugs, the average spent each week has dropped from £400 to £34 suggesting it was beneficial, Mr Hellawell stressed.

webTitle: The lesson: avoid the press, trust in your pollsters

fields.headline: The lesson: avoid the press, trust in your pollsters
fields.standfirst:
This election proved that now more than ever it's all about money and control of the media. And what America does, the world follows...
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: This election proved that now more than ever it's all about money and control of the media. And what America does, the world follows...
fields.body:
There is an iron law of American campaign politics. It says that the only way to win is to have higher numbers than the other guy. The only way to improve your numbers is by television advertising. The only way to get the advertising slots that reach the voters is by paying for them. And the only way to pay for them is to raise millions and millions of dollars.

Nothing that has happened in the 2000 election will have dented the US political class's faith in this iron law. This was an election won and lost by the most intensive television advertising campaign ever in the key states.

Political campaigners, like generals, always prepare for the next campaign on the basis of the endlessly re-examined lessons of the last one. So the big lesson that the American professionals will draw from the 2000 campaign is not that the political money mountains need to be brought under control. It is that campaign funding will have to increase more than ever in 2004. Campaign finance reform - the one great populist cause to emerge in the 2000 campaign - can simply go hang.

The second great lesson the professionals will learn is just as cynical. They will conclude that a winning campaign is all about better organisation, stricter discipline and never being knocked off course by the media, events, or voters.

This closest of modern US elections was also one of the least participative elections of modern times. It was won by professionals deploying professional thinking, techniques and resources to ensure that voters did the one thing required of them - vote. It was ruthless and controlling, and this morning's outcome will only confirm the professionals' belief that their way is the only way.

It was a campaign in which the messages were crafted by strategists and pollsters working with focus groups comprised of middle-of-the-road people who were not interested in politics. It was a campaign in which the internet became not the transforming participative democratic forum that many had hoped but a superbly effective weapon to add to the armoury of those who are directly involved - organisers, lobbyists, pollsters, journalists and activists.

The main candidates, Al Gore and George W Bush, worked from a campaign playbook which kept them away from unvetted crowds, avoided unscripted events and - above all - insulated them from a probing media. The candidates promoted their families and their relatives as surrogate campaigners as never before. They sought the company and endorsement of celebrities as never before. And they avoided the press.

For the modern candidate, the political press is an enemy every bit as dangerous as the opposing candidate. Gore in particular pursued a strategy of avoiding contact with journalists, especially those travelling with him on the campaign trail. Gore gave not a single press conference from the day he left the Democratic convention in Los Angeles in August until polling day yesterday. Bush, having initially made himself available to his own travelling press, abruptly ended that approach after he mangled the word "subliminable" as he struggled to explain the use of the word "Rats" in a subliminal frame of a campaign advertisement in early September.

After that, he was off limits too.

Not that the candidates did not want to get their message out. They did, but on their own terms. So they went on comedy programmes and children's television, on late night talk shows such as Letterman and Leno, and soft-focus daytime interview shows such as those of Oprah Winfrey and Regis Philbin. But they never went on the political programmes and they never took questions from political reporters.

Their focus was unerring and unsleeping. They wanted to control the media agenda. When they succeeded they were happy. When they failed they came close to panic, as both sides did at various times. But this was not some new discovery. It is the essential condition of the modern political campaign - the "permanent campaign" as Sidney Blumenthal, then a journalist but now a White House aide, dubbed it in a 1980s book.

In all things, the rest of the world looks to America for what is coming downstream towards it. Election campaigners in Britain have been glued to the 2000 election as they were to earlier contests, to learn new tricks, techniques and lessons. The Labour party sent its general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, to view the campaign. Conservative central office sent several officials to study the campaign, and William Hague himself paid a brief visit to the Republican convention.

They will all have learned what the American professionals have learned.

That modern elections are won by money - which can only come from rich people. That modern elections are won by control - which can only be achieved by defeating the media.

And that modern elections are won by organisation - which ensures that voters do the one thing that fewer and fewer of them seem interested in doing. As democracy withered again, the campaigners celebrated another triumph.

webTitle: Royal Society backs use of embryos to fight disease

fields.headline: Royal Society backs use of embryos to fight disease
fields.trailText: New research on human embryos could lead to powerful new treatments for serious injuries and degenerative diseases, according to a new study by members of Britain's science elite.
fields.body:
New research on human embryos could lead to powerful new treatments for serious injuries and degenerative diseases, according to a new study by members of Britain's science elite.

The Royal Society, has become the latest body to back a controversial step: to take human embryos not needed in infertility research, and use cells from them to reverse the effects of disorders such as Parkinson's disease.

The government is expected to allow a free vote this autumn on changes to the 1990 Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act to give legal sanction to this controversial step, which could bring powerful new treatments for serious injuries and degenerative diseases.

Stem cell therapy seemed impossible until three years ago when (quite separately) Scottish scientists cloned Dolly the sheep from an adult cell, and US commercial scientists found a way to keep embryo stem cells alive in a culture. Stem cells are the precursors of the 200 kinds of skin, bone, blood, nerve, muscle and organ cell that make up a human.

The two discoveries raised immediate hopes of a new class of treatment. Scientists now believe they could put the nucleus of a patient's cell into an unfertilised egg, watch it divide and take from it the embryo stem cells that are the precursors of all human tissue. Then they would be able to tailor new "personalised" nerve stem cells for people with neurodegenerative diseases, or pancreatic stem cells for children with diabetes.

webTitle: Doctors monitor Jodie's battle to survive

fields.headline: Doctors monitor Jodie's battle to survive
fields.standfirst:
Parents at twin's bedside after 20 hours of surgery to separate her from Mary, as surgeons speak of need for 'meticulous attention'

More about Jodie and Mary, the conjoined twins
fields.trailText: Doctors were monitoring the progress of the conjoined twin Jodie yesterday, after the operation to separate her from Mary.
fields.body:
Doctors were monitoring the progress of the conjoined twin Jodie yesterday, after the operation to separate her from Mary.

Her parents, who fought a legal battle against the procedure because it meant certain death for Mary, remained near Jodie's bedside at St Mary's hospital, Manchester.

The surgeons said the operation by a team of 20 took some 20 hours, five hours longer than expected, and did not finish until 5am.

Though it was exhausting for the surgeons - and traumatic for the parents - the time taken is not necessarily a cause for concern. Surgeons performing such intricate procedures almost always come across complications that alter their schedule.

The three-month-old girls could have been kept stable under anaesthetic for 24 hours, and there have been previous separation operations that have taken a similar length of time.

In a statement the hospital, which had never before carried out a separation operation, said Jodie's condition was "critical but stable", adding: "The first few days following an operation are the most critical, and our thoughts remain with Jodie and her parents."

Doctors will have watch for infections, probably the biggest threat to her survival, and other complications.

It is not known whether Jodie will require further operations. The surgeons were confident she would be able to lead a full and active life, but they could not dismiss the possibility that she could have difficulties in walking and be doubly incontinent.

Lewis Spitz, professor of paediatric surgery at Great Ormond Street hospital, London, and a leading specialist in separating conjoined twins, said the operation was longer than any of the 12 he had been involved in.

Asked about psychological problems, he said: "If separation takes place within the first few months of life, there are very few psychological problems." However, the surviving twin could experience a "void".

"A technique we have evolved is to have a mirror next to the baby, so they can have an image of something lying next to them. That really seems to have settled them in the days after surgery. You learn these little tricks."

He said Great Ormond Street introduced parents of conjoined twins to survivors, to make them aware of how twins grow up after separation. "It is a very useful method of counselling."

Professor Spitz said Jodie would now be "very unstable". She would require meticulous attention. "From a very large body mass you have cut it down by at least 45%. The heart is used to pumping blood through a large mass, which is now reduced. Intensive care and monitoring to replace fluid is required. It is important not to overload the circulation - it is easy to do that."

He said the cost per survivor of the treatment of conjoined twins was estimated by Great Ormond Street to be £250,000.

The parents, who are from the Maltese island of Gozo and opposed surgery on religious grounds, said an emotional farewell to Mary before the operation, which began on Monday morning. As Mary, who was born severely brain damaged, survived only because Jodie's heart pumped oxygenated blood around her body, the separation was bound to kill her.

In the parents' battle in the courts, the hospital argued that the operation ought to take place so that Jodie's life could be saved. If the twins had not been separated it was believed both would die because of the extra strain put on Jodie's heart.

The parents' stance was backed by the Roman Catholic church and the ProLife Alliance. Both were allowed to make submissions during an appeal court hearing.

Yesterday the ProLife Alliance criticised the part of the hospital's statement that claimed: "Unfortunately, despite all the efforts of the medical team, Mary sadly died."

An alliance spokesman said: "We are absolutely shocked at the hospital's cowardly and misleading statement. There was never any possible chance of survival for Mary once the operation began, as the medical team was perfectly aware.

"St Mary's took the parents to court to get permission to terminate the life of Mary, and very sadly this has been achieved. The hospital should have the courage of its convic tions and not try to hide behind euphemistic statements.

"We pray that Jodie will make a full recovery as soon as possible, and that the family will be able to return to the security and love of their own community."

Outside the hospital two protesters kept a candle-lit vigil for the twins and their parents.

Aileen Power, 57, a member of the Society for the Protection of the Unborn Child, said: "We feel it is necessary to pray because a dangerous precedent has been set in the world due to this operation."

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Man held over priest's killing
Detectives hunting the murderer of a leading Hindu priest have arrested a 26-year-old man, Leicester police said last night. The body of Harish Purohit, 42, was found by his father and brother in an empty house in Leicester on October 20. He had been stabbed 13 times.
fields.body:
Man held over priest's killing
Detectives hunting the murderer of a leading Hindu priest have arrested a 26-year-old man, Leicester police said last night. The body of Harish Purohit, 42, was found by his father and brother in an empty house in Leicester on October 20. He had been stabbed 13 times.

Punch and editor fined
Punch and its editor, James Steen, were yesterday fined a total of £25,000 for contempt of court in publishing an article by former MI5 officer David Shayler about the 1993 Bishopsgate bombing in London, publication being in breach of an injunction imposed in 1997.

Challenge to Ofsted ruling
The governors of Crown Woods school in Eltham, south London, and Greenwich council are jointly to seek a judicial review of the decision by Ofsted to put the school into special measures, an unprecedented challenge to the "failing" label. [Rebecca Smithers]

Teacher 'bought drug for pupil'
Teacher David Sudbury admitted having bought cannabis for a pupil, when confronted by the head of Rendcomb college, a private school in Gloucestershire, Gloucester crown court was told yesterday. Sudbury, 32, who has resigned but is claiming unfair dismissal, denies supplying a class B drug. The case continues.

Star died of natural causes
A coroner ruled yesterday that West End star Stephanie Lawrence, 50, died of natural causes - liver failure due to alcohol - ending speculation of suicide after her body was found at her home in west London on Saturday.

Taking no chances
Councillors in Southwold, Suffolk, are to discuss the possibility of installing CCTV cameras, even though a total of only seven crimes were reported in the town last month.

webTitle: Hackney mired in more cash chaos

fields.headline: Hackney mired in more cash chaos
fields.trailText: The crippled London borough of Hackney was plunged into further financial chaos yesterday as councillors attempted to claw back a £40m deficit with deep cuts to services and hundreds of redundancies.
fields.body:
The crippled London borough of Hackney was plunged into further financial chaos yesterday as councillors attempted to claw back a £40m deficit with deep cuts to services and hundreds of redundancies.

Problems in the east London authority were compounded by Whitehall's new local government inspectorate which effectively put the council on probation and warned that ministers might have to intervene to save the borough from financial meltdown.

In a scathing report, the inspectorate, part of the audit commission, concluded that Hackney's financial and operational problems were so serious that it needed outside help.

With the refuse collection service collapsing amid reports of rats scavenging in piles of rubbish, up to half the borough's council tax uncollected and 17,000 poorer residents waiting for unpaid housing benefit, riot police were called to a council meeting this week to protect councillors from angry residents.

Around 500 redundancies are likely as the council tries to drive through £22.5m of cuts. Labour group leader Jules Pipe, who runs the council with the Tory leader Eric Oller-enshaw, promised essential social services would run and schools would not close.

The council disclosed yesterday that its new managing director, Max Caller, had been holding talks with the government in an attempt to get extra help. "Hackney is in a very precarious financial situation and the problems it faces are far worse than anyone imagined," he said last night.

Dianne Abbott, Labour MP for Hackney North and Stoke Newington, urged ministers to give the council an emergency grant to save essential services. After damning reports from education and social services inspectorates, as well as from the government's district au ditor, hopes were high that Hackney had achieved stability under an unprecedented Labour-Tory administration.

But after a special inspection, the local government inspectorate listed a catalogue of failure and reported to ministers that Hackney was unable to meet financial commitments.

Wendy Thomson, director of inspection at the audit commission and the former chief executive of nearby Newham council, said: "Hackney is not a well run council and is letting down the people who live in the borough."

The commission has given the council until February to get its finances in order by agreeing spending cuts, collecting council tax and making housing benefit payments.

The council has been ordered to report progress every month. But it has also been told to get a top management team in place by May. If the council drags its feet, the commission will ask the government to intervene.

webTitle: Bets inquiry may question 20 MPs

fields.headline: Bets inquiry may question 20 MPs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Up to 20 Labour MPs placed bets on Michael Martin's campaign to become speaker of the Commons, it emerged last night as Elizabeth Filkin, parliamentary commissioner for standards, formally launched her investigation into the affair.
fields.body:
Up to 20 Labour MPs placed bets on Michael Martin's campaign to become speaker of the Commons, it emerged last night as Elizabeth Filkin, parliamentary commissioner for standards, formally launched her investigation into the affair.

The involvement of as many as 20 MPs, from England as well as Speaker Martin's political base in Scotland according to authoritative Westminster sources, will intensify pressure on Mrs Filkin and the Commons itself to adopt a tough self-policing stance.

Rumours which swept the Commons tearooms that an MP had made as much as £100,000 were quickly dismissed. But it is claimed that cheerful voters in some Glasgow pubs watched the parliamentary TV channel with unusual interest during the ballot on October 23.

It has been reported that the bookies took £50,000 in bets and paid out £1m, though not all to MPs. Like the punters themselves and the bets placed such claims are hard to confirm, as Mrs Fillkin's independent inquiry will discover. Many MPs - though not all - regard the bets as a form of insider trading that allowed members to benefit from information on which they both had prior knowledge and a vote. Odds as good as 20-1 were offered before bookmakers realised that Mr Martin, a former Glasgow shop steward, was the frontrunner.

So far only Frank Roy, Labour MP for Motherwell and Wishaw, has admitted placing a bet, £3,400, on odds of 20-1. Asked if other MPs also backed Mr Martin after Speaker Boothroyd announced her retirement in July, Mr Roy has been telling reporters: "That's not for me to say."

At the weekend the Glasgow leftwinger, George Galloway, wrote in a newspaper column that he knew of at least two other MPs who had placed bets. A separate newspaper survey reported that 42 Scots MPs had denied so doing, four could not be contacted and five - including the foreign secretary and racing tipster, Robin Cook - refused to comment.

webTitle: Four years' jail for nurse who poisoned patient

fields.headline: Four years' jail for nurse who poisoned patient
fields.trailText: A male nurse who worked a 12 hour night shift at a nursing home while holding down a hospital day job was yesterday jailed for four years after being convicted of poisoning a patient in his care in an attempt to endanger his life.
fields.body:
A male nurse who worked a 12 hour night shift at a nursing home while holding down a hospital day job was yesterday jailed for four years after being convicted of poisoning a patient in his care in an attempt to endanger his life.

Phillip Reed, 43, who was also found guilty of ill treating another elderly patient, was told he had breached the good name of his profession for which he would never work again.

Reed, a father of three, was said to have administered non-prescribed drugs to patients "to lighten his workload" while working long hours at the Bedwellty nursing home, in Aberbargoed, and Tonteg hospital, Church village, both in south Wales.

He was convicted last month at Cardiff crown court of administering poison to endanger the life of Bedwellty patient David Parker, 69, and of ill treating Ken Edwards, 64, another patient at the home. Sentencing was adjourned until yesterday for psychological reports.

He was acquitted of attempting to murder Mr Parker and a Tonteg patient who died hours after allegedly being given a morphine based drug in a dose 12 times the prescribed level.

The court heard Reed was working long hours in two demanding jobs and administered the drugs to reduce his burden. Mr Parker, an epileptic who had diabetes and depression, died after being given drugs at the nursing home. Mr Edwards was given three injections of a non-prescribed drug.

Sentencing him yesterday at Merthyr Tydfil crown court, Mr Justice Thomas told Reed he had seriously breached the good name of his profession. He was jailed for four years for the poisoning and 15 months, to run concurrently, for ill treatment.

webTitle: Chemist chain puts cold cures away

fields.headline: Chemist chain puts cold cures away
fields.trailText: A high street chemist chain yesterday began withdrawing from public view all over-the-counter cold and flu remedies involved in a safety review, forcing customers to ask for the products through shop pharmacists.
fields.body:
A high street chemist chain yesterday began withdrawing from public view all over-the-counter cold and flu remedies involved in a safety review, forcing customers to ask for the products through shop pharmacists.

Lloyds pharmacy, with 1,300 shops nationwide, said the measure was taken to safeguard consumers while government bodies checked on about a dozen products containing an ingredient linked to hundreds of strokes among young women in the US.

The products are usually displayed in cabinets behind counters and can be sold under special protocols by medicine counter staff. The com pany plans "as an interim extra safety measure" to put them into dispensaries, and customers requesting them will have a consultation with a pharmacist, who may suggest alternatives.

The chain sells 100,000 packs a year of Sinutab, 80,000 of Day Nurse, and 75,000 of Mucron, three of the best known names in the £10m a year UK market for products containing phenylpropanolamine (PPA).

Boots withdrew an own-brand "prolonged relief" cold capsules, to avoid confusion with Boots products that do not contain PPA, but continued selling other branded products at its pharmacy counters. The Superdrug chain was also continuing to sell the products.

The committee on the safety of medicines will today review the situation in Britain, after the decision of the American food and drug administration to ask companies to withdraw products containing PPA.

Other remedies containing the ingredient are Benylin Day and Night, Contac 400, Dimotapp, Efkormave, Triogesic, Triominic and Allereze Plus.

Manufacturers promised to work closely with regulators. They pointed out that maximum intakes of PPA permitted in Britain were 100mg a day, compared with 150mg a day in the US. Appetite suppressants with the ingredient, commonly used by dieters in America, were not available here.

SmithKline Beecham, which makes Day Nurse and Contac 400, said it was working with the medicines control agency (to which the CSM reports) and added: "Any review by any regulatory body has to look at the differences between conditions in diferent countries."

Pfizer, which makes Benylin Day and Night and Sinutab, said: "We will be guided by the medines control agency in the interests of consumers."

Decongestants containing PPA have been on sale for more than 20 years, and there have been two previous reviews of their use.

The Department of Health last night said packaging and leaflets already advised consumers that such products should not be used by those with high blood pressure, heart disease, diabetes, glaucoma and other conditions. The CSM would "advise the MCA of any further regulatory action which may be necessary".

The CSM would "advise the MCA of any further regulatory action which may be necessary".

webTitle: Pensioners call at No 10 in Westminster protest

fields.headline: Pensioners call at No 10 in Westminster protest
fields.standfirst:
Special report: welfare reform
Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Grey power came to Westminster yesterday as thousands of pensioners demonstrated on the eve of the chancellor's pre-budget report for restoration of the link between state pensions and average earnings.
fields.body:
Grey power came to Westminster yesterday as thousands of pensioners demonstrated on the eve of the chancellor's pre-budget report for restoration of the link between state pensions and average earnings.

About 1,500 crowded into Westminster Central Hall to hear Lady Castle, the veteran Labour politician who created the earnings link in 1974, demand "action not words" to get pension improvements enshrined in law.

"Let's have a bit of fighting policy, shall we? We are not going to whinge any more. We are going to demand and we are going to fight for it," she said to a standing ovation.

Later the National Pensioners Convention said about 200 pensioners staged a sit-down protest in the road outside the House of Commons, but there were no arrests.

Jack Jones, the convention's president, led a deputation to Tony Blair to explain why there must never be a repeat of last year's "miserable" 75p increase in the weekly state pension - the amount required to match price inflation over the previous year.

The prime minister is understood to have said nothing to confirm or deny reports of a £5 increase in the single pension and £8 for a couple, to be announced in the chancellor's statement today.

Mr Jones told the rally: "We are winning. Make no mistake, our campaign has been successful, it has had an impact on the government and we should see that in substantial increases."

But the pensioners' campaign would have to continue after the pre-budget statement. "We want the restoration of the link with earnings in the future," he said.

Rodney Bickerstaffe, general secretary of the public service union Unison, said: "We have a very simple message for the chancellor. Pensioners deserve a decent basic state pension. A £5 increase may offer a short-term boost... but unless a regular uprating such as a link with earnings is restored, the basic state pension will continue to wither on the vine."

As Mr Jones and his colleagues left for a further meeting with Gordon Brown, the chancellor, pensioners at the rally shouted "give him hell".

Tony Booth, the prime minister's father-in-law, said he was ashamed about the Labour government's record on pensions. "I am ashamed that this campaign is necessary. I am ashamed that we are being forced to fight for our rights, to fight for our dignity, because there is no dignity in poverty, Gordon Brown."

David Willetts, the shadow social security secretary, said the rally showed Mr Brown could no longer ignore pensioners demands. "Pensioners and the Conservative party want the same thing - to see a decent rise in the basic state pension - and that is what we have promised to deliver," he said.

Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, said: "Crucially we need to do far more for the poorest pensioners.

"You can either give an across the board increase to everybody, rich and poor alike, or you can give more than an earnings link for those people who are on very low pensions," he told BBC Radio 4's The World at One programme.

webTitle: Labour sinking, claims Hague

fields.headline: Labour sinking, claims Hague
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday bundled up all Britain's current ills and used them to accuse Tony Blair's government of losing control and creating "a very real sense of crisis".
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday bundled up all Britain's current ills and used them to accuse Tony Blair's government of losing control and creating "a very real sense of crisis".

He linked the floods, the fuel controversy and the paralysed rail network with such very different issues as crime, the NHS and the resignation of Chris Woodhead as chief schools inspector to suggest that Mr Blair was saying "don't blame me, I'm only the prime minister".

In his speech to the Conservative women's conference in London the Opposition leader suggested that Labour's tax rises have not produced the results that Mr Blair promised. "It's time to cut taxes for everyone," said Mr Hague. "If Labour won't, we will."

Renewing his challenge for a televised debate ahead of polling day - probably May next year - the Tory leader predicted: "The coming election will be a choice between a party that stands for heavier taxes and a party that stands for lighter taxes. I believe that the party that stands for lighter taxes will win." Mr Hague likened the government to a flooded village, "awash with problems, increasingly without power and cut off from the rest of the world". He warned: "A public that expects their government to be in control knows that this prime minister and this government have lost control."

With public opinion coming back the government's way Mr Hague was taking a gamble in assuming that voters want lower taxes rather than better public services, including the Tory cut in fuel taxes which Gordon Brown is unlikely to concede in today's pre-budget report. "Tony Blair is making a big mistake if he thinks that he can deal with the fuel crisis by simply buying off special interests with concessions," Mr Hague told the party audience.

"For the exorbitant cost of petrol is not just destroying the livelihoods of many farmers and road hauliers. It is also punishing the millions of families on tight budgets who use the car to deliver their children to school and to do their weekly shopping.

"It is punishing the millions of rural people for whom the car is a necessity, not a luxury. It is punishing the thousands of small businessmen and women who rely on their car to make a living."

webTitle: Letters: Geller: I can bend metal

fields.headline: Geller: I can bend metal
fields.trailText: Your Pass notes (November 6) imply I am a magician and conjuror - but that this cannot be stated outright because I am such a litigious fellow. I can say with absolute certainty I do not cheat.
fields.body:
Your Pass notes (November 6) imply I am a magician and conjuror - but that this cannot be stated outright because I am such a litigious fellow. I can say with absolute certainty I do not cheat. I am not a magician. I have been tested by some of the most eminent scientists in the most prestigious laboratories of the world, who wrote up their results in highly respected journals. Perhaps the gifted journalists who compile Pass notes were not aware of the wealth of scientific data, compiled by outstanding physicists such as the Nobel winner Brian Josephson at Cambridge and Professor John Hasted in London, which demonstrates metal-bending is a real phenomenon.

You give your journalists a sniper's brief - operate from heavy cover, fire in short bursts, work anonymously. And you dare to accuse me of subterfuge. If there was a spoonful of courage in any of the sceptics on your staff - and I know many journalists affect to despise the paranormal - I would challenge her or him to an exchange of letters: since 130 years of outstanding scientific research is documented that indicates the existence of human psychic powers, how can you possess the arrogance to dismiss it all? Can one of your writers tell me that? I predict, however, that your snipers will prefer to skulk in safety.

Uri Geller
urigeller@compuserve.com

webTitle: Letters: It's a yawn for us too

fields.headline: It's a yawn for us too
fields.trailText: Ever since the primaries began in January, we have been subjected to page after page on the contest for the US presidency. Yesterday we had most of the front page, three pages inside and several pages in G2.
fields.body:
 Ever since the primaries began in January, we have been subjected to page after page on the contest for the US presidency. Yesterday we had most of the front page, three pages inside and several pages in G2. How can you think the British are interested in this contest when, despite the countless millions of dollars spent, the American public is so overwhelmed by indifference that less than half of eligible voters will go to the polls?

Frederick Hughes
Ripon,
N Yorks

 Can the Guardian please now turn its attention to the other 95% of the world and debate global democracy, as proposed by Charter 99 (Letters, November 3)? For example, what is the World Trade Organisation is up to, one year after Seattle?

Mary Sayer
Manchester

 Re Kinky Friedman's Drop Kick Me Jesus Through the Goalposts of Life (Letters, November 6 and 7): I heard it on an Irish local radio show devoted to the worst country and western lyrics. My favourite was the "love song" which contained the lines: "If I'd killed you when I met you/I'd be out of jail by now."

Alan Williams
Pontypool

 May I add If You Ever Leave Me, Honey, Go Out Backwards So I Think You're Coming In?

Jason Ditton
Glasgow

 Re: Prize Crossword Solution 22041 (November 6): Blimey, no wonder I got stuck on 13 across. Just who is Ilfarto Goattai anyway?

Teresa Hewitt
Cheltenham, Glos

 Yesterday's letters contained missives from six academics, five of them professors, a canon and a lord. Isn't it time you had more regard for the demographics of your readership? Unless, worrying thought, you already do!

Mike Rennie

webTitle: Letters: Bad press

fields.headline: Bad press
fields.trailText: The deceit, lies and trickery involved in the Diego Garcia scandal (Letters, November 7) is indeed horrifying. But why did we have to wait 30 years to learn about it?
fields.body:
The deceit, lies and trickery involved in the Diego Garcia scandal (Letters, November 7) is indeed horrifying. But why did we have to wait 30 years to learn about it? Where were all the campaigning editors and investigative reporters at the time it was happening? It wasn't a difficult scandal to uncover. All the press had to do was to interview any one of the islanders to blow the government cover story wide open. I suspect editors knew all along what was happening but, given the pressures of the cold war, felt it would have been unpatriotic to expose what their government was up to. Disturbing, isn't it?

Phillip Knightley
London
PhillipGK@aol.com

webTitle: Letters: Fishing for a solution to floods

fields.headline: Fishing for a solution to floods
fields.trailText: Tough action is needed now to ensure fish stocks and coastal communities recover (Cod fishermen could be banned from North sea, November 6). Both fishermen and conservationists agree on the long-term goals of sustainable seas and a healthy fishing industry, on which many of the coastal communities depend.
fields.body:
 Tough action is needed now to ensure fish stocks and coastal communities recover (Cod fishermen could be banned from North sea, November 6). Both fishermen and conservationists agree on the long-term goals of sustainable seas and a healthy fishing industry, on which many of the coastal communities depend.

The UK government should introduce meaningful measures such as a network of regeneration areas to enhance and restore fish stocks, including pilot fishing-free zones. In addition, the common fisheries policy, under investigation by a Lords' select committee, needs to be radically reformed to recognise that marine areas in European waters face different pressures and therefore need unique regional management solutions.

Ignoring scientific advice about the imminent collapse of fish stocks will reduce British seas to a barren underwater world and the coastal towns and villages to a hollow shell of the vibrant communities they once were.

Robert Napier
Chief executive, WWF-UK

 The government could resolve a number of its dilemmas at a stroke by giving farmers generous grants to plant and maintain woodlands. Many farmers who have joined the fuel-tax lobby and the Countryside Alliance because they are worried about their livelihoods would be pacified. The trees would mop up carbon dioxide, helping to stave off global warming, and the wooded areas would act as sponges, evening out the flow of rainwater into rivers, which would reduce the risks of flash flooding. The government could also boost its international reputation at the environmental conference in the Hague next week.

Bill Courtney
Altrincham,
Cheshire

 There is another factor affecting run-off from hill land. With the substantial increase in stocking (due to government policies) over the last 50 years, soils in susceptible areas are becoming compacted, which reduces infiltration and increases run-off. This may be more important than drainage. RSPB is investigating soil compaction as a possible factor for the reduction in upland breeding wading birds and is looking at possible methods of reversing this trend in the Peak District.

Penny Anderson
Buxton, Derbs

webTitle: Letters: What drives the hauliers

fields.headline: What drives the hauliers
fields.trailText: At last someone's had the balls to say it like it is - the hauliers are in despair not because of high fuel costs, but because business, and consumers like me, refuse to pay the real price for goods
fields.body:
 At last someone's had the balls to say it like it is - the hauliers are in despair not because of high fuel costs, but because business, and consumers like me, refuse to pay the real price for goods (Truckers attacking the wrong enemy, November 7). Slashing prices has a measurable cost. You can't just go round saying "10% cheaper than last year", "lowest prices since 1992" without acknowledging that it means some farm worker losing his job, some haulier laying off his drivers, or textile workers losing their factory in Manchester because there's cheaper labour in India.

Tim Finney
Bishopstone,
Wiltshire
info@helenbrowning organics.co.uk

 You present a misleading impression of some of the costs for hauliers (Super- markets play key role in hauliers rising costs, November 7); £840 to fill a 1,000-litre tank equates to a price per litre of 84p. But by removing the VAT, which hauliers can reclaim, they would be paying 71.5p per litre. Also, most hauliers have their own bunkers and buy fuel direct from the oil companies in bulk. This results in a further 2p to 3p reduction per litre. Therefore the cost to the haulier is 68.5p per litre, significantly less than is being quoted by the road-haulage lobby.

Also, the vehicle excise duty quoted of £3,950 (five axles across the tractor/trailer combination) can be reduced to £2,950 for pollution-friendly vehicles and, by operating six axles, reduced further to £1,500. The haulage industry is basically suffering from overcapacity, hence supermarkets and other large organisations are able to drive down their transport costs.

Michael Hatfield
Chester

 I'm a partner in a distribution business running 10 trucks. At first sight we would stand to gain £60,000 if the government fully accepted the demands to cut fuel taxes. But I don't support the campaign because it does not make business sense. High taxes are a red herring. The problem smaller hauliers face is not overheads but excessive (and often unfair) competition. All these financial gains would be lost as the frantic haulage market drove prices back down to rock bottom. The small operators and particularly the owner-operators could collectively agree minimum prices below which they would not bid for work and also gain economies of scale (eg in bulk buying) enjoyed by the big players.

Whatever, the government must get the cowboys off the roads. By driving illegally and unsafely they can undercut any fair price, endangering the public and providing appalling service which damages the reputation of the industry. Please print only my email address. I don't want my depot blockaded.

Bob Cannell
bobcannell@hotmail.com

 I was disappointed to read that the "Jarrow" convoy of road hauliers has retracted its promise to go slow. Given the alarming road accident record of heavy goods vehicles this had seemed to be the most constructive part of the promised protest. For every kilometre they drive, HGV drivers are twice as likely to be involved in a fatal accident as car drivers.

They're also are more than three times more likely to be involved in an accident on minor roads than on the motorway, which may explain why 20% of their road death victims are pedestrians or cyclists. The fault seems to lie with carelessness rather than tiredness, since the peak time for HGV accidents is 8-9am. A permanent go slow sounds like a very attractive proposition.

Katherine G White
London
kgwhite@netcomuk.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: ... and halts the tube

fields.headline: ... and halts the tube
fields.trailText: Stephen Glaister (End of the line, November 7) rightly recalls that London Transport used bonds in the 30s. They were backed by cheap Treasury money and financed the biggest tube extensions London ever had.
fields.body:
 Stephen Glaister (End of the line, November 7) rightly recalls that London Transport used bonds in the 30s. They were backed by cheap Treasury money and financed the biggest tube extensions London ever had. They could be used that way again, both for upkeep and new construction. The key would be cast-iron contracts that left the risk with the contractors.

But London will see no further tube extensions, except maybe a Jubilee line branch to Woolwich and Thames Gateway. The big new jobs - extension of the East London line (which will be transferred to Railtrack), Crossrail and Chelsea-Hackney - are all outside the remit of Ken Livingstone and Bob Kiley. They are Railtrack schemes.

The huge risk is that they will get planned without reference to London's needs. For instance, Crossrail urgently needs redesigning to link with the Tilbury line and the Lee Valley, aiding Thames Gateway regeneration. Bob Kiley should now work out how to use 30s-style bonds, with Treasury support, to buy into these projects and make them work for London.

Prof Sir Peter Hall
University College London
p.hall@ucl.ac.uk

webTitle: Bright Station will float Smartlogik

fields.headline: Bright Station will float Smartlogik
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Internet technology group Bright Station is planning to float Smartlogik, its knowledge management software division, within the next year.
fields.body:
Internet technology group Bright Station is planning to float Smartlogik, its knowledge management software division, within the next year.

Bright Station, which provides internet and e-commerce solutions, and is run by entrepreneur Dan Wagner, clarified its plans as it reported yesterday a 35% widening of losses over the last quarter to £4.6m.

A company spokesperson said Smartlogik, which accounts for some 40% of the group's revenue, could be worth £1bn. Bright Station is expected to keep a stake of up to 60%.

Some analysts, however, were sceptical. Iain Staples at ABN Amro said: "Bright Station has a lot to prove before they float Smartlogik."

David Mattey, Bright Station's chief financial officer, said losses, which are in line with expectations, were due to costs associated with recruiting experienced staff, as well as increasing sales and marketing and developing infrastructure in the United States.

The company reported revenues of £2.4m, up 23% from the last quarter and expects to be profitable in early 2002.

Shares have fallen from a year high of 256p to a low of 47p. Yesterday the share price rose 1.5p or 2.59% to 59.5p

webTitle: Lavazza wires caffeine to the web

fields.headline: Lavazza wires caffeine to the web
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: First it was computers, then it was Wap phones; now even the office coffee machine is to hook itself up to the internet.
fields.body:
First it was computers, then it was Wap phones; now even the office coffee machine is to hook itself up to the internet.

Lavazza, the Italian espresso coffee company, yesterday said it would install 10,000 E-espresso points in the offices of business clients across Europe by the end of the year.

The technology will allow caffeine addicts to brew a cup to their preferred strength without leaving their computer terminals.

It will also mean that the machine can email suppliers with updates on customer demand and maintenance requirements.

E-Device, the Franco-American start-up that developed the technology, said it was also designing a feature which would allow users to access the web through a touch-sensitive screen mounted on the E-espressopoint.

Marc Berrebi, chairman of eDevice said the E-espressopoint would be a pilot product in what would be a huge new market opening up on the internet.
