webTitle: Shareholders urged to put more women at the top

fields.headline: Shareholders urged to put more women at the top
fields.trailText: The dominance of men in the boardrooms of Britain's biggest companies should be challenged by shareholders.
fields.body:
The dominance of men in the boardrooms of Britain's biggest companies should be challenged by shareholders.

This conclusion of a new report initiated by MP Harriet Harman follows an analysis which found that of the 1,247 executive and non-executive directorships of the country's 108 largest companies just 65 are held by women. Only one of them, Marjorie Scardino of Pearson, is a chief executive and the majority are non-executives. One of the woman included in the survey, Clara Freeman of Marks & Spencer, has since left.

More than half of the 108 have no women board members at all. Whether they are "new" or "old" economy companies made no difference.

But Denise Kingsmill, deputy chairman of the competition commission, cautioned yesterday that women should not be propelled to boardrooms for the sake of it.

"Women don't want to be on the boards just because they are woman," said Ms Kingsmill, herself a veteran non-executive director and the deputy chairman of retailer MFI after a boardroom battle.

The boardroom can be a lonely place and "seriously unpleasant", said Ms Kingsmill, who admitted yesterday she often felt she was appointed to the board of MFI because she was a "girl" and perceived to be unlikely to "rock the boat".

Her solution to getting more women into the boardroom, announced yesterday at an event sponsored by the Industrial Society, is to make "diver sity" a corporate governance issue and therefore demanded by shareholders.

"No board is going to do it because it is good and the right thing to do. It has to be a business issue," Ms Kingsmill said.

Ms Harman, along with Fawcett, a group which campaigns for equality between men and women, and the Industrial Society, intend to produce this FTSE Female index every year.

"Britain's boardrooms are one of the last no go areas for women," Ms Harman said yesterday. Her ambition is to end all-male boardrooms in three years' time although she acknowledged that this might appear to be quite a challenge.

Ms Harman said there was evidence that "institutional investors appear to want it to be cracked. But they don't know how to do it".

webTitle: BT Ignite tries the net to cut call prices

fields.headline: BT Ignite tries the net to cut call prices
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Widespread use of the internet to dramatically reduce the cost of voice phone calls moved a step closer yesterday when BT Ignite announced the beginning of commercial trials in the corporate market.
fields.body:
Widespread use of the internet to dramatically reduce the cost of voice phone calls moved a step closer yesterday when BT Ignite announced the beginning of commercial trials in the corporate market.

The company plans to launch a service in the middle of next year which will allow consumers to make calls from a computer to a conventional handset. In theory, the cost of a call anywhere in the world could be the same as the cost of accessing the web.

BT has entered a pilot scheme with Open, the interactive television business owned by BSkyB, for a series of services restricted to its own staff using internet protocol. The company expects calls to be of the same quality as mobile phones.

Craig Boundy, vice-president of internet services for BT Ignite, said costs would fall sharply in the medium term.

"The knack will be to keep the call on an IP network for as long as possible before terminating it on a conventional network, at which point you have to pay a fee to the operator that owns that network. BT is particularly well placed to do that," he added.

BT Ignite has committed to spend £5bn developing an internet protocol network across Europe.

Despite the threat of cannibalising BT's own revenues, Mr Boundy said the company could not afford to ignore the new technology.

"This is about a change in the way we value telecoms from pence per minute to paying for services. That has been talked about for a long time but it is now really happening," he said.

BT already offers a niche product, called SurfTalk, which allows users on its SurfTime service to talk computer to computer. It is preparing to launch an upgraded service that will allow internet users to answer phone calls from conventional handsets if they are online.

The company aims to make the service to corporate customers more widely available once the trials with Open are complete.

Mr Boundy stressed that the ability to make voice calls over IP networks was more about multimedia services than low cost calls.

Users can either have a headset connected to a computer terminal and make calls using their mouse or via an IP handset which looks similar to a conventional phone but comes with a screen.

Lucent Technology, which is providing hardware to BT, estimates that more than 2bn people will have used the internet to make voice calls by 2005.

BT Ignite was formed as part of the restructuring of its parent and takes in the international broadband and internet protocol business.

Further dramatic changes to the structure of BT are expected be disclosed tomorrow with the company's half-year results.

Colt Telecom improved revenues during the third quarter by 59% to £166.7m on the back of increasing use by corporate clients of high bandwidth services.

Pretax losses for the three months widened from £22m to £33m as the company continued its investment in building networks across Europe.

The company has £1.8bn in the bank which chief executive Paul Chisholm said would see it through to 2002 when it aims to have networks in 32 cities and a backbone across mainland Europe.

webTitle: Big may still be beautiful for M&S

fields.headline: Big may still be beautiful for M&S
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer chairman Luc Vandevelde yesterday revealed that the troubled retailer is selling £500,000 worth of leather jackets for women every week . Phenomenal turnover of the mid-length black or camel coloured jackets aside, the sales figures for the first five weeks of this trading year will not make impatient investors much happier.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer chairman Luc Vandevelde yesterday revealed that the troubled retailer is selling £500,000 worth of leather jackets for women every week . Phenomenal turnover of the mid-length black or camel coloured jackets aside, the sales figures for the first five weeks of this trading year will not make impatient investors much happier.

It is almost two years since the high street legend suffered its first fall in profits in a decade. The intervening period has been a torrid tale.

If the store group's new Belgian chairman fails to find solutions to the litany of customer criticisms - the wrong clothes in unappealing stores at too high prices - M&S will go down in history as one of the most stunning falls from grace in the nation's corporate history. If Mr Vandevelde and his new team succeed, they will be lauded for the biggest turnaround ever.

Everyone has a view on M&S, from shoppers to City analysts, big investors and the staff themselves. On the streets of Birmingham, care assistant Pat Burton, 56, speaks for many: "One minute they are claiming to be really fashionable with lots of trendy clothes for young people and the next we are bombarded with adverts saying the clothes are for larger women. They need to listen to what people really want rather than acting on a whim."

Even in its heyday, which, believe it or not could be dated back only three years, few customers flocked to M&S because it was trendy and cutting-edge. It was its dependability, providing clothing items that were good value but nondescript enough not to stand out.

"M&S needs to realise what they are good at, essentially supplying anonymous basics," is the advice of a leading City investor. "You don't want to turn up at a cocktail party in the same dress as someone else, but a big, black leather coat is completely different thing."

Even the food halls have problems. Until last month it was thought the M&S food operation had been largely immune to the group's problems, but the recent competition commission report into super- markets revealed that its food profits - which M&S has always kept secret - have been hammered in recent years.

Despite all its difficulties Marks & Spencer has 11% of the British clothing market, sells one in four men's suits and one in four pairs of women's knickers. Its margins and sales per square foot are ahead of many rivals. But, its shares keep falling. Three years ago they were changing hands at 664p, valuing the company at £19bn. Now they are languishing at just 195p, the company is worth barely £5bn, the basic value of its property, placing no value on the contents of its stores. Rumours of fresh takeover bids have resurfaced. Some City analysts say the shares are still too expensive.

Richard Hyman, chairman of retail consultancy Verdict, says: "Basically, they were a victim of their own success. Being the best, as M&S were for so long, is bound to foster an element of arrogance and being inward looking."

That corporate culture, instilled by the autocratic and now deposed chairman and chief executive, Sir Richard Greenbury, meant M&S failed to spot a change in the fast-moving world of British shopping. Speed is of the essence in the e-age, and this has fed through to fashions which are changing faster than ever.

The high street has also become polarised and has to compete with American-style out-of-town malls. Shoppers now either chase labels or low prices. The middle market, M&S's playground, has withered. Its fresh attempts to appeal to the masses through its first television campaign, featuring a larger, naked woman, appear to have backfired.

"Marks & Spencer treated the competition far too lightly," said Mr Hyman. "They just didn't see Next and Debenhams changing dramatically to reposition themselves in Marks & Spencer's backyard. For years M&S did quality at prices people could afford. Then Next and Debenhams started to provide a genuine alternative - good, focused branding and better ranging."

The management was probably a bigger problem. Throughout the 1990s the company was led by £1m-a-year Sir Richard. "He was a strong and focused leader, but M&S suffered through not having another strong man in the boardroom that Greenbury would listen to. And he did not manage the succession," says Mr Hyman. The result was that when Marks & Spencer's sales "fell off a cliff" as Sir Richard put it in 1998, a boardroom squabble broke out. Sir Richard was forced to hand over the chief executive's job to Peter Salsbury and eventually resigned altogether. Mr Salsbury has since been ousted and Mr Vandevelde has axed most of the board.

M&S expanded in 1997 at precisely the wrong time Shoppers were flush with cash from a series of building society windfalls. M&S splashed out £192m to buy 19 of Littlewoods' largest stores. Three years on, the stores are not performing. with only three or four profitable.

The new management is starting to make changes, getting rid of the endless rails of clothes in barn-like premises, introducing "concept" stores, where merchandise is grouped according to lifestyles, and its Autograph range of premium-priced clothing put together by designers such as Katharine Hamnett and Julien Macdonald. Innovations such as personal shoppers in some stores, beauty consultation areas, sizes for larger women, maternity clothes and lingerie-only shops in Europe are all welcome but there are still problems as the group's smaller British stores are not big enough to convert into the "concept" format and any plans M&S has for them are either non-existent or top secret.

One top shareholder said: "What is clear is that it isn't going to be a quick fix. It's a long slog but I doubt whether they will ever get back to their previous dominance".

Richard Hyman believes M&S's supertanker proportions could ultimately be its salvation. "In 20 years we will look back and say this was when UK retailing changed fundamentally. It will be much lower margin. There won't be much scope for small businesses. You will need to drive volume to make money and that means being big."

The beleaguered staff also refuse to give up hope. An assistant in the Liverpool store, said: "We are now listening to our customers more than we have ever done and the tide is definitely turning. I am not worried about my job - there is no way M&S will go out of business."

webTitle: Six stores close but staff can win bonus

fields.headline: Six stores close but staff can win bonus
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer is introducing performance-related pay for 50,000 staff in an attempt to boost sales in the Christmas run-up after a fall last month.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer is introducing performance-related pay for 50,000 staff in an attempt to boost sales in the Christmas run-up after a fall last month.

Luc Vandevelde, the Belgian chairman, admitted yesterday "there were no quick fixes" for the retailer as he announced six store closures, fewer than the City expected, and a cut in the size of two others.

In the two months before Christmas, which traditionally generate 25% of M&S profits, staff in the 287 stores stand to receive £75 bonuses for each month they meet sales targets.

Mr Vandevelde, who has to convince City sceptics that he can stem the decline, stood by his pledge to turn the group around in the next 16 months.

While profits for the six months to September 30, down 5% to £183m, were slightly higher than City forecasts, sales for the first five weeks of the second half caused concern. Clothing, footware and gift sales fell almost 15% in the five weeks while those of home products rose 7.6% and of food 5.8%. Overall, like-for-like sales were 8% down.

The core of the problem lay in adult clothing, from which M&S generates 40% of its business. The fuel crisis, poor weather and sales tactics employed at the same time last year exacerbated the decline.

Mr Vandevelde admitted that buying stores from Littlewoods three years ago had been an error. The way clothes are supplied to stores would change in the spring to allow the group to follow "fashion trends".

Emily Shamma, retail analyst at WestLB Panmure, said: "Whilst the theory is good, I've yet to see anything that shows the execution will be good."

The shares rose 10p to 195p in heavy volume generated, according to City sources, by "spivy rumours" of a takeover bid.

While M&S is closing six stores, all but one a former Littlewoods, it plans another nine "concept stores" - where the lighting is brighter and fashions are displayed differently - by Christmas. The closures will cost £44m but involve no redundancies.

The decision to accept other companies' credit cards held back profits in financial services which rose just £3m to £50m.

Despite some forecasts that dividend would be cut for a second time, it was held at 3.7p.

webTitle: No respite down on the farm as floods return

fields.headline: No respite down on the farm as floods return
fields.standfirst:
Forecasters predict more wild weather to come

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Almere Farm, about as close to England as you can get without leaving Wales, is set on the west bank of the River Dee; to the south flows the River Alun, to the north the Pulford Brook.
fields.body:
Almere Farm, about as close to England as you can get without leaving Wales, is set on the west bank of the River Dee; to the south flows the River Alun, to the north the Pulford Brook.

Yesterday there was no way of telling which watercourse was which: swollen by day after day of torrential rain the three have combined to form a lake three miles long by one and a half wide.

Someone estimated that the water could be 10ft deep in places. Hedges are submerged; mucky, wind-whipped waves divide round ancient oaks; the top foot of a footpath sign points mockingly across inundated pastures.

The Goodwins, whose family has farmed the 200 acres at Almere for almost a century, are now a 15-minute motor boat ride from dry land at the hamlet of Trevalyn, near Wrexham.

We docked at a tyre-covered muck heap, transferred to a rowing boat and glided through the stockyard, past the shed where cows tried to keep their feet dry, and moored at the 16th century farmhouse. The water was higher than our wellington boots and we were piggy-backed past the dining room, where water sloshed round an oak dresser laded with fine blue china, to the red-carpeted stairs. The family has taken its microwave and retreated to a bedroom.

The floods hit Almere last week, subsided and then came back at still greater depth on Monday night. All the Goodwins can do now is wait. It rained again yesterday.

"The thing is that you don't know how much water is going to come," said George Goodwin. "You see the damned stuff rising and all you can think is when is it going to stop."

He and his wife Pamela share the house with his mother Gladys, 83, who was whisked away by lifeboat last week, came back and now will not budge.

The environment agency meanwhile warned that with 43 severe flood warnings on 26 rivers in England and Wales the number of properties flooded is set to rise to more than 5,000.

The Met office said that the heavy rains were set to continue. In the north-east of England 18 severe flood warnings were issued yesterday.

Around 20,000 pupils were sent home from nearly 60 schools in the north as heavy rain waterlogged electricity circuits and flooded school complexes. Large parts of Staffordshire were badly affected by flood waters after the River Sow burst its banks.

In the west of England the River Severn from Shrewsbury in Shropshire to Tewkesbury in Gloucestershire was put back on severe flood warning yesterday morning.

Many people in parts of Kent and Sussex awoke to more flooding yesterday.

Forecasters warned Britain faces more devastating storms over the coming months. Piers Corbyn, of Weather Action, who bases his forecasts on solar activity,said: "It will be as bad as we have seen and probably worse."

webTitle: Hospital ready to welcome Spanish nurses

fields.headline: Hospital ready to welcome Spanish nurses
fields.standfirst:
Thirty recruits will fill staffing gaps in new year as harbinger of latest NHS jobs initiative

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Royal Preston Hospital, with its views of the Pennines and swollen river Ribble, could not be more different from most of Spain. But it will be the new home of Spanish nurses being recruited to ease the crisis in staffing levels.
fields.body:
Royal Preston Hospital, with its views of the Pennines and swollen river Ribble, could not be more different from most of Spain. But it will be the new home of Spanish nurses being recruited to ease the crisis in staffing levels.

The hospital and its neighbouring trust in Chorley have 100 vacancies for nurses. Around 30 of these jobs will be filled in the new year by staff from Spain, who are all the equivalent of state registered nurses and competent in written and spoken English.

Most of the vacancies are on medical wards, which can be less attractive to nurses, but there are also jobs available in intensive care.

As many as 5,000 nurses from Spain will be brought into NHS hospitals to help plug the gaps. Alan Milburn, health secretary, yesterday signed an agreement with the Spanish government to recruit them.

The pilot project involves hospitals in the Morecambe Bay trust, Preston trust, Chorley and South Ribble trust, Blackpool Victoria trust, and Blackburn, Hyndburn and Ribble Valley trust. It will bring in a total of 75 nurses.

They will be subjected to stringent English language tests and take a course in the technical language used in hospitals.

Dame Pauline Fielding, nursing director at the Royal Preston hospital and the Chorley and South Ribble trust, said the proportion of nursing vacancies across both hospitals was 4%. "This is pretty low compared with other hospitals," she said.

She said the hospitals always had vacancies on medical wards because it was such hard work. The pressures "used to be a problem in winter for medical wards, but now we are finding it is an all-year round pressure."

A recruitment party is going to Spain this month to recruit nurses for all five trusts.

Of the 30 new recruits, 22 E grade nurses will go to intensive care and eight D graders to medical wards. They will receive parity of pay with their British counterparts.

As part of their contracts, they will be offered a 12 week induction programme covering language and cultural awareness. Dame Pauline said Preston had many cultural facilities to offer.

The Spanish nurses will also be befriended by other hospital workers in a buddy scheme.

Denise Ruston, a clinical manager in the medical directorate at the Royal Preston hospital, said morale was "OK" on the wards, despite the nursing shortages. "The nurses in the medical directorate are very flexible," she said. "Some will do extra shifts because they are so dedicated. Obviously we have our ups and downs."

Each ward has 30 beds, with a ward manager, two junior sisters (or charge nurses) and eight to 10 staff nurses.

"It is easier to recruit nurses in other specialities such as oncology, intensive care and renal units," Ms Ruston said. "Overall we manage, but what cripples us is if staff are hit by the flu or other bugs. It is then that we start to struggle."

Jean Faugier, regional director of nursing for the NHS executive in the north-west, said at least 1,000 extra nurses were needed in the region.

She said the deal with Spain would be more than just a short-term solution to a staffing problem. "We hope it will lead to reciprocol learning arrangement, where eventually our nurses will go to Spain and get some experience of the Spanish services."

The Royal College of Nursing said that overseas nurses had always played an important part in the NHS.

But recruiting from overseas could never be an alternative to a strong home- grown nursing workforce.

Ivy Mitchell, 77, a patient on a medical ward, welcomed the news of nurses arriving from Spain. "It doesn't matter where a nurse comes from as long as you get the right care from them," she said. "It is important to have the same nurses, because they get to know you."

The British embassy in Madrid yesterday reported strong interest among Spanish nurses in working in the NHS.

A Department of Health spokeswoman said aGuardian article on plans to recruit up to 5,000 nurses from Spain was picked up by the Spanish media and triggered a stream of calls asking how to secure an NHS job.

Mr Milburn said the NHS plan envisaged the recruitment and training of 20,000 more nurses by 2004. His department said: "This agreement [with Spain] will help us plug the gap which exists between our ambitions for the health service and the staff we have available to deliver them."

Where they are keen to export health staff

Spain's health service provides universal cover, free at the point of delivery and funded almost entirely from taxes like the NHS. However, this was introduced only in the 1980s, and many people are covered by private schemes.

During modernisation, education of doctors and nurses was expanded and Spain has twice as many doctors per 1,000 of population as most European countries. There is a surplus of doctors and nurses, and some have gone to work abroad under schemes in Portugal, Italy and Ireland that are similar to that agreed with Britain.

Spain spends 6% of GDP on health, and has 338,000 health workers, 73,000 of them doctors. Under its devolved government, seven of the more powerful regions, including the Basque country and Catalonia, are entirely responsible for their own health care. The other 10 are organised from the centre, but it is planned to give them responsibility.

Primary care is the greatest strength. Modern, efficient health centres can be found even in remote rural areas. They are well equipped to do much of the work that in Britain is likely to be referred to hospitals. Some say, however, there is a tendency for GPs to bow to patient pressure and over-prescribe.

Spain's centre-right government has made an effort at reform. But the measures, including replacing brand-name drugs with generic alternatives and reducing the list of free medications, proved unpopular. Neverthless cost cutting, or cost controlling, remains a priority.

Adela Gooch in Madrid

webTitle: Business news in brief

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Jaguar faces strike ballot
fields.body:
Jaguar faces strike ballot

Workers at luxury carmaker Jaguar are to vote on industrial action after they turned down a two-year pay offer.

Ballot papers will be sent out in the next few days and the result is expected at the end of the month.

The move followed rejection by union members of a deal worth 4.25% in year one and at least 3.5% in year two.

Duncan Simpson, chief negotiator for the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said: "Our main objection to the pay deal is not the percentage rise, which is reasonable, but the extra money for team leaders which is divisive."

Deadline for Daewoo Motor

South Korea's third largest carmaker teetered on the brink of bankruptcy yesterday as creditors of Daewoo Motor gave unions until today to agree to job cuts needed for rescue funds from banks.

The brief reprieve reflected creditors' commitment to staving off bankruptcy at the carmaker, Korea Development Bank president Uhm Rak-yong said.

KDB and other creditors are in talks to sell Daewoo Motor and related firms to General Motors and partner Fiat.

Once the crown jewels in the Korean conglomerate, Daewoo Motor has faced an uncertain future since an expected sale to US carmaker Ford suddenly collapsed in mid-September.

Elderstreet falls to DKB

The private equity business of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, the investment banking division of Dresdner Bank, confirmed yesterday it has bought Elderstreet Investments, a UK venture capital company.

DKB will own 82% of the business, having taken an initial 18% interest in Elderstreet in 1999 but gave no further financial details of the acquisition.

DKB said that Elderstreet would develop a pan-European platform for early stage IT-software technology investments and launch a successor fund to Elderstreet Capital Partners to operate on a pan-European basis.

DKB will commit up to €75m (£45m) as anchor investor in the fund.

Elderstreet would retain its brand identity, team structure and investment focus, DKB said.

Discount house closes up shop

Anglo-South African insurance group Old Mutual is to close its Gerrard & King discount house, with a number of redundancies expected among the 53-strong staff.

Discount houses date back to 1825 to trade government bonds and treasury bills, and Gerrard & King was the last remaining such house.

Old Mutual is merging Gerrard's domestic equity and gilt stock borrowing and lending operations with the equivalent international businesses at its GNI unit.

webTitle: Sara Lee drops bid for Bernard Matthews empire

fields.headline: Sara Lee drops bid for Bernard Matthews empire
fields.trailText: Norfolk turkey farmer Bernard Matthews looks likely to succeed in his £232m bid to take his poultry empire private after US food conglomerate Sara Lee abandoned plans for a rival offer at the eleventh hour yesterday.
fields.body:
Norfolk turkey farmer Bernard Matthews looks likely to succeed in his £232m bid to take his poultry empire private after US food conglomerate Sara Lee abandoned plans for a rival offer at the eleventh hour yesterday.

Sara Lee withdrew just 24 hours before the final deadline for competing bids, in a surprise move which triggered glee at Bernard Matthews' Norwich headquarters.

Mr Matthews said he was "delighted" at the news, adding that his consortium would "look forward to progessing its full, fair and recommended offer for Bernard Matthews plc and returning it to family ownership".

Tension between the two sides remained high as advisers to the American firm accused Mr Matthews' side of "outrageous" conduct in withholding vital information until the last minute.

Sara Lee always faced an uphill task, as Mr Matthews' family controlled 42% of the turkey firm's shares. Insurance firm Royal & Sun Alliance, which has 4.5%, had also undertaken to accept the family buyout unless a competing offer emerged worth at least 10% more.

Sara Lee believed it would be able to capture Royal & Sun Alliance's approval until last week, when it became clear that a highly unusual clause in the insurer's acceptance undertaking allowed competing bidders only one chance. The clause allowed the family consortium to match any higher bid but banned outsiders from increasing their offers any further.

A source close to Sara Lee said this scuppered the US firm's chances: "They didn't make that clear in their first announcement. It's outrageous for them to miss out a crucial term of an irrevocable undertaking."

Bernard Matthews' managing director, David Joll, said the family firm had disclosed the crucial clause in its offer document last Wednesday, five days after revealing its intention to bid.

He said: "It's not new information; it was made available to their advisers some time ago."

The Matthews family, which is backed by HSBC, is offering 185p cash per share and is in the process of putting together a share alternative.

Mr Matthews issued a statement last night saying: "Now it is back to business with everyone working to supply our millions of customers with their Christmas turkeys."

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Serbian prisons in uproar
Chaos spread at three prisons in Serbia yesterday. One of them, at Nis, was on fire and shooting was reported when police stormed it to try to restore calm.
fields.body:
Serbian prisons in uproar
Chaos spread at three prisons in Serbia yesterday. One of them, at Nis, was on fire and shooting was reported when police stormed it to try to restore calm.

Serb prisoners in the towns of Pozarevac, Sremska Mitrovice and Nis revolted against alleged ill-treatment by guards. They also wanted to share in an amnesty proposed recently by the new president, Vojislav Kostunica, for ethnic Albanian prisoners. [AP, Nis]

Immigrants saved off Italy
The Italian coastguard averted a potential tragedy by towing to safety a rudderless ship carrying 1,000 illegal immigrants adrift in high seas yesterday.

The ship was guided into the south-eastern port of Otranto at 9am. A coastguard official said the passengers, mainly from Turkey but including Palestinians, Eritreans, Sinhalese and Chinese, were in good condition. Thirty people thought to be smugglers or crew members were arrested. [Reuters, Otranto, Italy]

Thai fireworks kill three
Three people died and 94 were injured after a big explosion at a fireworks shop in a crowded marketplace near Bangkok, hospital staff said yesterday.

Fireworks and firecrackers are in heavy demand for the annual Loy Kratong festival on Saturday, in which Thais float wreaths on rivers and canals and let off firecrackers to mark the end of the monsoon and pray for good luck. The police said it was too early to ascertain what caused the explosion in Samut Sakhon. [Reuters, Bangkok]

Uganda thwarts rebel uprising
At least 20 soldiers were killed in the northern town of Bunia after the Ugandan army sent in troops and tanks to stop a mutiny against the Congolese rebel leader Ernest Wamba dia Wamba.

The US-educated leader of the Congolese Rally for Democracy-Movement for the Liberation was attacked on Sunday by forces loyal to his rival Mbusa Nyamwisi, after Mr Wamba had named him vice-president. [AP, Kigali]

Giraffes, rhinos sailing home
Three South African rhinos and 22 giraffes who have spent a month at sea since being refused entry into Spain for fear of foot-and-mouth disease are finally on their way home, it was reported yesterday.

The animals will have almost circumnavigated Africa by the time they get home, sailing up the west coast from KwaZulu-Natal province and returning through the Suez canal. Two giraffes have died on board, probably due to the cramped conditions, prompting animal-rights activists to ask why they were not sent by air. [Reuters, Johannesburg]

They also wanted to share in an amnesty proposed recently by the new president, Vojislav Kostunica, for ethnic Albanian prisoners. [AP, Nis] Immigrants saved off Italy The Italian coastguard averted a potential tragedy by towing to safety a rudderless ship carrying 1,000 illegal immigrants adrift in high seas yesterday. The ship was guided into the south-eastern port of Otranto at 9am. A coastguard official said the passengers, mainly from Turkey but including Palestinians, Eritreans, Sinhalese and Chinese, were in good condition. Thirty people thought to be smugglers or crew members were arrested. [Reuters, Otranto, Italy] Thai fireworks kill three Three people died and 94 were injured after a big explosion at a fireworks shop in a crowded marketplace near Bangkok, hospital staff said yesterday. Fireworks and firecrackers are in heavy demand for the annual Loy Kratong festival on Saturday, in which Thais float wreaths on rivers and canals and let off firecrackers to mark the end of the monsoon and pray for good luck. The police said it was too early to ascertain what caused the explosion in Samut Sakhon. [Reuters, Bangkok] Uganda thwarts rebel uprising At least 20 soldiers were killed in the northern town of Bunia after the Ugandan army sent in troops and tanks to stop a mutiny against the Congolese rebel leader Ernest Wamba dia Wamba. The US-educated leader of the Congolese Rally for Democracy-Movement for the Liberation was attacked on Sunday by forces loyal to his rival Mbusa Nyamwisi, after Mr Wamba had named him vice-president. [AP, Kigali] Giraffes, rhinos sailing home Three South African rhinos and 22 giraffes who have spent a month at sea since being refused entry into Spain for fear of foot-and-mouth disease are finally on their way home, it was reported yesterday. The animals will have almost circumnavigated Africa by the time they get home, sailing up the west coast from KwaZulu-Natal province and returning through the Suez canal. Two giraffes have died on board, probably due to the cramped conditions, prompting animal-rights activists to ask why they were not sent by air. [Reuters, Johannesburg]

webTitle: Afghan women reach last refuge

fields.headline: Afghan women reach last refuge
fields.standfirst: The light of learning is being kept alive in the north-east, but hardline Taliban forces are closing in
fields.trailText: Bazia has been running from the Taliban for four years. A month ago she fled to Faizabad, the last significant town in Afghanistan still outside the control of the governing Islamic militia, and began taking a degree in medicine.
fields.body:
Bazia has been running from the Taliban for four years. A month ago she fled to Faizabad, the last significant town in Afghanistan still outside the control of the governing Islamic militia, and began taking a degree in medicine.

Now the Taliban forces are closing in on her again, desperate to take this small slice of north-eastern Afghanistan. "After Faizabad, where can we go?" said the 21-year-old.

As ethnic Tajiks, Bazia and her family are despised by the Taliban, who come mainly from Afghanistan's dominant Pashtun tribe. As an eloquent, educated woman she is a threat to their deeply conservative, male-dominated tribal structures.

In 1996 Bazia escaped from the capital, Kabul, with her family as the hardline militia seized power and began enforcing Islamic edicts. Women were confined to the home be hind blackened windows and forbidden from working. Girls' schools and colleges were promptly closed. Bazia took refuge in Parvan province, 30 miles north of the capital.

Then, as the Taliban approached last year, she fled again with her family 200 miles north to Taloqan, an opposition stronghold. Last month Taloqan too fell and Bazia drove with her family on rough dirt tracks through the mountains for two days to reach Faizabad.

"When the fighting got close to Taloqan, artillery fire was coming all around us," she said. "They wouldn't hesitate to abduct girls. I was an eyewitness that the Taliban burned many houses and plundered them."

Opposition forces promise to recapture Taloqan before the winter snows but in reality they are struggling to hold back the Taliban drive.

"We will stay and resist the Taliban until the last drop of our blood," she said.

"Even women will take up arms for the defence of Afghan independence."

In the meantime she and her 14 classmates, all women, are sitting on crudely hewn wooden chairs in a cold, whitewashed room in the Badakshan medical college, trying to start a seven-year medical degree. There are few textbooks for the college's 180 students, no laboratories and no electricity, but it is still said to be the best medical school left in Afghanistan.

Faizabad is little more than a big dusty village, caught in a valley of the Hindu Kush and divided by the cold waters of the Kokcha river, which flows west to the Oxus. Here women are as free as they can be in Afghanistan. They can work and walk alone in the streets. Yet outdoors they still must wear a burqa , the cloak that covers their hair, face and body.

When no men are watching they flick back the burqa to uncover their faces in a small sign of resistance that would earn them a beating in Taliban areas. Even mixed classes at the Badakshan medical college have been forbidden; theology lessons are compulsory.

"Since we are living in an Islamic country we want to have the veil to observe Islamic law. But we don't want to be kept inside our homes," said Lida, a second-year medical student who fled from Mazar-i-Sharif, a bustling city in the north now under Taliban control.

"Women living in Taliban areas are not free. I ask you, is it a sin to be a woman? If women bring such shame to Afghanistan then why don't they exterminate us all?"

Burhanuddin Rabbani, the Afghan president ousted by the Taliban in 1996 but still regarded by most countries as the head of state, is himself a deeply religious man. He has promised that the burqa will go when the war is ended.

"Our policies to women are quite clear," Mr Rabbani said in an interview. "They are equal. We have enabled women to work in government offices and to get an education."

But teachers are now paid just 60 pence a month, and often wait months for even that. Many have given up trying to teach.

Most women have had little education and some have married as young as 12. Many have lost husbands in the course of 20 years of fighting - first against the Soviet occupation forces, and later among the Afghans themselves - leaving them to cope alone with as many as 10 children.

Those with money could join the 6m Afghans who have moved abroad since the fighting began and find a better life among the refugees in Pakistan, Iran, Europe and the United States.

But for Bazia and her proud classmates, perhaps Afghanistan's last educated generation, escaping into exile is out of the question.

"In the future we will become doctors and treat the sick people of our country," she said. "We cannot leave now. Our country is everything."

webTitle: Diary

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
The identity of the mysterious Lord Henderson, who wrote with various complaints (the sight of me and my capacious arse, for example, waddling along west London's Goldhawk Road) is solved. This is Michael Henderson, a cricket writer on the Daily Telegraph - a paper which generously provides the headed notepaper for his letter-writing hobby. My colleague David McKie had a missive about classical music while Gary Younge got another after writing favourably about the Runnymede Trust's multiculturalism report."You clearly know nothing about your country," he wrote to Gary, who is black, and of Bajan descent. "This piece may set you on the road towards partial knowledge." The piece was an appreciation of great Britons by (who else?) my sane and rational friend Paul Johnson. He also advises Gary to buy "a decent recording of the Meistersinger. The blessed RW [Richard Wagner, the maestro of Nazism] wasn't English but he did know something of how the past informs the present. Unlike some people I could mention." Delightful.

Meanwhile, an email arrives from Jake Gavin concerning "an excellent new restaurant called the Bush Bar and Grill, opening next Monday on the Goldhawk Road, which will serve simple food, deliciously cooked, to all and sundry without discriminating between the capaciously arsed and skinnily derriered". Mr Gavin invites me to pop in this evening to road-test one of his cocktails. Very kind.

Britain's answer to the Spooneristic creature who may by now, God forbid, be president-elect, continues to defy predictions that political oratory is a dying form. When the Tory MP for York, Anne McIntosh, complained she had not been properly informed, in accordance with parliamentary etiquette, that John Dubya Prescott was visiting her constituency, the latter intervened with a typically lyrical speech. "I met you, you twit," he shouted. Miss McIntosh asked whether it was "parliamentary language to call a fellow parliamentarian a twit?", to which new Speaker Martin replied: "Order. It is not nice." Not nice. Do you think it's possible to take this Glaswegian hardman thing one step too far?

What a relief to see that the demonstration against savage cuts in public spending in Hackney on Monday night was attended by so many riot police in multi-coloured hats, even though there wasn't a hint of real violence. When the fuel protest charlatans were blockading the refineries in September, on the other hand, there wasn't a single riot policeman in evidence. Nothing like getting the policing priorities right, is there?

Did anyone see Ruth Gledhill, the Times's religious correspondent, on BBC1's Songs of Praise on Sunday, when apparently she was shown ballroom dancing? If so, please report at once.

Last week, I rebuked a reader who (in support of Frankie Howerd being cast as Gordon Brown), accredited "Infamy, infamy, they've all got in for me!" to Frankie in Up Pompeii; when in fact it was Kenneth Williams in Carry On Cleo. "Any real intellectual snob (or 'proper Kaufman', to use the technical term), would know that the line was borrowed from one of Muir and Norden's scripts for Take It From Here," writes Peter Grant from Oxford. "There seems to be a jinx on Diary stories that mention Gordon Brown." This reference to the revelation in the spring that Gordon and Sarah had split up is uncalled for. That's all in the past, and let's hear no more about it.

In Stockholm, Lars Jonsson is nursing a fractured skull, broken nose, a damaged cornea and various cuts and bruises. A Mrs Anne Jonsson awaits trial, meanwhile, for aggravated assault. The catalyst for the dispute was Lars's refusal to take her to a rally against domestic violence.

webTitle: Tommy and the cops ham it up in Suharto farce

fields.headline: Tommy and the cops ham it up in Suharto farce
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: The Indonesian attorney general announced yesterday that the Suharto estate in Jakarta would be searched for the former president's fugitive youngest son Hutomo "Tommy" Mandala Putra, who should have begun a jail sentence on Friday for defrauding the state of £7.5m.
fields.byline: John Aglionby  and agencies in Jakarta
fields.body:
The Indonesian attorney general announced yesterday that the Suharto estate in Jakarta would be searched for the former president's fugitive youngest son Hutomo "Tommy" Mandala Putra, who should have begun a jail sentence on Friday for defrauding the state of £7.5m.

Marzuki Darusman said he believed Putra was hiding at his home in the collection of family houses, known as Cendana, which was bristling with private security guards yesterday. An intelligence source told Reuters that there were up to 200 guards in case of trouble tomorrow, when protesters are planning a march to the estate .

But the authorities' farcically inept attempts to jail the playboy billionaire, and his lawyers' increasingly ridiculous excuses to stall the process, are fooling no one.

The whole affair, which is eroding what remnants of credibility President Abdurrahman Wahid has, is seen as the latest and most public manifestation of the power the Suharto family still wields, two years after its downfall.

Tommy, as he is universally known in Indonesia, was declared a fugitive at one minute past midnight after he failed to arrive at the Cipinang high security jail in Jakarta to begin his 18-month sentence.

The police waited until the afternoon to mobilise four teams of elite officers to look for him in the capital. Having announced where they were going to look, they had found out nothing about his whereabouts by late last night.

Meanwhile his lawyers took turns saying it was time for Tommy, 38, to abide by the law and that he could not turn himself in until he was guaranteed round-the-clock protection against threats of sodomy and murder in jail.

Twenty-four hours earlier one of the lawyers, Nudirman Munir, had said Tommy would surrender only when he was shown the original of the presidential decree rejecting a pardon. This was provided, but Tommy failed to appear.

It should never have got this far. The Indonesian media are asking why he was not imprisoned immediately when con victed on September 22, why he was not kept under surveillance during the stay of enforcement, and why the prosecutors let him leave for a "vital family engagement" on Friday afternoon when an arrest warrant had already been served.

Mr Darusman insisted yesterday that there was nothing political in Tommy's disappearance, but few Indonesians believe it, particularly as President Wahid met him in a Jakarta hotel while his appeal for a pardon was being considered.

The Jakarta Post wrote in an editorial this week: "With things as they are at present, [the president's] observation that his rejection of Tommy's appeal for a pardon is proof that the law rules supreme, and that the principle of equality before the law has been established, sounds rather hollow."

Endy Bayuni, the paper's managing editor, said that Tommy "honestly thinks he has done wonders for the country and that his father was an amazing president, so why should he go to jail".

Tommy and his five siblings amassed huge fortunes while their father ruled Indonesia for 32 years until May 1998.

Tommy has powerful friends, including government members, who are able to protect him, leaving President Wahid powerless, Mr Bayuni said.

"Tommy's whole intention is to turn this into a farce for Gus Dur" - the president's nickname. "Tommy knows Gus Dur has staked his whole reputation on getting the Suhartos into prison and so he's doing everything he can to undermine him."

webTitle: They went to outer space

fields.headline: They went to outer space
fields.standfirst:
Sixteen countries have bought a ludicrous time-share in the sky
Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Sixteen countries have bought a ludicrous time-share in the sky
fields.body:
The first residents of the new international space station have just completed their first week in orbit together and already the tensions are beginning to show. Yuri isn't putting the milk back in the fridge but that's not as annoying as that funny whistling-through-his-teeth thing that Sergei does all the time. The American, Bill Shepherd, is trying to hold it all together, but he's been on the defensive since that argument on the first morning which ended with him saying: "How was I to know I wasn't supposed to put the cat outside at night?"

The three astronauts will be cooped up together until February with no option of leaving or seeing anyone else, though Bill has yet to break it to his parents that they probably won't be able to come and stay for Thanksgiving this year. All flatshares are a strain, but one which involves being locked in a space pod for 18 weeks sounds like hell on Earth without the "on Earth" bit.

Eventually there will be accommodation for residents from all the 16 countries who are funding this project and presumably Channel 4 are now planning the space-age follow up to Big Brother. TV phone votes from around the world will determine who stays in the house and who gets cast out into the void of deep space.

At least if it produced a TV show we might be able to understand what the point of it all was. It has already cost $60bn, which makes it the second biggest waste of money of all time after the American presidential campaign. Do we really have to spend that much just to learn that men from Planet Earth have problems using a gravity free lavatory, when after thousands of years they still can't aim properly at the ordinary toilet bowl in their own bathrooms.

The history of space exploration is littered with bizarre projects that cost a fortune for no discernible benefit to us down here on Earth. Somewhere upon the moon is still parked the world's most expensive car, the Space Buggy, which was driven around for a few miles and then just abandoned; a sort of lunar equivalent of joy- riding. In the 1970s we marvelled at the technology on this amazing car, because eight-track music systems seemed quite impressive back then.

Then there was the Hubble telescope, which took pictures of outer space which took two weeks to be beamed back to Earth, and then another two weeks to be developed at Foto-Kwik. There was Skylab which was also talked about as a permanently manned space station, until they realised that if you want to live hundreds of miles from civilisation, cut off from any human contact or culture, then you can just move into one of those new devel opments in the Thames estuary. Next there is talk of a manned space trip to Mars, which seems like trying to run before we can walk. A successful manned rail trip to Birmingham New Street might be a start.

People who defend space expenditure always point to the incidental byproducts of the programmes to justify the enormous cost. "We'd never have got the non-stick saucepan if it hadn't been for the moon landings," they always say. Surely a programme that had been specifically designed just to develop non-stick saucepans might have achieved the same end at marginally less expense.

This latest project is the international equivalent of a timeshare apartment. Sixteen countries have been conned into paying their bit towards a half-built orbiting holiday home. Their government representative went along to the presentation because you got a free Sony Walkman just for turning up, but before long he found himself persuaded of the merits of his government having a little place of their own that they could use anytime of the year (as long as it was for a four-month spell in three years time). Like all holiday homes it is more use as a status symbol than somewhere you'd actually want to live.

But Daniel Goldin, the Head of Nasa, has defended the project by saying that now, "Instead of pointing missiles at each other, we'll be learning from each other." Perhaps this gives us a clue to the method behind all this madness. Maybe future residents of the space station will not be astronauts but political leaders. If Yasser Arafat and Ehud Barak cannot learn to get along after they've been trapped together in a tiny space capsule for four months, then we can be sure that they never will. David Trimble and Gerry Adams, Robert Mugabe and Ian Smith, Liam Gallagher and Robbie Williams; the place is probably already fully booked for the rest of the decade. Of course it is quite possible that all the world's sworn enemies will come back hating each other more than ever. But it still will have been worth spending all that money to send them up there for a few months - if only to give the rest of us down here a break for a while.

Their government representative went along to the presentation because you got a free Sony Walkman just for turning up, but before long he found himself persuaded of the merits of his government having a little place of their own that they could use anytime of the year (as long as it was for a four-month spell in three years time). Like all holiday homes it is more use as a status symbol than somewhere you'd actually want to live. But Daniel Goldin, the Head of Nasa, has defended the project by saying that now, "Instead of pointing missiles at each other, we'll be learning from each other." Perhaps this gives us a clue to the method behind all this madness. Maybe future residents of the space station will not be astronauts but political leaders. If Yasser Arafat and Ehud Barak cannot learn to get along after they've been trapped together in a tiny space capsule for four months, then we can be sure that they never will. David Trimble and Gerry Adams, Robert Mugabe and Ian Smith, Liam Gallagher and Robbie Williams; the place is probably already fully booked for the rest of the decade. Of course it is quite possible that all the world's sworn enemies will come back hating each other more than ever. But it still will have been worth spending all that money to send them up there for a few months - if only to give the rest of us down here a break for a while. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Public confidence hides private nerves as the votes pile up

fields.headline: Public confidence hides private nerves as the votes pile up
fields.standfirst: The party's HQ exudes cash and optimism Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Like speculators who had gambled everything on a single investment, George W Bush and his backers assembled under torrential rain in Texas last night to discover if the most expensive campaign in US political history had paid off.
fields.body:
Like speculators who had gambled everything on a single investment, George W Bush and his backers assembled under torrential rain in Texas last night to discover if the most expensive campaign in US political history had paid off.

Large-scale corporate contributors checked in alongside Republican heavyweights at the Four Seasons hotel in Austin where the Texas governor and his family awaited the early returns. At the centre of the action was Karl Rove, the Bush strategist, who shuttled between the campaign headquarters and the hotel armed with a notepad and a calculator.

Exuding the studied optimism which the Bush campaign has made its signature, Mr Rove predicted winning 320 of the 538 votes in the electoral college, which formally determines the presidency under the constitution.

"It's going to be a long night for the Gore campaign," he told reporters, saying that his staff were watching Florida, Pennsylvania and West Virginia in the east for early indications of the result.

Mr Rove's confidence however belied a nervous mood in the party headquarters. Unlike the Gore-Lieberman's scrappy single-storey office on the outskirts of Nashville, the Bush-Cheney centre, at the heart of Austin's commercial district, was all slick grandeur, reflecting the campaign's superior financial resources. With its deep carpets and hushed urgency it looked and felt more like the head office of a bank. The well-dressed staffers were aware that they were on the brink of becoming the new US political elite. But some were actively discussing the possibility of winning the popular vote but narrowly losing the contest in the electoral college. In that case, one said: "There should be pressure put on the delegates to reflect the national will."

The Governor calls

All but two states - Maine and Nebraska - cast their votes in the electoral college on a winner-takes-all basis, but delegates have been known to defy the majority vote in their states and switch their vote.

Anticipating an agonisingly close finish, the Bush campaign set aside over $80m for a concerted effort in the last two weeks to mobilise its core supporters. Party officials said 110m pamphlets had been posted and 62m phone calls had been made to persuade Republicans to vote.

Mr Bush placed a handful of calls from the governor's mansion, introducing himself as "George W Bush, seeking the presidency." "I feel great if I know people are going to the polls, and that's why I'm calling," he told one supporter. "I appreciate your strong support. Make sure you take the family. If you convert families from Gore to Bush that counts double. It's one less vote for him and one more for me."

While Mr Gore was chasing votes in Florida in the early hours of yesterday morning, Mr Bush flew back to Austin and had a night's sleep in his own bed, a calculated gesture of confidence. Asked how he was feeling, he replied: "Calm. Let me see if you got this by now. I trust the people. I do. We poured our hearts and souls into this campaign."

After voting with his wife at a courthouse in Austin, he moved to the Four Seasons hotel to watch the returns with his family, a political dynasty which includes his father, the former president, and his brother Jeb, the Florida governor.

George senior was hoping to become the first former president since 1824 to see his son follow in his footsteps. The only previous father-son presidents were John Adams and John Quincy Adams, the second and sixth presidents respectively.

Outside the state building a huge podium had been erected for the press, for what Bush staffers promised would be the biggest victory celebration ever. If not, one activist joked, "It will be the most expensive concession speech in history."

webTitle: Tired team makes final pitch

fields.headline: Tired team makes final pitch
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore voted in his home town of Carthage, not far from his campaign headquarters in Nashville, after an extraordinary sweep through 11 states, an indication of how tight the contest was being seen right until the very last moment.
fields.body:
Al Gore voted in his home town of Carthage, not far from his campaign headquarters in Nashville, after an extraordinary sweep through 11 states, an indication of how tight the contest was being seen right until the very last moment. His final campaign appearance before voting started was in Tampa, Florida, when he met a group of night-shift care workers at 4am.

Florida was chosen for the last trip as a signal of how much Mr Gore valued its votes. "It's not an accident that it's here in Tampa," Mr Gore, his eyes almost closed with weariness, told the workers, "because Florida may well be the state that decides this contest." George W Bush's brother Jeb is governor of the state.

As the votes began to come in under the sunny Tennessee skies, the Democrats' vice-presidential candidate, Joe Lieberman, and his wife arrived to watch the results with the Gores at a Nashville hotel. Then it was on to the War Memorial Plaza for the last of the hundreds of rallies of the campaign.

Bob Schrum, a senior Gore adviser, would only say at a press conference in Nashville that the team was "very tired and very optimistic". Then Mr Gore's 100,000 volunteers started telephoning voters to get them down to the polls, and sending off the last of the 30m emails that have been dispatched throughout the campaign.

This has been the first internet election and the Democrats' young team has made full use of it. The implications of reaching voters this way are enormous because it allows candidates to home in with very specific messages to groups.

There was an indication of the international interest in the campaign from the number of foreign journalists who were in Nashville to cover the results. A total of 231 foreign correspondents were still in town, with Japan having most (58), followed by the UK (39), Spain (28), France (15), Germany (14), Russia and Italy (both 12). The Russians and Spanish have most television crews (five each).

Even as the votes were being counted, there were discussions under way on how Mr Gore could have run a better campaign, particularly when he seemed to be riding high in opinion polls before the three televised debates. It is privately accepted by Gore advisers that he failed to capitalise on his lead and on the healthy US economy, and presented the kind of personality that clearly turned off many undecided voters, with what many perceived as arrogance.

Another problem for Mr Gore was his inability to enthuse the left both within his party and among those who voted for Ralph Nader. Many on the left outside the Democratic party took the view that Mr Gore was not much better than Mr Bush, and made it clear that they believed it did not matter if the Green candidate allowed the Republicans in. On election eve in Harlem, New York, Mr Nader was repeating one of his campaign mantras that "the only difference between Gore and Bush is the velocity with which their knees hit the floor when corporations bang on their door".

Mr Nader, regarded in the Gore camp as the "grim reaper", was not thought to pose a problem until the later stages of the campaign, when it became clear that he was polling better than expected in key states such as Oregon and Pennsylvania. By then, he had gathered momentum and the Republicans were happy to see him play the role that Ross Perot did in 1992, when his votes were widely seen as helping Bill Clinton defeat George W Bush's father.

But for all that, Mr Gore's supporters, gathering in their hundreds in central Nashville, were standing by their man, in the homeland of country music. They blamed the Republicans for spreading false messages with the most expensive advertising campaign ever in a presidential election.

webTitle: The great dome robbery

fields.headline: The great dome robbery
fields.standfirst:
Thieves use digger, smoke bombs and powerboat

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Twelve men equipped with a bulldozer, a powerboat and as much audacity as any criminals since the Great Train Robbery almost 40 years ago raided the Millennium Dome yesterday hoping to pull off one of the most daring robberies the country has seen.
fields.body:
Twelve men equipped with a bulldozer, a powerboat and as much audacity as any criminals since the Great Train Robbery almost 40 years ago raided the Millennium Dome yesterday hoping to pull off one of the most daring robberies the country has seen.

Four of them, wearing gasmasks and body armour, crashed through the perimeter fence on a mechanical digger and hurtled towards a display of diamonds worth as much as £350m, lobbing smoke bombs and firing nailguns as visitors, including children, were touring the site.

But instead of escaping with the 203 carat Millennium Star - one of the most valuable stones ever cut - and 11 other "priceless" blue diamonds - they were snared by a police operation every bit as bold as their own.

Officers from Scotland Yard's Flying Squad and armed response units were posing as cleaners, their guns hidden in black binliners. They lay in wait for the robbers outside a 4ft thick concrete vault where the stones were on display. Police said no shots were fired and the robbers surrendered without a struggle.

In a day of unremitting drama, seven of their alleged accomplices were also arrested. All were British. One, who was seized at a farmhouse in Kent, is aged 62.

The raid had been anticipated for months following a tip-off to the Metropolitan police, thought to have been from a paid informer.

An operation involving 100 officers from London and Kent - codenamed Magician - was set up in total secrecy. The Cabinet Office and senior figures in the New Millennium Experience Company, including Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, and the mining company De Beers, which owns the diamonds, were informed.

The commissioner of the Metropolitan police, Sir John Stevens, was also briefed.

The decision to allow the raid to take place was a risky one, especially as schoolchildren were in the dome when the raid occurred. However, the officer in charge of the investigation, Detective Superintendent Jon Shatford, said it was the only way to gather compelling evidence.

Police refused to be drawn last night on whether the attempted heist was the work of sophisticated criminals or "chancers". Some aspects bear striking resemblances to the recent James Bond movie The World Is Not Enough. "It is obvious there was a good degree of planning," a source said.

One suspect was seized in a powerboat which had been moored to the Queen Elizabeth II pier next to the dome.

Another was arrested on the north bank of the Thames at Lower Lee Crossings, opposite the dome. This suspect is believed to have been monitoring police messages.

Six other men were arrested at two farm houses in west Kent - at Collier Street and Horsmonden - by the local force's serious crime squad. Police released the ages of five: 32, 34, 38, 58 and 62.

All 12 men were being questioned at stations in London and the south-east last night.

Events unfolded at 9.30am, half an hour after a powerboat glided up to Queen Elizabeth jetty and cut its two engines to avoid drawing attention.

On the other side of the dome site, four men posing as builders revved a bulldozer, preparing, it seemed, for work on a nearby site. To the 64 visitors already touring the dome, the movements yesterday were without significance. To the Flying Squad, they signalled the imminent attempt to pull off the biggest robbery since the Brink's-Mat raid at Heathrow in 1983.

At 9.30, the gang made an audacious and extraordinary move: the digger clattered at full pelt into the wire fence, crushing it flat before startled security guards. It then charged towards the dome's money zone. In the mayhem, four masked men slipped through the narrow door of the diamond vault and headed for what they thought was the Millennium Star, a diamond so distinctive that it could never be sold on the open market.

In fact, they were looking at a replica - the 12 diamonds had been replaced with crystal copies the day before, following a police request.

Once inside, the robbers had effectively imprisoned themselves within the 4ft concrete walls.

Without a lookout standing guard, they hammered on the reinforced glass cases with hammers, sledgehammers and electric nailguns. Armed police surrounded the vault and ordered them to drop their weapons and come out.

Ozcan Ocak, who works at the dome, said: "I heard a terrible crashing noise as if there was an accident. When I went out to look I saw a bulldozer outside going through the money zone. There were police everywhere at the time. We did not take it seriously for a moment but then the police told us to get back."

Mr Ocak, added: "I felt a sense of disbelief. It was like something out of a movie. Someone next to me even asked whether this was part of the live entertainment at the dome. There was smoke all over the area. You could smell gunpowder right up your nostrils."

He later glimpsed two of the men who had been captured. One was aged about 25; the other was wearing a white hooded top.

Security staff rushed visitors away from the money zone and a party of schoolchildren from Surrey huddled in a room and sang hymns to keep their spirits up.

London Underground was ordered to shut North Greenwich station, which serves the dome, at the request of the Met and London Ambulance was put on standby.

Scotland Yard refused to discuss the gang's motives, saying the operation was at a delicate stage.

Diamond experts, however, speculated that the robbers were either working to order, possibly for a private collector, or for a syndicate in the Middle East that would cut the diamonds into smaller rocks be fore selling them. Another possibility is that the robbers were unaware how difficult it would be to dispose of such distinctive diamonds, even on the black market.

A former Flying Squad commander, John O'Connor, suggested that the robbers might have been behind two previous failed raids in London, in which powerboats were used as getaway vessels.

Although he refused to discuss the details of the case, Det Supt Shatford was sure of one thing when he gave a press conference at the dome at midday. "Had this been carried out in accordance with their wishes, it would have been the largest robbery in the world. It was a very audacious attempt at robbery, but was foiled by an even more audacious police response. The minute the individuals made an overt at tempt to commit the robbery they were arrested with overwhelming force.

"Tactically this was an extremely difficult operation and it took a great deal of planning. Our paramount concern throughout was the threat to the public."

Asked why the police had not stepped in before the gang reached the zone, he said: "The biggest danger would have been to let them escape or frustrate them before they could commit the offence. We have to produce the best evidence. If we fail to do that we are letting the public down because we are saying it is too difficult for us and we will let them go and commit crime elsewhere. The planning we went through and the result vindicates the strategy used."

But Mr Gerbeau, chief executive of the New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the dome, made it clear the management would have preferred to have avoided the police showdown.

"The police asked us to collaborate and this is a public building so they took over," he said. "It's a police operation so they make the calls. We had no choice _ My worst nightmare was for someone to be hurt. I haven't slept very well these past few weeks."

Andrew Lamont, a spokesman for De Beers, said the company was first told of the risk to the diamonds in September, when floor plans for the display were stolen from the dome.

An anonymous caller offered to return the plans for money, but De Beers called the police. "At this point we were informed by Scotland Yard that they were already investigating a possible threat to the display."

Scotland Yard insisted last night that the theft of the plans was "completely separate" from yesterday's raid.

Mr Lamont thought the robbers were either working to order for a Mr Big, who would keep the diamonds in a private collection, or were amateurs, who had no idea that the stones could not be sold in their present state.

"Cutting up the Millennium Star would be like cutting up a Van Gogh or Monet. It would only be worth a tiny fraction of the whole."

webTitle: Fetch Sony predicts decade of the robot

fields.headline: Fetch Sony predicts decade of the robot
fields.trailText: The creator of Sony's robot pet Aibo says his toy will be the companion of the future, but its days as a guide dog for the blind are still far off, writes Tatsuya Mistuda.
fields.body:
The creator of Sony's robot pet Aibo says his toy will be the companion of the future, but its days as a guide dog for the blind are still far off, writes Tatsuya Mistuda.

"The 1980s was the decade of the PC, the 90s of the internet, but I believe the decade just starting will be the decade of the robot," Toshitada Doi, president of Sony Digital Creatures Laboratory, said yesterday in Tokyo.

An upgraded but cheaper version of Aibo (above) reaches shops on November 16 priced about 150,000 yen (£976). It has a camera in its nose to capture those special moments and can better express anger or joy.

Mr Doi added: "Ten years from now, I believe most households will keep two or three personal robots and their performance will increase 100 times."
Reuters

webTitle: Flowers mark end of divers' bid to recover Kursk dead

fields.headline: Flowers mark end of divers' bid to recover Kursk dead
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: Russia abandoned its efforts yesterday to raise the corpses of 106 seamen remaining inside the sunken submarine Kursk when the Norwegian diving platform Regalia left the scene of the disaster in the Barents Sea to head home.
fields.body:
Russia abandoned its efforts yesterday to raise the corpses of 106 seamen remaining inside the sunken submarine Kursk when the Norwegian diving platform Regalia left the scene of the disaster in the Barents Sea to head home.

After 17 days of descending into the icy Arctic depths, cutting their way repeatedly into the vessel, and retrieving the bodies of 12 sailors, the joint team of Russian and Norwegian deep-sea divers was stood down.

At a meeting on board the Regalia yesterday morning it was decided to halt the mission. Russian officers made plain that the navy was against cutting any more holes in the 150-metre submarine, which sank off Murmansk on August 12.

Plans are being made to try to raise the nuclear-powered vessel next summer, although the cost of such an operation is being put at £35m.

It is thought that the Russians have neither the technical means nor the funds to conduct the salvage operation.

The 18 divers involved in recovering the bodies were reported to have observed a minute's silence yesterday for the 106 submariners buried at sea and cast flowers on the water before the Regalia departed for its home port in Norway.

Captain Vladimir Navrotsky, the Russian navy spokesman, said: "They stood at attention on the Regalia and released a wreath into the water.

"In their short speeches, the divers said they did everything they could for the Kursk, even more."

Captain Navrotsky said that further cutting of the submarine could jeopardise the hoisting plans, and he hinted that the cutting could also create problems with the vessel's two nuclear reactors.

High seas and strong winds have also been complicating the operation.

All 12 of the bodies brought to the surface from the stern of the Kursk have been identified, and the discovery of a letter written by one of the trapped seamen while the sub lay crippled gave the lie to statements from President Vladimir Putin and officials that the 118 crewmen died instantly when two explosions sank the sub on August 12.

It is now known that at least 23 of the crewsurvived the initial blasts. There are also some claims that the survivors may have lived on for several days afterwards, but these are contentious.

The Russian state commission investigating the tragedy, headed by the deputy prime minister Ilya Klebanov, is to meet today.

Senior navy officers cling to the view that the Kursk was sunk by a collision, since covered up, with an American or British submarine.

Both countries have denied being involved.

Admiral Vladimir Kuroyedov, the navy chief, said he would defend this collision scenario at today's meeting.

"I've got facts, but not enough proof. But that's only a question of time. The proof is not only at the bottom of the sea," he said.

Igor Kudrik, an expert on the Russian navy with the Norwegian environmental organisation Bellona, dismissed the recurring Russian claims of a collision cover-up.

"The submarine disaster was caused by an accident inside the submarine.

"But a final conclusion can only be made after the submarine has been lifted, if the Russian authorities agree to tell the truth about this tragedy."

webTitle: Thus has seen better days

fields.headline: Thus has seen better days
fields.trailText: Since the hi-tech bubble started deflating back in the spring few listed companies have been quite as sad as Thus.
fields.body:
Since the hi-tech bubble started deflating back in the spring few listed companies have been quite as sad as Thus.

From a high of 844.5p in March, shareholders have looked on as the value of their investment has shrunk more than nine fold on the back of profit warnings and concerns about its financial position.

Yesterday its stock price hit a fresh low before recovering (if that is the right word) to finish at 80p, a decline of 4p. But this did not stop some of the market's shrewder investors moving into the stock in aggressive manner.

Make no mistake this is a brave move. Thus posts interim figures today and they are not expected to make pleasant reading. Nevertheless the gossips believe the figures will be sugared with some good news. Apparently Thus will move to offset concerns about its financial position with the appointment of a new financial director and news that 50.1% stakeholder Scottish Power (down 4.5p to 538.5p) will allow it to explore alternative avenues of funding. The new director, it is said, will come from FTSE 100 telecoms group Cable & Wireless (up 6p to 890p).

He or she will need to work quickly. Deutsche Bank says Thus, through a £220m loan facility with Scottish Power, only has enough cash to see it through to the second quarter of next year. At that point it will need a further £300m-£400m if it is to survive. A company spokesman refused to comment.

Aside from Thus, engineering group Glynwed was the other stock that really caught the eye. A dull performer for most of the day its shares rose sharply before the close, settling 12.5p higher at 198p. Word has it that a predator is about to make its move, although more sober commentators said a leading broker was about to turn bullish on the company.

Pizza Express eased 11p to 660.5p on rumours that it is ready to make a hostile 70p-a-share offer for City Centre Restaurants (up 2.25p to 56.5p), owner of the Garfunkel's and Caffe Uno chains.

Last week City Centre announced it had rejected a 65p-a-share offer from a third party, widely believed to be Pizza Express. Apparently the hostile offer will be made in conjunction with a consortium of property investors, the idea being that Pizza Express will cherry pick the sites in City Centre's portfolio - which includes some 300 restaurants - and leave the remainder to the consortium.

In the wider market it was one of those sessions when the performance of the index leader Vodafone dictated events. Shares in the mobile phone group, hurt in the past three sessions on the back of earnings downgrades, rallied 15p to 258p.

Without that gain - the equivalent of 40 FTSE 100 points - leading shares would have closed flat as most investors were refusing to do anything until the US presidential election and the pre-Budget report are out of the way. The FTSE 100 rose 35.9 points to 6,466.9. Elsewhere things were not so bright. Without Vodafone affect to help, the FTSE 250 fell 21.7 points to 6,805.1 and the Techmark lost 36.36 points to 3,462.15.

Marks & Spencer, up 10p to 195p in heavy trade, was among the best performers. Dealers suggested the move had little to do with its interim figures, which as expected were poor. It seems the more speculative end of the market believes someone is casting their eye over the group.

BAT fell 20p to 480p on news of a ruling by a US judge who upheld a verdict that big tobacco firms should pay $145bn (£101bn) to sick smokers.

At the other end of the market, Walker Greenbank, the company which famously supplied the £350-a-roll Pugin wallpaper for the lord chancellor's state apartments, rose 4p, or 12.12%, to 37p. Back in October the company admitted it had received an approach and traders believe a deal is close.
