webTitle: Second time lucky?

fields.headline: Second time lucky?
fields.trailText: For those investors with clairvoyant tendencies Ellis & Everard has proved to be a nice little earner. Since the world's fourth largest chemicals distributor revealed last week that it had received a number of takeover approaches its share price has rocketed. Yesterday the shares, at 148.5p a week ago, were standing at 258p, after rising 14p.
fields.body:
For those investors with clairvoyant tendencies Ellis & Everard has proved to be a nice little earner. Since the world's fourth largest chemicals distributor revealed last week that it had received a number of takeover approaches its share price has rocketed. Yesterday the shares, at 148.5p a week ago, were standing at 258p, after rising 14p.

However, for those who missed the boat the first time around there is another chance. According to gossips in the Square Mile the board of Ellis & Everard has decided to give up its independence to a company willing to pay 300p for each of its 100m shares. If the speculation is to be believed the details of the offer will be unveiled to the market later this week.

The buyer is expected to be either Ashland, the largest chemicals distributor in North America, or Brenntag, a leading European chemcials distributor.

webTitle: At this price?  GWR

fields.headline: At this price?  GWR
fields.trailText: The radio sector has been in the doldrums of late. It has suffered the general downward trend in media sparked by the change in sentiment toward dot.com stocks. But the slide of the dot.coms has also had a more tangible effect.
fields.body:
The radio sector has been in the doldrums of late. It has suffered the general downward trend in media sparked by the change in sentiment toward dot.com stocks. But the slide of the dot.coms has also had a more tangible effect.

Much of the cash burn, the feverish spend on marketing to establish brand names, found its way into the pockets of radio companies - usually at the top end of the rate card. Now that much of that cash has fallen away it is producing unflattering comparisons with last year.

GWR has managed to avoid the cycle. Most of that cash was aimed at metropolitan areas where GWR owns few stations. It did not benefit as much from the dot.com explosion and neither has it suffered by comparison.

The company yesterday reported a 24% increase in revenues to £16.9m for the first half of the year.

Profits were dented by investment in building a series of local internet portals and supporting digital services and fell from £9.1m to £6.9m. GWR's shares fell 3% to 782.5p against their peak of £11.14 in March.

The level of investment in the internet might be of concern although analysts widely agree that if a local radio company cannot make money from the web then no media owner can.

The real focus though should be on GWR's stewardship of Classic FM since acquiring the station in 1996, which demonstrates the company's core ability to manage radio stations well. GWR has built Classic's share of audience over that period from 2.6% to 4.3% of the national listening audience.

According to Rajar, 6m people now tune in for an average 7.2 hours a week against 4.5m for four hours a week. That has translated through to revenue growth of 28% for the station.

With the communications white paper due next month and likely to relax ownership rules GWR will be able to acquire further stations and encourage the same kind of growth elsewhere. Buy.

webTitle: FirstGroup attacks rail pandemonium

fields.headline: FirstGroup attacks rail pandemonium
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: One of Britain's leading bus and train operators, FirstGroup, yesterday attacked Railtrack for the "pandemonium" which it produced in the industry following the Hatfield rail crash.
fields.body:
One of Britain's leading bus and train operators, FirstGroup, yesterday attacked Railtrack for the "pandemonium" which it produced in the industry following the Hatfield rail crash.

But Moir Lockhead, the chief executive of FirstGroup, which owns three rail franchises, said he expected no long term harm to passenger numbers from the repairs and disruption to the rail network. He conceded that FirstGroup's rail business had been severely affected by track repairs, but he expected passengers to return and not be lost to the roads or other forms of transport.

Mr Lockhead said that the company, which operates the First Great Western franchise, involved in last year's Paddington rail crash, had recovered well from the tragedy. It was still able to increase passenger usage by 7.5%

Announcing results for the six months to September, Mr Lockhead said that FirstGroup had increased its rail profits by 50% from £17.8m to £26.9m in spite of fears about safety and service quality.

FirstGroup's good performance on the railways enabled it to achieve total half year profits of £58.9m, up 7%. Bus operating profits fell slightly to £47m but US school bus operations secured profits of £16.1m. The interim dividend is being raised from 2.7p to 3p.

Mr Lockhead said that fuel prices were fixed until next March, but bus fares would have to be increased from April. He expected they would rise by about 5%.

The company's disposal of Bristol airport, in which it has a 51% share, is due to be completed in the next two to three months. The sale is expected to raise about £200m, and British and overseas candidates have expressed an interest.

Mr Lockhead said that FirstGroup hoped to introduce America's yellow schoolbus concept into Britain early next year. He said that local authorities in greater Manchester and Leeds had expressed an interest.

He expected prototype vehicles to be running around several inner cities after design specifications had been approved.

webTitle: £33,000 for GNER train drivers

fields.headline: £33,000 for GNER train drivers
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Train drivers employed by Great North Eastern Railway have secured a 20 per cent pay rise to £33,000 a year making them the highest paid in Britain.
fields.body:
Train drivers employed by Great North Eastern Railway have secured a 20 per cent pay rise to £33,000 a year making them the highest paid in Britain.

The deal, agreed between GNER, the company which was at the heart of the Hatfield rail crash, and the train drivers' union (Aslef), will put the drivers on a salary grade and give them a professional status, which has long been denied train drivers.

The deal reflects the enormous advance made by train drivers since privatisation. The pay of most of Britain's 17,000 drivers has doubled in four years, partly driven by the need of the 25 train operating companies to hold on to skilled staff.

Mick Rix, Aslef's general secretary, said last night: "This is good news for drivers. It gives them a status enjoyed by pilots in the airline industry. In many cases, they are responsible for more passengers."

GNER said that the agreement covering its 270 drivers was right for the company. It had never had any bad industrial relations with its drivers and the deal reflected the importance of their status.

The deal has taken the GNER drivers ahead of their colleagues who drive Eurostar trains between London and Paris. They receive just over £32,000, but Aslef is pressing for recognition rights at the company by threatening to hold a series of one day strikes later this month.

webTitle: Cassani ready to lead Go management buyout

fields.headline: Cassani ready to lead Go management buyout
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Barbara Cassani, Go's chief executive, yesterday confirmed that she was prepared to lead a management buyout from British Airways of its no-frills airline but that it could take up to six months before the matter was settled.
fields.body:
Barbara Cassani, Go's chief executive, yesterday confirmed that she was prepared to lead a management buyout from British Airways of its no-frills airline but that it could take up to six months before the matter was settled.

Ms Cassani said that she had explained the situation to a meeting of the company's staff. "They feel very excited that they can continue to make a contribution to the company's well being and that together we can take it forward." She said she would be happy to work with somebody else in a different set up. "Everybody in Go feels passionately about the company and wants to have a stake in its future," she added.

Go announced yesterday that it lost £21.9 m in the year to March on a turnover of £100 m. But it expects to make a small profit for the current year after being in the black every month since March. BA's investment in the company has been put at £50m for the past three years. Go was always expected to make a small profit in its third operating year. Ryanair, Ireland's low cost airline, last night made it clear that it was not interested in buying Go, even if BA offered to fund an investigation into the project.

Michael O'Leary, Ryanair's chief executive, said he doubted if Go could be profitable all the year round in the long term.

webTitle: Chirac backs feed ban as France braces for more CJD deaths

fields.headline: Chirac backs feed ban as France braces for more CJD deaths
fields.standfirst: www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/bse
fields.trailText: President Jacques Chirac intervened in France's spiralling beef crisis yesterday as the junior health minister, Dominique Gillot, warned people to expect many more deaths from new variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, which is believed to come from the meat of cows infected with BSE.
fields.body:
President Jacques Chirac intervened in France's spiralling beef crisis yesterday as the junior health minister, Dominique Gillot, warned people to expect many more deaths from new variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, which is believed to come from the meat of cows infected with BSE.

Amid mounting consumer fears about the safety of French beef, Mr Chirac was joined by the daily Le Monde in calling for an immediate ban on the use of meat and bone meal in animal feed, a measure adopted by Britain in 1996.

Most French cases of BSE - bovine spongiform encephalopathy, colloquially known in France as vache folle, or mad cow disease - have been traced to cattle eating feed containing such meal, intended for pigs or chickens.

Two people have so far died of new variant CJD (vCJD) in France, compared with 80 in Britain, but a threefold increase in the number of BSE cases identified in cattle this year, combined with a hypermarket chain's admission that it had unwittingly sold several tonnes of suspect beef, have sparked near panic in consumers and school authorities.

"With the increase in the number of cases of mad cow disease discovered in France, it is highly likely that we will have several dozen cases of vCJD," Ms Gillot said. "We must prepare for that. The number of people showing possible symptoms of the disease is rising."

Amid what the agriculture minister, Jean Glavany, called a "national psychosis", beef sales have plummeted by as much as 40%; mayors in a dozen main towns and cities have banned beef from school canteens; restaurants have dropped beef on the bone from their menus; and the Socialist-led government faces at least two lawsuits accusing it of failing to take adequate action to keep BSE out of France.

José Bové, a leading anti-globalisation campaigner who supports the return to traditional farming methods, wants every agriculture minister since 1988 put in the dock as "accessories" to the illegal importation of 14,000 tonnes of British meat and bone meal to France between 1993 to 1996, in defiance of a ban imposed in 1990.

Separately, the parents of a 19-year-old man believed to be suffering from vCJD plan to sue the state for "poisoning" their son, who was featured in a harrowing French TV documentary broadcast on Monday.

The government has asked the national food safety agency, Afssa, to assess whether the ban on meat and bone meal in cattle feed should be extended to mixtures fed to pigs and chickens.

But Mr Chirac does not want to wait the three to four months the agency is expected to take to deliver its verdict.

"In my opinion, without waiting for the results, we must suspend use of these meals in all animals feeds," he said on TV.

Le Monde agreed. "This consumer panic is certainly excessive and perhaps unjustified," it said. "But it is indispensable that steps be taken rapidly to allay people's fears. A ban on meat and bone meal in all ani mal feed is being studied by the experts - but there are times when experts must be pushed."

The government's director of public health, Lucien Abenhaim, insisted that "if there was a serious problem in butchers' cabinets, rest assured I would take the necessary action". But Ms Gillot was less reassuring.

"I can't say 'don't worry' to people who ask me about it, because it's true that the prion [rogue protein particle] that causes both BSE and vCJD is a formidable infectious agent," she said. "We do not know all its modes of transmission, and we have no treatment for it."

webTitle: East German leader appeals over Wall deaths

fields.headline: East German leader appeals over Wall deaths
fields.trailText: East Germany's last communist leader is due at the European court of human rights in Strasbourg today for a historic challenge to what he has termed "victors' justice".
fields.body:
East Germany's last communist leader is due at the European court of human rights in Strasbourg today for a historic challenge to what he has termed "victors' justice".

Egon Krenz, the hardliner who led the former German Democratic Republic (GDR) in its last weeks in the autumn of 1989, was convicted of manslaughter three years ago for his role in the deaths of East Germans killed trying to flee to the west. He has been in jail since January.

The outcome of his appeal could have an impact on hundreds of former border guards and officials convicted since reunification in 1990. Krenz's lawyers intend to argue that the former leader did not break East Germany's law, and that the laws of the reunified Germany cannot be applied to him retrospectively.

Krenz left jail before dawn yesterday after being granted three days of freedom to attend the hearing.

"The cold war ended in Europe 10 years ago, but it is nevertheless still being waged in German courtrooms," Krenz, 63, said outside the prison.

"The chief German prosecutor told me after the last appeal that I didn't stand a chance in the European court. But I have never lost hope."

Krenz's lawyer, Robert Unger, said: "For the first time, the case is to be handled by an unprejudiced, non-German court."

As his supporters, including the former Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, have indignantly stressed, Krenz was the man who brought about the collapse of communism in eastern Europe. It was he who ordered the Berlin Wall to be opened in November 1989, though he did so only in response to a wave of popular protest that threatened to turn into an uprising.

Krenz's conviction was in connection with four deaths at the Berlin Wall in the 1980s when he was a member of the politburo.

His cause was given a boost in July when a Berlin court acquitted three other former politburo members of manslaughter. The defence had argued, as Krenz's lawyers intend to do, that law cannot be applied retrospectively.

The presiding judge ruled that there was not enough evidence to convict them. "They were simply passive, no more and no less," he said.

Krenz is appealing together with a former defence minister, Heinz Kessler, a former deputy minister, Fritz Streletz, and a former border guard. Only their lawyers will be permitted to address the court in Strasbourg.

Last month two former senior East German officials who were convicted along with Krenz were pardoned, just before the 10th anniversary of German reunification. Unlike Krenz, they had expressed remorse for their past actions.

Krenz was given a six-and-a-half-year prison sentence, but he is allowed out each day to work, marketing medical support stockings to eastern Europe.

A panel of 17 judges is expected to hear the case. They will first have to decide whether the court has jurisdiction and whether there are grounds to proceed. A ruling is not expected until next year.

webTitle: Land seizures administer an organic slap in Mafia's face

fields.headline: Land seizures administer an organic slap in Mafia's face
fields.trailText: Not content with banging them up in jail, Sicily is seizing land owned by Mafia bosses for organic farms to cash in on the backlash against genetically modified foods.
fields.body:
Not content with banging them up in jail, Sicily is seizing land owned by Mafia bosses for organic farms to cash in on the backlash against genetically modified foods.

Six cooperatives have been set up in the Palermo region to turn 200 hectares (500 acres) of former no-go areas into fields of wheat, olives and vegetables.

Launched this week, the joint initiative by church and state is aimed at the Cosa Nostra's heartland to maximise the symbolic challenge to the organisation. The first cooperative will be called Placido Rizzotto, after a trade unionist murdered by Mafiosi in 1948 for leading a series of land occupations. The scheme was approved after the runaway success of a pioneering harvest in the town of Corleone, on a patch owned by Bernardo Provenzano, nicknamed Binu the Tractor because he mows people down.

Marketed as anti-Mafia olive oil, the product was a big hit at last month's Salone del Gusto, a food fair in Turin. Enthusiasts stole several bottles.

Alfonso Pecoraro Scanio, the agriculture minister, hailed the experiment as leading the way in Italy's strategy of producing high-quality organic exports. Capitalising on food scares, including the one about genetically modified foods, is seen as an opportunity in a country unable to compete on price with foreign competitors.

Mr Provenzano, today's Cosa Nostra chief, has been "in hiding" for 37 years, though the term is a relative one: he is believed to sneak home regularly.

More than 60 locals are expected to work on the farms. "The aim is to create jobs and push back the Mafia's influence," said Maria Maniscalco, the mayor of San Giuseppe Jato, whose life has been threatened and whose car has been burned.

The initiative is the latest in a series of challenges. Earlier this year a factory in San Giuseppe Jato started exporting coppolas, the beret associated with Cosa Nostra, to reclaim the symbol for Sicily.

Corleone, after decades of blanking out the memory of the murdered Rizzotto, last month applauded a film about his life. Next month it will inaugurate a Mafia museum.

webTitle: Last night's TV

fields.headline: Natural born criminals
fields.trailText: Cutting Edge / The Sins
fields.body:
Where would we be without crime? No Morse, no Taggart, no Crimewatch UK, no humorous Randall and Hopkirk... in other words, we'd all be a lot better off, and to prove the point Cutting Edge (Channel 4) showed the full degradation to which a life of crime can lead. Shooters, a feature-length drama to kick off the new series, has already stirred up indignation for using real criminals in the main roles rather than actors, although for this we should be grateful. If there's one thing more irksome than real villains profiting from their misdeeds, it's British actors swaggering around in emulation of the hoods they will never be.

Shooters followed a ramshackle Liverpool gang from a botched drugs heist through a downward spiral of violence and coke-fuelled hysteria. There was little to appeal, and much to repel: a cack-handed murder, with the victim bound hand and foot; gang fights on waste ground with the opponents biting each other's faces off; compulsive drug use that led to misery rather than elation. At the centre of the storm was Big John, a simple giant of a man, club bouncer by night and gangster by day. Big John witnessed, and in part caused, the initial murder; unconcerned by this, he shoved half the stolen gear up his nose and then drove around Liverpool in a big and very obviously new car.

John's senior partner in crime was Dezzy, who looked like Craig David on steroids and was much the more intelligent of the two. He showed remorse by vomiting after the murder, and counselled discretion in the splashy wake of the crime. While John hoovered "beak" off the back of his hand like 21st-century snuff, Dezzy confessed the murder to his mother ("you broke my heart") and went into melancholic semi-retirement.

Shooters was gripping not because of the simplistic moral (John died in a welter of blood in the back of his flash car) or because of the performances, excellent though they were. Where it scored over all other crime dramas was in its command of detail. While other shows indicate villainy by an agreed set of props and devices (usually involving pole-dancing clubs and Tudorbethan Barrett homes), Shooters revealed the desperate quality of life in which crime breeds and from which it can never deliver you. John and his face-biting pal Franny indulged in joyless beak-and-Baileys parties in their over-decorated flats. The gang met in sweaty desperation at the gym, bulking up their drug- ravaged torsos with ridiculous weights routines. Spare guns were stashed in the children's teddy-bear pyjama cases. Best of all was a scene in which the musketeers set off in a sports car, the owner unable to drive "because I'm banned". In a touching, pathetic gesture of gangster cool, all left their seatbelts undone. This, one suspects, is closer to underworld reality than Guy Ritchie and his lovely Lock, Stock cohorts would have us believe.

The final scene, although unsubtle, was bludgeoningly effective. As Big John breathed his last, we cut to slow-motion footage of the nightclub where he worked, complete with a fairground music score. A clumsy device, but seldom has the link between "innocent" recreational drug use and organised crime been made with such persuasive force.

Far from this reality was another sort of crime drama, The Sins (BBC1). Last night we reached Lust, and the show rose to the occasion with flair. Len (Pete Postlethwaite) still had one foot in the criminal underworld, personified by the standard flash villains in designer clothes. In-between, however, he had time for a mid-life sex crisis, persuading himself that he was gay after an unexpected gym stiffy followed hot on the heels of a bout of conjugal impotence. All this was compounded by the fact that his daughter, Chastity, was working her way through the entire male population of Oxford, sometimes two at a time. Cher could have told Len that naming your child Chastity doesn't necessarily make for a quiet life, but Len stormed off to Oxford to sort out his daughter, his sexuality and his criminal associates all in one go.

This sounds stupendously contrived on the page, and it's a tribute to William Ivory's writing and Pete Postlethwaite's performance that it not only made sense but was actually moving and funny. The Sins is a strange show, schematic and occasionally halting, but when it works - in Len's final strophe on the joys of sexual love, for instance - it flies.

webTitle: Notebook: BP emphasises weaker margins

fields.headline: Sir John sings the blues as profits double
fields.standfirst: BP emphasises weaker margins
fields.trailText: Sir John Browne, chief executive of BP, must have found it difficult to keep a straight face presenting yesterday's third-quarter figures. Mark Moody-Stewart took the first wave of Pavlovian flak, announcing Shell's billion-dollar-a-month gusher last week.
fields.body:
Sir John Browne, chief executive of BP, must have found it difficult to keep a straight face presenting yesterday's third-quarter figures. Mark Moody-Stewart took the first wave of Pavlovian flak, announcing Shell's billion-dollar-a-month gusher last week.

However, Sir John was managing to do it on the eve of the Pre-Budget report - in the face of all those pre-speech briefings on the freezing of fuel duty.

No wonder he was playing the profits down and insisting to anyone that would listen that retailing margins have been damaged across Europe by the recent fuel protests. The company's forecourts in Britain have even been losing money.

Of course, a change in fuel duty does not have a direct impact on BP's profitability. A windfall tax, on the other hand, dressed up as a review of North Sea taxation, certainly would - and while the received wisdom remains that Gordon Brown will wait for more clarity on the medium-term price of crude before revisiting this, the threat remains that some sort of passing reference will be made later today.

Actually getting more revenue out of the North Sea without damaging development in the area is another matter. Production there has risen by at least a quarter since the tax regime was last reformed in 1993. And thumping the Scottish economy in the run-up to an election might not seem such a great idea to Mr Brown next spring.

M&S paradox
Marks & Spencer boasts it is "exclusively for everyone" but its latest advertising campaign demonstrates just how much of a paradox that is.

The former high street icon used a large, naked woman to inform shoppers that it is okay to be "normal" - known internally as the hallelujah campaign - and then followed it up this week with the "breathless" campaign - men ogling after a slim woman in M&S party gear.

This is the crux of the M&S problem. Being "exclusively for everyone" is difficult to carry off when its role as a middle market retailer is being destroyed.

Chairman Luc Vandevelde said M&S was being attacked from both sides: Matalan leading the way for the discounters; Zara for the more up-market chains. M&S is being squeezed and having difficulty working out where it stands.

The prospects do not look good as M&S enters the crucial seven week trading period before Christmas, from which it generates 25% of annualised profits. The staff are being offered performance-linked pay for the first time in their careers and, in the words of one executive director, have been "empowered". The centralisation of the past has been eradicated, it is also claimed.

Persuading staff to sell is one thing but getting shoppers to spend is another, and, more importantly, spend at higher prices so that any rise in sales does not eat into profits. Finding more basic, classic items - like the black and camel leather coats selling at £190 - that customers will fight for must also be key.

M&S is selling £500,000 worth of such coats each week, a demonstration of the power it wields - when it gets it right. The problem is that when it gets its wrong the pain is big too. Lost sales from supply hiccups cost £11m in sales in the first five weeks of the second half. Every sale counts in the current climate. M&S does not look comfortable going into a cold, wet winter.

Euro effects
What a way to run a currency. Last Friday the European Central Bank moved into the foreign exchange market. It did the same again on Monday. It was, it said, concerned "about the global and domestic repercussions of the exchange rate of the euro, including its impact on price stability".

Now, the FX market has still to make its mind up about the tactics and the timing of intervention. The ECB's statement, however, was at least consistent with the earlier G7 intervention and with the bank's stated policy priority.

So what happens yesterday? Up pops Italian treasury minister Vincenzo Visco saying that the intervention was not driven by worries about inflation at all. Inflation was not a problem.

Instead the bank's interventions were "related to what [it] reckons to be useful to the euro and the signals on the currency level it wants to send to the market".

fields.bodyText: Sir John Browne, chief executive of BP, must have found it difficult to keep a straight face presenting yesterday's third-quarter figures. Mark Moody-Stewart took the first wave of Pavlovian flak, announcing Shell's billion-dollar-a-month gusher last week. However, Sir John was managing to do it on the eve of the Pre-Budget report - in the face of all those pre-speech briefings on the freezing of fuel duty. No wonder he was playing the profits down and insisting to anyone that would listen that retailing margins have been damaged across Europe by the recent fuel protests. The company's forecourts in Britain have even been losing money. Of course, a change in fuel duty does not have a direct impact on BP's profitability. A windfall tax, on the other hand, dressed up as a review of North Sea taxation, certainly would - and while the received wisdom remains that Gordon Brown will wait for more clarity on the medium-term price of crude before revisiting this, the threat remains that some sort of passing reference will be made later today. Actually getting more revenue out of the North Sea without damaging development in the area is another matter. Production there has risen by at least a quarter since the tax regime was last reformed in 1993. And thumping the Scottish economy in the run-up to an election might not seem such a great idea to Mr Brown next spring. M&S paradox Marks & Spencer boasts it is "exclusively for everyone" but its latest advertising campaign demonstrates just how much of a paradox that is. The former high street icon used a large, naked woman to inform shoppers that it is okay to be "normal" - known internally as the hallelujah campaign - and then followed it up this week with the "breathless" campaign - men ogling after a slim woman in M&S party gear. This is the crux of the M&S problem. Being "exclusively for everyone" is difficult to carry off when its role as a middle market retailer is being destroyed. Chairman Luc Vandevelde said M&S was being attacked from both sides: Matalan leading the way for the discounters; Zara for the more up-market chains. M&S is being squeezed and having difficulty working out where it stands. The prospects do not look good as M&S enters the crucial seven week trading period before Christmas, from which it generates 25% of annualised profits. The staff are being offered performance-linked pay for the first time in their careers and, in the words of one executive director, have been "empowered". The centralisation of the past has been eradicated, it is also claimed. Persuading staff to sell is one thing but getting shoppers to spend is another, and, more importantly, spend at higher prices so that any rise in sales does not eat into profits. Finding more basic, classic items - like the black and camel leather coats selling at £190 - that customers will fight for must also be key. Lost sales from supply hiccups cost £11m in sales in the first five weeks of the second half. Every sale counts in the current climate. M&S does not look comfortable going into a cold, wet winter. webTitle: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Laboratories Of Power / Rebel Yell
fields.body:
With grimly appropriate timing, Richard Black investigates the work of the International Panel on Climate Change, which has studied the effects of global warming for the past 12 years. The IPCC is one of the Laboratories Of Power (9.0pm, Radio 4), those scientific bodies established to co-ordinate joint action on global issues. Sadly, however, it still finds great difficulty persuading politicians to respond properly to the evidence it has collated.

One of the earliest rebel couplets was voiced by John Ball during the 1381 Peasant's Revolt - "When Adam delved and Eve span, who was then the gentleman?". Even earlier, no doubt, Ramses II got comparably dyspeptic mutter ings from the 19th Dynasty labourers sweating over Abu Simbel. Tom Robinson doesn't go that far back for his survey of the Rebel Yell (10.0pm, Radio 2), but he has pulled together enough modern protest songs to fill six programmes. His eclectic opening mixture ranges from Woody Guthrie to Billy Holliday (pictured).

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Chocolat / Catch-22 / The Corruptor / Salon Kitty
fields.body:
Chocolat

(Claire Denis, 1987)

6pm FilmFour

Told mainly in flashback, with a young woman (Mireille Perrier) plane-bound for the Cameroons and telling a fellow traveller about her childhood there. An idyllic life as the French official's daughter, and her friendship with houseboy Isaach de Bankolé, are undermined by the arrival of a group of plane crash survivors, who insinuate the worst of colonialist values into the once-happy home. Nostalgic but unsentimental in tone, it's an adept debut by Denis, with a pulsing Abdullah Ibrahim soundtrack.

Catch-22

(Mike Nichols, 1970)

8pm, Sky Cinema

Buck Henry's adaptation of the great Joseph Heller novel was a box-office flop, although it did succeed in capturing some of the insane laughter of that wartime world. The exceptional cast helps: Orson Welles, Martin Balsam, Richard Benjamin, Jon Voight, Martin Sheen and, leading them all, Alan Arkin's Captain Yossarian, caught madden ingly on the horns of catch-22: the only way to avoid combat is to plead insanity. But to plead insanity demonstrates a healthy - and rational - sense of self-preservation.

The Corruptor

(James Foley, 1999)

10.15pm, Sky MovieMax

Beefy thriller with Mark Wahlberg's Irish cop and Chow Yun-Fat as his boss taking on New York's Triad gangs and confronting issues of personal integrity in a corrupt environment. It's a compelling mix of the pair's highly individual styles: Wahlberg pragmatic, down to earth and gloomily introspective, Chow making with the extravagant martial arts flurries of his Hong Kong movies.

Salon Kitty

(Tinto Brass, 1976)

1.50am, FilmFour

Smutty peeks into a Berlin brothel, where Helmut Berger's Nazi officer is keeping an intimate eye on party colleagues to work out their loyalties. Brass claimed it was a study in moral degeneracy, but it's really all about the sexiness of the uniforms, and the era.

webTitle: Random views

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What pest controllers are watching on TV.
fields.trailText: What pest controllers are watching on TV.
fields.body:
David Tatt: "Ooh, well. I don't get to see the telly when I'm working, and that's a shame because I always had this vision of me sitting at home with my feet up when I'd turned forty. I'd always wanted to run a sweet shop or a chippy or something. TV? Well I watch the sport and the news. That's it. Last sitcom? Er... I watched the Irish one on Channel 4. The bookshop one [Black Books]. It was just on and I watched it. Did I like it? I thought it was quite funny, but quite strange. I don't think I liked it a lot."

Jon Little: "I don't think I've ever seen pest control on TV, unless it's something like a documentary about builders or bad hygiene. It's not really a heroic job, but it could be. You could get a programme about a man with pigeon fancier's lung and show his dying strains as he picks more pigeon shit out of loft spaces. The amount of shit we see! It's a very dangerous job, you can get all sorts. I would like to star in it, alongside Davina McCall. The nation's favourite? Oh yes. She's lovely. Shame she's married, isn't it?"

Marie Tenterden: "I once went round to a famous presenter's house - no I'm not going to tell you who it was; he does news reporting - and it was an absolute pigsty. You can tell he had some money and everything, but I think he was a bit of a tearaway. Telly programmes I like are the dramas - like the one with Martin Clunes, that was the last one I watched. He played a rogue, on a bicycle. Phwoar! Sorry, I do rather fancy him though."

George Paphides: "I like to watch the news reports and then I like to watch videos with my children and cry. Why? Because they're so awful! How many times have I seen the Lion King and Tarzan? Too many! I watch a bit of Jeremy Paxman or something until I close my eyes and go to dreamland. My dreams are beautiful, but in the day it is a nightmare - all rats and cockroaches, hahaha! Only kidding, it's all right really. I just wish the video recorder would break sometimes and I could have some peace."

 Sin Pattenden spoke to workers at AB Pest Control, London

webTitle: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Tamar Valley
fields.trailText: Tamar Valley
fields.body:
The big striped top, looped with a strand of lights, appears magical beyond dark trees at St Germans. The audience for Footsbarn's version of The Inspector by Gogol has converged from miles around - directed by flashlights to park under the looming bulk of the ancient church, treading over soggy bark chippings through mud to The Lawn, set well away from Port Eliot house, where round windows are lit up.

The travelling theatre group, created and based in Cornwall in the 1970s, has returned for the first time since 1981, when it left for mainland Europe, the more generous grants and welcoming atmosphere. We saw their boisterous final production in Liskeard's public hall and, in 1986, glimpsed a poster in Blois chateau. Now, inside the heated tent, the howl of wolves and sound of hooves compete with real trains crossing the Tiddy viaduct. The band strikes up and the show begins. Fantastic stage effects, masks, gigantic models, acrobatics and exaggerated acting by the multi-lingual cast all contribute to the humour and pathos, as corrupt officials struggle to deceive the so-called inspector about their affairs.

Outside at 10pm, it is calm and starlit. Two days later, gales and floods prevail, preventing the final performance. The group have packed up caravans and trailers and returned to base at La Chausée in central France. The Tamar burst its banks below Gunnislake, less than a year since the last big flood. The land is sodden; only about half the winter corn is tilled, hardly any maize harvested, and store animals are being sold early and cheap to prevent poaching of pasture.

webTitle: The return of Auf Wiedersehen, Pet

fields.headline: The magnificent seven
fields.standfirst: Auf Wiedersehen, Pet is coming back. The original cast have agreed to reprise their roles in what was one of television's greatest ever dramas. Adam Sweeting explains why it captured the spirit of its time so perfectly.
fields.trailText: Auf Wiedersehen, Pet is coming back. The original cast have agreed to reprise their roles in what was one of television's greatest ever dramas. Adam Sweeting explains why it captured the spirit of its time so perfectly.
fields.body:
If you were to compile a list of programmes that viewers most wanted to bring back to their screens, the mid-80s comic drama about Geordie brickies seeking work in Germany, Auf Wiedersehen, Pet, would score pretty high, at least among voters old enough to remember it. Despite the fact that there's nothing remotely comparable to it in the current broadcasting schedules, Auf Wiedersehen clocked in at number 46 in the British Film Industry's poll of the Top 100 TV programmes of all time last September, one place behind Only Fools And Horses and, bafflingly, just ahead of Tiswas.

What made the BFI poll intriguing was that it represented the views of the present-day controllers of British television, who show little enthusiasm for making the kind of programmes that they apparently consider to have been the backbone of British TV over the past 30-odd years. As one cultural commentator recently put it, today's TV toffs "hark back to a golden age of classic programmes like Jewel In The Crown, Play For Today and Auf Wiedersehen, Pet - but they take fright at the thought of commissioning anything that might similarly delight today's viewers." Mal Young, the BBC's head of drama series, outlined the current orthodoxy in TV-thinking in his extraordinary Royal Television Society Lecture last year. A former Brookside producer and now in charge of EastEnders, Mal proposed that soaps are the all-purpose telly pick-me-up, offering drama, education, and social usefulness - oh, and ratings of course - to such a degree that "they unify the nation".

Such people might find a germ of comfort from the news that the BBC is planning to bring back Auf Wiedersehen, featuring six of the seven original cast members (Gary Holton, Cockney geezer and ex-punk rocker, died during the filming of the final series in 1986), and that eight new episodes are already under construction by the series' original writers, Dick Clement and Ian La Frenais. When it was first screened in 1983, Auf Wiedersehen was made by Witzend for Central TV, but the BBC's Alan Yentob has been eagerly pursuing the idea of a revival ever since Franc Roddam, who dreamed up the idea in the first place, after his own experience of working on building sites in Germany, floated the notion of an updated sequel.

At the start of the 80s, Roddam (a BBC veteran and the director of the movie Quadrophenia) had expounded his ideas about a bunch of itinerant British workers to Clement and La Frenais. The duo immediately warmed to the concept, but developed it beyond Roddam's original sitcom- ish notion and expanded it into a wider-ranging piece of drama, drawing in a broad spectrum of characters and social observations.

With the precious gift of hindsight, it's easy to appreciate their enduring achievement as writers, but perhaps equally amazing is the strength of the cast of unknowns that was enlisted for Auf Wiedersehen, all of whom have been able to build impressive careers from the leg-up that the series gave them. Timothy Spall (who was nominated for an Oscar for his performance in Mike Leigh's Secrets And Lies) played Barry, the exasperatingly dull Brummie electrician. Kevin "Sgt Lewis" Whately played newly-married Neville, desperate to provide for his wife and future family. Tim Healy and Christopher Fairbank have become familiar faces across a broad swathe of British TV drama, while Pat Roach, who played Bomber the bricklayer, went on to specialise as movie villains in the likes of Raiders Of The Lost Ark and Never Say Never Again. Above all, it was Jimmy Nail as the violent, dour and bigoted Oz who stuck in the imagination, a portrayal as steeped in bleak 80s-style bitterness and disillusion as Bernard Hill's Yosser in Boys From The Black Stuff.

The way that both series tapped unerringly into the spirit of the period, particularly as far as working-class northerners were concerned, was echoed in the way that Newcastle United fans used to taunt Liverpool supporters with chants of "Oz is harder than Yosser". Auf Wiedersehen's most significant achievement, apart from ratings reaching as high as 14 million, was the way it was able to reflect on the nature of British working-class life, from both a British and a foreign perspective, without letting often brutal dramatic events overwhelm its comic perspective.

The BBC is remaining tight-lipped about how the new series might have moved the ageing brickies forward in a world much changed from what it was during the 80s. Who knows - perhaps we might even find them trying their hand as émigré IT workers seeking to fill the thousands of vacancies in Germany's hi-tech sector (Gordon Brown's IR35 tax is driving tech-minded freelancers abroad, since it forces them to pay the same tax as salaried employees). Whatever the plotlines, one insider at the Beeb observed that the cast are keen to try to make the Auf Wiedersehen lightning strike twice because of the quality of Clement and La Frenais' writing. "They did such a fantastic job not just on The Likely Lads but on Whatever Happened To The Likely Lads, which was every bit as good as the original." Here's hoping.

webTitle: £10,000 payout to Japan PoWs

fields.headline: £10,000 payout to Japan PoWs
fields.standfirst: 'Debt of honour' repaid after 50-year struggle
fields.trailText: A 50-year struggle by thousands of former prisoners of war subjected to forced labour and torture by Japan in the second world war finally ended yesterday.
fields.body:
A 50-year struggle by thousands of former prisoners of war subjected to forced labour and torture by Japan in the second world war finally ended yesterday.

The survivors, and the widows of those who have since died, were given a one-off payment of £10,000 in recognition of what the defence minister, Lewis Moonie, called their unique experience.

He said the tax-free ex gratia payment would repay a "debt of honour" owed by Britain to members of the armed forces, the merchant navy, or civilians, who returned home in late 1945. In the words of some, they were "forgotten people".

The Ministry of Defence said the payments, to 16,700 people, including more than 4,500 widows, would be administered by the Blackpool-based war pensions agency as soon as possible.

"It is very important that the wheels are set in motion very quickly," Martyn Day, the lawyer who has fought their case for the past eight years, said yesterday. Each day, more than one of those eligible died, he said.

"I am really delighted with the decision", said Mr Day who took up the case after an approach from his uncle, John Gott, a former prisoner of war in the Far East.

He said the former PoWs would now withdraw their claims against the Japanese government.

Arthur Titherington, chairman of the Japanese Labour Camps Survivors Association, who was forced to work in copper mines in Taiwan, said: "Today is a great day. The British government has shown that it has fully understood the importance of these issues to today's society.

"My only disappointment is that the real culprit, that is the Japanese government, has got away scot-free. The least it can do is recognise the gross errors of its past which it can do by providing a full, unequivocal apology."

Keith Martin, chairman of the Association of British Civilian Internees Far East Region, said: "Our members can now look forward with satisfaction that their suffering and losses have finally been recognised after so many years."

Ian Townsend, general secretary of the Royal British Legion, described the move as "a very satisfactory end to what has been a long struggle for recognition of what they went through in captivity".

Over 50,000 British troops and civilians were captured in Singapore in 1942 - 25% died in captivity. The PoWs received £76 by the 1951 San Francisco peace treaty. The treaty stated that if Japan agreed to better terms with other countries, British PoWs could demand the same treatment.

In 1955 former Swiss PoWs received £2,000. Documents Mr Martin discovered in 1998 at the Public Record Office revealed Whitehall's attitude. They showed that in 1955, Lord Reading, a Foreign Office minister, agreed with his officials that "we are at present unpopular enough with the Japanese without having to exert further pressure which would be likely to cause the maximum of resentment for the minimum of advantage".

After years of campaigning, the former PoWs met Tony Blair in 1998. Earlier this year, the Foreign Office told them it was not prepared to make a claim against the Japanese government.

In June, the Isle of Man agreed to pay its former PoWs £10,000, and Canada also agreed to pay its PoWs £10,000. By July Mr Blair agreed in principle to the payments.

Mr Moonie said it would cost £167m.
fields.bodyText: A 50-year struggle by thousands of former prisoners of war subjected to forced labour and torture by Japan in the second world war finally ended yesterday. The survivors, and the widows of those who have since died, were given a one-off payment of £10,000 in recognition of what the defence minister, Lewis Moonie, called their unique experience. He said the tax-free ex gratia payment would repay a "debt of honour" owed by Britain to members of the armed forces, the merchant navy, or civilians, who returned home in late 1945. In the words of some, they were "forgotten people". The Ministry of Defence said the payments, to 16,700 people, including more than 4,500 widows, would be administered by the Blackpool-based war pensions agency as soon as possible. "It is very important that the wheels are set in motion very quickly," Martyn Day, the lawyer who has fought their case for the past eight years, said yesterday. Each day, more than one of those eligible died, he said. "I am really delighted with the decision", said Mr Day who took up the case after an approach from his uncle, John Gott, a former prisoner of war in the Far East. He said the former PoWs would now withdraw their claims against the Japanese government. Arthur Titherington, chairman of the Japanese Labour Camps Survivors Association, who was forced to work in copper mines in Taiwan, said: "Today is a great day. The British government has shown that it has fully understood the importance of these issues to today's society. "My only disappointment is that the real culprit, that is the Japanese government, has got away scot-free. The least it can do is recognise the gross errors of its past which it can do by providing a full, unequivocal apology." Keith Martin, chairman of the Association of British Civilian Internees Far East Region, said: "Our members can now look forward with satisfaction that their suffering and losses have finally been recognised after so many years." Ian Townsend, general secretary of the Royal British Legion, described the move as "a very satisfactory end to what has been a long struggle for recognition of what they went through in captivity". Over 50,000 British troops and civilians were captured in Singapore in 1942 - 25% died in captivity. The PoWs received £76 by the 1951 San Francisco peace treaty. The treaty stated that if Japan agreed to better terms with other countries, British PoWs could demand the same treatment. In 1955 former Swiss PoWs received £2,000. Documents Mr Martin discovered in 1998 at the Public Record Office revealed Whitehall's attitude. They showed that in 1955, Lord Reading, a Foreign Office minister, agreed with his officials that "we are at present unpopular enough with the Japanese without having to exert further pressure which would be likely to cause the maximum of resentment for the minimum of advantage". After years of campaigning, the former PoWs met Tony Blair in 1998. Earlier this year, the Foreign Office told them it was not prepared to make a claim against the Japanese government. In June, the Isle of Man agreed to pay its former PoWs £10,000, and Canada also agreed to pay its PoWs £10,000. By July Mr Blair agreed in principle to the payments. Mr Moonie said it would cost £167m.

webTitle: Ashdown tells how father stood by Indian troops

fields.headline: Ashdown tells how father stood by Indian troops
fields.trailText: Sir Paddy Ashdown revealed yesterday how his father was brought before a court martial for refusing to comply with an order to abandon Indian troops under his command during the Dunkirk retreat.
fields.body:
Sir Paddy Ashdown revealed yesterday how his father was brought before a court martial for refusing to comply with an order to abandon Indian troops under his command during the Dunkirk retreat.

The order had been "idiotic and disgraceful", said Sir Paddy, who was a Royal Marine captain before he was leader of the Liberal Democrats. His father, who ended the war a colonel, was in the Royal Indian Army Service Corps, based in the Punjab. In 1939 he took a platoon of Indian soldiers and their troop of mules as one of four mule trains to join the British Expeditionary Force in France.

During the BEF's 100-mile retreat in June 1940, the order went out from a senior British officer to set loose the mules and the Indians; the British officers were ordered to make their way to Dunkirk for evacuation, since officers were in short supply.

Sir Paddy's father, John, disobeyed, turning loose the mules but marching his platoon to Dunkirk without loss. There he secured a berth for them all on the last ship out before the jetty was bombed. Back in England, he was reunited with his wife, Lois, but court martialled for disobeying an order. The court martial was subsequently thrown out, according to Sir Paddy.

The Ministry of Defence, when first approached about the story by the Southall-based TV company Zee TV, said its archive department had after two days been unable to find any record of Indian troops at Dunkirk; it also reported it had lost the records of Indian Army court martials. Zee TV located a record of the Indian troops' presence in hours at the Imperial War Museum. The ministry then asserted that the command to cut loose the Indians and mules, made by a single officer, did not amount to an official order.

Sir Paddy said last night: "It may seem that the order was a racist one in the context of our time, but my father thought simply that these were his men, he was responsible for them, and he must bring them back. That was the beginning and the end of it."

webTitle: Pages of history

fields.headline: Pages of history
fields.standfirst: Veterans reclaim wartime documents
fields.trailText: Moving personal accounts of British soldiers' experiences during the second world war were revealed by the Ministry of Defence yesterday as private papers and diaries confiscated by the Nazis were finally returned 60 years on.
fields.body:
Moving personal accounts of British soldiers' experiences during the second world war were revealed by the Ministry of Defence yesterday as private papers and diaries confiscated by the Nazis were finally returned 60 years on.

The papers were taken from British and Common wealth soldiers captured in France in 1940 while others were seized from men taken prisoner in the Western Desert. In a ceremony at the Imperial War Museum in London, the diaries, paybooks and photographs, stored since the mid-1940s in a Russian vault, were handed back by defence minister Lewis Moonie.

War veterans and their families travelled from all over Britain to receive their property. They were joined by representatives from Canada, New Zealand, Australia, India, Nepal and Pakistan.

Efforts to trace the owners' families began in 1997 when the Russian government handed over photocopies of British paybooks and diaries to Tony Blair. The originals were given to Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, last year. Of the 79 veterans the MoD set out to trace, all but seven have been found.

Yesterday, the family of Lt Col George Duncan, who escaped by tunnel from a German PoW camp, spoke of their joy at being reunited with his battered diary, which combines light-hearted episodes with moments of fear. It also includes maps of routes through France and sketches of prison camps in Poland and Germany. His son, Peter, 44, said: "Before his death my father told us of his escape from Biberach camp. But reading his diary makes it even more poignant."

webTitle: Interview: Amanda Roocroft

fields.headline: 'This is a horrid job. I would rather be a teacher'
fields.standfirst: Amanda Roocroft, the reluctant diva, talks to Stephen Moss.
fields.trailText: Amanda Roocroft, the reluctant diva, talks to Stephen Moss.
fields.body:
Sitting in on a rehearsal at the Royal Opera House is a rare privilege. When it is Amanda Roocroft being put through her paces in Katya Kabanova, which opens at Covent Garden on Friday, it is something more than that. The power and commitment she brings to the rehearsal, throwing herself to the floor and ignoring concerned offers of knee-pads, makes you wonder how this performance can be topped on stage.

Roocroft has become inseparable from Janacek's self-destructive heroine, who rebels against her oppressive marriage. She triumphed in the role at Glyndebourne in 1998 and has come to see it as the turning point in a career that had seemed to be going off the rails. "The three years leading up to that Katya were bleak and empty," she says. "I'm glad they're over." This unhappiest of operas has, oddly, become her lucky charm.

In rehearsal, Roocroft appears to have boundless confidence: playing the role to the hilt; listening intently to director David Edwards and conductor Simone Young but having her always succinct say too; producing her throaty laugh when things go wrong. But talk to her and the confidence evaporates: she dislikes interviews, critical scrutiny, the whole ego-driven business of opera.

Her crisis in the mid-1990s was part professional, part personal. She felt others' expectations were enveloping her and that her record company at the time, EMI, was interested only in turning her into a marketable commodity. Her marriage to German baritone Manfred Hemm was also on the point of breakdown. They are now divorced and Roocroft has married David Gowland, the vocal coach whom she met while rehearsing that life-changing Glyndebourne Katya.

The break-up of her marriage clearly informed her playing of the role at Glyndebourne, but she says her understanding of what it is to feel repressed and alienated lies deeper than that. "From a very early age I wanted to be a singer, and my friends didn't understand that. I always felt like the outsider and never really felt that I belonged in a group. If Katya were to leave her marriage and go off with Boris [her weak-willed lover], that relationship wouldn't last either. She is unique. She doesn't belong here - she doesn't belong anywhere."

Empathy is crucial for Roocroft. She needs to get under a character's skin and says that her failures as Pamina in The Magic Flute reflect her inability to find anything of substance in the role. Katya is evidently someone with whom she feels a considerable affinity.

Was it difficult reprising the role two years on? "I rubbed out all the translation and musical notes and started again. I retranslated it, relearned it. I'm older now. I've seen more, done more. It's like an actor approaching a role he's done 20 times before. He would find new ways of saying the same thing." Roocroft also played Janacek's other tragic heroine, Jenufa, at Glyndebourne this summer, winning acclaim in a widely admired production. "Katya and Jenufa are gifts for a soprano and for me, because I enjoy the acting side of it. What makes it more liberating is the language. Because I don't speak Czech, I have to convey emotions through sound. I have to act with my voice, and not knowing the language challenges you to do that."

She is careful to draw a distinction between the two characters, both of whom are trapped by their domestic circumstances and dominated by powerful older women - Katya by her mother-in-law, Jenufa by her stepmother. "Jenufa is more rounded than Katya," she says. "Katya is on a one-way street to self-destruction, whereas Jenufa's is the journey of young girl to mature woman. She lives a lot along the way and is a big person, capable of tremendous forgiveness."

The repression that both women suffer in closed, conservative communities can be difficult for modern, liberal-minded audiences to comprehend, but Roocroft understands the setting. "I was brought up in Coppull, a mining village in Lancashire. It was very small and everybody knew everyone else's business. My mother was from a town 10 miles away and we were viewed with suspicion because we weren't born and bred in the village. It took 20 years to be accepted."

Her parents were teachers, and her mother was a pianist who had put her family ahead of a potential career as a musician. Roocroft played piano and cornet - she was in the local brass band until she was 21 - but she always wanted to be a professional singer. She studied singing at the Royal Northern College of Music and was hailed as a rising star, but now believes that such instant recognition damaged her.

"I wanted to be a singer from the age of eight. I enjoyed the sensation of singing, exploring roles. But then people heard about me and I felt I had to live up to their hopes. At college, there's always a flavour of the month and it was me. I thought, 'OK, it's me; it'll be somebody else next.' But it continued after college. I was a young girl in the profession who had to earn her right to be there."

She had some bad notices, both for stage performances and for her debut recital disc, and she reacted badly. "There was one particularly unkind review of the recording, which I read in a taxi on the day of the launch," she recalls. "I remember thinking, 'If I just stayed in this taxi and told him to drive, I could just go and get lost and never be found.' From then on, I was fighting constantly with my confidence."

Her relationship with EMI ended, largely because Roocroft refused to play the role of diva. "I didn't want to be a superstar," she insists. "I wanted to do a good job and be respected in my profession for that. EMI couldn't understand that I didn't want to do interviews. I tasted stardom twice [first when she burst on to the professional stage in the early 90s, then when EMI promoted her] and I realised that it's not for me." She also resented attempts to cast her as a Lesley Garrett-style Lancashire lass. A Daily Mail photographer once turned up with a pint of beer as a prop; she asked him what had happened to the flat cap and ferret.

Roocroft is now without a record contract and has no immediate prospect of recording her core roles: Katya, Jenufa, Fiordiligi, Mimi, Desdemona. This disappoints her. "It would be nice to have a few things on disc for my grandchildren to listen to."

Looking back, she can make sense of what went wrong in those early days. "I fretted terribly in my 20s. I felt the responsibility to do the roles justice and I thought about the history of the roles and the performers who had done them. There was an expectation that I would be the next great star, and I felt that I had to look to these people and deliver what they did. Now I realise I don't have to do that."

Again, it was Katya who helped her find herself. "I didn't know anything about her. Glyndebourne offered me the video and I said I'd rather not see it. I wanted to create the role afresh, and they allowed me to do that within the framework of the original production. It has given me the confidence to say, 'OK, this is my way. I can't be anybody else.' "

Roocroft lives in Sussex (she has been flooded out in recent weeks) with her husband and two sons, four-year-old Dominic and one-year-old James. With Dominic starting school she has made sure she will be working in the UK a great deal over the next two years - as well as Katya, she will be singing three other major roles at Covent Garden in that period.

She is a paradoxical figure: in love with singing but uncomfortable with stardom. There were times when she considered giving it up, depressed by being constantly judged, the artificial friendships developed in the brief but intense period of rehearsal and performance.

"This is a horrid profession, and if it wasn't for the fact that I can't imagine my life without singing I would take a degree in teaching, and go and teach infants," she says. That would no doubt have been teaching's gain, but opera's grave loss.

 Katya Kabanova is in repertory at the Royal Opera House, London WC2, from Friday. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

webTitle: Predicting tastes

fields.headline: You'll love this
fields.standfirst: Predicting tastes
fields.trailText: Most of us happy consumers are resigned to seeing our musical tastes narrow as our arteries harden. But now there are external mechanisms designed to keep our tastes on the straight and narrow.
fields.body:
Most of us happy consumers are resigned to seeing our musical tastes narrow as our arteries harden. But now there are external mechanisms designed to keep our tastes on the straight and narrow.

Internet CD retailers like to profile their customers and - theoretically at least - flatter them by catering directly to their tastes. Several of the music monthlies offer the same discreet service, with that telling clause: "If you like this, then you'll also like that."

In reality, though, it doesn't quite work. Imagine trying to customer-profile Elvis Costello: "If you like Abba's Knowing Me, Knowing You, then you'll also like Dirk Bogarde reciting A Foggy Day in London Town, Monteverdi's The Coronation of Poppea, and Porter Wagoner and Dolly Parton's Her and the Car and the Mobile Home." These tracks are all included in the 500 "albums essential to a happy life" that Costello has compiled in the current issue of Vanity Fair.

Not so much Desert Island Discs as an entire Subcontinent Discs, Costello's choices tumble out one after another, leaping genres in fortuitous alphabetical juxtapositions: Dowland, Duparc, Durante, Dury. A manifesto for catholic listening, it reinforces what we always knew, that Costello is a breathless enthusiast, always ready to pay homage to people he likes - pop's answer to Martin Scorsese. Next week at the Royal Festival Hall, he puts his money where his mouth is by appearing with Deborah Harry in Fire at Keaton's Bar and Grill, by wry New York jazzer Roy Nathanson (who features in the 500).

Not many musicians in mainstream rock and pop either listen to such a range or take the trouble to broadcast their enthusiasms. Rock people generally prefer not to advertise other artists' work (one CD sale for another act is one lost for yourself) and even fewer like to acknowledge influence, preferring it to seem as though their genius has sprung fully formed from the hip of the zeitgeist. A few, though, have been moved not just to enthuse but to curate: Costello is one of several artists who have been involved in the South Bank's Meltdown festivals, which over the past few years have provided insights into the secret pleasures of Scott Walker (morose modern classical), Nick Cave (Samuel Beckett and American folk anthologist Harry Smith) and Laurie Anderson (quite fond of Lou Reed). All of them are following in the footsteps of Brian Eno, whose own brief-lived 1970s label Obscure Records gave mainstream pop consumers their first inkling of life in the avant-garde fringes - as a result of which that fringe was drawn closer to the mainstream.

Dropping modish names was always a way for mainstream pop people to establish themselves as arbiters of nowness and nextness, like Madonna conferring grace on up-and-coming producers. But stating your tastes can also damage and dissipate your profile: a certain breed of fans prefer their heroes to be as tunnel-visioned as themselves. In 1977 John Lydon, still a Sex Pistol, presented his personal favourites on Capital Radio, and an audience who expected undiluted Iggy and the MC5 were suddenly exposed to Captain Beefheart, Tim Buckley and grandiose English angst-crooner Peter Hammill. Lydon alienated a chunk of his audience overnight. Conversely, Blur, when they veered back to ragged guitar stuff, scored points for honesty by admitting that they pretty much owed it all to American act Pavement for showing the way.

While curator culture is a side avenue in mainstream pop, in dance music it is so dominant that it has swept the board entirely. Here, the curators (the DJs) rule unchallenged, and yet their influence seems to stem largely from the fact that, in the worst cases, they give their audiences exactly what they expect to hear. In that respect, DJs are profiling their audiences as neatly and restrictively as the e-vendors.

In pop, it's not such an anomaly for an act like Radiohead to plug Messiaen ("If you like Kid A, you'll like the Turangalla symphony"); the real revolution in listening habits would come if Tim Westwood played the odd Mingus track, or they threw in the odd burst of Fauré at Fabric.

 Fire at Keaton's Bar and Grill is at the Royal Festival Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), next Tuesday.

All of them are following in the footsteps of Brian Eno, whose own brief-lived 1970s label Obscure Records gave mainstream pop consumers their first inkling of life in the avant-garde fringes - as a result of which that fringe was drawn closer to the mainstream. Dropping modish names was always a way for mainstream pop people to establish themselves as arbiters of nowness and nextness, like Madonna conferring grace on up-and-coming producers. But stating your tastes can also damage and dissipate your profile: a certain breed of fans prefer their heroes to be as tunnel-visioned as themselves. In 1977 John Lydon, still a Sex Pistol, presented his personal favourites on Capital Radio, and an audience who expected undiluted Iggy and the MC5 were suddenly exposed to Captain Beefheart, Tim Buckley and grandiose English angst-crooner Peter Hammill. Lydon alienated a chunk of his audience overnight. Conversely, Blur, when they veered back to ragged guitar stuff, scored points for honesty by admitting that they pretty much owed it all to American act Pavement for showing the way. While curator culture is a side avenue in mainstream pop, in dance music it is so dominant that it has swept the board entirely. Here, the curators (the DJs) rule unchallenged, and yet their influence seems to stem largely from the fact that, in the worst cases, they give their audiences exactly what they expect to hear. In that respect, DJs are profiling their audiences as neatly and restrictively as the e-vendors. In pop, it's not such an anomaly for an act like Radiohead to plug Messiaen ("If you like Kid A, you'll like the Turangalla symphony"); the real revolution in listening habits would come if Tim Westwood played the odd Mingus track, or they threw in the odd burst of Fauré at Fabric.  Fire at Keaton's Bar and Grill is at the Royal Festival Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), next Tuesday.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Woman dies in coach crash
A woman passenger died and 13 people were injured yesterday when an Oxford Express coach travelling from Heathrow hit a recovery vehicle on the M40 hard shoulder in Oxfordshire. The coach then hit a stationary lorry before stopping on an embankment. Three people, including the male coach driver, 61, from Oxford, were seriously injured.
fields.body:
Woman dies in coach crash
A woman passenger died and 13 people were injured yesterday when an Oxford Express coach travelling from Heathrow hit a recovery vehicle on the M40 hard shoulder in Oxfordshire. The coach then hit a stationary lorry before stopping on an embankment. Three people, including the male coach driver, 61, from Oxford, were seriously injured.

Driver in court over 58 deaths
Lorry driver Perry Wacker, 32, from Rotterdam, was committed in custody for trial on 58 counts of manslaughter yesterday at Dover magistrates court in Kent. The charges follow the discovery of 58 dead Chinese illegal immigrants in the back of a lorry in June.

Murder case to be reviewed
The criminal cases review commission is to re-investigate the case of RAF squadron leader Nicholas Tucker, 49, who was jailed for life for murdering his wife Carol at Lackford, Suffolk, after becoming besotted with a Serbian interpreter in Bosnia.

Thermos goes cold on Thetford
Production of Thermos flasks at Thetford, Norfolk, is to cease after 35 years, and move to China. The factory is closing with the loss of 330 jobs, after Thermos announced losses running to millions earlier this year.

Priest accused of RAF burglary
A security investigation has been launched after a priest and a Catholic worker were allegedly found inside a nuclear warhead compound at RAF Wittering, Peterborough. Martin Newell, 33, of Canning Town, east London, and Susan van der Hiyden, 31, are in custody charged with burglary.

webTitle: Interview: Isabelle Adjani

fields.headline: She who must be obeyed
fields.standfirst: Isabelle Adjani is back on stage after 17 years - and she won't let anyone spoil her big moment.Stuart Jeffries reports from Paris.
fields.trailText: Isabelle Adjani is back on stage after 17 years - and she won't let anyone spoil her big moment.
fields.body:
It was billed as one of the most eagerly awaited events of the Paris season, and it was certainly one of the most perilous. Isabelle Adjani was returning to the stage after an absence of 17 years to play the lead in La Dame aux Camélias. Along with Peter Brooks's forthcoming English-language production of Hamlet and the premiere of Yasmina Reza's new play, Life x 3, Adjani's return was this autumn's big theatrical opening in France. "It's Isabelle Adjani's last chance," screamed a banner headline in Le Parisien newspaper on the eve of the show's first night last month.

The 45-year-old star was to play Marguerite Gautier in the 1852 drama by Alexandre Dumas fils - taking the title role that had already been immortalised by Sarah Bernhardt and Greta Garbo. Adjani had been in nothing worth seeing since the 1994 film La Reine Margot. Did she still have what it took to captivate that old monster, le Tout-Paris ? Everybody was very excited.

It wasn't just the length of her absence that made the return of "la reine Isabelle" (Voici magazine's term) risky. It was the fear that the 22m franc (about £2m) production might collapse under Adjani's demands. "Marguerite is one of those roles that excite the imagination," said Adjani in a rare interview with Paris Match earlier this year. "I said to myself: 'This is a dream that I haven't yet realised in my career.' So when I was offered the part, I accepted at once."

But, once she accepted the role, she was all over the production like a rash. Robert Hossein, artistic director of the Thétre Marigny, was the person who had invited Adjani to play the role; but, after repeated clashes with the star, he threw in the towel in April. Alfredo Arias took over, some say at Adjani's behest, but he in turn came into conflict with the star. She wanted her say over set design. She didn't care for Dominique Borg's costumes, finding the dresses too heavy. She refused to have her name in lights outside the theatre. She wanted more famous performers in the production, while Arias preferred to cast actors not well known to the public. Adjani's reported daily fee varies between 60,000 and 80,000 francs (£6,000-£8,000), not quite what footballer Nicolas Anelka is being paid across town at Paris Saint-Germain, but still quite a few bob by most people's reckoning.

Rehearsals were rumoured to be fraught, and more than one French newspaper dubbed her an icy diva, capricious and temperamental. According to reports, she was prone to tantrums that upset the rest of the cast. But director Arias said: "She isn't capricious, just a perfectionist." She also fell out with her press officer after a story appeared at the "wrong" time. She declined to do a TV interview because she didn't like the host, and then refused to do promotional work for the play. She has even strictly controlled the release of photographs of the play.

But perhaps Adjani's very reticence helped to make the production irresistibly intriguing. More than 50,000 tickets have been sold for 100 performances of the play, which runs until January 25; it is fully booked until Christmas. With Adjani refusing to furnish French journalists with quotations, they were thrown back on their own prose. And what amazingly gushing stuff that was. "She's the greatest of our stars," eulogised Pierre Vavasseur in Le Parisien. "What we love about her is her porcelain fragility and her refusal to be too easily broken." Olivier Schmitt in Le Monde was more measured: "She is older, less pretty but more beautiful." On Saturday, Figaro magazine made Adjani its cover star. There she was, black hair centre-parted, steel-blue eyes facing down the reader, clutch ing a bouquet of camelias that vied with her ivory visage for the most white thing on view. And inside there was yet another bloke waxing lyrical about Adjani's charms. "Isabelle Adjani is that actress who can cry for no reason. She has a red nose for eternity. A melancholy and droll being who can only play tragedy," wrote Stéphane Denis. He went on in this vein for several paragraphs, before musing thus: "In the 80s, when we were totally in love with her, we asked ourselves if she was the incarnation of pleasure or the incarnation of sadness." (Who is this "we", Stéphane? No matter.)

Figaro still hadn't done with gushing. On the next page, a theatre-goer called Joel Gabrielli had written an open letter to Adjani. "How to describe the indescribable? How to explain an immense emotion, an immense happiness? How to evoke my indescribable joy?"

Never mind the rhetorical questions - is she any good on stage? To some extent, that's beside the point. Adjani unleashed her allure on French men a while ago and is still coasting on its momentum. Basking in her stage aura is all that a good many people in France seem to want to do. This is not to single out French theatre-goers. The same is true in the West End and on Broadway. When a big star hits the boards, no one cares what the critics think. Some people are just too big to be hurt by the critics, unless they really stink. And Adjani didn't stink, despite some misgivings by reviewers. Hervé Gauville of Libération wrote that she "possesses an interesting vocal register. It allows her to descend one or two tones lower than the other actors, then to climb up again without warning. She uses this effect too often in a redundant manner, which cancels the effects of surprise. Predictably, she relies too much on her iconic power and not enough on the actor's resources."

Gauville didn't care for the sets, either. And the rest of the cast wasn't very good. Perhaps the problem was the play itself. Proust argued in A la Recherche du Temps Perdu that only in La Traviata did the work become great art. "Verdi gave La Dame aux Camélias the style which the play lacked. I say that not because the drama of Alexandre Dumas fils seems mediocre to me but because when a dramatic work touches popular sentiment, it needs music."

True, perhaps, but the thousands who will leave the theatre enchanted after seeing the iconic Adjani perform will no doubt disagree.

 La Dame aux Camélias is at the Thétre Marigny, Paris (00 33 1 53 96 70 00), until January 25.
