webTitle: Portillo stand on transport spend attacked

fields.headline: Portillo stand on transport spend attacked
fields.standfirst:
Opposition pledges sought on £180bn network plan: Continental hauliers expected to help pay for roads

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The CBI rounded angrily on Michael Portillo yesterday after the shadow chancellor refused to pledge a future Conservative government to Labour's £180bn plan to boost the UK's transport network over the next decade.
fields.body:
The CBI rounded angrily on Michael Portillo yesterday after the shadow chancellor refused to pledge a future Conservative government to Labour's £180bn plan to boost the UK's transport network over the next decade.

Digby Jones, the CBI's director general, said he was disappointed at Mr Portillo's reluctance to back a bipartisan approach to infrastructure spending and insisted the employers' organisation would keep up the pressure on William Hague to include a specific transport pledge in his election manifesto.

The CBI also challenged the shadow chancellor's claim that in the past 10 years of the Conservative government investment exceeded what the government was committed to.

Mr Jones said: "I was quite surprised about that. It doesn't sound true to me." He praised the government for taking a long-term view of transport needs, but said the programme was vulnerable to a change of government.

"You can't deal with something neglected for 50 years in the lifetime of one government," he said at the end of the CBI's conference. Mr Jones said that both business and the public needed a period of stability in which transport was improved.

Asked by the CBI director general whether he was prepared to back the £180bn plan, Mr Portillo said he would copy Gordon Brown's approach before the last general election and wait to see the state of the public finances before making any commitments.

"The supposed 10-year programme is a completely unbankable commitment," Mr Portillo said. "Who is going to verify it? In any case it's a somewhat modest commitment. In the last 10 years of the Conservative government investment exceeded the amount the government is committed to.

"We will take a different view about the balance between the state and the private sector. We traditionally have had different views and we will continue to have different views. Our record [on transport] is a lot better than people paint it."

Michael Roberts, the CBI director responsible for transport matters, said: "If Mr Portillo is saying that the Tory record compares favourably with the £180bn plan then that cannot be true. It is news to us."

Despite the row over transport, Mr Jones said he welcomed Mr Portillo's recognition that Britain needed the right sort of competitive environment to attract and keep glob ally mobile businesses. He said: "But delivery is what it is all about, not just talking the talk."

Mr Portillo accused the government of damaging the economy with higher taxes and interest rates caused by its big increases in public spending. He added that Britain was swimming against a global tide, even within Europe, where countries such as Germany were embarking on major tax-reduction programmes.

"My fear is a Britain that swims against the global tide is a Britain that sooner or later drowns," Mr Portillo said. "I'm not surprised that we have seen a tax payers revolt."

He added that the government was getting in to a traditional British syndrome of deciding how public money should be spent rather than working out how to create wealth. "There is a large public sector surplus, but whose surplus is it anyway? You can create a surplus if you over-tax the people and the people have been over-taxed."

While Mr Portillo said there was nothing the government could do to bring down the value of the pound, he said it could help struggling businesses by reducing the burden of taxation and can take pressure off interest rates by encouraging saving. "If we were not committed to such massive increases in public spending that would reduce the pressure on interest rates and that would bring relief to business."

webTitle: Interview: Bryony Lavery

fields.headline: Good grief
fields.standfirst: When Bryony Lavery lost her parents, it could have broken her. Instead it was her making as a writer.
fields.trailText: When Bryony Lavery lost her parents, it could have broken her. Instead it was her making as a writer.
fields.body:
Bryony Lavery has been a fixture in British theatre for more than two decades, quietly writing for women's companies, children, the radio and those areas that never merit more than a paragraph in most books about the British stage. Now, at 52, an age when many of her peers have peaked, Lavery looks in danger of turning into a major British playwright.

It began three years ago with a play called Goliath, inspired by Beatrix Campbell's book about the riots that exploded across Britain's housing estates in 1991. This tough and compassionate piece was the first indication that Lavery could do more than give us a jolly good time in the theatre. It was swiftly followed by Frozen, an agonising and tender play about a mother, a paedophile and a psychiatrist bound together by the disappearance of a 10-year-old girl, which won Lavery the Theatrical Management Association best new play award for 1998.

This week Lavery is riding the crest of a wave. Behind the Scenes at the Museum, her adaptation of Kate Atkinson's story of a dysfunctional family, is playing in York, and A Wedding Story, a moving drama about marriage and the nature of love, opened at Birmingham on Monday night and will transfer to London in the New Year.

So what happened?

Lavery dates her late flowering to her mother's death three years ago, followed by her father's a year later. The misery of their deaths, combined with the earlier suicide of her ex-husband, whom she had married when she was young before coming out as a lesbian, made Lavery realise that she didn't have to joke all the time. "I am by nature a happy person. I wake up smiling. I used to say to my parents: 'You didn't give me the Brontë upbringing to become a writer.' I didn't feel I could write anything but comedies."

There is a wonderful scene in A Wedding Story in which the grown-up Sally and Robin express their resentment and bewilderment at having to act like adults in the face of the descent of their mother, Evelyn, into dementia and the inability of their father, Peter, to cope. "I am not grown-up enough for this. I look sophisticated and handsome but actually I'm only six," declares Robin. "I'm actually not old enough to do my own coat buttons up," says Sally. "It's an outrage expecting two tiny children like us to cope with this." As with much of Lavery's best writing there is a terrible, unacknowledged truth behind the joshing: that as long as our parents are alive we refuse to really acknowledge that we are fully adult.

"My parents' deaths made me grow up in every sense," says Lavery. "There is a release in death. You forgive the dead for all the things that seemed so huge and irritating in life. You think that was just small potatoes. It changes your perspective."

There is plenty of laughter in A Wedding Story, a play that with its mix of comedy, tragedy, movie culture and popular song constantly seems to be heading for a fall but ultimately soars. But it is also deadly serious. At its heart is an examination of what it is to love and how much our love for each other is built on shared memories. Peter and Evelyn appear to have had a blissfully happy marriage but Evelyn's Alzheimer's destroys not only her brain cells but love itself.

"I thought this play was a clever disguise of my own feelings about love and death," says Lavery. "But the rehearsal process has left me feeling ragged and raw. I didn't set out to write about myself but I've used the emotion, loss and grief in my life and found a story to excise and explain it." But she gives short shrift to anyone who thinks that the gay Sally, who is scared of commitment, might be a self-portrait. "The characters are braver than me, wittier, better dressed, have nicer haircuts and behave much better than I would. This is not my life," she says.

And, unlike the characters in A Wedding Story, Lavery has plenty to be cheerful about. "I used to be so jealous of young playwrights who wrote brilliant plays and got lots of attention. Now I'm pleased I didn't peak early. Instead of doing my best work 20 years ago, I'm doing it now and I've never been so happy."

 A Wedding Story is at Birmingham Rep (0121-236 4455), until November 25 and opens at the Soho Theatre, London W1 (020-7478 0100), in January.

I didn't set out to write about myself but I've used the emotion, loss and grief in my life and found a story to excise and explain it." But she gives short shrift to anyone who thinks that the gay Sally, who is scared of commitment, might be a self-portrait. "The characters are braver than me, wittier, better dressed, have nicer haircuts and behave much better than I would. This is not my life," she says. And, unlike the characters in A Wedding Story, Lavery has plenty to be cheerful about. "I used to be so jealous of young playwrights who wrote brilliant plays and got lots of attention. Now I'm pleased I didn't peak early. Instead of doing my best work 20 years ago, I'm doing it now and I've never been so happy."  A Wedding Story is at Birmingham Rep (0121-236 4455), until November 25 and opens at the Soho Theatre, London W1 (020-7478 0100), in January.

webTitle: Rival says Mugabe could be on way out by Christmas

fields.headline: Rival says Mugabe could be on way out by Christmas
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's main opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, predicted yesterday that a series of planned demonstrations and strikes would topple President Robert Mugabe within the next few months.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's main opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, predicted yesterday that a series of planned demonstrations and strikes would topple President Robert Mugabe within the next few months.

Mr Tsvangirai, who heads the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), left London last night to return to Zimbabwe. In an interview with the Guardian, he said the timing for unleashing the demonstrations was still under discussion but that it could be before Christmas.

"The way the pressure is mounting in the country, people have been urging us to take immediate action. We are working out our plans. I do not think we have even three to four months or we will be overtaken by spontaneous events. It could be sparked by the lack of payment for civil servants. Inflation is at a galloping rate. It may be caused by shortages.

Although Mr Mugabe still has two years of his six-year presidential term to run, his grip on power has been weakened by Zimbabwe's economic crisis, which many citizens attribute to the government's involvement in the war in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where some ministers and officers have financial interests.

The result has been steep rises in the price of sugar, bread, transport and other basics and severe fuel shortages. There were riots last month.

Calling on Mr Mugabe to resign to avoid bloodshed, Mr Tsvangirai said: "The end for Mugabe is irreversible. It depends on how it is managed. He can always opt to complete his term, but that would undermine the economy. That is impossible. Or he could accelerate the transition without anarchy. The response of Mugabe is unpredictable."

Mr Tsvangirai was confident that Mr Mugabe, 76, would go. He admitted that the strategy was risky and that Mr Mugabe could use force to try to suppress demonstrations but he claimed that Mr Mugabe was running out of options.

The MDC leader has been on a two-week tour of Europe cultivating support. He saw the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, in London on Monday.

Mr Tsvangirai said: "The mood [in Zimbabwe] is very tense. We are caught between a restless population and an arrogant government."

President Mugabe, he said, "has been resilient so far but for the first time he is facing the real possibility of losing power".

Mr Tsvangirai, who is committed to pulling Zimbabwe out of the Congo war, is making the calculation that the army will not intervene to save Mr Mugabe. He admitted that lots of officers had become rich from that war, but many others had not and they would not support Mr Mugabe in suppressing demonstrations.

Mr Tsvangirai added that Zimbabwean forces were in a perilous position in Congo, because Zimbabwe's air force was unable to provide any cover, having run out of fuel.

There has been discussion in Harare about putting Mr Mugabe on trial for human rights abuses.

Mr Tsvangirai said: "It is unpredictable what would happen after change. A lot of people would demand retribution but strategically we would be looking at the future rather than the past."

Mr Mugabe has threatened to arrest Mr Tsvangirai, but the MDC leader professed not to be worried. "I have been personally harassed. I have been put in jail. One more arrest will not matter."

The former Rhodesian leader Ian Smith returned to Zimbabwe from Britain earlier yesterday, dismissing threats that he would be arrested and echoing Mr Tsvangirai's call for Mugabe to resign.

"He must heed calls from his own people because he has destroyed this country. We cannot afford him any more," Mr Smith, 86, told reporters at Harare international airport.

webTitle: Infineon warns on chips

fields.headline: Infineon warns on chips
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Semiconductor maker Infineon rattled the sector with a warning that demand for memory chips is poised to fall sharply in the last quarter.
fields.body:
Semiconductor maker Infineon rattled the sector with a warning that demand for memory chips is poised to fall sharply in the last quarter.

The Munich-based group said lower demand from personal computer makers was expected to feed through into lower prices and warned the market might not recover until well into next year.

"Due to current uncertainties in the worldwide PC markets, Infineon expects weaker demand and consequently lower prices in its memory business in the first quarter of fiscal 2001 which is the last quarter of calender year 2000," the company said yesterday.

The news overshadowed record profits from the business and hit other stocks in the sector as its reinforced concerns about the immediate outlook for the industry.

Shares in STMicoelectronics, for example, were down more than 3% on the day amid rumours of possible analysts' downgrading of the semiconductor sector. Infineon's own shares were even harder hit losing almost 6% to €51.30 (£31). That left them sharply down on their peak of €93.60 but still well ahead of the €35 at which they were sold when Infineon was floated on the German stock market by its parent company, Siemens, which still holds a 71% stake.

For the fiscal year just ended Infineon turned in a net profit of €1.13bn against just €61m the previous year. Sales were up by almost three quarters to €7.28bn. Though the group was cautious about the immediate outlook it was bullish for the longer term.

Infineon noted that, according to industry analysts Dataquest, the worldwide semiconductor market is expected to grow 27% in the calendar 2001 and said it expected to grow significantly above the industry average.

Infineon president and chief executive Dr Ulrich Schumacher said: "We expect the market outlook to remain strong into 2003. Infineon is in an excellent position to take advantage of this huge potential by gaining market share in our fast-growing, high-margin businesses."

webTitle: Mother who killed her son put in care

fields.headline: Mother who killed her son put in care
fields.standfirst: Graduate's arranged marriage led to depression
fields.trailText: A highly qualified and loving mother was yesterday ordered to be detained indefinitely in psychiatric care after having set fire to her house and killed her son in despair brought on by post-natal depression and the consequences of an arranged marriage.
fields.body:
A highly qualified and loving mother was yesterday ordered to be detained indefinitely in psychiatric care after having set fire to her house and killed her son in despair brought on by post-natal depression and the consequences of an arranged marriage.

Saheeda Kapde, 30, a Bombay University graduate who speaks four languages, admitted the manslaughter of Nihaal, aged six, by scattering matches round her home in Batley, West Yorkshire, and lighting either his bedding or some paper. The boy suffered 40% burns and died in bed from smoke inhalation.

Kapde, 30, denied murder. Mr Justice Harrison, sitting at Leeds crown court, accepted her manslaughter plea on the grounds of diminished responsibility because of severe psychiatric illness.

The court heard that she became increasingly unstable following her marriage in 1989 to Abdul Kapde, who brought her to Britain where he got work as a taxi driver. A graduate with bright prospects, she never took to a small West Yorkshire town or the life of a wife and mother.

Paul Worsley QC, prosecuting, told the court: "The marriage and the move to the UK were the beginning of a long history of depression with intermittent suicide attempts." Kapde was taken to hospital repeatedly, and apparent improvements in her condition were short-lived.

Mr Worsley said she had been reducing her stabilising drugs before the tragedy, and seemed to be better. But on the morning of the fire she had broken down in tears before her health visitor, saying she wanted to leave her husband but did not dare go to hospital in case she was sectioned and had her son taken from her. That night she started a fire that rapidly spread through the detached house. She was found outside by the emer gency services screaming uncontrollably. On being taken away she sobbed: "I meant to kill myself." She later told her husband: "I did it. I threw matches around the house."

Mr Worsley said: "She was tragically going through a disturbed state of mind at the time."

A psychiatrist, John Kent, told the court she had a rare form of post-natal psychosis that led to schizophrenia.

Her defence counsel, Simon Lawler QC, said that this had begun when the family had money problems: Mr Kapde was working long hours and his wife was struck by the severe depression.

"For an educated and intelligent woman her treatment by her husband and family caused her not only to feel isolated, but increasingly repressed and depressed - [but] for all her problems she had been an excellent mother."

Kapde also denied two charges of attempted murder which were left on the file.

webTitle: Boat for a king:  First plank vessel unearthed

fields.headline: Boat for a king:  First plank vessel unearthed
fields.trailText: American and Egyptian archaeologists believe they have unearthed the oldest example of a boat built by a more elaborate method than hollowing out a tree trunk. But debate is raging over whether it was intended to float on water or through the afterlife.
fields.body:
American and Egyptian archaeologists believe they have unearthed the oldest example of a boat built by a more elaborate method than hollowing out a tree trunk. But debate is raging over whether it was intended to float on water or through the afterlife.

The vessel was found at Abydos, a rich archaeological area in Sohag governate, nearly 300 miles south of Cairo. It was made of cedar planks - probably from Lebanon - drilled with holes and lashed together by rope. Archaeologists found it in a boat-shaped tomb 29 metres long, made out of mud bricks and buried deep in the sand.

The vessel, thought to be part of a 14-strong flotilla buried near a royal cemetery, is the earliest known example of a boat using complex constrution techniques, say experts.

Older vessels have been found in Europe and Africa, but they are canoes hollowed from a single piece of wood.

Finding it at Abydos puts the boat at more than 5,000 years old, predating the pyramids at Giza. Experts believe it could shed further light on the earliest Egyptian dynasties.

"This is the first time we have found royal boats in the area, proving that the pharaohs used Abydos, not only Saqqara and Giza, as royal cemeteries," said Gaballa Ali Gaballa, secretary general of Egypt's Supreme Council of Antiquities. "It is a very important discovery which will change our perception of ancient history."

So far, only one boat has been fully recovered at the site. Dating back at least to the First Dynasty, 3,000BC, it is 23 metres long, two metres wide and 75cm high, and was probably powered by up to 30 rowers. Though it is said to resemble the royal vessels of Khufu in Giza and King Senusert III's boat at Dahshur, it is thought to be hundreds of years older.

Previously, the only indication that boats as ancient as the Abydos one existed came from paintings on the walls of tombs and on pottery dating back to 3,500BC.

"This means that royal boats date back definitely to the First Dynasty, not the Fourth, as was previously thought," Mr Gaballa said.

But Zahi Hawas, in charge of the Pyramids plateau in Giza, begs to differ.

He describes the find as "significant and important because it is the first time solar boats have been found in Egypt", but says that the vessels were meant to help the king battle against evil in the afterlife, not battle live enemies on the Nile.

"Solar boats are symbolic boats, buried next to the deceased to help him in the afterlife ... They could not have been used on the Nile."

The ancient Egyptians believed that when a pharaoh died he would sail down Egypt's great river, along with the sun god, Ra. Traces of yellow pigment were found on the craft, suggesting that the boat was brightly painted.

Although Mr Hawas expects more boats to be unearthed when excavations resume this winter, he discounts expectations that a total of 24 vessels will be found at Abydos, one for each hour of the day.

webTitle: Putting his heart into donor appeal

fields.headline: Putting his heart into donor appeal
fields.trailText: Today Robert Moss will be able to peer into his own heart. So will millions of others who go to see it pickled in a jar of formaldehyde at the Science Museum in London.
fields.body:
Today Robert Moss will be able to peer into his own heart. So will millions of others who go to see it pickled in a jar of formaldehyde at the Science Museum in London.

Mr Moss, a 61-year-old businessman from Driffield in the East Riding, has a new heart, transplanted at Papworth Hospital in August after surgeons found a suitable donor.

He caught rheumatic fever at the age of seven. Doctors tried to stop him running in cross-country sports when he was young because of the damage suspected then to his heart. And though he read law at Oxford, got involved with family companies and lived a busy life, he had increasing difficulties for the next 54 years.

He had open-heart surgery in 1994 and a pacemaker installed in 1996. This year surgeons at Cambridge replaced his heart. So Mr Moss presented his old heart, swollen to three times normal size, to the nation. He wants people to know about the crisis in transplant surgery, with patients outnumbering donors many times over.

"I am trying to make people aware that you can have all the medical teams in the world and all the aftercare, whatever, but you don't leave first base without a donor," he said. "John Wallwork, the head surgeon at Papworth, says the only thing that is limiting him and his team is lack of donors. People are making very unselfish gifts of organs at a time when they are very depressed, down and traumatised. It is just so generous. Without the donors, the thing would come to a grinding halt.

"I suppose my old heart shows hearts can be very resilient. They tell me it was about three times the size of a normal heart, which I suppose would be about right, because it is a very defective pump," he said.

He still needs to take immunosuppressant drugs and does not think about having someone else's heart inside him for fear of the process of immune rejection. "So far I have shown no signs of rejection whatever, although I do realise that everybody does sooner or later," he added.

The heart remains his. To display it in the new Wellcome wing the museum scientists had to apply to Her Majesty's inspector of anatomy at the Royal College of Surgeons. After the exhibition, the heart will again be Mr Moss's to dispose of. He is more interested in his new life. "It is like having a reconditioned engine in your car," he says. "The difference is absolutely staggering."

webTitle: Public confused by too many competing charities

fields.headline: Public confused by too many competing charities
fields.trailText: Seven out of 10 people think there are too many charities doing similar work in competition with each other, a survey has found.
fields.body:
Seven out of 10 people think there are too many charities doing similar work in competition with each other, a survey has found.

One in three people says there is a lack of information necessary to make informed decisions about supporting charities. And more than two in three would welcome league tables rating charities by efficiency and performance.

The findings, from an ICM survey commissioned by the Media Trust, come as the trust and the Guardian today jointly stage a debate on the proliferation of charities.

The number of registered charities in England and Wales has risen from 47,000 in 1964 to 185,000 today. The total has shown the first year-on-year recorded drop, but only because the charity commission has been running a special exercise to strip the register of any organisation that has not filed returns for four years.

John Stoker, chief charity commissioner, said freedom to establish a new charity, where appropriate, was an important part of the voluntary sector's independence from the state.

However, people should first consider whether they could work with an existing charity, just as charities should do more to work together. "The commission urges charities to look out constructively for opportunities to do this."

webTitle: Vietnamese herbalists seal lucrative deal with drugs company

fields.headline: Vietnamese herbalists seal lucrative deal with drugs company
fields.trailText: A family of Vietnamese doctors could become multi-millionaires after striking a deal allowing Phytopharm, the plant-based drugs company, to test the medical properties of three East Asian roots. The Oxford firm announced yesterday that it had struck a deal with Ba Hoang, a Vietnamese herbal practitioner whose family has built a library of plant therapies over the course of generations.
fields.body:
A family of Vietnamese doctors could become multi-millionaires after striking a deal allowing Phytopharm, the plant-based drugs company, to test the medical properties of three East Asian roots. The Oxford firm announced yesterday that it had struck a deal with Ba Hoang, a Vietnamese herbal practitioner whose family has built a library of plant therapies over the course of generations.

Initially, Phytopharm will take the family's samples of a Chinese root which could treat ITP - an immune deficiency in which the blood fails to clot and which affects 58m to 66m patients worldwide a year.

The company will then look at a Vietnamese treatment for the kidney disorder glomerulonephritis and a Chinese plant for asthma.

Phytopharm's chief executive, Richard Dixey, said: "Dr Hoang came to us, having heard about our work. His family has collated plants from all over China, India and Vietnam over the years."

"After contacting us, he began to send us patient records showing really quite dramatic results."

If the work is successful, Dr Hoang will receive royalties estimated to be between 5% and 10% of all future sales.

The asthma treatment is potentially the most lucrative - asthma care in the United States alone is estimated to cost over $11bn annually.

webTitle: Manchester United 1 - 0 Dynamo Kiev

fields.headline: Manchester United 1 - 0 Dynamo Kiev
fields.trailText:
Man Utd: Barthez, P. Neville, Irwin, G. Neville, Brown, Beckham, Butt, Keane, Giggs, Cole, Sheringham.
Subs: Van Der Gouw, Yorke, Solskjaer, Wallwork, Fortune, Silvestre, Greening.

Man Utd: Barthez, P. Neville, Irwin, G. Neville, Brown, Beckham, Butt, Keane, Giggs, Cole, Sheringham.
Subs: Van Der Gouw, Yorke, Solskjaer, Wallwork, Fortune, Silvestre, Greening.

Dynamo Kiev: Shovkovskyi, Khatskevitch, Kaladze, Vaschuk, Holovko, Nesmachnyi, Gerasimenko, Bialkevich, Bodnar, Shatskikh, Lysytskyy.
Subs: Kernozenko, Demetradze, Yashkin, Fedorov, Kardash, Kuzmichev, Serebrennikov.

Referee: Claude Colombo (France)

1 min Dynamo kick off in a game United must win if they are to even try justifying not taking this year's FA Cup seriously.
2 United's midfield looking feisty, closing down at every opportunity.
5 Massive clearance to Giggs down the left leads to the Welshman darting inside. Stumbles, crowd appeals but nothing given.
6 Giggs works hard down the wing, centres sharply, but Shovkovski handles well.
7 Barthez takes a throw-in level with his area. Honestly, he's such a card...
10 Sheringham stoops to get a head to Irwin's first-time cross, but floats over harmlessly. United thwarting Dynamo's attempts to keep the ball so far, though.
11 Giggs intercepts in midfield and has a run at the Kiev defence. They don't appear to like it, either, but the pace carries the ball over the line as he reaches the area.
14 Giggs and Sheringham work it well down the middle but the latter's ball fails to reach Cole.
16 Butt up-ended 30 yards out. Beckham's freekick not one of his best, but still forces the 'keeper to collect on the bounce to his right.
17 GOAL Man Utd 1 - 0 Dynamo Kiev After Kiev get inside United's defence for the first time, United break with Cole. Ball eventually comes back in to Keane whose shot is parried but falls for Sheringham to scramble home.
20 Irwin gets behind Kiev's back line again, but his pull back misses everyone and the Ukrainians celar.
24 United are absorbing everything Dynamo can come up with and look more imaginative when they have the ball, which is most of the time.
28 Sheringham knocks it down on the edge of the area. Keane's bouncing shot doesn't really trouble Shovkovskyi.
30 Dynamo in nosebleed territory around the United area. Two brief forays lead to a corner. Ends with Kiev's first shot on goal (wahay!) by Nesmachnyi. But it's rubbish.
33 Sheringham dummiesneattly for Butt to race through the middle but the carrot top fails to return the favour, his pass under-hit and cut out by a Dynamo defender.
35 Substitution for Man Utd, Quinton Fortune replacing Ryan Giggs.
39 Keane fouled as United move forward through the middle. Beckham has a go from a full 35 yards but its straight at the keeper again.
40 Kaladze fires way over from the edge of United's penalty area after Beckham dithered and was robbed in midfield.
42 Sheringham edges into the area and stumbles as he turns. United fans wake up for a moment, crying foul, but the referee correctly waves play one.
44 As the half draws to a close, Dynamo are enjoying most of the possession, United happy to sit back.
45 Keladze has another go. He isn't getting any nearer, though, this shot ending up in the Gods.
47 Kiev force a corner which is taken short, but comes to nothing. Ref blows for oranges.

46 United kick off the second half. Straight away Nesmachnyi wanders up the field and shoots into the side netting.
47 Cole, not looking totally up for it so far tonight, just fails to make contact with Sheringham's pull back.
50 United make pretty patterns as they move slowly upfield, but it takes Beckham rasper from 25 yards to make anything of it, Shovkovskyi palming over. the corner comes to nothing.
52 Another Beckham pop from distance fizzes wide.
55 Bodnar put down by Fortune level with the left side of United's box. the resultant freekick is headed over.
57 Game just limping along now, Kiev seemingly unable to liven matters up, United just unwilling to take any risks.
59 Kiev are apparently on a huge bonus if they can win this. Proof, at least, that not everything comes down to money, judging by the Ukrainians' showing.
62 Substitution for Dynamo, Kuzmichev replacing Gerasimenko.
66 Another move, Man Utd's this time, breaks down as Butt and Fortune get their wires crossed. Not a thriller, this.
67 Another Dynamo sunstitution, Shatskikh making way for Demetradze.
68 United awarded a freekick "well within Beckham territory". Said shaven-headed pin-up obligingly curls it into the crowd.
71 Kiev work the ball about the pitch without any real challenges coming in, but still fail to make any ground. United crowd making long overdue sounds of dissatisfaction.
74 United substitution, Yorke coming on for goalscorer Teddy Sheringham.
75 Good run down the left by Irwin earns a corner, but it comes to nothing.
76 Dynamo substitution, Fedorov replacing captain Holovko.
78 Dynamo come to life for a minute, Bodnar running at Irwin and pulling it square before Bialkevich's shot goes wide. Signs of life, though, maybe.
79 Cole reminds Shovkovskyi what he's there for, the Dynamo keeper smothering well.
81 Keladze gets goalside of Phil Neville and crosses hard, but ball drummed back out again. Home crowd getting the shakes though.
82 Dermetradze has added something to Kiev's play, and United are not helping themselves in idfield, either, with passes so often going astray.
83 Keane gives away a freekick out on the Kiev left. Cross has pace, but United deal with it safely.
85 Dermetradze misses an absolute sitter for Dynamo. Bodnar gets behind Irwin and crosses along the six yard line, but the Dynamo sub manages to steer it wide with Barthez utterly helpless.
88 The scare seems to have given United a bit of a jolt. A couple of good moves are followed by Butt going close after patient ball work by Yorke.
89 United's final substitution, Silvestre replacing Fortune, who was a sub himself.
91 With the crowd whistling for time, Brown nearly gives everyone a scare by heading back to Barthez with a pair of Dynamo strikers lurking.
94 Dermetradze hits a last gasp cross hard across Barthez's goal. The clearance comes back with interest, but no sooner is it charged down to safety than the referee blows for full time. United qualify for the next round.

webTitle: Residential care will disappear, says Greengross

fields.headline: Grey demands set to rise
fields.standfirst: Greengross predicts eventual demise of residential care
fields.trailText: Greengross predicts eventual demise of residential care.
fields.body:
Residential homes for older people are on the way out, the former director general of charity Age Concern is forecasting today.

Baroness Greengross, who retired in the summer after 13 years at the helm of the charity, says the next generation of older people will not put up with current services - including residential care.

"The new demands of the older population may well lead to the demise of residential care as we know it, and its substitution by genuine community care and extra-care specialist housing," she predicts. "However, hand in hand with this, the need for individual, long-term care and for help and advice will grow, together with the need for comprehensive systems of advocacy for those people who are frail and vulnerable and will continue to need our specialist help if social justice is to be a reality."

Greengross is making her comments in the annual Graham lecture, organised by charity Counsel and Care. The lecture is in memory of Bob and Jocelin Graham, founders of the charity which provides advice, help and advocacy for older people.

In 20 years, Greengross points out, people aged 50 or more will count for almost half of Britain's population and comprise well over half the electorate. They will not be satisfied with what is being provided for older people at present.

"Older people are not going to be as compliant or easily satisfied as in the past," she says. "They are no longer a hand-me-down generation, willing to accept what has been given to them.

"We've bred a new generation of older people who are more educated and self-reliant, more ready to question authority, assert their rights and make their legitimate demands on society."

There will have to be "a complete shift" in attitudes to older people and their services, Greengross says. "All aspects of society, especially health, social care and consumer goods and services, will have to change to meet older people's demands and respond to their growing political and consumer power."

webTitle: Successful scheme for people with mental health problems

fields.headline: Work to live
fields.standfirst: How do you rebuild self-esteem in people with mental health problems? You give them a job.  Linda Jackson reports
fields.trailText: How do you rebuild self-esteem in people with mental health problems? You give them a job. Linda Jackson reports.
fields.body:
Keith Dymond had been looking forward to his retirement, swimming in the warm seas off Tenerife and writing children's stories. But at the age of 59, his plans crashed around him after he suffered a breakdown and was on the brink of suicide. The collapse was triggered by the loss of his job as a local authority manager.

He hit rock bottom 18 months ago. Since then, he has rebuilt his self-esteem and self-worth and has a new job as an account manager for one of Britain's most innovative employment projects. And along with his new post, he says, he has rediscovered the will to live.

The employment initiative in Cornwall that allowed Dymond to get back on his feet has received little national attention. But John Mahoney, joint head of mental health at the Department of Health, described it as "fantastic" after paying a visit during the summer while on holiday in the area.

The initiative is called Pentreath Industries. It provides work experience, jobs and training for people with severe mental health problems in one of the country's unemployment blackspots. Part of its success is the way it has adopted a dual-track approach, developing operations which take advantage of Cornwall's popularity as a tourist destination while also offering training in office skills, computer literacy and desktop publishing at its own printworks in St Austell.

Pentreath currently has 12 separate projects, including seven emerging social firms, dotted around the county. These include a guest house in Falmouth, with extra facilities for the disabled; Cornish World, a quarterly magazine for Cornish exiles; Pedals, a bicycle hire and restoration business; and Cornish Wood, a woodworking business making planters and birdhouses sold through the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds.

The success of Pentreath, a registered charity, has gone against all the odds. Only this year, Cornwall was made a priority area by the European Union and awarded "objective one" status in recognition of its ailing rural economy. The farming and fishing communities are still in crisis. Transport remains a huge problem in a county 120 miles long. Yet employment and training opportunities for people with severe mental health problems have never been better.

People with schizophrenia or manic depression, who 11 years ago might have folded bandages - for nominal pay - as industrial therapy at St Lawrence's hospital in Bodmin, have set up their own businesses or found permanent employment after training with Pentreath.

The charity was set up by Cornwall and Isles of Scilly health authority in 1990 as part of the care in the community drive. The number of trainees has since risen from 50 to 500. All have a history of severe mental illness and have been referred by community mental health teams.

For Dymond, who was a £22,000-a-year training manager for Cornwall county council, the charity offered him a lifeline after he lost his job in a management shake-up. He recalls: "Those were the worst four months of my life. It was absolutely dreadful.

"I was given alternative work but I was left totally demoralised. What happened was unbelievable. I had a breakdown 15 years ago, but this was worse. I eventually cracked and ended up in hospital. There was no light at the end of the tunnel."

He was forced to sell his luxurious, four-bedroom bungalow and find somewhere smaller. However, that has also proved too expensive - with the result that he has been forced to sell up a second time in 18 months and buy something smaller still.

Dymond, who is receiving long-term treatment for severe depression, is philosophical after the trauma of the past two years. He says: "My wife and I were really looking forward to going to Tenerife. That will never happen, but I went on a computer training course with Pentreath and I am now working again - something I did not think was possible a few months ago."

Another success story is that of Neil, who wishes not to be identified, who at the age of 29 thought he would never get a job after spending long periods in and out of hospital. Last year, he realised his dream of working at the Lost Gardens of Heligan, near Mevagissey, after completing a national vocational qualification in environmental conservation and gaining a number of machine handling qualifications while a trainee with Pentreath.

Mike Helliwell, senior gardener at Heligan, says: "Neil's performance is entirely up to our expectations. His time-keeping and reliability are faultless, and he has some impressive machine-handling qualifications."

Most Pentreath trainees complete one of 24 accredited courses at sites across the county. Training is also offered in horticulture and landscape design, with opportunities to work at Heaven Scent Nurseries, another emerging social firm at St Austell.

Penny Robertson, Pentreath's chief executive, says: "People who come to Pentreath often think they have no future. Mental illness is so destructive it takes away a person's confidence or self-esteem. The illness and medication not only take away a person's skill level, they also take away hope. At times, people can't control their thought processes. It is the final indignity.

"The first thing we do is sit down and talk to people at an early stage and identify something the person is interested in. We try to identify vocational aspirations and a route to achieve it. Sometimes we identify things which people think they want to do but aren't achievable. We try to achieve realistic perceptions of what people can do. If we don't offer the training required, we try to find it from another source."

A good relationship with employers in the county has resulted in 40 companies offering training placements. Links are currently being forged with Cornwall College, which offers catering courses. It is hoped there will be an opportunity to provide on-the-job training at Trevaylor, the £250,000 Falmouth guesthouse which Pentreath bought with the help of a grant from the national lottery charities board.

Grants account for almost 90% of Pentreath's income, which last year amounted to more than £1m. A third of this was core funding from Cornwall Healthcare Trust, which provides backing for each trainee for three years. This was matched by a grant from the European Social Fund. A further 10% came from the lottery charities board, and 8% was generated from trading by the social firms.

The charity has come a long way since 1990. During the past 12 months, 19 people went into full-time jobs. Yet there is still a waiting list of people with mental health problems wanting to join. Robertson says: "Our work has only just begun. We must expand our existing operations, establish new projects in some areas and extend our partnerships with local employers."

For Dymond, who now works full-time for Pentreath, the charity has given him his life back. "If it was not for Pentreath I would not be around," he says. "I was given a step up just when I needed it. For that I feel very privileged."

Benefits and stresses of hard-edged projects

A store of unclaimed push bikes at Penzance police station was instrumental in the setting up of Pedals, Pentreath's bicycle hire business. The machines have been carefully restored by trainees who started work last autumn.

The doors of the business were opened at Easter. With 40 bicycles and five trailers for hire at a prime site opposite the town's railway station, Pentreath hopes that Pedals may soon be a real money-spinner. Helen Field, project leader, says that as well as learning about bike restoration, trainees are developing their own route maps and guides.

People with mental health problems are also involved in producing the quarterly magazine Cornish World. Out of print for a year, it was relaunched last December, and now has more than 1,000 subscribers worldwide.

Field, says working in the commercial world means there is a "hard edge" to the business. Work can offer benefits, but also stresses. While some trainees had gone on to university or full-time work, others have dropped out. "We are working in a commercial world, but we are also working with people who are ill, who might become poorly and need a break," says Field. "If you imagine therapy as a swimming pool, we are the deep end."

webTitle: No social care for disabled refugees

fields.headline: Act of cruelty
fields.standfirst: Mike George reports on how disabled refugees and asylum seekers are falling through the support net
fields.trailText: Mike George reports on how disabled refugees and asylum seekers are falling through the support net.
fields.body:
There is no shortage of numbers when it comes to refugees and asylum seekers in this country. More than 70,000 people applied for asylum last year; there is a backlog of 100,000 claims awaiting a decision; and supporting asylum seekers has required local authorities to run up a claimed £30m deficit.

Strangely, though, nobody really knows how many refugees and asylum seekers are disabled. The Home Office and the departments of health and social security are unable to provide any figures, and even the new national asylum support service (Nass) does not know. Various academics and voluntary agencies have carried out small-scale surveys and the best, rough, estimate seems to be something more than 20,000.

Keri Roberts, of the social policy research unit at York University, and her colleagues researching this issue, are finding that while disabled refugees and asylum seekers are among the most vulnerable people in Britain, they are usually not getting the right - or indeed any - support.

One voluntary children's agency found, almost by accident, an asylum seeker family with an autistic child living in one room at the top of a bed and breakfast hotel. Nothing had been done about the child's needs. And even when refugee status has been granted, things are not necessarily any better.

Sarah Merzouk, who works for the Refugee Housing Association, has been helping a newly-arrived refugee from Burundi who, although he understands English, is deaf and mute. As a refugee, he is entitled to benefits. But when Merzouk tried to help him obtain income support, she says the benefits agency insisted he apply for work, or jobseeker's allowance, without taking into account his need to learn British sign language. Merzouk says she is also having difficulty getting the local authority to carry out a community care assessment of his disabilities.

Problems like these are commonplace, says Roberts. But some cases are especially upsetting. Miran Ahmad, coordinator of the Kurdish Disability Organisation, recounts several instances of asylum seekers physically and psychologically scarred by torture.

It might be thought that on the first anniversary on Saturday of the Immigration and Asylum Act, the aim of which was to "modernise" and "streamline" the system, the plight of these most vulnerable asylum seekers would have improved.

But the act made no specific reference to disabled people, although it did establish Nass, which is charged with organising vouchers, accommodation, and generally providing or arranging the necessary support for asylum seekers. Alison Fenney, head of policy at the Refugee Council, says Nass has so far failed to make any difference. "In particular, there is a lack of interface between it and the community care system operated by local authorities."

Many of the problems seem largely inbuilt. Disabled asylum seekers have to exist on vouchers, at 70% of income support rates, even though the government accepts there are significant and genuine costs associated with most disabilities. But refugees and asylum seekers are not usually eligible for disability benefits. Nor may the shops which take vouchers stock foods appropriate for people with diabetes, for example.

Vanessa Davis, team leader at the Disability Alliance charity, says she and some refugee groups have been trying for most of the year to persuade Barbara Roche, immigration minister, to take seriously the costs of disability. "But all we're told is that everything is decided on a case-by-case basis, so there's clearly no policy on the matter. Similarly, we've been asking Nass what they can do to provide proper support, and again we've received no answer."

Davis also points out that the act's emphasis on dispersing asylum seekers from London and Kent has led Nass to prioritise its work on finding accommodation. This, she says, has marginalised issues such as assessment and support for disabled people. In addition, Nass carries out its work in partnership with "reception assistants" - local voluntary asylum and refugee agencies seldom familiar with disability.

As a consequence many slip through the net - though as Davis argues, in reality there may be no "net". The act's dispersal policy has added to the problem according to Alan Sklan, clinical director of the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture. "Although in theory asylum seekers and refugees who have been tortured are not supposed to be dispersed, because it's recognised that here in London we can offer the necessary multi-disciplinary support, we're very aware that it doesn't always happen," says Sklan.

"The government should have planned for dispersal by building up regional centres which could offer proper services. Instead we have hard-pressed health and local authorities struggling to identify and meet the sometimes considerable needs of victims of torture."

Most refugee and disability agencies accept that local authorities and NHS trusts have been put in a difficult position. Geoff Alltimes, from the Association of Directors of Social Services' disabilities committee, says authorities are finding it hard enough to cope with accommodating asylum seekers and are simply unable to engage in the outreach and follow-up work required to identify and meet the needs of disabled people.

As for health needs, campaigners cite many instances where GPs have been unwilling to place disabled refugees and asylum seekers on their lists - principally, they say, because they do not have access to interpreters.

Fenney, at the Refugee Council, says: "This is all a huge grey area, at both policy and operational level. Many local authorities believe that Nass is, or should be, providing all the support, whereas Nass itself seems content to say to local authorities that, provided disabled asylum seekers meet their community care eligibility criteria, then local authority social services departments should provide the support."

The real victims of this lack of joined-up thinking are refugees and asylum seekers themselves. Kishor Patel, corporate race equality adviser at the Royal National Institute for the Blind, says problems in accessing services are leading visually impaired people to become needlessly blind.

And Roberts points out that: "We will continue to see limbless asylum seekers reliant on vouchers redeemable at shops they are unable to get to, and deaf asylum seekers dispersed to areas where no one understands their sign language."

webTitle: A Family Holiday Association-sponsored vacation

fields.headline: Breath of fresh air
fields.standfirst: John Cunningham finds families in difficulties can have a grand time on holiday
fields.trailText: John Cunningham finds families in difficulties can have a grand time on holiday.
fields.body:
As Grand Hotels go, the establishment bearing that illustrious name on Margate's seafront in Kent is not in the luxury league. Even so, last week it was providing guests with a range of holistic facilities few of its eponymous five-star cousins could match.

On offer was a package including reflexology, massage, fitness, drumming, drama, music and movement, and one-to-one counselling sessions. For children: singing, dancing, playgroups, mask-making, face-painting and a junk band.

The presence of a team of therapists and a social worker was a clue that the clients comprised a special group - 20 deprived families, pilot-testing a holiday combining a seaside stay with workshops and therapies to alleviate some of the stress of living on the breadline in London.

Following the government's wish that its social inclusion policy should include leisure and tourism, the Family Holiday Association (FHA) has been seeking resorts as partners to try out a new type of break which offers more than fresh air and fun to families in difficult circumstances.

Taking a group of families to the seaside in late October and putting on a programme to cater for them, while hoping to tap local goodwill, sounds less daunting than it proved to be. Several places were approached, but Thanet district council, which covers Margate, "were the brave ones who put their hands up," says FHA director Jenny Stephenson.

It certainly wasn't the case that Margate was so down on its luck that it would grab any chance to fill winter beds. True, since the 1970s, it had weathered the exodus of Brits bound for overseas sunspots, and the recent influx of asylum seekers. But its fortunes have improved, says Iris Johnson, councillor in charge of tourism. Margate, she says, has "a history of hotels filling beds with people on benefit; then mostly replaced by asylum seekers. Now we're turning that situation round and getting a lot of long-weekend guests."

Euro grants, and local investment and marketing, have made an impact. There's a big regeneration scheme to cheer up the haggard face of the historic centre. Tarted up, it could be like Brighton's famous Lanes.

The FHA's interest in the town follows the idea of increasing the value of holidays to deprived families. It was put to Stephenson, at a chance meeting, by Vera Waters, a social worker who now runs holistic health programmes. It took some time to turn the notion, which was a departure from the holidays the charity usually offers, into a viable scheme.

Stephenson says she was keen to see what more they could do to relieve pressures on a family while having a week away. The main purpose is still that parents and children should enjoy the respite; the workshops are laid on to offer help in parenting skills, making friendships and to grasp what community building is about.

However, the FHA was concerned that the benefits of workshops and counselling should not be lost when the parents went home. They took applicants from two family centres in London, in the hope that staff there would assist parents in finding a way of continuing any therapies or workshops they liked in Margate.

After five sunny, blowy, rainy days in and around Margate, most of the feedback has been positive. It helped break the ice that some of the families - single mums, two dads, a granny or two, and more than 30 children, all under 12 - knew each other from the family centres in London.

Mary, a single mum, said her stay "had opened up doorways"; she'd never been able to afford massage or reflexology on her low income, but now she was now thinking of doing reflexology at a local college.

Jane was one of several lone mums who said the main value of the programme - each day begins and ends with a communal meeting - was the chance to socialise, "a huge jolt" from the isolation of Camden. Derek, bringing up two children on his own, reckoned his life could be better if he had access in London to the activities he had tried in Margate, but he didn't know if this would be possible.

The holiday ended last Friday, and the partners - Thanet council, the FHA and Vera Waters - will now be assessing its success. Preliminary conclusions are that they are very keen - in varying degrees. Waters is so convinced that families can be helped, she would like to see a centre built somewhere with a permanent team to offer therapeutic holidays.

The FHA, which helps about 1,000 families a year experiencing bereavement, depression, disability, emotional or physical abuse, or overcrowded or inadequate housing, also wants to be make this enhanced holiday a part of what it can offer some of its clients.

Stephenson is enthusiastic about the immediate feedback from Margate, but she will be monitoring to see if parents follow up any of the sources and therapies they were introduced to during their break.

If the scheme takes off, it will depend on funding from councils in whose areas the families live and help from the resorts where they are to stay. Though it is not the only factor, cost is important. The FHA persuaded hotels to charge a break-even rate; Thanet council provided several facilities, including a community bus; and the team of facilitators charged a reduced rate. But, because so many extras have to be provided, and because the amount of local goodwill varies, it is more expensive than traditional FHA holidays.

With resorts sensitive about their image, to which the local economy is tied, there is the question of how willing they will be to host a group of disadvantaged families. The message from Labour-controlled Margate is that it was glad to welcome the FHA because it could afford to do so.

Johnson is very supportive. She asked 30 hotels if they would offer off-season rooms; she got 15 positive replies, and three were used in the pilot. "Now that the well-heeled are coming, we can afford to help the less well-heeled," she says.

As Margate gets 2.3m visitors a year (1.4m of them on day trips) there was never any question of the place been swamped by deprived families. However, Johnson indicates there are limits to the town's generous welcome. Given her responsibility for tourism, she says the priority on the accommodation front is to upgrade hotels, "and when somebody books in for a holiday, they don't want to hear the world's problems".

Ironically, that has an historic ring in Margate. When, in a healthful flurry in the 19th century, the town's Sea Bathing Hospital was built at the water's edge, the scrofulous poor were brought there by boat, so that well-heeled locals didn't have to look at the down-at-heel sick.

A break with tradition

The Family Holiday Association, founded in 1975, provides breaks for 1,000 families - some 5,000 adults and children - every year. It makes an average grant of £360. The charity relies heavily on donations and gifts, which last year comprised 90% of its £714,000 income. About £136,000 of this was earmarked for holidays this year for youngsters in care.

The English Tourism Council (ETC) estimates that 25% of the population is excluded from taking holidays, mostly because of cost. An ETC survey of 310 GPs found that 65% believed health was adversely affected by inability to take a holiday. And 87% said holidays could alleviate stress-related illness.

The FHA is on 020-7436 3304.

webTitle: Don't blame global warming for floods

fields.headline: Don't blame the climate
fields.standfirst: Why the current floods are not all caused by global warming
fields.trailText: Why the current floods are not all caused by global warming.
fields.body:
There is no river nearby, but last week the Brighton suburb of Bevendean was drying out after a flood. Carpets, sodden furniture, washing machines and freezers were being thrown into skips, mud hosed out of houses. People knew what to do; it had happened before. Four small dams meant to protect houses filled and overflowed. Muddy water, run-off from fields planted with winter cereals, had flowed down a normally dry valley and into the houses.

But much of the damage resulted from flow from a different field - one that bypassed the dams; here a gully 1.5 metres deep and several hundred metres long had been cut by floodwater early on October 12 and discharged hundreds of tons of mud into houses and roads.

Between 1976 and 1993, 60 incidents of flooding of properties occurred in the Brighton area. A substantial number will have been added in 2000. At Rottingdean, 3km from Bevendean, in October 1987, around £400,000 of damage was done to about 30 houses, half of which was borne by household insurers.

There is a pattern to the flooding: almost all incidents occur in the months of October and November; all involve run-off from fields prepared for, or sown with winter wheat. The fields are bare and even moderate amounts of rainfall result in muddy flows leaving the fields by way of gullies. Farmers often claim that these are "freak events" but this is nonsense - one farmer making this claim was asked when the previous case of flooding of the nearby village was, and he replied "last year".

Over the hill from Bevendean is the well-known vineyard of Breaky Bottom. The farmhouse, built in 1827 in a dry valley was not flooded until 1976 and then again in 1982, 1987 and last week. The flood frequency has increased since the slopes up-valley began to be cultivated with cereals.

Under grass there was no threat as there was little run-off and no erosion. A series of October floods in 1987 resulted in considerable damage to house and vines and a long-running legal dispute with undisclosed damages being paid to Peter Hall at Breaky Bottom. The case sought to prove that cultivation of steep slopes for wheat constituted a predictable risk of downvalley flooding; that it was done in the knowledge of that risk; that nothing had been done to mitigate that risk; and that land use and farming practices were mainly responsible rather than heavy rain.

Central to the case, and others like it, is the assertion that it is how, when and where the land is cultivated, not the fact that it rains hard, that is the main cause of flood damage. Farmers thus have a responsibility to manage land wisely which includes being aware of downvalley risk of flooding.

This is not only a South Downs problem, in other parts of the country where houses are adjacent to farmland the incidence of flooding has increased since the adoption of winter cereals in the 70s. Particularly at risk is the Isle of Wight, Devon, Somerset, Kent and parts of the east and west midlands.

The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (MAFF) have recently published a series of advisory booklets for farmers on "Controlling Soil Erosion". The "soil code" also devotes several pages to the risks of run-off and erosion. The risk of damage to properties and roads is clearly recognised, and farmers are told how to assess that risk. They are advised that if the problems are "regular and severe" to seek further advice and to consider switching to grass. The approach is voluntary, but at least the advice is freely available and farmers cannot claim ignorance.

There are success stories that show that property can be protected from muddy floods. At Rottingdean, a deal between the farmer and his landlord Brighton borough council led to a reduction in the area of cereals and the construction of a substantial dam: there has been no flooding since 1987.

At Sompting, near Worthing, after several repeat floodings of houses, the farmer constructed small dams and put areas of the basin under grass using set-aside payments. This has been effective and since 1993 no property damage has occurred.

Such examples of good practice need to be more widely known. Similarly, in the southern Netherlands, Belgium and northern France, with histories of property damage by run-off, radical approaches involving cooperation between local communities and farmers and EU funding have started to make progress in providing protection.

Recent media reports of flooding in south-east England have linked it to climate change. While there may be an element of exceptional rainfall, new developments on floodplains have clearly contributed to the catalogue of damage. Floodplains are meant to store water not to be cluttered with houses.

Damage occurs where property is in close proximity to bare cultivated fields: these sites are quite predictable. Damage will not occur every year, but in relatively wet autumns such as 1982, 1987 and 2000. Farmers at these sites are engaged in a risk-taking activity (commonly called a gamble) and can expect to lose every few years. But the real losers are the insurance companies, the local councils and the householders: costs of damage to crops are minimal compared to those associated with the flooding of houses.

Nothing has changed and we cannot blame the climate.

 Dr John Boardman is head of the Environmental Change Institute, Oxford, and has worked on erosion and flooding problems for 20 years.

At Rottingdean, a deal between the farmer and his landlord Brighton borough council led to a reduction in the area of cereals and the construction of a substantial dam: there has been no flooding since 1987. At Sompting, near Worthing, after several repeat floodings of houses, the farmer constructed small dams and put areas of the basin under grass using set-aside payments. This has been effective and since 1993 no property damage has occurred. Such examples of good practice need to be more widely known. Similarly, in the southern Netherlands, Belgium and northern France, with histories of property damage by run-off, radical approaches involving cooperation between local communities and farmers and EU funding have started to make progress in providing protection. Recent media reports of flooding in south-east England have linked it to climate change. While there may be an element of exceptional rainfall, new developments on floodplains have clearly contributed to the catalogue of damage. Floodplains are meant to store water not to be cluttered with houses. Damage occurs where property is in close proximity to bare cultivated fields: these sites are quite predictable. Damage will not occur every year, but in relatively wet autumns such as 1982, 1987 and 2000. Farmers at these sites are engaged in a risk-taking activity (commonly called a gamble) and can expect to lose every few years. But the real losers are the insurance companies, the local councils and the householders: costs of damage to crops are minimal compared to those associated with the flooding of houses. Nothing has changed and we cannot blame the climate.  Dr John Boardman is head of the Environmental Change Institute, Oxford, and has worked on erosion and flooding problems for 20 years.

fields.trailText:
Time flies

Stourbridge News, 26.10.00 (Toby Smith, Stourbridge)

Time flies
A man who hobbled on crutches into a jewellery shop in Dudley, West Midlands, ran off with a £10,000 Rolex watch.
Stourbridge News, 26.10.00 (Toby Smith, Stourbridge)

Paper trail
Fifteen tonnes of discarded Yellow Pages directories are being shredded and laid under new road surfaces in south Devon to reduce vehicle noise.
Western Morning News, 17.10.00 (Hetty Fletcher, Budleigh Salterton)

Line of inquiry
A professor at Northumbria University is preparing a paper on the great British tradition of queuing.
Sunday Independent, 8.10.00 (L Peters, Cullompton)

Whistle blown
Gloucester city council has threatened its refuse collectors and building workers with the sack if they wolf-whistle or make lewd comments to passing women.
News North West, 23.10.00 (Ian Fletcher, Manchester)

Playing dirty
A parks soccer match in Kent was interrupted when the wife of one of the players walked on to the pitch and dumped a pile of dirty washing in the centre circle. Brighton and Hove Leader, 20.10.00 (John Beeken, Saltdean)

Magic carpet
An old rug used to line a builder's van sold for £26,500 at an auction in East Sussex after it was identified as a 19th-century Persian carpet.
Worcestershire Evening Mail, 26.10.00 (Simon Harley, Redditch)

Lady luck
Female lobsters caught off the north-east coast between North Shields and Berwick are being bought back from wholesalers and returned to the sea as part of a project to boost stocks.
Newcastle Journal, 18.10.00 (Anne Liddon, Tynemouth)

Funny money
Practical jokers who stole a shop dummy from a Sheffield store have demanded a £1m ransom in Monopoly money.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 27.10.00 (Jon Gurling, Birmingham)

It's hot cricket
Pupils at a primary school in Nettleham, Lincolnshire, were given African crickets seasoned with curry powder for lunch as part of a science experiment.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 23.10.00 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Emergency call
Police officers in the West Midlands are being invited to become sperm donors by a fertility service which has on its books 7,000 women desperate to start a family.
Metro, 26.10.00 (J Mohamed, Ilford)

Boy racers
A five-year-old Sheffield boy, whose parents don't even own a car, has been summoned to court for driving without a licence - just weeks after his eight-year-old brother was mistakenly charged with committing a string of motoring offences in a Ford XR3i.
Sheffield Telegraph, 20.10.00 (Richard Chessun, Sheffield)

Flying off the handle
The owner of a pedigree Rottweiler puppy that caught fleas from cats and dogs at his neighbours' house in Tonypandy, south Wales, was jailed for smashing their windows with a pick-axe handle.
Western Mail, 19.10.00 (Linda Spurdle, Swansea)

No place like home
A homeless man in Bristol has been assigned a park bench with a postcode as an official address by his GP so that his details can be entered into the computer database.
Big Issue, 16.10.00 (Alistair Barber, Cirencester)

webTitle: Society: Readers' letters

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Write to Guardian Society, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; or fax 020-7713 4154 or email society@guardian.co.uk Please supply your full address. Letters may be edited.
fields.body:
Write to Guardian Society, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; or fax 020-7713 4154 or email society@theguardian.com Please supply your full address. Letters may be edited.

Gaps in evidence

Judy Hirst's otherwise comprehensive overview of the state of British dentistry (Gaps and fillings, November 1) contained several highly debatable statements. The one I would particularly like to challenge is the statement that NHS dentists provide ill-fitting dentures, poorly matched veneers ... and "the list goes on".

There has always been a quality control system in NHS dentistry, but the satisfaction of the patient is the final arbiter. A patient has the right to complain about sub-standard work. At this stage, any dentist, NHS or private, will replace the defective work free of charge if he or she feels that the complaint is justified.

However, where there is a dispute between patient and dentist, there is a recognised, clearly marked - free of charge - pathway within the NHS that enables a patient to get recompense and/or replacement of defective work. Frequently, offending dentists can be fined - sometimes heavily. Contrast this with the private sector, where the only option for pursuing a complaint is through the (expensive) courts.
Keith Tomlinson
NHS dentist and general dental practice adviser to Sheffield Health

Gaps and fillings was full of gaps in evidence. Much of the contents of the article comes, unattributed, from the British Dental Association.

What is the evidence that the NHS is 1,800 dentists down? That NHS root fillings are more likely to fail than private ones? That NHS fillings are made of inferior materials and veneers poorly matched? In an era of evidence-based medicine, such unsubstantiated statements are unacceptable.

Dental health has improved markedly. That is why fewer people are registered with dentists. Many young adults rightly consider themselves at low risk of oral and dental diseases and are consequently not visiting dentists.
Professor Aubrey Sheiham
Department of epidemiology and public health
University College London Medical School

Gaps and fillings parrots a subtle misrepresentation of the York review of fluoridation. It repeats the view held by dentists and public health "experts" who favoured fluoridation before the review and are now too closed-minded to recognise its findings.

The review concludes that reduction in tooth decay due to fluoride is smaller than previously reported, but that fluoridation of water causes teeth to become mottled by fluorosis. It clearly implies that as many children would need fillings due to fluorosis as would avoid fillings due to fluoride.

The review states: "This evidence on positive and negative effects needs to be considered along with the ethical, environmental, ecological, financial and legal issues that surround decisions about water fluoridation." Is it too much to hope that dentists will heed this conclusion?
John Dalton
Frizington
Cumbria

Partnerships that work

Sue Beenstock's summary of the work of the Youth Build Trust (Building a solid future, November 1) misses a crucial point about such schemes, now appearing all over the country.

One of the exciting elements of this kind of scheme is that it brings together local partnerships of trainers, housing associations and support agencies. Jason Stanton's success, as winner of the Young Builders Award, is his own achievement and we all celebrate that. But the scheme in Norwich was an outstanding success due to that partnership working, which included the Children's Society.

So congratulations to Norwich City College, Cotman housing association, JS Hay contractors and all the other young people on the scheme that made it work.
Chris Hull
Project leader
The Children's Society
Norwich

Patient should be primary

As chief executive of the National Council for Hospice and Specialist Palliative Care Services (NCHSPCS), the umbrella organisation for palliative care, I was concerned to read of Ron Holbeche's battle to have some control over the final months of his life (Final plea for dignity, November 1).

Terminally ill patients with severe mental illness have as much right as anyone else to have their physical symptoms relieved and to receive appropriate psychological and spiritual support. Their families, too, have the same rights as other families for support both in the terminal phase and in bereavement.

Apart from the fact that he says the unwanted Depixol injection adds to his physical pain, it would seem that, for Holbeche, psychological support includes being able to paint. Depixol, through draining his energy, deprives him of this too. All the facts of this case are not in the public domain, and the psychiatrists involved clearly felt their action was justified. However, it appears from the information available that the Depixol injection is reducing quality of life, as death approaches.

This case illustrates the need for mental health professionals to work closely with specialists in palliative care in such circumstances, to ensure the patient receives the best possible care.
Eve Richardson
Chief executive
NCHSPCS
London

 Editor's note: Ron Holbeche was given a further injection last Thursday.

Putting up barriers

I also thought it would be a good idea to learn to lipread before possibly losing some hearing (Letters, October 18). But the local authority told me the classes were only for the hearing-impaired and that it was "impossible for hearing people to learn". Another obstruction on the path towards integrated living of the "disabled" and "able bodied"!
J Wheatley
Norwich
