webTitle: Ogoniland still under threat

fields.headline: Some things never change
fields.standfirst: Five years after Ken Saro-Wiwa was executed, his brother Owens Wiwa and Andy Rowell find Ogoniland under threat
fields.trailText: Five years after Ken Saro-Wiwa was executed, his brother Owens Wiwa and Andy Rowell find Ogoniland under threat.
fields.body:
As the fifth anniversary of the hanging of the Ogoni leader and environmentalist Ken Saro-Wiwa approaches on November 10, tension is once again rising in the Niger delta, as Shell attempts to return to Ogoniland, after an absence of seven years.

It is a move vehemently opposed by Mosop - the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People - of which Saro-Wiwa was president. In April this year its congress announced that Shell, which announced record £2bn profits last month, could enter Ogoni only to remove its remaining facilities, not restart them.

Despite this, Shell announced last month that it wanted to reactivate its 125 oil wells in Ogoniland. Bobo Brown, Shell's PR manager in Nigeria, said that there was also a "need to halt the pollution of the area, caused by the emitting of poisonous gases into the environment from leaking oil wells."

"We do want to get back into Ogoni," confirms Dave Stewart, a Shell spokesperson in London, "but only when everyone is in full agreement". This seems unlikely in the short term. In the five years since his execution, the protests that Saro-Wiwa and Mosop started have spread to other communities, spurred on by the grim reality of everyday life in the delta.

For millions of people, there is a daily struggle to gain access to basic necessities such as clean water, health care and education. "Ogoni people still languish in poverty, deprivation, marginalisation and environmental devastation," says Mosop.

In contrast, in affluent north America and Europe, Shell has been trying to rebuild its tarnished image. It launched its "profits and principles: is there a choice" PR campaign, highlighting its commitment to environmental issues and human rights.

The double page adverts are slick. As a beautiful African face stares out at you, the ad says: "None of Our Business? Or the Heart of Our Business: Human Rights. It's not the usual business priority. At Shell, we are committed to support fundamental human rights ... We invest in the communities around us to create new opportunities and growth."

"When Shell says that it respects human rights I do not believe them," responds Ike Okonta, from Environmental Rights Action, the Nigerian Friends of the Earth. "You cannot devolve the environmental wellbeing of a people from the general conception of human rights. Right now in the delta, everything Shell does by way of oil exploration leads to devastation of the environment. Shell still works with the Nigerian government to make sure that the local people, who are trying to restore their farmlands, don't stand up and protest."

Whatever position Shell takes it is working with a government that has been brutal in protecting its oil interests. For example, this year also sees the 10th anniversary of the "massacre" of Umuechem. In October 1990, the Etche community of Umuechem protested against Shell. At the threat of the demonstration, Shell called in the notorious Mobile Police Force.

Eighty people were killed and some 495 homes destroyed. Although the official inquiry blamed the police for the incident, the community's frustration with the company was clear in their evidence, complaining that Shell's drilling operations had "had serious adverse effects" and that their farmlands were "covered by oil spillage/blowout and rendered unsuitable for farming".

Umuechem was a chilling precursor to the military backlash unleashed against protesters over the next decade. When the Ogoni mobilised in 1993, with Ken Saro-Wiwa leading the grassroots rebellion, 2,000 people were killed, with an estimated 80,000 made homeless in the next couple of years.

Despite the threat of violent retaliation, the neighbouring Ijaw community mobilised in 1998, the same year that the reviled General Sani Abacha died. Many saw the passing of Abacha, who had defied world opinion to sign Saro-Wiwa's death warrant, as a welcome step. However, Human Rights Watch reported "human rights abuses in the oil producing communities continue and the basic situation in the delta remains unchanged".

By December 1998, Ijaw activists had adopted the "Kaiama Declaration", which demanded an end to oil production in their area. "We are tired of gas flaring, oil spillages, blowouts and being labelled saboteurs and terrorists," said the declaration. The military crackdown was both predictable and brutal. There were deaths of "possibly over 200 people; the torture and inhuman treatment of others; and the arbitrary detention of many more", recorded Human Rights Watch. Girls as young as 12 were raped or tortured.

They also documented how the Nigerian military destroyed Odi, a town of 15,000 in Ijawland in November 1999, demolishing every building, except the bank, the church and the health centre. Hundreds of unarmed civilians were killed. "When I went back in March I saw a town I used to know razed to the ground," says Okonta. "Everything was burnt down. There was still the smell of rotting flesh. It was cold-blooded murder of old men and women".

Despite the continuing violence, the appointment of a civilian government, headed by former military head of state, Olusegun Obasanjo, in May 1999, had given new hope to Saro-Wiwa's family that his body might be released for burial. Their hopes were raised the following month when the new president gave permission for the remains to be released. In February 2000, forensic experts flew [with Owens Wiwa] to exhume the body. However, at the last minute the government refused to give access to the grave.

A symbolic burial for Saro-Wiwa, according to the Ogoni tradition, was held instead in April. Placed in his coffin were two of his favourite novels and his pipe, requests that he had made in his will. Over 100,000 Ogonis attended ceremonies in the week-long events to mark the occasion.

The family feels that the reason the authorities blocked the burial is that, under the Nigerian legal system, if they had given his body back then it could be interpreted as an official acknowledgement that Saro-Wiwa was innocent. This could hamper Shell's defence in the legal action the family is taking against the company in New York. Shell has said that the case should be dismissed as Saro-Wiwa was a convicted murderer.

Undeterred, the Saro-Wiwa family wrote to Obasanjo last month: "We are concerned that Ken Saro-Wiwa is still regarded as a criminal in the Nigerian statute books despite the fact that independent observers, including a UN fact-finding team, have questioned the fairness of the tribunal that sentenced him and the legality of his execution." They therefore requested "that you exonerate him of the wrongful conviction of murder". The president has yet to reply.

But the signs are not good. The violence and collusion continue. Last month, according to the Ijaw National Congress, 10 activists were killed protesting against the Italian oil company, Agip.

Also last month, Obasanjo nominated the ex-deputy managing director of Shell in Nigeria, Godwin Omene, to head the new Niger Delta Development Commission. If Omene's appointment is approved, which looks likely, it will be a severe blow to the communities who had thought an independent development organisation might assist their plight.

"Godwin Omene is from the delta and we believe he would have the interests of the delta at heart and would try and make sure that a fair share of oil revenues would be put to use developing the region," says Dave Stewart from Shell.

"It is very true that those in the delta have a very different life from other oil regions such as Norway or the UK. But what can we do about it? We could say its the government's responsibility, but we don't," said Stewart. "In the last year we spent $50m on community developments. This year we will spend more."

 Andy Rowell is a freelance journalist; Owens Wiwa is Ken Saro-Wiwa's brother and now lives in Canada.

Also last month, Obasanjo nominated the ex-deputy managing director of Shell in Nigeria, Godwin Omene, to head the new Niger Delta Development Commission. If Omene's appointment is approved, which looks likely, it will be a severe blow to the communities who had thought an independent development organisation might assist their plight. "Godwin Omene is from the delta and we believe he would have the interests of the delta at heart and would try and make sure that a fair share of oil revenues would be put to use developing the region," says Dave Stewart from Shell. "It is very true that those in the delta have a very different life from other oil regions such as Norway or the UK. But what can we do about it? We could say its the government's responsibility, but we don't," said Stewart. "In the last year we spent $50m on community developments. This year we will spend more."  Andy Rowell is a freelance journalist; Owens Wiwa is Ken Saro-Wiwa's brother and now lives in Canada.

webTitle: Malcolm Dean on the Runnymede report

fields.headline: When it pays to be clear
fields.trailText: Labour is planning to make patriotism a key pillar in the next election, according to a letter to ministers, leaked at the weekend.
fields.body:
Labour is planning to make patriotism a key pillar in the next election, according to a letter to ministers, leaked at the weekend. It warns ministers that "questions of national identity are going to be important" and insists "we must maintain our view of patriotism which is broadly and more profoundly rooted than the narrow Tory view".

Come in Runnymede Trust, the cue for your commission on the future of multi ethnic Britain has arrived. Here is a report, which as well as bringing together the many important reforms for rooting out racism across the social policy front, directly addresses national identity. Its aim was to ensure future minority ethnic people feel not only citizens with equal rights but part of the national story.

But the best start to the debate would be a recognition by Runnymede that they made two serious mistakes: too much media spinning, and an extremely confused final message, after a good analysis, on national identity.

Incredibly, there were leaks to Sunday, Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday papers before the launch last month under the shadow of a Daily Telegraph front page splash "'British' is a racist word, says report".

Yet far from being angry about this splash, commission organisers I talked to at the launch expressed delight at the large number of TV and radio teams attracted by the Telegraph story. The backlash came later, when it became clear the Telegraph had set the agenda. Runnymede's chair, Samir Shah, was forced to write a Guardian commentary denying that the report called for the abolition of "Britain", and Stuart Hall, a commissioner, followed in our letters page last week.

However, the fault is not the media's, but the commission's: first, by its drip, drip, drip tactic; second, by its confused message. Addressing whether Britishness had a future, or whether it had been undermined "irretrievably" by devolution, globalisation and the new cultural diversity, it concluded with a jumble of contradictory statements: the problem of conflating Britishness with Englishness; the hope of a new adjective, like Nordic for Scandinavia, for the UK's separate parts; the plain fact that "the word British will never do on its own"; contradicted by it being not ideal but "acceptable", though particularly in hyphenated form, such as Black-British. Rarely can such an important message have been so muddled.

When challenged, two commission members agreed. Asked why they hadn't asked for more clarity, they told me they had felt unqualified to challenge the chapter's distinguished author, Stuart Hall. A grave and serious mistake.

webTitle: Society: Eco soundings

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Rights for rivers | Housing hypocrisy | Crystal clear
fields.body:
Rights for rivers

Bangladesh knows more about floods than any other country, and could be the worst affected by global warming. So Gawher Nayee Wahra, who runs ActionAid in Dhaka, was feeling quite at home last week on a visit to dripping, bleating Britain.

He put our floods in the context of what was going on in Bangladesh: did we know that 3m people had just lost their homes and their livelihoods following a massive storm in an area that had not been flooded for more than 60 years? That the climate was changing there radically, with more and more extreme and untimely events? Or that 100,000 people lose their homes in Bangladesh each year, not because of flooding but simply because the rivers change their course?

He denounced the north's international "disaster pornography" that he said was killing Bangladeshis by only giving money when there were dead bodies, with nothing to help people prepare. And he wanted rivers to have negotiating rights and to sit on international negotiating bodies. "River is living object. River has mind, body, will. It is a living creature. River can talk, but we cannot hear it." He asks: "Who will represent rivers?" The logic is different but impeccable.

Housing hypocrisy

The current British flooding has (at last) been linked to global warming and the insurance industry is bleating about the need to increase premiums. It is also sending a delegation to the Hague climate talks to plead with politicians to cut greenhouse gas emissions and save the industry from long-term bankruptcy.

If the punishment for hypocrites is to be struck by a bolt of lightning, they should watch out, according to the Association for the Conservation of Energy. Their latest research shows that the fastest growing emissions in Britain come from office blocks - owned in large part by insurance companies. About £40bn worth at the last count, and the landlords rake in the rents and (with the honourable exception of Prudential) do nothing about the energy efficiency of their tenants.

Crystal clear

While some papers bash away at Europe and all its works, the European Commission has often been called on by the environmental movement to come to the rescue like the cavalry in old westerns.

The bugle rang out again last week when it decided the Crystal Palace redevelopment needed to be investigated. Bromley council has been called to account for its actions - well done the commission and the Crystal Palace Campaign.

webTitle: Too many charities?

fields.headline: Too many cooks?
fields.standfirst: Every year 5,000 new charities are created. With a new poll showing a rise in public scepticism, is it time to stop the proliferation? Alison Benjamin reports
fields.trailText: Every year 5,000 new charities are created. With a new poll showing a rise in public scepticism, is it time to stop the proliferation? Alison Benjamin reports.
fields.body:
There are more than 185,000 registered charities in England and Wales. The number is rising by 5,000 a year. As you read this, another charity will be created somewhere in the country. The charity commission lists 620 cancer charities alone and more than 200 charities working with homeless people just in London.

No wonder 70% of the public think there are too many charities doing similar work and competing with each other, according to new ICM opinion poll figures. The poll was carried out for the Media Trust, which, with the support of the Guardian, is today staging a debate on charity proliferation and duplication, asking whether confidence in the sector is being crucially undermined.

Gordon McVie, director general of Cancer Research Campaign (CRC), the second largest cancer charity, openly acknowledges that the public is confused by the sheer number of charities. He warns: "Out of confusion mistrust is bred, and the charity sector only functions because of trust." Numerous small cancer research charities, he claims, end up granting funds to scientists whose requests for funding CRC has turned down. "Something has to be done," he says.

However McVie takes a different view on the idea of the big four cancer charities merging. It would be inappropriate, he says, for CRC and the Imperial Cancer Research Fund to merge with cancer care charities Marie Curie Cancer Care and Macmillan Cancer Relief. As for having one cancer research outfit, he insists that they already jointly fund research projects running to several million pounds. "Research suggests that we raise more money separately and that volunteers and donors are loyal to a brand," McVie says.

Yet using fundraising to justify charities' existence can be a vicious circle. As the number of charities continues to grow, so does competition for funds - resulting in more aggressive marketing and fundraising techniques which further undermine public confidence.

The public rightly believes that charities are spending more charitable funds trying to get them to part with their money. A study of leading cancer charities by Manchester Business School found that, in 1997, just 65% of money raised was spent on the cause, compared to 90% in 1992. Across all charities, the average was 67% spent on charitable causes in 1997, compared to 80% five years earlier.

Despite a number of successful charity mergers this year - producing amalgamated organisations such as Parentline Plus and Alone in London - charities expert Moira Guthrie warns that mergers are no panacea. "They eat up time and money in the short term, services can suffer and they are not a guaranteed success," says Guthrie, author of Mix, Match, Merge?, a study of the issues involved. She favours more partnership. "If attention is concentrated on the vision for future services and how to achieve it, the potential strategic value of partnership becomes clear."

Funders, government and even royalty - patrons to hundreds of charities - are pushing this line. The Media Trust, which assists charities in use of the media, was drawn to the issue by a realisation that it was being approached for advice by the same types of charities.

Chris Hanvey, director of the John Ellerman Foundation, a grant-giving body, will argue at today's debate that duplication, particularly among small charities, creates waste and inefficiency. "It's often a personal response to a tragedy," he says. "A daughter dies of leukaemia and a father sets up a leukaemia trust in her memory. There's a lot of displaced energy. If they stood back and looked at how they could work with an existing charity, they would probably help the cause much more."

The charity commission insists that it now raises points like this before registering charities. It claims that a "gateway" - as opposed to a "rubber stamp" - approach to registration has reduced the number of successful applicants to 65%, from about 90% a couple of years ago. Chief commissioner John Stoker says: "We want to encourage people to engage in charitable activity." But he adds: "We urge charities to look out for opportunities to cooperate in the interests of beneficiaries."

The John Ellerman Foundation, which annually distributes to charities grants worth more than £4m, has set up a grant programme designed to promote joint working. To date, however, take-up has been disappointing. Whether government pressure will fare any better remains to be seen. Under latest guidelines from the active community unit, joint applications will be given priority for £59m of grants to be awarded over the next three years.

There are, however, strong arguments against forcing charities to merge or enter shotgun marriages. Ed Mayo, director of the New Economics Foundation think-tank, insists that not enough voices are heard in a sector dominated by the largest charities.

Despite 95% of charities being too small to employ paid staff and half having annual incomes of less than £1,900, Mayo wants more diversity in the sector and more user involvement to increase flexibility and innovation. "We need to look at new models of social action and take a mutual approach that encourages user involvement, is inclusive and empowering," he says. But he also calls for a tougher environment that rewards outputs and effective measurement, instead of fundraising, and makes the sector more accountable and transparent.

This lack of accountability may be the crux of the problem. Almost a third of people questioned by ICM felt they did not have sufficient details to make informed decisions about supporting charities.

Some of the blame for this has been laid at the door of the charity commission, which has failed to ensure that even all larger charities conform to its accounting and reporting standards known as Sorp.

In a number of countries, independent accreditation schemes operate successfully, rating charities against set criteria, including fundraising costs. According to ICM, 68% of people would favour league tables to rate charities' efficiency and performance.

The Consumer Association has been trying to get this idea off the ground through the Accreditation Bureau for Fundraising Organisations, but bureau chief executive John Beishon says the scheme went down "like a lead balloon" when it was launched two years ago. "The response from charities was: 'What on earth do they think they're doing, sticking their nose in our business?'"

There is, though, a feeling in the sector that the time is fast approaching when it will have to bite the bullet. Almost three-quarters of national voluntary organisations predict increased media scrutiny over the next five years, and 60% believe the trustworthiness of the sector will be more regularly questioned. The question is, will it take a new agency - an "Ofvol" perhaps - to achieve it?

webTitle: Health key to inner-city regeneration

fields.headline: Prevention plan
fields.standfirst: Health key to inner-city regeneration
fields.trailText: Health key to inner-city regeneration.
fields.body:
Health care and regeneration do not always sing from the same hymnsheet. But a programme launched this week aims to fuse the two disciplines to tackle root causes of illness in disadvantaged neighbourhoods.

The scheme, drawn up by the King's Fund health policy institute, will last an initial three years and focus on work in London. It will promote the inclusion of health objectives in regeneration projects across the capital, whether through small-scale and time limited involvement or through full-blown partnership.

Among the first projects chosen, the fund will be working with East Thames Housing Group in developing a network of foyers. There will also be support for a New Deal for communities initiative in Clapham Park, south London, where the fund will advise on a health needs assessment. And the fund will collaborate with homelessness charity Crisis in establishing a supportive housing scheme modelled on the groundbreaking Times Square Hotel in New York.

Julia Neuberger, the fund's chief executive, says lack of work, poor housing and crime are major causes of ill health among the poor and excluded.

"Urban regeneration schemes aim to tackle these issues. They are also prime targets for the NHS in its drive to reduce the health gap. Yet the active involvement of health workers in regeneration, or of regeneration workers in health improvement, is patchy," she says.

By bringing together health and regeneration, Neuberger says, they can achieve more than either could in isolation. "The regeneration of deprived areas will be more successful for communities if their health needs are properly understood and addressed."

The fund's health and regeneration programme will be managed from next month by Teresa Edmans, who headed the first and only NHS-led single regeneration budget scheme - in Redbridge and Waltham Forest, north-east London.

webTitle: Mapping youth failure

fields.headline: Mapping youth failure
fields.standfirst: Deprivation hot spots identified by Prince's Trust
fields.trailText: Deprivation hot spots identified by Prince's Trust.
fields.body:
Spelthorne in Surrey is not usually associated with deprivation. Nor are the Medway towns in Kent. Yet these are among areas today identified as "hot spots" across England and Wales where young people are least likely to succeed.

The localities have been earmarked by research, the first of its kind, for youth charity The Prince's Trust. Instead of going by conventional deprivation indices, the study has mapped a wide range of factors considered likely to limit young people in later life.

These factors are: not being in education or work; being from a minority ethnic group; dependency on state benefits; being in local authority care; not gaining qualifications at school or being absent from it; and becoming involved in crime, whether as perpetrator or victim.

On this basis, disadvantage is shown to be highest among young people in London, Wales, the north-east and Yorkshire and Humber. But hot spots are also detected in areas such as Spelthorne, the Medway towns, Dover, Brighton and Hove, Great Yarmouth and Peterborough. On individual factors, such as numbers in care, even localities such as Herefordshire and West Sussex feature highly.

Tom Shebbeare, the trust's chief executive, says: "This is crucial information, as the specific needs of young people are not always captured by existing measures of disadvantage. Youth deprivation has a more disproportionate effect on the whole neighbourhood: for example, through escalating crime levels. Pinpointing these hot spots is the first step in helping to regenerate these communities."

The research was conducted by the New Policy Institute. The findings are presented as not definitive, but as intended to raise questions and provoke inquiry in areas identified as having high disadvantage. The work was planned as an internal exercise, but the trust has decided to release it for wider use.

Mapping Disadvantage, the research report, names the 10 "highest need areas for young people" as: Birmingham, Blaenau Gwent, Hackney, Haringey, Islington, Kingston upon Hull, Liverpool, Manchester, Middlesbrough, Newham, Nottingham and Southwark.

The report concludes: "There is mounting evidence that intervention in the lives of disadvantaged young people plays a key part in neighbourhood renewal - indeed, there is a disproportionately negative effect in not investing in young people."

webTitle: Voluntary groups win cuts guarantee

fields.headline: Pardon granted
fields.standfirst: Voluntary groups win cuts guarantee
fields.trailText: Voluntary groups win cuts guarantee.
fields.body:
Charities and local authorities will be studying closely the outcome of a judicial review in which Haringey council in north London has been upbraided for the way it cut grant aid to two voluntary groups. The ruling could have widespread repercussions.

The review was sought by Age Concern Haringey and the Haringey Consortium of Disabled People and Carers, after the council moved to cut funding for the current financial year. Age Concern's grant was reduced by £14,900 and the consortium's by £33,000.

The groups said they had been given only 48 hours' notice of the proposals, approved by council policymakers last December 22; that it had been difficult to obtain full details over the Christmas period; and that their appeals had been heard in the presence of a councillor primarily responsible for the cuts.

Mr Justice Scott-Baker ruled that while Haringey had not acted unlawfully, it had failed to give due consideration to the two groups. In similar circumstances in future, grant recipients should be given written prior notice of cuts; they should have reasonable opportunity to make representations to the council; and that any such representations must be considered before a final decision is reached.

Haringey has undertaken that any future appeals by voluntary groups against funding cuts will be heard by people "independent of the body which decided upon them". It says: "To this end, the council will have to identify designated members to deal with any appeals from voluntary organisations and these members will not be involved in the earlier decision to reduce grant aid."

George Peacock, who chairs Age Concern Haringey, says the outcome has vindicated the stance taken by the two groups. Although the council had faced pressing financial difficulties, its duty to consult with older and disabled people should have been paramount.

In a statement, Haringey said: "The council very much regrets that it had to implement cuts from the funding for these organisations, a situation that was dictated by financial necessity. We recognise the enormously valuable work that these two organisations carry out in and for the local community, and we hope that there will be no lasting detriment to our relationship with them."

The groups said they had been given only 48 hours' notice of the proposals, approved by council policymakers last December 22; that it had been difficult to obtain full details over the Christmas period; and that their appeals had been heard in the presence of a councillor primarily responsible for the cuts. Mr Justice Scott-Baker ruled that while Haringey had not acted unlawfully, it had failed to give due consideration to the two groups. In similar circumstances in future, grant recipients should be given written prior notice of cuts; they should have reasonable opportunity to make representations to the council; and that any such representations must be considered before a final decision is reached. Haringey has undertaken that any future appeals by voluntary groups against funding cuts will be heard by people "independent of the body which decided upon them". It says: "To this end, the council will have to identify designated members to deal with any appeals from voluntary organisations and these members will not be involved in the earlier decision to reduce grant aid." George Peacock, who chairs Age Concern Haringey, says the outcome has vindicated the stance taken by the two groups. Although the council had faced pressing financial difficulties, its duty to consult with older and disabled people should have been paramount. In a statement, Haringey said: "The council very much regrets that it had to implement cuts from the funding for these organisations, a situation that was dictated by financial necessity. We recognise the enormously valuable work that these two organisations carry out in and for the local community, and we hope that there will be no lasting detriment to our relationship with them."

webTitle: Rebirth of Castle Vale council estate

fields.headline: The art of revival
fields.standfirst: Once one of the most notorious postcodes in the West Midlands, Castle Vale now has a reputation for cultural innovation. Chris Arnot on the rebirth of Birmingham's biggest post-war council estate
fields.trailText: Once one of the most notorious postcodes in the West Midlands, Castle Vale now has a reputation for cultural innovation. Chris Arnot on the rebirth of Birmingham's biggest post-war council estate.
fields.body:
Have I None, a new work by playwright Edward Bond, had its world premiere last week - not at the Royal Shakespeare Company, the Royal National Theatre or even the Royal Court, but in the 60s leisure centre on Birmingham's once-notorious Castle Vale estate. The place was packed.

It was the same when the City of Birmingham Touring Opera - now renamed the Birmingham Opera Company - performed Smetana's The Two Widows there earlier this year. A couple from Warwick blithely told a reporter from regional television that they'd been to the opera house in Vienna shortly before coming to Castle Vale. Not so long ago, it was difficult enough to persuade Brummie taxi drivers - let alone opera buffs from comfortable shire towns - to venture on to the estate.

Ian Bingham, chairman of Castle Vale's tenants and residents alliance, seems bemused but delighted by the changes. "From my perspective," he says, "it's great to have all these things happening here." Not just opera and theatre, mind you, but serious public art. Well, some of it's serious and some more lighthearted.

Community artist Tim Tolkien can do both. Grand-nephew of the writer JRR Tolkien, he does extraordinary things with scrap metal. Witness the smiling children's faces beaming from metal banners and benches scattered around the estate. None appear to be vandalised - perhaps because Tolkien involved local youngsters in their design. And he consulted even more widely for the major sculpture of curved and gleaming steel which is to be unveiled officially next week on a traffic island that is the gateway to the estate.

The steel represents the vapour trails of three Spitfire aircraft in the process of take-off. But it has been consultation with those at ground level, rather than imposition from on high, that has been key to the continuing transformation of Castle Vale.

"If local people are at the heart of the process, then real progress can be made," says Angus Kennedy, chief executive of Castle Vale's housing action trust (HAT), which featured prominently in two government award schemes for best practice this year.

The last two years, in fact, have seen the HAT's early spadework begin to bear fruit. At the core of the new shopping centre is one of the biggest Sainsbury's stores outside London, complete with its own cafeteria. "Everything's beginning to seem much better round here," says retired electrician Ron Cook, contemplating a plate empty apart from a slice of tomato in a pool of brown sauce. Beyond the shoulder of his wife, Pam, I can see Kennedy showing round a delegation from the French government, keen to observe the role of new shopping centres in regeneration schemes.

Sainsbury's has proved a useful source of jobs - albeit mainly for women. The day nursery has been revived and is now "full to bursting". New bus services have been brought in and old ones extended - a vital factor for job seekers on an estate where only 50% of people have cars. Meanwhile, more than 40 units for starter-businesses have just opened on the edge of Castle Vale. "Thirty are let already, which is a much faster take-up than we expected," says Kennedy.

Like the five other HATs set up by the last Conservative government in 1993, Castle Vale has not gone short of funds - £103.5m from the public purse and £71m in private donations to date. "It was difficult at the beginning," Kennedy recalls, "because we came in on the crest of a wave of expectation. Word had got round that big money was coming into the estate and, naturally enough, people were saying: 'Can I have my bit of it, please?'"

They would. But not immediately and not directly in thick wads. "Partnership and consultation" become meaningless buzz words without some direction. Perhaps Tolkien's sculpture on the traffic island is symbolic of the way things are done here. The three main commercial sponsors all have some connection with the Spitfire. Rubery Owen Holdings and Cincinnati are descended from companies which supplied components, while Jaguar has its assembly plant in what was once the Castle Bromwich Aeroplane Factory.

Tolkien was left in no doubt that local pride and identity were still wrapped up in the area's contribution to the war effort. Between 1940 and 1945, some 12,000 planes rolled out of the factory and over the road to the aerodrome for test flights.

Another 20 years would pass before the city council began building on the airfield what would become the biggest post-war estate in Birmingham, housing 11,000 people. Many of them lived at ground level. But, as the years went on, drivers and passengers heading along the M6 to and from Spaghetti Junction saw as the outward manifestation of Castle Vale only the stark outline of grim-looking tower blocks.

Not any more. Twenty-five towers have been demolished already and another seven are earmarked to be pulled down. The two blocks set to remain are far from grim. One houses elderly people in warden-assisted accommodation, with a host of community initiatives. Other, attractive, low-rise accommodation for the elderly has been added. "It's like being in a holiday complex," says Margery Dunscombe, 76.

Everywhere there is much evidence of home improvements on behalf of the 3,500 tenants whom the HAT inherited from the city council. In a reversal of the usual pattern, the brand new tiling and brickwork stands out sharply in drab rows of 60s maisonettes owned by those who bought their homes from the local authority in the 80s. Meanwhile, Barratt is building a small private estate on Castle Vale, and a cul-de-sac of half-timbered semis is the result of a flourishing self-build group.

Kennedy was aware from the start, though, that infrastructure improvements alone would not reverse 30 years of decline. Without enhancing employment prospects, there could be no real progress. "From being one of the highest unemployment areas in Birmingham, we've now fallen below the city average," he says.

That's remarkable for an estate whose B35 postcode might as well have been attached to a leper colony, judging by the effect it once had on employers. "We've had to work hard with the local business community to tailor training programmes to their needs and change perceptions," says Kennedy. "Firms like Jaguar and Sainsbury's are now consulting our skills register to save themselves the cost of advertising."

But he's conscious that perceptions of B35 among those outside his business group still lag some way behind the new reality. There is still much work to be done with estate agents, banks and, yes, taxi drivers. "At least the changes are now being seen by more outsiders," he says. "Having Sainsbury's here brings them on to the estate."

In somewhat greater numbers, one suspects, than even the attraction of Edward Bond or the Birmingham Opera Company.

Laying the foundations for change

Major social problems are not going to disappear overnight from Castle Vale. Twelve welfare organisations, dealing with everything from drug and alcohol abuse to domestic violence, have just come together under one new roof. But the courts still have to decide whether the housing action trust (HAT) can evict six families said to have been causing a disproportionate amount of criminal damage on the estate.

"It will take a generation before you totally turn round a place like this," says HAT chief executive Angus Kennedy.

His trust, though, has only until 2005 to continue making progress. Under the terms laid down by the previous government, residents will then have a choice: they can hand over their estate to a community-based housing association and a development trust, or they can vote to bring back the city council as landlords.

webTitle: Unsatisfactory mental health provision for youngsters

fields.headline: Mind the children
fields.standfirst: Serious gaps in mental health provision for young people
fields.trailText: Serious gaps in mental health provision for young people.
fields.body:
Children and young people regularly have to wait more than three days for "immediate" in-patient mental health treatment, according to a report today highlighting gaps in service provision. Two or three weeks wait are said to be not unusual.

The report, for charity Young Minds, warns that there is a "serious mismatch" between in-patient provision and the demand for it. There is also mounting pressure on child and adolescent mental health services (CAMHS) in general, leaving them struggling to cope with young patients with serious problems.

Young Minds is calling on the government to extend its national service framework for adult mental health to include children and young people. Peter Wilson, the charity's director, says: "If a national service framework is thought essential to bring about a sustained standards-based improvement across mental health services for adults, it is hard to understand how children's services, which are even less well developed, can be expected to improve without a comparable approach."

The report follows a review last year by the audit commission, which expressed concern at wide variation in standards of CAMHS care and found that one in three relevant NHS trusts felt unable to respond effectively to young people in crisis. Young Minds' research, based on interviews with psychiatrists, social services managers, education officials and others, indicates a national shortage of in-patient resources, with some parts of the country "almost totally lacking provision".

According to the report, Whose Crisis?, some interviewees recounted having had to send - or attempt to send - children and young people long distances up to hundreds of miles to get a bed. "Several have described the difficulties of 'selling a unit they hardly knew, in a strange area' to a young person and their family - with the not uncommon, and not unsurprising, result that often the patient might then refuse to go."

Suitable units also often operate only on a Monday to Friday basis, the report says. "Organising an admission at the end of the week, or over weekend periods, is especially problematic, and even accessing telephone advice from in-patient staff is highly difficult."

Young Minds calculates that in a primary school of 250 children, three will be seriously depressed and 11 others will be suffering "significant distress". In a secondary school of 1,000 pupils, some 50 will be seriously depressed and 100 more will be suffering significant distress. Services, the charity says, are not geared to deal with such a scale of problems.

Good practice cited in the report includes Snowsfields, an in-patient CAMHS unit opened in 1998 at Guy's hospital, south London. It has 10 beds and four day places for young people aged 13-18 and offers a round-the-clock emergency admission service, while aiming to admit urgent cases on the day of referral.

 Whose Crisis? is available at £12.50 inc p&p from 020-7336 8445.

webTitle: CHI needs new image, says report

fields.headline: Revamp for 'hit squad'
fields.standfirst: CHI report reveals internal concerns over negative image
fields.trailText: CHI report reveals internal concerns over negative image.
fields.body:
The inspection body charged with reviewing standards of NHS care is to revamp its image in an attempt to distance itself from Ofsted, the controversial education inspectorate run by Chris Woodhead until his resignation last week.

An internal report for the commission for health improvement (CHI) reveals it is "uncomfortable" at being perceived as the health service equivalent of Ofsted, which became notorious for its "name and shame" approach and for its unpopularity among teachers. The commission is worried that it is regarded negatively by NHS bodies as a "hit squad" or as a "namer and shamer" - a reputation that will detract from its attempts to collaborate with hospitals to help them develop better services.

The report reveals internal concerns that the CHI, headed by chief executive Peter Homa, is regarded with cynicism by health service staff, has a negative media image and is virtually unknown to the general public.

The organisation, which will carry out independent inquiries into problem hospitals and review standards of care in local health services, is considering "repositioning" itself to improve its poor image - even though it has yet to publish the results of any of its investigations. "The NHS perceives us as an 'Ofsted for the health service', which we are not comfortable with," the report says. "But an inspectorate for the health service (and one that is developmental and consistent) must be a good thing."

Among other measures, the report recommends that the CHI drops the use of the word "inspect" from its corporate vocabulary because of its "negative connotations". Instead, it suggests, the word "assessment" should be used.

The report was written by Matt Tee, CHI director of communications, who was formerly head of news at the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI). Before that, he was public relations director at the Guy's and St Thomas' hospital trust in London.

The commission, which was set up in April, is a key part of the government's plans to drive up standards of care across the NHS. It is due to publish its first reports within the next couple of weeks. But the report warns that the NHS is "cynical" about its claims to be independent of government, and distrustful of its wider aims and values.

"I believe the NHS has mostly heard our message that we want to be developmental, but is cynical about our ability, let alone desire, to behave differently," writes Tee.

The report hints that the CHI's reputation may have been damaged by the government spin that accompanied its launch, when aggressive terminology such as "hit squad" was bandied around to describe its role. While that spin initially gave it a strong, front page profile, it may have caused long-term damage to its relations with the health service.

A survey in September by health accreditation company Health Quality Services and trade magazine Health Service Journal found most NHS managers "fearful of inspection" by CHI. Many of those surveyed felt inspections would be stressful, costly and punitive and would lead to many committed staff being forced out of the NHS.

The commission report admits that early national media coverage of its role has locked negative perceptions of its work into the mind of the media. "The political journalists think of us purely as Ofsted for the health service and aren't really interested in any other story," it says, "... unless we turn sharply on the government, or the government gives us significant new teeth."

The report urges a charm offensive on the trade and professional media, which, it says, "have a huge influence on how we are seen because they are seen as dispassionate commentators and what they write is respected".

But the report also warns that the CHI must prove it is independent and must be "prepared to say things that will make the government, the NHS and the public uncomfortable at times".

webTitle: Budget, opinion: 'Statement combined economic good sense with realism'

fields.headline: 'Statement combined economic good sense with realism'
fields.standfirst:
Matthew Taylor of the Institute for Public Policy Research thinktank analyses today's pre-budget report by Chancellor Gordon Brown
The Institute for Public Policy Research
Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Opinion: Matthew Taylor of the Institute for Public Policy Research thinktank analyses today's pre-budget report by Chancellor Gordon Brown
fields.body:
After all the pre-briefing, it was hard not to feel a sense of anti-climax about the chancellor's statement. Even the inevitable rabbit pulled out of the hat - an extra £50 on the pensioners' winter fuel bonus - was hardly earth shattering. But ultimately the lack of surprises does little to take away from a statement that combined economic good sense with political realism.

For pensioners, there was a variety of good news that should help to diffuse anger over [last year's "miserable" 75p increase in the weekly state pension]. In the medium term, the government still has the task of removing the suspicion amongst older people that the minimum income guarantee (MIG) is complicated and stigmatising. Until the MIG feels like a popular entitlement, the focus will continue to be on the basic state pension.

In the longer term, increases in the MIG will add to the government's problem of ensuring that the state second pension lifts people significantly above benefit levels. The increase in the pensioner credit will help a little, but the fundamental problem of making it worthwhile for those on low-income people to save will remain.

On the fuel issue, the statement included a balanced package that acknowledges the concerns of motorists and hauliers, but keeps the government's environmental priorities to the fore. By linking fuel tax cuts to cleaner fuels, the government will be rewarding behaviour which improves air quality.

Mr Brown also made it clear that the freeze on fuel duty is dependent on high oil prices remaining. If, however, the price of oil were to fall once again, then to maintain its climate policies, the government will have to reinstate fuel duty increases. It is important to note that while ultra-low sulphur fuel is better for air quality, it emits the same amount of CO2 as conventional fuel.

In policy terms, possibly the most significant part of the statement was the package of measures to boost investment in inner cities. Lord Rogers [the architect and chairman of the urban task force set up by the government] has had to wait a long time to see the implementation of his plans for urban regeneration, but Mr Brown's package provides a strong basis for the urban white paper to be unveiled later this year.

In terms of our old friend prudence, despite the appearance of a give-away budget, the chancellor is right to be taking advantage of 3% growth to repay debt. The issue of what to do with the fruits of growth was also central to the US election. The outcome, when it eventually comes, will shed light on the "new politics of surplus".

Which takes us to the politics of the statement. The chancellor will hope that this has pacified the pensioner and road lobbies without either appearing to cave in or to have risked the overall health of the economy. The Tories will no doubt be stuck between reassuring voters that they will honour Labour's commitments if they win the election and arguing that Mr Brown has been opportunistic. Many in the Tories' ranks are already arguing that the proposal to scrap the free TV licence, winter and Christmas bonuses could be an electoral disaster.

The core Tory argument is likely to be that the autumn statement shows that Labour can find money for anything if it wants to, and that this undermines the argument that tax cuts have to lead to cuts in public services. This may strengthen the Tory case, but is seems unlikely to be sufficient to shift the public mood from a basic belief that investment in services is a higher priority than further tax cuts.

In the long term, the Tories will be seeking to build up a picture of Labour as a party that throws money at every problem and that keeps "the people's surplus" rather than trusting people to spend it themselves. Eventually this argument could inflict real damage on Labour (just as it did on [US presidential contender] Al Gore), but it seems unlikely to be until the election after next (at the earliest) that the battleground on tax and spend shifts the Tories' way.

In the longer term, increases in the MIG will add to the government's problem of ensuring that the state second pension lifts people significantly above benefit levels. The increase in the pensioner credit will help a little, but the fundamental problem of making it worthwhile for those on low-income people to save will remain. On the fuel issue, the statement included a balanced package that acknowledges the concerns of motorists and hauliers, but keeps the government's environmental priorities to the fore. By linking fuel tax cuts to cleaner fuels, the government will be rewarding behaviour which improves air quality. Mr Brown also made it clear that the freeze on fuel duty is dependent on high oil prices remaining. If, however, the price of oil were to fall once again, then to maintain its climate policies, the government will have to reinstate fuel duty increases. It is important to note that while ultra-low sulphur fuel is better for air quality, it emits the same amount of CO2 as conventional fuel. In policy terms, possibly the most significant part of the statement was the package of measures to boost investment in inner cities. Lord Rogers [the architect and chairman of the urban task force set up by the government] has had to wait a long time to see the implementation of his plans for urban regeneration, but Mr Brown's package provides a strong basis for the urban white paper to be unveiled later this year. In terms of our old friend prudence, despite the appearance of a give-away budget, the chancellor is right to be taking advantage of 3% growth to repay debt. The issue of what to do with the fruits of growth was also central to the US election. The outcome, when it eventually comes, will shed light on the "new politics of surplus". Which takes us to the politics of the statement. The chancellor will hope that this has pacified the pensioner and road lobbies without either appearing to cave in or to have risked the overall health of the economy. The Tories will no doubt be stuck between reassuring voters that they will honour Labour's commitments if they win the election and arguing that Mr Brown has been opportunistic. Many in the Tories' ranks are already arguing that the proposal to scrap the free TV licence, winter and Christmas bonuses could be an electoral disaster. The core Tory argument is likely to be that the autumn statement shows that Labour can find money for anything if it wants to, and that this undermines the argument that tax cuts have to lead to cuts in public services. This may strengthen the Tory case, but is seems unlikely to be sufficient to shift the public mood from a basic belief that investment in services is a higher priority than further tax cuts. In the long term, the Tories will be seeking to build up a picture of Labour as a party that throws money at every problem and that keeps "the people's surplus" rather than trusting people to spend it themselves. Eventually this argument could inflict real damage on Labour (just as it did on [US presidential contender] Al Gore), but it seems unlikely to be until the election after next (at the earliest) that the battleground on tax and spend shifts the Tories' way.

webTitle: Florida's chief lawyer could hold keys to White House

fields.headline: Florida's chief lawyer could hold keys to White House
fields.standfirst: Derek Brown takes a look at Florida's attorney-general Bob Butterworth, who may have to decide who becomes president if the vote recount gives rise to a legal dispute
fields.trailText: Profile: Derek Brown takes a look at Florida's attorney-general Bob Butterworth, who may have to decide who becomes president if the vote recount gives rise to a legal dispute.
fields.body:
The almost absurd theatricality of the presidential elections could yet end in the dry dust of legal argument. And if that happens, the most powerful man in the nation could be Bob Butterworth.

Butterworth, not the best-known name in American politics, is the attorney-general of Florida, the state that will decide the presidency. The first count produced the narrowest of victories for George W. Bush - by less than 2,000 votes out of nearly 6m.

The bulk of the ballots will be relatively easy to tally. They are pierced, rather than marked, so that computers can conduct the actual count.

But in one precinct, some Gore voters have complained that the format of the ballot led them wrongly to vote for rightwing outsider Pat Buchanan.

Then there are the so-called absentee votes, mostly from military personnel based overseas. Election officials say they are mostly counted, but in such a tight race even a handful of late votes could tip the balance - and provoke legal dispute.

Enter Bob Butterworth who, as the senior law official in the state, could soon be stepping on to the centre of the national stage. That in itself could provoke a legal storm. For Butterworth happens to be Al Gore's Florida campaign chairman.

An ardent Democrat, he has campaigned vigorously for the vice-president, even while going about his duties as a member of state cabinet headed by Governor Jeb Bush - brother of George W.

There is nothing remotely odd about this in the American system, where law officers are elected rather than appointed. Butterworth has himself won four straight four-year terms in his present office, starting in 1986, and is clearly a popular and trusted man.

Nor is there the slightest chance that Butterworth's judgement, if it is called upon, will be swayed by partisan preference. "The Florida vote will be an accurate vote for whichever candidate it might fall for," he said this morning, in the exhausted aftermath of a campaign which has come down to a handful of votes - and, just possibly, a hatful of legal quibbles.

webTitle: Hospital ready to welcome Spanish nurses

fields.headline: Hospital ready to welcome Spanish nurses
fields.standfirst: Thirty recruits will fill staffing gaps in new year as harbinger of latest NHS jobs initiative
fields.trailText: Royal Preston Hospital, with its views of the Pennines and swollen river Ribble, could not be more different from most of Spain. But it will be the new home of Spanish nurses being recruited to ease the crisis in staffing levels.
fields.body:
Royal Preston Hospital, with its views of the Pennines and swollen river Ribble, could not be more different from most of Spain. But it will be the new home of Spanish nurses being recruited to ease the crisis in staffing levels.

The hospital and its neighbouring trust in Chorley have 100 vacancies for nurses. Around 30 of these jobs will be filled in the new year by staff from Spain, who are all the equivalent of state registered nurses and competent in written and spoken English.

Most of the vacancies are on medical wards, which can be less attractive to nurses, but there are also jobs available in intensive care.

As many as 5,000 nurses from Spain will be brought into NHS hospitals to help plug the gaps. Alan Milburn, health secretary, yesterday signed an agreement with the Spanish government to recruit them.

The pilot project involves hospitals in the Morecambe Bay trust, Preston trust, Chorley and South Ribble trust, Blackpool Victoria trust, and Blackburn, Hyndburn and Ribble Valley trust. It will bring in a total of 75 nurses.

They will be subjected to stringent English language tests and take a course in the technical language used in hospitals.

Dame Pauline Fielding, nursing director at the Royal Preston hospital and the Chorley and South Ribble trust, said the proportion of nursing vacancies across both hospitals was 4%. "This is pretty low compared with other hospitals," she said.

She said the hospitals always had vacancies on medical wards because it was such hard work. The pressures "used to be a problem in winter for medical wards, but now we are finding it is an all-year round pressure."

A recruitment party is going to Spain this month to recruit nurses for all five trusts.

Of the 30 new recruits, 22 E grade nurses will go to intensive care and eight D graders to medical wards. They will receive parity of pay with their British counterparts.

As part of their contracts, they will be offered a 12 week induction programme covering language and cultural awareness. Dame Pauline said Preston had many cultural facilities to offer.

The Spanish nurses will also be befriended by other hospital workers in a buddy scheme.

Denise Ruston, a clinical manager in the medical directorate at the Royal Preston hospital, said morale was "OK" on the wards, despite the nursing shortages. "The nurses in the medical directorate are very flexible," she said. "Some will do extra shifts because they are so dedicated. Obviously we have our ups and downs."

Each ward has 30 beds, with a ward manager, two junior sisters (or charge nurses) and eight to 10 staff nurses.

"It is easier to recruit nurses in other specialities such as oncology, intensive care and renal units," Ms Ruston said. "Overall we manage, but what cripples us is if staff are hit by the flu or other bugs. It is then that we start to struggle."

Jean Faugier, regional director of nursing for the NHS executive in the north-west, said at least 1,000 extra nurses were needed in the region.

She said the deal with Spain would be more than just a short-term solution to a staffing problem. "We hope it will lead to reciprocol learning arrangement, where eventually our nurses will go to Spain and get some experience of the Spanish services."

The Royal College of Nursing said that overseas nurses had always played an important part in the NHS.

But recruiting from overseas could never be an alternative to a strong home- grown nursing workforce.

Ivy Mitchell, 77, a patient on a medical ward, welcomed the news of nurses arriving from Spain. "It doesn't matter where a nurse comes from as long as you get the right care from them," she said. "It is important to have the same nurses, because they get to know you."

The British embassy in Madrid yesterday reported strong interest among Spanish nurses in working in the NHS.

A Department of Health spokeswoman said aGuardian article on plans to recruit up to 5,000 nurses from Spain was picked up by the Spanish media and triggered a stream of calls asking how to secure an NHS job.

Mr Milburn said the NHS plan envisaged the recruitment and training of 20,000 more nurses by 2004. His department said: "This agreement [with Spain] will help us plug the gap which exists between our ambitions for the health service and the staff we have available to deliver them."

Where they are keen to export health staff

Spain's health service provides universal cover, free at the point of delivery and funded almost entirely from taxes like the NHS. However, this was introduced only in the 1980s, and many people are covered by private schemes.

During modernisation, education of doctors and nurses was expanded and Spain has twice as many doctors per 1,000 of population as most European countries. There is a surplus of doctors and nurses, and some have gone to work abroad under schemes in Portugal, Italy and Ireland that are similar to that agreed with Britain.

Spain spends 6% of GDP on health, and has 338,000 health workers, 73,000 of them doctors. Under its devolved government, seven of the more powerful regions, including the Basque country and Catalonia, are entirely responsible for their own health care. The other 10 are organised from the centre, but it is planned to give them responsibility.

Primary care is the greatest strength. Modern, efficient health centres can be found even in remote rural areas. They are well equipped to do much of the work that in Britain is likely to be referred to hospitals. Some say, however, there is a tendency for GPs to bow to patient pressure and over-prescribe.

Spain's centre-right government has made an effort at reform. But the measures, including replacing brand-name drugs with generic alternatives and reducing the list of free medications, proved unpopular. Neverthless cost cutting, or cost controlling, remains a priority.

Adela Gooch in Madrid

webTitle: Mixed reaction to Brown's cash pledges

fields.headline: Mixed reaction to Brown's cash pledges
fields.standfirst:
Pre-budget statement: the main points
Special report: the Budget

Responses to chancellor Gordon Brown's pre-Budget report
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, said the report was about "quick fixes" from a chancellor in "full retreat".
fields.body:
Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, said the report was about "quick fixes" from a chancellor in "full retreat".


Brynle Williams, the Welsh farmer at the forefront of the recent fuel protests, said: "It's an insult  I believe the chancellor is trying to drive a wedge between the haulage industry,agriculture and the general public and I don't believe he is going to succeed.

"The general public will see through this for what it is. He has tried to seduce us with tokens like three pence off a litre, but it is not going to work.

"There will be no fuel protests as far as I am concerned. But I will do all I can to lobby politicians.

"I cannot, of course, speak for hard-liners and I have always said we should wait the full 60 days. This is a final slap in the face for the general public and Mr Brown is insulting our integrity."

Mark Francis, vice-chairman of the People's Fuel Lobby, said his members needed more time to consider the "complicated issues" before deciding their full response to Mr Brown's statement.

He said: "It was a large package of offers. I feel they were token offers in many areas. "There were some significant concessions given to certain sections but not enough to others. At this present moment in time, Jarrow and Hyde Park are on."

Roy Masterson, a haulier who led the fuel blockades at Trafford Park in Greater Manchester, said: "It's very, very poor ... it goes nowhere to addressing the imbalance that the British people suffer in relation to the rest of Europe.

"Taxing foreign lorry drivers up to our level will not help manufacturing or the people of this country, that is a misleader. Gordon Brown needs to come out of his office and meet people like myself - it might enlighten him.

"The rally will go on to London and further talks will have to take place if he is going to make hauliers happy."

Gary Kitchen, national organiser of the National Pensioners Convention, said: "This will do nothing to dampen pensioners' anger.

"We are very disappointed with the increases to pensions If the link with earnings had been maintained pensions would not be at £97.45 and we had hoped for a substantial increase.

"While the rises are welcome they do not go far enough."

Gordon Lishman, director general of Age Concern, said: "The fact remains that most pensioners want a higher basic state pension rather than means-tested support.

"Up to three-quarters of a million of the poorest older people do not claim the income support they are entitled to, either for a lack of information or fear of stigma.

"Six months into the £15 million Government campaign to encourage more pensioners to take up income support only 5% have claimed successfully. With these results we cannot be confident that the increased income support will reach the pensioners."

Dr Ian Peters, deputy director general at the British Chamber of Commerce, said: "Easing VAT is imaginative and will help, but much more needs to be done if small firms are to grow and compete. We were not looking for a lot more - the Chancellor did a lot in the last Budget."

And Dr Peters added that the announced tax relief on share options, was "something we have proposed and that is welcome but we need to see something done to help provide incentives for employees in unquoted firms."

Digby Jones, director general of the Confederation of British Industry, said: "These measures will give business a much-needed boost and won't pose a threat to economic stability.

"The Chancellor has responded to concerns about the rising business tax burden, but we have yet to examine the details. He is giving business a platform on which it can create wealth on a socially inclusive basis.

"The fight must continue to make the proposal unanswerable that Britain is the place to invest in a globally mobile world and today's announcement makes a good contribution to that fight."

An AA spokesman said: "Ultra low sulphur petrol [ULSP] is virtually unavailable at the moment, it's not easy to find at all. We aren't convinced at this stage that the industry will be able to produce enough of it. It's not an easy fuel to produce."

A Shell spokesman said: "We will make ULSP available nationwide by the time of the next Budget. There is no such thing as an easy-to-produce fuel but it is something we have just created production capacity for."

Archie Norman , the shadow environment secretary, commenting on the tax changes for urban areas, said: "After three and a half wasted years it is too late for Labour to reclaim their lost credentials.

"Conservatives support tax incentives for development, but Gordon Brown's proposals today are meagre fare for inner cities suffering from cuts in investment over the last three years, rising crime and more homelessness.

"Labour's sixfold failure on the inner cities is testimony to the hypocrisy of a government that has forgotten its roots."

Fuel protesters: the fight continues

webTitle: Sun loses TV news editor

fields.headline: Sun TV news editor joins PR firm
fields.standfirst: Nov 8: Sun man wins Weakest Link
fields.trailText: 4.30pm The Sun TV news editor, Johnathan Plunkett, has quit to take up a new career on the other side of the fence, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
The Sun's TV news editor, Johnathan Plunkett, has quit to take up a new career as a PR.

After just five months in the job, Mr Plunkett handed in his notice to work with PR maestro Brian MacLaurin.

He will be an associate director at MacLaurin, one of the biggest agencies in London, responsible for PR for Chris Tarrant and Andrew Neil.

Ian Monk, director of McLaurin PR said: "We are delighted. We have been chasing him for weeks. His wealth of contacts fits in perfectly with our core media business."

He said Mr Plunkett would be working across the board with clients ranging from Procter & Gamble to Planet 24 and BBC Worldwide.

It is believed that Mr Plunkett and his bosses at the Sun agreed that the TV editor job, which is one of the most important positions on the paper, was not for him.

He will be working out three months' notice.

Sun deputy editor Fergus Shanahan said: "He has resigned and we wish him well in his future career."

There had been speculation that there were clashes between Mr Plunkett and Sun executives over exclusive stories on rival papers.

The 29-year-old reporter was plucked from the relative obscurity of Heat magazine and given the job in June. Prior to that he had worked for Broadcast magazine, where he built up a network of contacts in the TV industry.

However, the move to the biggest selling title in the country was a major step up for Mr Plunkett, who had little newspaper experience.

Mr Plunkett, an Oxford graduate, made the papers himself today as the winner of a journalists-only special edition of The Weakest Link.

webTitle: Pensioners unimpressed with Brown giveaway

fields.headline: Pensioners unimpressed with Brown giveaway
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Pensioners' leaders this evening renewed their calls for the link between the state pension and earnings to be restored following the chancellor's pre-budget statement.
fields.body:
Pensioners' leaders this evening renewed their calls for the link between the state pension and earnings to be restored following the chancellor's pre-budget statement.

Gordon Brown today gave a cash boost to the elderly - raising pensions and increasing the winter allowance. But he rejected the key demand of campaigners to restore the link between earnings and the basic state pension.

The chancellor told the Commons that from next April there would be a cash increase of £5 a week for single pensioners and £8 a week for couples.

The winter allowance - which goes to every pensioner household free of tax - will be raised from £150 to £200 this year. And the minimum income guarantee will rise to £100 a week for single pensioners and to £154 for couples in 2003.

But pensioners must apply for the minimum income guarantee, which is means-tested - leading to frustration and resentment for many.

The national organiser of the National Pensioners Convention, Gary Kitchen, said Mr Brown's announcement would "do nothing to dampen pensioners' anger" . He repeated the call for pensions to be linked to earnings, made in a 1,000-strong lobby at Westminster yesterday.

"If the link with earnings had been maintained, pensions would not be at £97.45," he said. We had hoped for a substantial increase. While the rises are welcome they do not go far enough."

The director general of Age Concern, Gordon Lishman, said: "Most pensioners want a higher basic state pension rather than means-tested support. Up to three quarters of a million of the poorest older people do not claim the income support they are entitled to, either for a lack of information or fear of stigma."

He added: "Six months into the £15m government campaign to encourage more pensioners to take up income support only 5% have claimed successfully. With these results we cannot be confident that the increased income support will reach the pensioners."

fields.bodyText: Pensioners' leaders this evening renewed their calls for the link between the state pension and earnings to be restored following the chancellor's pre-budget statement. Gordon Brown today gave a cash boost to the elderly - raising pensions and increasing the winter allowance. But he rejected the key demand of campaigners to restore the link between earnings and the basic state pension. The chancellor told the Commons that from next April there would be a cash increase of £5 a week for single pensioners and £8 a week for couples. The winter allowance - which goes to every pensioner household free of tax - will be raised from £150 to £200 this year. And the minimum income guarantee will rise to £100 a week for single pensioners and to £154 for couples in 2003. But pensioners must apply for the minimum income guarantee, which is means-tested - leading to frustration and resentment for many. The national organiser of the National Pensioners Convention, Gary Kitchen, said Mr Brown's announcement would "do nothing to dampen pensioners' anger" . He repeated the call for pensions to be linked to earnings, made in a 1,000-strong lobby at Westminster yesterday. The director general of Age Concern, Gordon Lishman, said: "Most pensioners want a higher basic state pension rather than means-tested support. Up to three quarters of a million of the poorest older people do not claim the income support they are entitled to, either for a lack of information or fear of stigma." webTitle: Pensioners and motorists gain from mini-Budget

fields.headline: Pensioners and motorists gain from mini-Budget
fields.standfirst:
Pre-budget statement: the main points
Special report: the Budget

 Freeze on fuel duty
 'Brit disc' tax on foreign lorries on UK roads
 New pension credit will be linked to earnings
 £5 a week extra for single pensioners and £8 a week for couples
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown delivered his "mini-Budget" today which, as anticipated, gave extra cash to pensioners and motorists.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown delivered his "mini-Budget" today which, as anticipated, gave extra cash to pensioners and motorists.

Transport

Mr Brown announced a freeze in fuel duty and a cut of 3p per litre in "green" ultra-low sulphur petrol (ULSP) and diesel, which he said would be available in every garage next year.

Mr Brown told MPs in his pre-budget statement in the Commons: "I recognise and I understand the very genuine concerns of motorists and hauliers."

The chancellor said 1.5p per litre would normally have been added to petrol and diesel from Budget day next year, raising £560m - which he would now forgo by cancelling the planned increase.

He said the move followed a successful experiment with low sulphur diesel which would now be extended to petrol. Mr Brown stressed this was part of the government meeting its environmental obligations, as well as addressing motorists' concerns.

He said he now expected ULSP to make up 100% of the market next year, and after announcing other changes to excise duties said his total package of help to motorists was equivalent to 4p a litre off fuel duty and for hauliers was worth 8p per litre off diesel.

The chancellor's gamble was that his announcements would be enough to head off another fuel blockade like the one in September which crippled fuel supplies. He said that overall his changes on fuel and excise duty for cars and lorries would cost £1bn.

A 'Brit disc' scheme to charge foreign lorries for using British roads because they escape paying Britain's high rates of vehicle excise duty will be introduced, Mr Brown said. Some British lorries will pay £2,000 less in excise duty.

Pensions

In response to pensioners' protests, Mr Brown declared: "I have decided that the transitional arrangements should ensure that over the next two years pensioner incomes should rise faster than inflation and indeed faster than earnings.

"So from next April we propose that for the single pensioner there should be a cash increase of £5-a-week and for a married couple a rise of £8-a-week."

There would be a further rise over the next two years to equal a rise of £8-a-week for a single person and £12.80 for couples.

The economy

Mr Brown also promised to deliver the "lowest direct tax burden for 30 years" for Britain's hard-working families.

He told MPs that he would introduce targeted tax cuts to improve stability, productivity and long-term viability in the British economy.

"We want to see all citizens sharing in rising prosperity," added Mr Brown, with the country achieving American-style productivity rates.

He announced consultations on three major corporation taxes to boost business, dealing with third-party savings taxes and other levies on profits.

But Mr Brown, addressing a packed Commons, stressed: "We will do nothing to put at risk the economic stability that has given this country lower unemployment" and achieved higher investment in public services such as education and health.

A raft of measures to improve the business climate was then announced by Mr Brown, alongside measures to aid savers. The tax-free limit for ISA tax-free accounts was set, for example, at £7,000 instead of £5,000 for the next five years.

Mr Brown also promised a "radical reform" of tax incentives to help businesses start up and grow in inner city areas.

Education

A £200m boost for school building repairs was also announced.

Headteachers will be free to spend the money on things like redecorating classrooms, new boilers or library facilities, Mr Brown said.

It will be handed out directly to many schools in the next few weeks in order to save on red tape, said the Department for Education and Employment.

In September, the education secretary, David Blunkett, announced at the Labour Party Conference that £7.8 billion would be spent on renewing more than 7,500 schools in England.

The money announced today will be going to schools around the UK although most of it - up to £170m - is set to be spent in England.

Other main points:
 Winter allowance up from £150 to £200 this year
 Inflation within 2.5% target
 250,000 young people have moved from welfare to work
 Manufacturing to grow next year by 2% to 2.5%
 Exports to grow next year 7%-7.5%
 Growth next year predicted at 2.25%-2.75%
 Proposals to simplify VAT
 Extra tax relief on share options for e-commerce companies
 "Lowest family tax burden for 30 years"
 ISA's tax free limit up £2000-£3000
 Stamp duty exemption in poor areas
 New Deal available to 150,000 more lone parents
 Government will have £16.6bn surplus this year
 Government forecasts £16bn in 2001-2002
 Government forecasts £16bn for 2002-2003
 Government says debt ratio will drop to 30%
