webTitle: The pre-Budget report

fields.headline: The pre-Budget report
fields.standfirst: Gordon Brown is preparing his fourth pre-Budget report, but what is it and what does it mean? Julian Glover explains
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is preparing his fourth pre-Budget report, but what is it and what does it mean? We explain.
fields.body:
What is the pre-Budget report?
The pre-Budget report is an invention of Gordon Brown's - the first one was given on 26 November 1997 and the latest, the fourth, will be made in the Commons on Wednesday afternoon. The chancellor introduced it as a stepping-stone between full Budgets, given each spring. The statement provides a progress report on what has been achieved so far, gives an update on the state of the economy and the government finances, and sets out the direction of government policy in the run up to the spring Budget.

How does it differ from the Budget?
The Treasury's intention was that the pre-Budget report would be an informal announcement of the long-term things the government planned to do, rather than a specific set of formal policy announcements - that task was left to the Budget. In his first report to the Commons, the chancellor went out of his way to explain that he wanted to hear people disagree with his suggestions. "My aim," he said, "is to begin a national debate on the major economic issues we face. For too long in the past, Britain has lacked a shared sense of common economic purpose. I want to encourage an open discussion of the economic problems we will all have to address and the possible solutions that are open to us to secure our long-term economic future." The government even set up a roadshow afterwards in the hope of sparking a national debate that would shape the spring 1998 Budget.

Did it work out like this?
Not really. In recent years, the pre-Budget report has come to be seen as a second Budget, rather than a broad-brush analysis of long-term economic planning. Ideas such as the roadshow and national debate seem to have gone out of the window.

Why?
Partly because the media treats all the chancellor's announcements as firm policy proposals, meaning he has to take care in the report not to stray from the government's established economic agenda. There is little room for the broad-brush discussion that the chancellor hoped to achieve. And partly, too, because the government has been unwilling to talk about the key long-term economic issue facing Britain - the euro. In the absence of that, the pre-Budget report has been filled with more immediate issues.

So what will this week's report say?
Much of it has been revealed to the press, so the report is unlikely to be a surprise. It will focus on two issues, both of which have been causing the government political problems. The first, the cost of motoring, which led to protests earlier this year, will be addressed by freezing tax increases on petrol and possibly by offering some sort of rebate on vehicle excise duty. The second political issue, the level of the state pension, will probably be addressed by offering pensioners a one-off above inflation rise in the state pension of £5 a week.

Will these moves be popular?
Yes - but it is not clear whether they will be enough to silence protests. Pensioners want their pensions to be linked to the national rise in earnings and drivers want fuel taxes to be cut, rather than simply frozen. The government's willingness to meet both sets of demands halfway may not be the end of the story.

webTitle: The chancellor's statement, part 1: the economy

fields.headline: The chancellor's statement, part 1: the economy
fields.standfirst: Statement by the Chancellor of the Exchequer on the Pre-Budget Report on Wednesday 8 November 2000
fields.trailText: In 1997 Britain had rising inflation, a deficit of 28 billion pounds, a national debt that had doubled and was at risk of repeating the old familiar stop go cycle.
fields.body:
In 1997 Britain had rising inflation, a deficit of 28 billion pounds, a national debt that had doubled and was at risk of repeating the old familiar stop go cycle.

So, in this Pre-Budget Report - which will address specific and immediate concerns - we will do nothing to put at risk the economic stability that has given us the lowest unemployment for 20 years, the lowest inflation for 30 years, mortgages 4 per cent - 1,000 pounds - below the average of the previous 20 years, and a Budget discipline that has enabled us to cut borrowing and now invest more every year in hospitals, schools and public services.

And this hard-won and newly-won stability now gives Britain an opportunity we can either seize or squander - the opportunity to achieve high and sustained levels of productivity growth, and so ensure long term prosperity not just for some but for all.

Yet every time the British economy has started to grow - as in the 1980s - Governments have taken short-term decisions on tax and spending which have put inflation, interest rates and economic stability at risk.

So, Britain has a choice - the choice that underlies this Pre-Budget Report.

The risk for Britain is to repeat the 80s' mistake of taking economic strength for granted even when we still have a large productivity gap with our competitors and trying to run the economy at a capacity not yet achieved. Our choice - the choice of the Pre-Budget Report - is that we build economic strength by investing and through tax incentives encouraging a new generation of entrepreneurs.

The risk for Britain is a repeat of the late 80s' mistake - claiming a surplus one year could fund tax cuts for every year and - by committing in tax what was yet to be earned - stoking up an unsustainable consumer boom, forcing interest and mortgage rates to rise. We will take no risks with stability. Our choice - the choice of the Pre-Budget Report - is to lock in stability by - as I will announce today - prudently cutting debt and debt interest payments to keep inflation and interest rates low.

The risk for Britain would be to cut investment in education and our infrastructure and perpetuate decades of neglect and undermine our economy. This Pre-Budget Report makes a different choice: to move forward with our three year spending plans that will double public investment - from education and health, to transport, policing, and the environment - and by continuing to cut both debt interest and unemployment, combining public spending with targeted tax cuts to do more for pensioners and, as I will show, give families the lowest direct tax burden for 30 years.

So, this Pre-Budget Statement sets out a balanced approach - first stability and prudence to keep interest rates low, second tackling under-investment and then, when it is affordable to do so, targeted tax cuts for the Nation's priorities.

Let me turn first to the forecasts for the economy.

Since 1997 our first and most fundamental economic choice has been, through Bank of England independence, tough controls on public spending and difficult decisions on tax, to build economic stability.

There were those in this House who predicted our policies would bring recession. I can report to the House that this year:

 inflation is meeting its 2.5 per cent target;

 long term interest rates are around the lowest for 30 years, the same as those in Germany and lower than America;

I can also report that the economy is forecast to grow by 3 per cent this year:

 manufacturing - despite its difficulties - by one and a quarter per cent and exports growing by eight per cent;

 consumer demand growing by 3.5 per cent with living standards rising;

 and business investment which has grown by 1.5 per cent as we lock in a higher level of investment as a share of our economy, 14.5 per cent, than at any time in 40 years, a bigger share of our economy than of the American economy;

 and in total, fixed investment has this year grown by two and a half per cent;

 with 1.1 million more men and women in work than in 1997, Britain now has the lowest unemployment since 1979, the lowest long term unemployment since 1978, the lowest youth unemployment since 1975;

 the highest employment ever among women;

 unemployment now lower in every region. With today one million vacancies spread across the country.

And this month we plan to reach our promised target: 250,000 young people from Welfare to Work.

And it is precisely because we have taken the trouble to build the long term foundation for success, and precisely because we have resisted short termism that would threaten stability in interest rates that I can report that, even in times of uncertainty for the world economy over oil prices and exchange rates, the Treasury forecast for next year is that:

 inflation will meet its target of 2.5 per cent;

 manufacturing will grow by between two and two and a quarter per cent;

 exports will grow by between 7 and 7.5 per cent;

 growth will range from two and a quarter to two and three quarter per cent;

 consumer demand will grow by two and a quarter to two and a half per cent;

 business investment by 1.5 to 2 per cent; and

 total investment by four and a quarter to four and a half per cent.

There were those who predicted our public spending plans would lead to higher inflation and that the economy would run out of control:

 between 1979 and 1997 inflation averaged 6.2 per cent;

 since 1997 it has been less than half as much - 2.4 per cent;

 interest rates from 1979 averaged 10 per cent. Since 1997 6 per cent;

 mortgage rates from 1979, 11 per cent. Since 1997 mortgage rates an average of 7 per cent;

Growth from 1979 averaged 2 per cent. Since 1997 it has been 2.7 per cent.

So we have steered a course of stability, but we are not satisfied. Long term prosperity for all is our objective, achieving, in this decade, full employment, higher education for the majority of young people, sustained improvements in our public services and with an end to child and pensioner poverty, not just some, but all citizens sharing in rising prosperity.

And long term prosperity for all depends upon us reaching American levels of productivity growth - and on removing the barriers - by tackling under-investment, skill deficiencies, resistance to new technology and restrictive practices wherever they arise: building a stronger enterprise culture open to all.

So, today, as part of the Government's contribution to a new and necessary drive for higher productivity, I am proposing to encourage entrepreneurship and expand investment.

To make Britain the best place in the world for multinationals to locate, we will build upon our cut in corporation tax from 33p to 30p - the lowest of all major countries, the lowest in our history - by consulting on three major changes:

 to abolish from April 2001 the withholding tax, not only on international bonds, but normally on payments of interest and royalties between companies in the UK;

 to relieve tax on sales of substantial shareholdings by companies;

 and in line with the needs of the new economy, tax relief for intellectual property and goodwill, as we create the best modern environment for business in the world.

I can tell the House that this year corporation tax revenues are 2.5 billion pounds lower than forecast.

While it has been put to me that North Sea oil companies, earning higher profits from higher oil prices should be subject to special taxes, I can tell the House that I am determined not to make short term decisions based on short term factors. The key issue is the level of long term investment in the North Sea. And this will be the approach that will guide budget decisions in future.

My second set of proposals help small businesses whose numbers have grown already by 150,000 since 1997. Last year we cut small company corporation tax - once 23p - to 20p and introduced a new 10p rate, an overall cut in small company tax bills of nearly 25 per cent. Today I am publishing for consultation with small businesses a set of proposals that simplify small business VAT and are of direct help to up to half a million small businesses.

Capital allowances and tax credits to encourage investment have already saved over 800 million pounds to business since 1997, a third of a billion pounds to manufacturing.

Because I understand the importance of manufacturing I will now examine, for the Budget, further incentives that help manufacturing: in particular the proposals from the CBI and EEF to extend the R and D tax credit.

To help smaller high risk and e commerce companies recruit and retain the staff they need, we propose to expand tax relief for share options and make Britain the most attractive environment for e commerce.  stamp duty exemption for all properties in our most disadvantaged communities;

 accelerated tax relief for cleaning up contaminated land;

 VAT cuts to reduce the costs of residential property conversions;

 tax relief to bring empty flats over shops back into use.

And to consult on:

 further business rate relief for small business in assisted areas;

 a new and generous tax credit for community investment;

 the creation of the first Community Development Venture Fund.

The Secretary of State for Education and Employment and I will:

 intensify coaching help for the 50,000 young people still out of work;

 consult on introducing a new service that will help redundant workers move quickly into new jobs;

 investigate how with tax free and in some cases free adult learning we can help upgrade fast changing workforce skills;

 extend the New Deal for lone parents with our nationwide programme of choices starting next April and extend to a further 150,000 lone parents not on income support the opportunity to get back to work;

 agree a new partnership with the voluntary sector to help those with disabilities who want work to get it, while with a 200 million a year additional package that the Secretary for Social Security will announce tomorrow improving the living standards of those unable to work and carers;

 and for each area drawing up local full employment plans addressing all barriers to full employment in their local areas.

webTitle: The chancellor's statement, part 3: families and pensioners

fields.headline: The chancellor's statement, part 3: families and pensioners
fields.trailText: I turn now to specific measures of benefit to families and to pensioners.
fields.body:
I turn now to specific measures of benefit to families and to pensioners.

Mr Speaker, our aim is that not just some, but every child has the best start in life and that we halve child poverty in the coming decade.

Families need help most at the time when parents are bringing up their children. And as we extend our new integrated system of child support -from 15 pounds a week child benefit for every child to a maximum of 50 pounds - our priority in the coming Budget is the new children's tax credit, a tax cut for families.

This family tax cut, which replaces married couples allowance, will be paid on top of child benefit to around 5 million families at 8.50 pounds a week, worth 442 pounds a year.

On current figures the proposals on which we are consulting would, if implemented, mean that overall the tax burden would not rise next year and I will achieve my aim of next year cutting the direct tax burden on the typical family below 20 per cent. It will fall from 20.3 to 18.6 per cent, the lowest level since 1972.

But I believe in the coming Budget we can offer a larger tax cut for families. My aim is to increase the family tax cut to 10 pounds a week, in total a 520 pound a year tax cut, increasing families' incomes.

And just as we are introducing a new system of child support based on the foundation of child benefit - but at the heart of which is the new working families tax credit - so too it is now time, based on the same principle, to raise pensioner incomes by a tax and benefit reform that will have as its foundation the basic state pension, and will have as an essential building block - like the working families tax credit - a new and generous pension credit.

Our aim for pensions reform is both to end pensioner poverty and to ensure that all pensioners share in the rising prosperity of the nation.

But in a new world of rapidly diverging pensioners' incomes - already 17 per cent of couples are retiring on more than 20,000 pounds a year, and this percentage grows year on year - and where, as a result, inequalities between pensioner incomes are as great as inequalities within the population as a whole - we will best meet our obligations to pensioners by a new approach.

To plan for the future based on a flat rate earnings-linked rise paid to all, which would give exactly the same to those with incomes above 20,000 pounds as to those on middle incomes - and because the income support system would do absolutely nothing for the poorest - would mean that by the time today's 45 year olds were retiring, for every 6 billion pounds extra spent on an earnings link, 2 billion pounds went to pensioners with incomes above 20,000 pounds at today's prices, thus meaning less is available for the middle and lower income pensioners, who are our first priority.

So, we need a policy that does most for those who need most and at the same time ensures that all pensioners - the very poor, those on modest incomes and the relatively comfortable - share in the rising prosperity of the nation.

Let me tell the House what the new system, which will integrate tax and benefits and build upon the basic pension a new pension credit will look like in 2003, and then I will set out the transitional arrangements.

First, for those in and at risk of poverty, we will radically improve the minimum income guarantee.

I can tell the House that the minimum income guarantee, which was 68.80 pounds in 1997, is 78.45 pounds today, and will be raised in April by 14 pounds to 92.15 pounds. For thousands of our poorest pensioners, 700 pounds extra a year.

I can also tell the House today that when the new system is introduced in April 2003, the minimum income guarantee will be set not at 92 pounds, but at 100 pounds a week, 22 pounds a week more than today. For the first time a single pensioner guaranteed at least a 100 pounds a week. And for couples a rise from 106.60 pounds in 1997 to 154 pounds.

And every year after that I can tell the House that the minimum income guarantee will be raised in line with earnings.

With the winter allowance a 32 per cent increase in income even after inflation - demonstrating our determination that no pensioner is left behind as this Government works to ensure that pensioner poverty is a thing of the past.

More than 2 million will benefit. People will be able to claim by phone. They will do so at the point of retirement and whatever adjustments thereafter would need to be made only when circumstances change.

But we have a second obligation - to millions of pensioners who, after a lifetime of hard work, have modest occupational pensions and modest savings, but receive nothing from the system on top of their basic pension and have until now been penalised, not rewarded for their savings. People whom we meet every week in our constituencies - and this Government is determined that people who have worked hard and saved all their lives should now receive more.

Tomorrow the Secretary of State for Social Security's statement will outline the new integrated tax and benefit system - both the pension credit and the new pensioner tax arrangements.

I said in the budget that I wanted the beneficiaries of the new credit to be single pensioners with incomes up to £100 and pensioner couples with incomes up to £150.

I can now tell the House that pensioner couples with incomes below 200 pounds, and single pensioners with income below 135 pounds , many millions of pensioners, will receive the new pension credit.

And I can tell the House that while the pension will rise in line with inflation, the new pension credit will itself rise in line with earnings every year.

In this way, we will give recipients of the pension credit more than even the earnings link in the basic state pension would give them.

The pensioners tax allowance will be set at April 2003 at an even higher level - 6,560 pounds for the single pensioner - and for the next parliament we propose the pensioners tax allowance also rises in line with earnings.

For the vast majority of pensioners, the middle and low income pensioners of Britain, the new system will provide extra cash on top of the basic pension: sums of between one pound and 23 pounds a week.

Achieving all our aims:

 for millions of the neediest pensioners relief from poverty;

 for those on modest incomes a reward for their savings and occupational pensions more than an earning link could offer them;

 and ensuring that all pensioners can enjoy a share in the rising standards of living of the country.

As we move to this new and better system the Social Security Secretary and I have decided that the transitional arrangements should ensure that over the next two years, pensioner incomes should rise faster than inflation and indeed faster than earnings.

So from April next year we propose that for the single pensioner there should be a cash increase of 5 pounds a week and for a married couple a rise of 8 pounds a week.

And I can tell the House that the following year we can also guarantee the pension will rise well above prices. There will be a cash increase of 3 pounds for single pensioners and 4.80 pounds for married couples.

Over two years, a cash rise of 8 pounds a week for single pensioners and 12.80 pounds a week for couples.

For pensions 2.6 billion pounds more each year, on top of more for health, education, transport policing and public services.

Mr Speaker, those who would spend this money on tax-cutting should now tell us which hospitals, which schools, which public services they would cut.

We have made our choice

Investment,

Targeted tax cuts.

Keeping mortgage rates low

More for pensions and families.

A stronger, fairer Britain.

Mr Speaker, I have one final announcement.

I have had representations to abolish the winter fuel allowance and indeed abolish the free TV licence for over 75s. I have even received representations to abolish the Christmas bonus.

I have rejected such options that would give with one hand and take with another.

I can confirm that now and in future years the free TV licences will remain for the over 75s as we have promised.

The Christmas bonus will continue and the winter allowance will be paid at 150 pounds.

But the transitional arrangements to our new pension reform will not start next year, but can start this year, indeed they will start this week.

I can confirm that cheques are being sent out from Monday that will be paid to every pensioner household in Britain.

The winter allowance will not be paid at 150 pounds this year.

Nor will it be abolished.

For this year specially - the first year of the transitional arrangements - it will be paid not at 150 pounds, but at 200 pounds to every pensioner household free of tax.

And I commend this statement to the House.

Part 2: the fiscal stance

webTitle: The chancellor's statement, part 2: the fiscal stance

fields.headline: The chancellor's statement, part 2: the fiscal stance
fields.trailText: Mr Speaker, high productivity and rising employment depend not just on ending decades of under-investment and targeting tax incentives on our priorities, but on entrenching a low inflation culture that prudently keeps interest rates and mortgage rates as low as possible.
fields.body:
Mr Speaker, high productivity and rising employment depend not just on ending decades of under-investment and targeting tax incentives on our priorities, but on entrenching a low inflation culture that prudently keeps interest rates and mortgage rates as low as possible.

It is because we have learned from the mistakes of the eighties and before that I can tell the House that - in spite of demands made to me - I have decided - in the interests of keeping interest rates and mortgage rates as low as possible - to lock in, over the coming years, a fiscal stance that is the same or is tighter than we said at the time of the Budget.

Let me give the House the background and the full financial figures.

Our first fiscal rule - the golden rule, the first rule necessary to keep interest rates and mortgage rates as low as possible - is that over the cycle there must be a current surplus. So however tempting it may be for some to identify large temporary surpluses as an excuse for permanent injections of resources into the economy, our golden rule demands constant prudence.

In the Budget I forecast this year's current surplus at 14 billion pounds. I now forecast this surplus to be 16.6 billion pounds, and in the years from 2001-2, the current surpluses are forecast to be 16, 14, 8, and 8. Figures that ensure we remain on course to balance the current Budget over the economic cycle, even on the most cautious of cases.

Our second fiscal rule - the sustainable investment rule, a bulwark against short termism that again helps keep interest rates and mortgage rates as low as possible - is that while, over the cycle, we will borrow for investment, we do not borrow for consumption and we keep debt at a prudent and sustainable level below 40 per cent of national income.

After a doubling of national debt in the early 1990s the ratio of debt to national income had, by 1997, risen to 44 per cent.

Having made the necessary difficult tax and spending decisions, we have, in the three years since 1997, reduced the ratio of debt to national income from 44 per cent to 41.9 per cent to 39.6 and 36.8 per cent this April.

I can report to this House that two decisions - first, the decision to use the proceeds from the spectrum auction to reduce our debt and second, to use this year's surplus to repay debt - now make possible a further and even more substantial reduction in debt that will keep interest payments low.

Because we are, in total, cutting the stock of debt by as much as one third, I can report to the house that the public sector net debt as a share of GDP will now fall from 36.8 per cent last year to 32.3 per cent this year to 30.9 per cent in 2001-2 and from what was a debt to GDP ratio as high as 44 per cent in 1997, I can report that this ratio is forecast to fall to 30 per cent and remain there in future years.

And with long term interest rates lower and debt well within the 40 per cent ceiling, we are not only well placed to deal with the ups and downs of the economic cycle but have the best platform for years for sustained long term growth

Our budget forecast for net borrowing was a surplus of 6.5 billion pounds this year. We now forecast the surplus to be 10 billion pounds this year, and 6 billion next. In future years the deficits will be 1, 10, 12 and 13 as we borrow to invest.

Mr Speaker, in every one of the next five years, adjusting for the cycle a fiscal stance that is the same or is tighter than at the time of the budget.

And this year, with the spectrum proceeds, the net cash debt repayment will be 28 billion pounds.

So our approach is to reject the old vicious circle of the eighties - rising debt, higher long term interest rates, higher debt repayment costs, lower growth, higher unemployment and enforced cuts in public spending, the old boom and bust.

Instead, as we promised, we have by our decisions created a virtuous circle of falling debt, lower long term interest rates, lower unemployment, lower debt payments and a stronger economy releasing more resources for public spending.

I can report to the House that because of this virtuous circle, lower unemployment has brought savings in social security which, compared with the Budget, provide an additional 1.5 billion pounds next year, and 2 and 2.5 billion pounds in future years.

And in addition to higher government revenues this year from higher employment, higher earnings growth and steady growth, debt interest payments are now lower than we forecast at the time of the Budget - by 2.5 billion pounds next year and 2 billion pounds in the next two years.

When we came into Government we were paying out more in debt interest payments than we were spending on our schools. Soon, as a result of cutting debt payments, we will be able to spend fifty per cent more on our schools than we do on debt interest.

Over the last twenty years, 42 pence of every additional pound spent went to debt interest and social security. In the early nineties it was 50 per cent of every pound.

Debt and social security will require now only 17 pence of every pound - leaving more than 80 pence in every pound of additional spending for hospitals, schools and vital services, enabling us to tackle the long term under-investment in Britain.

It is therefore because we have cut the cost of debt and unemployment - now costing 5 billion pounds less than in 1997 - and because we have also secured sustainable growth that we are able to lock in a fiscal tightening, meet all our fiscal rules, and, within this prudent framework, we are in an even stronger position than in July to tackle under-investment and target tax cuts on our nation's priorities.

Since July I have received representations from people in this House about public spending, including representations which propose spending growth only in line with 2 per cent GDP growth a year. I have studied this proposal in detail. It would mean by year three, cuts in spending of 16 billion pounds and after taking into account the measures I will announce on pensions today, more than 16 billion pounds.

I have rejected these representations and because the economy both needs and can afford - and cannot afford not to -to tackle long term under investment, the Education Secretary will tomorrow, as part of allocating his annual 5 per cent real term increase in education every year, announce resources for the new learning and skills council.

And because investment is needed in our infrastructure not just for social reasons but to build economic strength the Minister for Transport will announce how every region city and town will benefit from new investment in roads, and with new funds from the spending review allocated to each region for economic regeneration the Deputy Prime Minister will shortly publish his rural and urban white papers.

As part of the 5.6 per cent real term's rise in NHS spending each year for the next 3 years, the Secretary of State for Health will announce for each of the next three years his allocations to health authorities up to 2004.

And in addition to the statement on pensions from my Rt Hon Friend the Secretary of State for Social Security tomorrow, and the extra allocation we have made to improve flood defences, my Rt Hon Friend the Secretary of State for Education is announcing today additional allocations to our schools.

The windfall tax is money raised from the utilities specifically for the purpose of extending employment opportunity through the New Deal and educational opportunity, renovating so far 17,000 schools. Such has been the success of the New Deal in getting people back to work that the windfall levy account is underspent by 200 million. So the Secretary of State for Education and Employment and I have decided that, in addition to the rise in education spending this year, lower unemployment means we can allocate new money for every school in every constituency of the country, money to be available this year for repairs and improvements, money to be paid direct to the school.

The head teacher of every primary school will receive a cheque for between 4,000 and 7,000 pounds.

The head teacher of each secondary school, will receive, for the smaller schools 10,000 pounds; for the larger schools 30,000 pounds: prudence once again for a purpose - enabling us to target resources to our priorities and in a sustainable way.

And this prudence also allows us now to match public spending increases by tax cuts targeted on the country's priorities, including making reforms in the tax treatment of transport and the environment - to which I now turn.

Between 1997 and 1999 retaining the fuel escalator introduced in 1993 helped cut borrowing by 30 billion pounds, helping deliver lower interest rates - and enabling us to begin the long overdue investment in transport, the NHS, and schools. And it will have brought about a cut in carbon dioxide pollution by an estimated one to two and a half million tonnes a year by 2010.

But today, like all countries, we are having to deal with the rise in world oil prices from 11 to 31 dollars. Because OPEC itself accepts that the world price is unacceptably high, our international efforts are geared to ensuring that production is raised and prices fall.

So I recognise and understand the very genuine concerns that motorists and hauliers have - and it is because here in Britain we have already cut the deficit, already set aside 180 billions for the 10 year transport plan and already shown how we are meeting the Kyoto targets that in the last Budget I removed the fuel escalator, and made environmentally based cuts in car and lorry licences and gave new incentives for environmentally efficient fuels.

And in line with the principles we have set down I am now able today to show how we can complete these reforms and do more to meet people's concerns - without putting at risk either our economic stability, necessary investment in public services, or our environmental gains. Indeed, the reforms I now propose are tailor-made to meet our environmental obligations.

I propose at a cost of 560 million pounds, a freeze in excise duties - an across-the-board duty freeze on all fuels that would initially last until April 2002-- and, if the oil price remains at a high price between now and then, I can tell the house that there would be a duty freeze for a further year.

I intend to go further in three vital respects.

On top of the duty freeze - budgeted for in our fiscal arithmetic - the first of the proposals I will consult upon would itself involve additional expenditure of as much as an extra 1,000 million pounds and help promote substantial benefit to the environment .

Yesterday we published a report showing the environmental benefits from the introduction of ultra low sulphur diesel in reducing local air pollution.

As a result of cuts we made in excise duty on ultra low sulphur diesel, usage in Britain has risen from 20 per cent in 1997 to 40 per cent in 1998 to 100 per cent in 2000. On 1 October we reduced the duty on ultra low sulphur petrol by 1p a litre.

I propose from Budget 2001 a further reduction of 2p a litre - making a cut of 3p in total on all ultra low sulphur petrol.

It is by giving this incentive for cleaner fuels that we can both advance our environmental principles and ensure - with a 3p cut per litre in all ultra low sulphur duty a cheaper cleaner fuel available in every garage, a better deal for drivers and cleaner air across Britain.

I can also announce that for all the cars which still use lead replacement petrol - where there is no longer an environmental case for a higher duty rate - I propose from Budget day to end the differential and cut the excise duty by 2p per litre.

I propose support for scrapping or converting older lorries with a 100 million investment fund, including help for buying the new lorries that meet the highest technological and environment standards and support for the introduction of logistics and computerisation.

The Deputy Prime Minister will also announce help for an industry-wide training and retraining scheme.

But we can do more.

So that foreign lorries pay their share of the costs of using our roads, we intend to introduce in Britain a vignette system, a British disc under which non-British companies and lorries pay their share to Britain for using British roads.

The Government has considered an essential user rebate or blue diesel scheme for lorry diesel.

Such a scheme would be administratively cumbersome, could be levied only on future purchases of diesel, and would have to be opened to foreign lorries using British roads. It would not help hauliers where their fuel prices are directly passed on to customers. It would have no environmental benefits

The scheme I am proposing is far better. Subject to consultation and legal clearance I now propose to bring forward a much needed reform begun last year in vehicle excise duty for lorries that will radically cut rates for larger lorries with traditionally high license fees,. The scheme will be implemented in Budget 2001 - to sweep aside the 100 separate rates, consolidate them into only seven rate bands , linked to environmental standards, and cutting the rates to match the lowest in Europe.

Over 250,000 lorries will each pay lower licence fees as a result of a 300 million pound annual cut in licence fees. 100,000 lorries will save over 1,000. The average saving per lorry will be 715 a year and the cuts are the equivalent in value to a cut of 3 pence in the price of diesel for the haulage industry, and again with environmental incentives built in.

Our proposals for the detailed new scheme - and license rates-- are published today and the Government is able to start the transitional arrangements to this new licence system immediately.

I have allocated 265 million pounds for this financial year - half of the annual revenue raised from lorry VED - to be spend before March for a refund scheme that can repay lorry owners up to half of this year's licence fee. 250,000 lorries, and all large lorries, will benefit from the refunds. They will be worth for some of the largest lorries paying the highest fees 1,000 and up to 4,000 pounds this year . Refunds will be paid from next month, payments to be completed by the end of January - the detailed arrangements to be announced by the Minister for Transport.

To help restructuring and investment in farming, the Minister for Agriculture announced last week an addition to this year's 220 million pound package of measures - agri money compensation for arable producers. In addition to freezing duty on red diesel at its current rate of 3p a litre, I also intend in Budget 2001 to abolish VED on tractors and agricultural vehicles completely.

I now have a similar proposal for car license fees. Consistent with our environmental principle that we tax vehicle ownership less, I want now to complete our environmentally based reform of vehicle excise duty for cars .

The new licence fee we are introducing for new cars registered from March 2001 is linked to environmental efficiency.

For all cars under 1200 cc there is also now a lower rate licence fee with a 55 pound deduction on the standard licence.

While this change has been welcomed, many, especially those in rural areas, have put it to me that greater choice would be available to rural motorists and motorists generally if the 55 pound deduction could be accessible for, not just cars under 1200 cc, but for cars up to 1500 ccs, including, for example, the Focus, Golf, Astra, Escort and the Rover 214.

So I propose to extend the lower rate licence fee, the 55 pound discount, to cars up to 1500 cc, to be paid out from July but to be backdated from today. So all those who have a car from 1200 to 1500 cc -an extra 5.4 million cars-will be entitled to 55 pound off their annual licence fee from today.

So in total, over 8.5 million existing cars, one in every three, will now pay 55 pounds below the standard fee.

So, for motorists as a whole, with the duty freeze, the new reduced licence fee and the cut for ultra low sulphur petrol, the proposed Budget package makes changes worth the equivalent of a 4p a litre cut while meeting our environmental objectives.

And by next year for the haulage industry changes that are worth the equivalent of a cut of 8 pence on a litre: in each case meeting our environmental obligations, not putting at risk public investment in vital services, nor the stability of the economy. Measures upon which Ministers are now inviting discussion in the Pre-Budget consultation which will take place as Ministers visit every region of the country.

webTitle: Florida recount as election hangs on knife edge

fields.headline: Florida recount as election hangs on knife edge
fields.standfirst:
Special report: US election race

 Result delayed until tomorrow
 Automatic recount in key state
 Gore will not concede defeat
 Gore leads popular vote
fields.trailText:
Automatic recount in Florida
 Gore will not concede defeat
 Gore leads popular vote
Special report: US election race
fields.body:
The Democratic candidate, Al Gore, refused to concede defeat to his Republican rival, George W Bush, today as the closeness of the crucial vote in Florida triggered an automatic recount in the state.

Election officials in Florida were ordered to begin a recount of nearly 6m votes in the stunningly close election for US president after the margin between George W Bush and Al Gore shrank through the night.

The final result is not expected until tomorrow at the earliest - although it may possibly be delayed by legal challenges.

Florida's secretary of state said the recount should be finished by the end of the day tomorrow (Florida is five hours behind Britain). Both national parties were sending teams of lawyers to monitor the recount. At last count, Mr Bush led Mr Gore by 1,655 votes in an unofficial Associated Press count with an unknown number of absentee ballots yet to be counted.

Mr Gore and Mr Bush were tied at 48% apiece in the national vote today. The pressure on the recount is intense because Florida, with its 25 electoral votes, is the state that will decide who becomes 43rd president of the United States.

With the vote difference less than 0.5% an automatic recount was triggered under state law.

The law allows 10 days to count outstanding overseas ballots as long as they are postmarked no later than election day.

In the 538-seat national electoral college - which decides the election - Mr Gore had 260 votes and Mr Bush 246 of the 270 needed to win. Florida has 25 electoral votes, so the winner of that state will capture the presidency. The remaining seven votes come from Oregon.

In the United States as a whole, the popular vote count was seesawing. The overall vote at 2.45pm GMT was:

webTitle: LWT's Lythgoe wooed by Carlton

fields.headline: LWT's Lythgoe wooed by Carlton
fields.trailText: 5pm: LWT's Nigel Lythgoe, the man behind top ITV stars including Cilla Black and Michael Barrymore, is being lured away by arch-rival Carlton. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The man behind ITV's biggest stars, including Cilla Black and Michael Barrymore, is being lured away from London Weekend Television for six months.

Nigel Lythgoe, one of LWT's most senior executives, is being headhunted by arch-rival Carlton to oversee the production of the UK version of smash hit US reality show Survive!.

Sources claim that Carlton-owned production company Planet 24, which is making the show, made the approach. But talks could collapse because LWT has asked for massive financial compensation, possibly running to as much as £200,000

LWT chiefs want to cover the cost of a half-year salary, bonus payments and pension, according to well-informed insiders.

"Nigel is one of our most senior executives. He does not come cheaply," said one source.

Lord Alli, who runs Planet 24, is still hoping, however, that he can prise Mr Lythgoe away from LWT on secondment.

It is believed that ITV network centre bosses also want Mr Lythgoe to oversee the high-profile project, which will be filmed off Malaysia.

The programme will be one of the most important in next year's schedule - in America it was the only show to challenge the might of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? - and ITV programming director David Liddiment is determined that a safe pair of hands oversees the production.

However, bosses at LWT parent group Granada are also worried that Mr Lythgoe's absence would leave its entertainment department leaderless and vulnerable at a time when Saturday night shows are coming under increasing pressure.

LWT has long been the powerhouse of Saturday night entertainment and Mr Lythgoe has been an important player. He has been responsible for Blind Date, Moment of Truth and Barrymore.

The move is part of a concerted attempt by Carlton and Granada to work closer together.

webTitle: Profile: Mr Black Gay UK

fields.headline: Silent pride
fields.standfirst: The first Mr Black Gay UK, Stephen Anglin, tells Emma Lindsey about prejudice in his community
fields.trailText: The first Mr Black Gay UK, Stephen Anglin, tells Emma Lindsey about prejudice in his community.
fields.body:
Stephen Anglin is Britain's first Mr Black Gay UK, but he can't tell his family because they haven't spoken to him in seven years. By day, 33-year-old Anglin is a photo-lab technician, but his nights used to be spent in secrecy until finally he decided to tell his mother the truth.

"I thought, 'I'm not going to hide it any more', and since me and my mum were so close, I didn't think it would make any difference," he says. "I've never been in trouble, my mum never had the police knocking at her door, but she just couldn't accept it."

Anglin later learned, from his twin brother, that their mother no longer considers him her son. He confides: "The thing that stops me from going to see her is the fear that she would slam the door in my face. The rejection would be too much."

With the likes of Julian Clary and Graham Norton on our television screens, gay pride marches on the streets, and the assimilation of camp culture into the mainstream, it might seem that being "out and proud" is no big deal. Maybe not in middle class, white communities.

But in the black community, it remains a massive taboo. Homosexuality is viewed as "the white man's disease" which sufferers should keep to themselves. Being gay and what's worse, being out, just isn't done in the black community.

Growing up in Dalston, east London, Anglin had to get used to it. "Some people actually refuse to recognise that gay people exist because they think it is so unnatural," he says. "But what is normal? I knew I was gay from the age of six, although I didn't know the word for it. I just felt different from the other boys. I never liked playing rough games like football and I was more comfortable playing with girls - I just fitted in better with them."

If anti-gay sentiment is strong among black people in Britain, in Jamaica, where Anglin's family is from, gay men or "batty men" live in secret or deal with the violent consequences of being open. Anglin recalls: "In Jamaica, you would get gunmen storming parties where gay people were. I will never put a foot in that country again. I would have to pretend to be straight, and it has taken me such a long time to come to terms with my sexuality there is no way I would want to go back to hiding."

Strongly-held religious beliefs and different cultural mores are the main reasons for this stance. Many argue that there is nothing wrong with it: rather, it is the "normalisation" of homosexuality in society which is the problem; and, further, promoting it in the form of staging awards ceremonies such as Mr Black Gay UK, serves no useful purpose. Patrick Salami, director of the sexual health charity, Blackliners, which ran the award scheme, disagrees.

"The point of the event was to shift this issue into the arena for debate," says Salami. "I am concerned about the number of young black men who are confused about their sexuality, but have no one to talk to because of the degree of hostility towards homosexuality within the black community.

"The fact is that gay black men do exist and always have done. There is no good to be gained from pretending it isn't so. Anything that is kept under wraps has the potential to do damage. Once things are out in the open, it is easier for people to accept. Families and individuals need to face reality and start a debate about how we deal with this issue in our community and what are the best ways to go forward."

Blackliners began life 10 years ago as a telephone helpline. Without it, Anglin says, he would have been lost at a time when he was wrestling with what being openly gay would mean for him.

"There are a lot more gay black men around than people could ever imagine, but they won't come out. The black community being the way it is, it's easy to get pushed into a corner, into doing what everyone else does. I've been to a gay club on a Friday night and the next day, seen the same guy who was dancing the night before, walking in Brixton with his girlfriend and pushing a pram," he says.

For Anglin, getting to the point where he can feel accepted within the black community is still a long way off. "If I could turn back the clock and I knew everything that would happen as a result of my coming out, I would do the same thing again. It has made me a stronger person. You have to be allowed to be who you are - it is a basic human right. I am part of the new generation. I am proud to be black and I am proud to be gay."

webTitle: Udate dating agency launches in the UK

fields.headline: Udate dating agency launches in the UK
fields.trailText: UK online dating agency Udate is planning a £2m assault on the UK market, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
A UK online dating agency that chose to locate its business in the US to evade crippling start-up costs, now plans a £2m assault on the UK market.

Udate.co.uk had its official UK launch last night although the founders already claim to have more than 100,000 members in the UK.

The company, which is listed on Nasdaq, has been operating for around 18 months in the US and is about to pass its 1 millionth member.

Membership in the UK costs from £5.95 for a ten-day membership to £22.95 for a two-month Gold membership. Subscriptions account for some 85% of Udate's revenues.

According to Udate president and ceo Mel Morris, Udate will reach profitability in the first quarter of next year.

He said Udate's figures showed it was one of the stickiest websites on the internet, with users spending an average of between 1-4 hours a day on the site.

Udate is aimed primarily at an audience of over-25s and enjoys a position at the top end of the US dating industry. Competitors include Matchmaker and Match.com.

"We offer a very different type of service. Members keep coming back to Udate because there is a strong feel-good factor on the site - we're about quality not quantity," said Mr Morris.

In the UK, Udate hopes to pull in up to 1,000 new members a day on the back of word of mouth and 'real world' events such as social evenings, vacations and various gatherings.

Mr Morris said that while the company's head office is in Derby, it saved almost £3m over 18 months by locating its ISP and server in the US.

webTitle: Rangers 2 - 2 Monaco

fields.headline: Simone steals Rangers glory
fields.standfirst:
Miller 3, Mols 52 | Da Costa 38, Simone 78
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Monaco's Marco Simone ended Rangers hopes of progressing to the next stage as Sturm Graz played out a 2-2 draw with Galatasaray too ensure it is these two teams that make the leap from Group D.
fields.body:
Rangers were quite cruelly ejected from the Champions League last night. Monaco, twice behind, on both occasions barged their way back, although on the second occasion Rangers more or less posted their own death notice.

Lorenzo Amoruso, their preposterously flawed captain, was robbed of the ball 20 yards in front of his own penalty area as he foolishly marauded upfield with his team in front. French players stormed the big Italian before laying the ball into the path of Marco Simone, whose finish flew beneath the body of Jesper Christiansen, the Rangers goalkeeper.

It would be no satisfaction to Rangers that this result was useless to Monaco as well. Both these teams required victory to prolong their Champions League involvement beyond beyond Christmas.

Sturm Graz who had to win to give Rangers the chance of advancement drew 2-2 with Galatasaray, the Austrian club content to play keep ball in the final minutes in Istanbul. The game was taut with nerves, never mind from players obsessed with such stakes, but from an Ibrox crowd which quickly swallowed Rangers' early lead and settled into their seats in a state of high anxiety. The old Fortress Ibrox, as it used to be called in the 1960s, has witnessed many a piece of theatre but few so gripping as this.

Dick Advocaat chose to gamble. As if the collective brow of 50,000 was not fevered enough, it was a risk going with Michael Mols, preciously talented though only half-fit, instead of Rod Wallace, who endured this torment from the bench. For all his heroics, this match proved a struggle for Mols, whose movement seemed grinding due to his injured knee.

Advocaat is certainly a law unto himself. He also chose to relegate the Turk, Kerimoglu Tugay, a player who brought composure and stealth to Rangers' midfield in their previous Group D outings, to the bench. On top of Giovanni van Bronckhorst's injured absence from midfield, the instinct for this seemed reckless in the extreme - at least in the few minutes in which we could consider it before Rangers took their early lead. Kenny Miller, who has the pace of a hare when given his chance, has had to sit as sullenly as a tortoise on the edge of the team since Advocaat purchased him for £2.2m from Hibs. Having scored three goals in three starts, Miller had been starting to lean on Advocaat, and five in one match against St Mirren at the weekend simply flushed the Dutchman's cheeks.

Miller received his fifth Rangers start last night and scored inside three minutes. The sweeping move from the Scottish champions was a joy to behold, from Barry Ferguson's lofted pass out to Arthur Numan, to the full-back's volleyed cross which fell sweetly at the back post. It was the execution which proved the least enticing part, though Rangers remained grateful. Pablo Contreras made a hash of clearing the ball, leaving Miller to lash his shot off the defender and past Stephane Porato.

The French, though, sharpened their talons and Rangers suffered in the 37th minute. Simone, their prized Italian, who forsook Milan for a life in France, had already been squirming this way and that before he trudged over to take a corner. The ball arrived with venom at Rangers' near post for Francisco Da Costa to beat everyone and direct his header past Christiansen.

Yet Mols, despite being obviously stiff, produced the deed which vindicated Advocaat's faith in him.

Fernando Ricksen's long punt after 51 minutes, headed on by Ronald de Boer, was even misjudged by the striker, whose control seemed to let him down. Mols still recovered, though, to lash a shot which seemed to go through Porato as it sped into the net. Monaco's second equaliser after 77 minutes. Simone pounced and ran the ball into the area before ramming it home.

Rangers (3-5-2): Christiansen; Wilson, Amoruso, Vidmar; Ricksen, Ferguson, De Boer (Wallace, 78min), Albertz (McCann, 85), Numan; Miller, Mols (Tugay, 55).

Monaco (4-4-2): Porato; Da Costa, Christanval, Irles, Contreras; Giuly, Dabo, Gallardo, Bonnal; (Nonda, Prso, 57), Simone.

Referee: L Michel (Slovakia).

fields.trailText: STABBED LEEDS FAN STABLE IN HOSPITAL

STABBED LEEDS FAN STABLE IN HOSPITAL

A Leeds United fan who suffered a pierced bladder during a brawl in Milan last night is today recovering in hospital and said to be stable. The 31-year-old, whose name has been withheld, was in the city ahead of tonight's crucial match against AC Milan. He has been described as a "professional" and "not the sort of individual who would get involved in trouble".

The incident comes just seven months after Leeds fans Kevin Speight and Christopher Loftus were stabbed to death in Turkey before the club's fateful game against Galatasaray.

Peter Ridsdale, the club chairman, said the incident left him feeling drained. "So far we have tried to shield the team from the news - clearly when you travel you do not want to hear of incidents such as this," he said. "I'm feeling pretty drained by the situation to be frank. Incidents like today bring the difficult times flooding back again."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

BRAD NEWS

Who wants to be a Bradford millionaire*? That's the question being asked today, mainly by the Fiver, as the shortlist for the manager's job at Valley Parade gets longer, then shorter, then longer again - much like a chimpanzee's [this paragraph has been cut short for reasons of space]

First out of the running this morning was current caretaker coach, and supposed favourite for the job, Stuart McCall. The 36-year-old gingernut has decided to keep on playing, a decision he could come to regret if, say, the next manager decides to flog him to Hartlepool. "I don't believe that I can do the manager's position justice while I am still playing at Premiership level," McCall said. "The time will come when I'll hang up my boots and my ambition in the future is to become a manager should the opportunity arise."

The Fiver wonders whether McCall has spent much time studying gift horses and, in particular, their eating faculties. Especially when the Merseyside benefit agency's most wanted, Roy Evans, is about. The affable former Liverpool failure is now the favourite to become Big Bantam, although Howard Kendall, Steve Bruce, Steve Coppell and even the esteemed Kelvin Koogan (not to be confused with the Kelvin Koogan of Koogan's turf accountancy) are still in the running.

Meanwhile, Chris Hutchings said this: "A dozen games isn't long enough to show people what you can do and I expected to be given a few more to turn things round."

* silk hat not included

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Turning to a foreign coach is the biggest mistake that we could make. It would be the annihilation of all our work. It would be shameful because we have the coaches in France to do the job" - Aime Jacquet, World Cup winner, mouths off, as helpfully translated by the Daily Mail.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

BET FIVER

In the wake of the Koog card-school rumpus, you wouldn't put much money on the FA being stupid enough to announce changes to their betting rules which make it easier for players to gamble. But you'd be a mug punter, because: a) that's crediting the FA with too much intelligence, and; b) they have. Today, a vigorously tic-tacing FA spokesperson explained the new regulations which allow players to spill the contents of their pouches into a bookmaker's lap.

"A more clearly worded definition was required to make the differentiation between participants who are directly involved in a game, or have inside knowledge of that game, and use that to bet or assist others in placing bets," explained the helpful spokesperson in perfect monotone. He droned on, explaining that while a restriction still applies on players or coaches betting on matches involving their own team (and/or clubs playing in the same division or cup competition), they can fritter away as much of their not-hard-earned as they like on other games.

The reason for this ill-timed change? Well, the previous laws technically forbade Sunday League players from staking money on the outcome of a Premiership match - which is patently ridiculous and so in that respect it all makes sense. But whether it is so clever to reveal these changes to the public in the current climate is another matter. After all, if the public think players are more concerned with placing large sums of money on wait a minute that cheery cartwheeling circus act over there it's not Steve Claridge and Keith Gillespie, is it?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

The Daily Star believes Barcelona will try to sign both Mark Viduka and Paul Robinson from Leeds. The paper believes any deal would be financed by the sale of Jari Litmanen, Frank De Boer and Boudewijn Zenden from Camp Nou.

Marian Pahars has been linked with a move from Southampton to Manchester City.

West Ham, Middlesbrough, Coventry, Spurs and Newcastle are in the hunt for Honduran defender Jorge Samuel Cabellero.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Wimbledon midfielder Robbie Earle has decided to end his playing career on the advice of a specialist after failing to recover from a serious stomach injury.

Vidar Riseth is set to complete a £1.2m move from Celtic to Bundesliga side Munich 1860 later today.

Aberdeen defender Russell Anderson has been ruled out for the rest of the season with knee ligament damage.

Former Celtic captain John McPhail has died at the age of 76 after a short illness. McPhail scored the winning goal in the 1951 Scottish Cup final and was capped five times by Scotland.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match - Live (7.30pm) Some football, probably with a two-hour break in the middle (for news).

The Big Match (11.30pm) Some football, probably with a two-hour break in the middle (to allow Terry Venables' ego to breathe).

Sky Sports 1: The Last Word with Jimmy Hill (7pm) Probably babbling on about toe-pokes, or something.

Futbol Mundial (7.30pm) Brush up on your xenophobia here.

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm) Tonight, McCaff spills coffee all over Clive Allen's notes, rendering them useless. Clive does not notice.

Radio 5 Live: Football (7.30pm) From where we're sitting, Alan Green looks good to us. We're positioned behind a pillar, of course.

webTitle: Handling bullying

fields.headline: Bully for you
fields.standfirst: What do you do if your son or daughter is being picked on at school? Teach them to fight, tell them to run away or, worse, turn them into a snitch? Jane Thynne on the perils of playground politics.
fields.trailText: What do you do if your son or daughter is being picked on at school? Teach them to fight, tell them to run away or, worse, turn them into a snitch? Jane Thynne on the perils of playground politics.
fields.body:
'A good thing happened at school today," announced my four year old, proudly. "Justin hit me." I wondered how this could possibly be good.

"Well, I told the teacher and she made Justin stand in the corner," replied Charlie, eyes shining.

It was hard to greet this exchange with anything but a shudder. How was it that I had produced a tiny tell-tale, whose readiness so young to inform on his peers would no doubt lead to a bruising time throughout his school years? But my horror was swiftly followed by the realisation that Charlie was only obeying orders - the orders I have handed out from birth onwards about not hitting back, deflecting aggression in any confrontation and consulting an adult at every turn. Mediation through a higher authority would produce results, I told the children. And in Charlie's case, it had.

If only it were that simple. But what makes it tougher for my boys, as far as parental guidance is concerned, is that they are caught in the crossfire of radically conflicting advice. While I preach a United Nations style of conflict resolution, my husband, who points out that he has the advantage of having actually been a boy in a playground, prefers to repeat his favourite anecdote about downing a larger pupil with a single blow when he was six. As far as the guidance goes, it is Old Testament versus New Testament. An eye for an eye or turn the other cheek. Churchill or Chamberlain. To say the least, it is a mixed message.

But if we have been guilty of confusing our children, then I'm sure we're not alone. The question of answering violence with violence appears to be so taboo that many parents cannot be relied upon to answer truthfully. It seems they would rather turn a blind eye to the Lord of the Flies world of the playground and leave the children to sort out their own battles. No one wants an aggressive child, but neither does anyone want one who can't fend for itself. Few people will admit to advising their child to hit back, but everyone tells children to "stand up to bullies". The question they don't answer is exactly how you go about standing up to a bully. The old line that "all bullies are cowards" must look even less convincing when somebody bigger and tougher is standing four inches away, taking your favourite conker out of your blazer pocket.

Being picked on is an occupational hazard for fictional schoolchildren too, from Tom Brown, who was roasted over a fire by Flashman, right up to Harry Potter's ghastly Draco Malfoy with his sidekicks Crabbe and Goyle. Whereas in literature the message is always that aggressors can be outwitted, in life that is not always the case.

"It's a class thing, of course," says Oliver James, clinical psychologist and author of a forthcoming book about parental nurture They F*** You Up Your Mum and Dad. "How a child should respond to aggression depends totally on what environment they are in. In a playground full of children who have received significant physical punishment, in a school where the ratio of kids to teachers is not brilliant, it is useful to learn the skills to protect yourself. But in a middle-class prep school, you learn from an early age that authority is on your side, so the best thing to do is to call in a teacher."

Very often, the advice a parent gives varies according to the children themselves. Are they, to use school-style euphemism, "lively" or "sensitive"? "Freddie has always been a very placid child," says my friend Melanie, "so there was no point in telling him to hit back. I don't want to turn him into a thumper."

According to Liz, the mother of two sons: "When Matti first went to school, I said: 'If some kid hits you, hit him back twice really hard. Then he won't hit you again.' It was my instinctive reaction, though I rather regret it. But now that he's 11, if someone hit him, I'd advise him to run. He's small and it's the age where they get their teeth knocked out."

T here can be benefits in refraining from giving advice at all, according to Jane Cassidy, a clinical psychotherapist at the Tavistock Centre in London. "Just be honest. Present each side without saying which you should choose. It's good to take a step back and let them think about what happens when you act on your feelings. After all, there are situations as an adult in which you have to stand your ground against aggression and others, such as a road rage situation, in which you might be advised not to get out of the car."

Ultimately, Oliver James says, children will take their behavioural cues from their environment. "When I was young I went to a series of boarding schools where violence was very necessary. But then I was moved to Eton. Three weeks in, I received a very small provocation and responded by thumping the boy on the nose. Nobody said anything, but they were all very, very shocked. And that reaction alone made sure I never did it again."

webTitle: Teaching your children Jewish culture

fields.headline: Bagels for Christmas
fields.standfirst: If you're Jewish but don't believe in God, what do you teach your children about their culture? Daniel Lee says celebrate your background, but only take the best bits.
fields.trailText: If you're Jewish but don't believe in God, what do you teach your children about their culture? Daniel Lee says celebrate your background, but only take the best bits.
fields.body:
A bagel shop in Brick Lane, east London was where I introduced my new girlfriend to my Jewish culture. I couldn't wait for Paula, with a Protestant mother and Catholic father, to try one of these hard bread rolls stuffed with salmon, the cream cheese oozing through the hole in its centre. OK, she may afterwards have developed food poisoning and a two-year allergy to smoked fish, but no one said that getting to know another culture would be easy.

Bagels are one of the few everyday reminders of the Jewish presence in this country. There are also many well-known Jewish personalities - the ubiquitous Robert Winston, for example. And there is a long list of Yiddish and Hebrew words that have added colour to the English language - nosh, shlep, chutzpah, kosher, shtoom. But Jewish culture does not have the omnipresent icons and symbols to match the awe-inspiring cathedrals, numerous churches, classical music's constant references to Christianity and all-embracing festivals such as Easter and Christmas - things which fire the imagination of a child.

I don't have a problem with this. I even sang in the choir on Songs of Praise once: I was drafted in because I attended a local music school, but I mimed the words. Some of my best friends are from Christian backgrounds, not least Paula.

Just as Paula and I - both atheists with non-religious parents - to some extent had a Christian upbringing by default, so will our children. I had no religious education and the festivals were never central in my parents' home. But they did have me circumcised and when I was 13, they asked me if I wanted a Bar Mitzva. I refused, thus passing up the lifetime supply of fountain pens I would have received as gifts. Our son Ben, five, is attending a Church of England school, and Becky, three, is likely to follow suit, so it is up to us to add Jewish culture to the mix of memories and rituals that make up their lives.

We have parties at Easter and Christmas, but also for the chief Jewish festivals, such as Passover with its use of salt water in the Seder meal to remember the tears of the Jews and joy at a new life liberated from slavery. How many ceremonies can be so moving and educational? The culture of diaspora also brings with it a distinctive cuisine and the Yiddish language. When my 92-year-old grandmother Beatrice calls me "bubbeleh" (a term of affection that means honey - literally "little grandmother"), the expression illuminates a path back through hundreds of years of tradition. There is that caustic sense of humour, a tradition of music both haunting and sad and a cherishing of life that is at the heart of Jewish culture: when a baby is born or a marriage confirmed, the toast is "l'chaim" (to life). Apart from anything else, this seems a good philosophy to pass on to a child.

For Ben and Becky to know Jewish culture is to have an essential link with their past. It will add richness to their lives. But fathoming the definition of a non-believing Jew, such as myself, in order to decide what to pass on to them is trickier. A belief in God is, thankfully, only necessary if you want to embrace Judaism as well as Jewish culture - something I have no wish to do. There have been many articles, pamphlets and books with titles such as The Jewish Question and What Is A Jew? But there is no clear answer: because of the diaspora, different people have adopted different lifestyles depending on country and region. Jews in Britain occupy a very different place to Jews in Israel or the US.

My ancestors arrived around the turn of the 20th century, many from Vitebsk in Belarus. Some were filled with revolutionary zeal, partly because they were driven to it by pogroms and partly because they were inspired by the dream of building a more just society. Some remained in the UK for only a few years before returning to the old country to help their comrades.

My grandfather, Phil Piratin, turned his back on orthodox Judaism. After studying at Yeshivoth (a religious school), he joined instead - and much to his father's disgust - the Communist party. He was elected as a councillor in Stepney in the late 30s, after the Battle of Cable Street when local activists fought police to stop Oswald Moseley's Blackshirts from marching through the Jewish east end. In 1945, he became the constituency's Communist MP. Our children's family history is thus social history, too; but what will it mean to them?

To know your background is to understand your fundamental loyalties. When, for instance, Paula and I came to discuss whether or not to have Benjamin circumcised, I was shocked by my strength of feeling. I had no reason to want to subject him to this operation, yet emotionally I did because of its powerful symbolism in marking a tribal affiliation. I couldn't help feeling that not to do so was like turning my back on a long line of suffering and achievement. In the end, we decided not to circumcise him but that decision means that Ben is different from me.

I feel Jewish: I am a Jew even though I am an atheist and have chosen not to embrace many of the rituals. When Norman Tebbit devised his repugnant cricket test - if West Indians don't support England then they are not truly English - he was making it clear that he saw them as temporary tenants, not freeholders, in his land. I have on occasion received similar reminders of my tenure. When I criticised the British involvement in Kosovo at a dinner party recently, one guest inquired politely: "But what about you and Israel?" The implication was clear: my loyalty and true home lay elsewhere, even though I have never lived in the Middle East and the last relative of mine who was an immigrant arrived here a century ago.

How will Ben and Becky feel if (or, perhaps, when) in the playground they are subjected to anti-semitic jibes without even knowing why? They will be completely unprepared. Far better for us to explain why such an event, horrible as it is, may be an opportunity to challenge prejudice. Imagine, worse still, that, ignorant of their own history, they were to begin Jew-baiting themselves. What damage would it do to them if they were to discover the truth so late?

I, and perhaps many like me, am irrationally afraid that by looking back to old traditions, we are taking a step on the path back towards the ghetto. But the opposite is the case: by picking the best from our past we create something new and better for the future. Soon, we will be lighting the Menorah candles for Chanukah, decorating the Christmas tree and eating bagels with bacon for breakfast.
