To know your background is to understand your fundamental loyalties. When, for instance, Paula and I came to discuss whether or not to have Benjamin circumcised, I was shocked by my strength of feeling. I had no reason to want to subject him to this operation, yet emotionally I did because of its powerful symbolism in marking a tribal affiliation. I couldn't help feeling that not to do so was like turning my back on a long line of suffering and achievement. In the end, we decided not to circumcise him but that decision means that Ben is different from me. I feel Jewish: I am a Jew even though I am an atheist and have chosen not to embrace many of the rituals. When Norman Tebbit devised his repugnant cricket test - if West Indians don't support England then they are not truly English - he was making it clear that he saw them as temporary tenants, not freeholders, in his land. I have on occasion received similar reminders of my tenure. When I criticised the British involvement in Kosovo at a dinner party recently, one guest inquired politely: "But what about you and Israel?" The implication was clear: my loyalty and true home lay elsewhere, even though I have never lived in the Middle East and the last relative of mine who was an immigrant arrived here a century ago. How will Ben and Becky feel if (or, perhaps, when) in the playground they are subjected to anti-semitic jibes without even knowing why? They will be completely unprepared. Far better for us to explain why such an event, horrible as it is, may be an opportunity to challenge prejudice. Imagine, worse still, that, ignorant of their own history, they were to begin Jew-baiting themselves. What damage would it do to them if they were to discover the truth so late? I, and perhaps many like me, am irrationally afraid that by looking back to old traditions, we are taking a step on the path back towards the ghetto. But the opposite is the case: by picking the best from our past we create something new and better for the future. Soon, we will be lighting the Menorah candles for Chanukah, decorating the Christmas tree and eating bagels with bacon for breakfast.

webTitle: The panel

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: the government is backing a booklet extolling the virtues of married life. How important is it for children that their parents are wed?
fields.trailText: The Question: the government is backing a booklet extolling the virtues of married life. How important is it for children that their parents are wed?
fields.body:
Caroline Schofield Single parent with one child

I can't imagine people going round announcing that they're getting married because the government says it's best. My daughter doesn't see coming from a single-parent home as a problem. She has a good relationship with her father. In fact, one of her friends pointed to a boy the other day and said, "That's the boy whose mum and dad live together", as if he was the odd one out. I don't see anything wrong with being married, but I don't like the phrase "marriage is best": best for who and better than what? It's patronising and sanctimonious and reminds me of Victorian Britain.

 Verdict: Not at all

Tina Wase Divorced with four children

I am one adult stretched between four children and that is very hard. I think children need adults around who make them feel cared for, secure and give some input. My ex-husband was abysmal with the children; instead of him, I have an army of friends. If anyone turned round to me and said that my children's upbringing was second-rate because I no longer had a husband to help me with them, I would be incensed. I do think it's preferable for a woman to bring children up with a male partner - but I don't think that walking down the aisle miraculously improves your parenting skills.

 Verdict: Not very

Peter Stanford Married with two children

From our children's point of view, all that matters now is that we're mummy and daddy. It may be more of an issue later in life, since they're going to be educated in the Catholic system, because there is still a prejudice against unmarried parents there. But this is a big issue for me: I wouldn't have wanted to have children outside marriage. Partly because it's just what I know, and partly for the security of having a family within that institutional framework. And there is a spiritual dimension: I'm perfectly happy for people not to have that belief, but I do.

 Verdict: Very necessary

Jane Harter Cohabiting with her partner and their son

I think it would be a retrograde step for the government to try to reinforce this stereotype of happy family life. I was unmarried and pregnant with my now grown-up daughter 26 years ago and there was an enormous stigma attached to it. I did go on to marry her father, but it was a disaster. What matters is not the public statement of commitment at a wedding, but the private commitment to bring up your children in a loving way. The fantasy of a wedding means that the event becomes more important than what happens afterwards. It's a case of style over substance.

 Verdict: It's trivial

Lisa Saffron Director of PinkParents UK

Speaking as a mother of a 15-year-old daughter with a partner of 10 years, I'd say that the contest for the best type of family was rigged: lesbians excel at taking on parental responsibility, modelling egalitarian relationships and teaching their children acceptance of diversity. There are many different types of families, each with strengths and weaknesses and all deserving of support. It is not the type of family that matters, it's what happens within families. The government's role should be to help families by offering realistic and non-judgmental support.

 Verdict: It's irrelevant

webTitle: Interview: Chuck Palahniuk

fields.headline: Blokes on the ropes
fields.standfirst: Blood, guts and fighting are Chuck Palahniuk's fascinations.  The writer of Fight Club thinks that men need to reclaim masculinity - with their fists. But, Dave Hill finds, he's really just a softie at heart.
fields.trailText: Blood, guts and fighting are Chuck Palahniuk's fascinations. The writer of Fight Club thinks that men need to reclaim masculinity - with their fists. But, Dave Hill finds, he's really just a softie at heart.
fields.body:
Sentiment does not gush into the soul when reading the novels of Chuck Palahniuk. Fight Club, the bruising debut that made his reputation, concerns guys beating seven shades out of each other in the name of personal growth. Survivor, his second book, centres on the only member of a death cult left alive following a mass suicide. His latest, Invisible Monsters, enters the psyches of men, women and others balanced somewhere in between, who run amok in the cultural china shop where catwalk fashion, sexual transgression and the grim realities of "gender reassignment" meet.

In these latest thrumming pages we make the acquaintance of citizens with half their faces blown off or leafing eagerly through catalogues of surgically pre-fabricated vaginas. In all his books the prose of Palahniuk - pronounced "paula-nick" - is hard and glittering, his sentences dark diamonds of bleak insight and unforgiving parody. But hark: he knows of harmony, of tenderness, of love. "All of the books," he explains, "are just a very, very cynical way of getting to a sentimental place."

As ever with creativity that amplifies awfulness in order to uncover something finer and braver, Palahniuk's stories have suffered from dimwitted misinterpretations. For example, David Fincher's funny and powerful film version of Fight Club was denounced in some quarters as an advertisement for fascism when, if anything, it might be read as a warning about how a certain form of idealised masculinity can manifest itself in slavish, martial forms.

Palahniuk's characters are always on the run from all that is bland and predictable, soporific and safe: Ikea furnishings, career conformity, obedient consumerism, being dumbly beautiful for a living. What does it say, though, about his vision that his first evocation of a revolt against convention principally depicted men learning how to use their fists on one another?

"Fight Club came out of something that all my peers talked about," he says. "It is that their fathers had never taught them what they needed to know about becoming men. And what I'm learning more and more is that these fathers had not been taught by their own fathers."

The book is also informed by knuckle-on-bone experience. Palahniuk, 38, spent several frustrating years trying to make it as a writer of some kind. He worked on trucks by day and went to bars by night where sometimes he became involved in dust-ups.

What he derived from these encounters is the curious thing we all learn when we see boxers embrace at the finish of a bout: that a physical contest can also bind the protagonists in mutual respect. Palahniuk is certain that there are some things in life that men innately enjoy and should be given - given back - cultural permission to express. "If we try to suppress that completely, it is going to erupt in some horrible uncontrolled way. In a culture where we have condemned all forms of violence as invalid and not needed, violence still comes up. It comes up in hyper-violent ways, like in school shootings."

The notion that men must be allowed to be men or else all society - women included - suffers, is consistent with the mantras of the American men's movement and the mytho-poetic prescriptions of its patron saint, Robert Bly, the author of Iron John. Palahniuk also seems in sympathy with the argument that conventional manly virtues have been done down in the keyboard-driven, postindustrial economy, and he has not missed the irony that while men's interest in violent sports today causes concern, women's incursions into the same territory are often applauded. So when men box it is mindless violence and when women box it is liberation?

"Right."

For Palahniuk the male protagonists of Fight Club are human spirits in revolt against the deadening destinies society that allots them. Many of his friends are teachers and, like teachers here, they often com plain that education is increasingly about schooling children for niches rather than educating them to create their own place in the world: "They're taught to accept the world the way it is. I felt that all of my schooling was to get me a good corporate job so I could be a good corporate citizen, pay my taxes, live politely and then die."

Where Palahniuk was concerned, the system seems to have failed. He has written his own life script instead. He grew up in a trailer in the desert, the part that lies in east Washington state: "Cactus and sage brush and coyotes. We were really, really poor."

His mother was an office manager, his father worked on the railroad which came in handy because whenever a freight train was derailed he was the first to know. Some of Palahniuk's most vivid childhood memories are of stealing out en famille at dead of night - he has a brother and two sisters - to pilfer from the train-wreck.

It is a story that he makes use of in Invisible Monsters, when one of the characters looks back on a past she is desperate to escape.

A thick vein of such dark comedy pulses through his writing. His mother now works in a nuclear- powered factory, and he savours her tales of radioactive mice penetrating the confectionery machines. His father is dead - murdered 18 months ago along with a woman he was dating. The trail of the woman's former husband, who had, allegedly, been threatening to kill her for three years, has just been picked up. "My father walked in on the end of a chain of events. He happened to be the unhappy man who had answered her personal ad in a magazine."

Palahniuk thinks that personal catastrophe and conflict can deepen human relationships and make us richer as people: the blood of the fight-club floors, the drug-deranged odyssey of self-mutilation that powers Invisible Monsters. His character, named Brandy Alexander, dazzlingly suspended midway between sexes, lives out a kind of makeover that goes more than skin deep.

The novel's narrator is his first in a female voice and addresses the questionable premise underlying Fight Club - that men and women are fundamentally different kinds of humans and that those differences are finally decisive. However, Palahniuk was surprised by the reaction of women to his book. "I used to believe Fight Club was a men's phenomenon. But I got so much response from women saying that they want that form of expression for themselves. They, too, respond to the notion that sometimes you must destroy if you are going to make things better."

All of this suggests a different way of making sense out of today's gender flux and clutter. If masculinity means guts and vigour, and a passion for controlling your own destiny, then it is not so much an essence exclusive to one sex as a metaphor that both sexes can make use of. And if emasculation means the numbing of the senses, then it is a menace to everybody, men, women and all.

· Invisible Monsters is published by Vintage, £6.99. Chuck Palahniuk is giving a series of readings throughout the country from today. Details: 020-7840 8688.

webTitle: BT set to announce flotation of mobile phone arm

fields.headline: BT set to announce flotation of mobile phone arm
fields.trailText: 4pm: BT is set to unveil a partial flotation of its mobile phone division as the City braces itself for a drastic cut in profits. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
BT is set to throw its mobile phone division into a turbulent IPO market, as the City braces itself for a drastic cut in the company's third quarter profits.

The telecoms operator could raise £10bn from a partial flotation of BT Wireless, which includes the Cellnet arm and is valued at between £28bn and £40bn.

BT said it will announce the results of a strategic review by the end of the year, but speculation is mounting that the group will reveal some of its decisions in tomorrow's first half results.

Analysts expect the figures to reflect the cost of bidding for European mobile phone licences, with third quarter pre-tax profits cut from £890m to £429m.

The figures will increase the pressure on BT to reduce its £30bn debt burden, with a flotation of BT Wireless the City's favoured option.

Anthea Gaukroger, telecoms analyst at Greig Middleton, said: "It is likely BT will float off 25% of the wireless division, take £10bn off its debts and sell its stakes in European telecoms operators. It will relieve the pressure on the balance sheets."

However, BT will face the twin problems of competition and negative market sentiment towards telecoms stocks should it decide to float.

Spanish rival Telefonica and France Telecom's Orange are committed to floating over the next few months, with T-Mobile of Germany set to follow.

The three companies are valued together at around £120bn, which may stretch investors' wallets to breaking point.

"If BT doesn't act soon, then market conditions could deteriorate further for telecoms issues," added Ms Gaukroger.

BT is committed to the flotation or sale of its Yell directories business, but a recent cut in its debt rating by Moody's Investors Service demonstrates the pressure for further divestments.

webTitle: Petspark.com boss bullish despite stakeholder collapse

fields.headline: Petspark.com boss bullish despite US site's demise
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: The boss of UK pet website Petspark.com remains upbeat despite the collapse of US-based Pets.com, writes Amy Vickers
fields.body:
The boss of Petspark.com, the UK pet website in which the now-defunct Pets.com has a 30% stake, has denied that his business is threatened by the collapse of the US site.

Adrian Marrullier, European chief operating officer of Petspark.com, said he still had money in the bank and would be solvent well into next year.

He said: "We're not about to be acquired and we're not laying off staff. What's happened to Pets.com has no direct effect on us, even if it does question the category [online pet product retailing]."

Mr Marrullier added that he was still negotiating a partnership with a bricks-and-mortar pet product retailer, rumoured to be Petsmart, but wouldn't give any indication of when an announcement would be made.

Petspark.com has raised more than $9.5m, $7m of which came from Pets.com, and has been incubated by Brainspark.

The US site announced yesterday that it was shutting down and laying off more than 255 of its 320 employees after a search for new funding proved fruitless. Mr Marrullier said he was happy to work with whoever buys Pets.com or its remaining assets.

The biggest casualty of the Pets.com collapse is Amazon.com, which invested $60m for a 30% stake in the business.

webTitle: US presidential election outcome mystifies the media

fields.headline: Papers as confused as readers as to election outcome
fields.standfirst: The final leg of the race to the White House may make for nailbiting news, but for commentators in the US press it's also frustratingly elusive
fields.trailText: The final leg of the race to the White House may make for nailbiting news, but for commentators it's also frustratingly elusive, says Derek Brown.
fields.body:
For editors in the US, the outcome of the presidential election - which may not be finalised until next week - is a dream and a nightmare. The stunningly close result is a once in a lifetime political story. The problem is, it was still unclear by the time most morning editions were published.

Most of the online papers are getting around the problem by revamping their electronic front pages with agency copy. But with the updates coming thick and fast, the editors must be almost as confused as their readers.

With only a handful of ballots to be counted - or recounted - it is clear that Al Gore won the popular vote. But he will almost certainly lose the race for the White House because of the electoral college system.

The vice-president would have found it particularly hard to read this morning's Tennessean, the paper for which he once worked as a reporter. It carries a detailed map of his home state where George W Bush scored a clear victory.

The Chicago Tribune reports another dramatic outcome of the polls: the first ever election of a dead man to the US senate: " The late Gov Mel Carnahan was victorious early Wednesday over Republican Sen John Ashcroft of Missouri. Carnahan's name stayed on the ballot in spite of his death last month.

"Carnahan's triumph marks the first time a dead person has been elected to the US Senate. His widow, Jean, has agreed to accept an appointment to take his place. From the moment Carnahan's plane crashed on 16 October, nothing about this state's contest for the senate had been simple or predictable, nor would it be on election day."

Columnist Steve Neal, writing in the Chicago Sun-Times, jumps the gun by discussing the likely administration to be put together by "president-elect George W Bush". He predicts that it will feature prominent members of a previous George Bush cabinet, including former army chief Colin Powell as Secretary of State.

The Los Angeles Times reports the nailbiting last hours of the campaign: "With the race so taut, Gore continued campaigning relentlessly Tuesday night, even after polls closed in the east and midwest. Manning the phones from his hotel suite in Nashville, he joined his wife, Tipper, and Lieberman in calling radio stations in several states where ballots were still being cast.

"Early in the evening, when several television networks called the vote in Florida, Michigan and Illinois for the vice-president, 'cheers went up around the room' in the Gores' suite, press secretary Douglas Hattaway said. The group took a brief dinner break, he said, then 'got back on the phones'."

The Dallas Morning News, which staunchly backed Bush, is frustrated by the close finish, and gloomily reports that the crucial Florida result, hanging on a handful of postal votes, may prolong the agony: "Florida election law requires a vote recount if the margin of difference is less than one half of one percent. Several Florida counties still have absentee ballots to count and elections officials expect several thousand votes from overseas. Elections officials weren't sure how long it would take this time, but said it took 10 days in 1996 to count overseas absentee ballots."

In the eye of the Florida psephological storm, the Miami Herald jumps both ways at once, reporting that Mr Bush led in the state, then saw his lead evaporate. The paper is breathless: "The result was astounding: The election of an American president after a campaign that inspired a remarkable nationwide turnout of voters now hinged on uncounted ballots from one precinct in Pompano Beach, a recount of some absentee ballots in Broward and Miami Dade counties, and, eventually, a legally mandated recount of the entire vote in Florida." The Herald's unofficial table of results shows Mr Bush leading Mr Gore in Florida by just 1784 votes out of nearly six million.

But with the updates coming thick and fast, the editors must be almost as confused as their readers. With only a handful of ballots to be counted - or recounted - it is clear that Al Gore won the popular vote. But he will almost certainly lose the race for the White House because of the electoral college system. The vice-president would have found it particularly hard to read this morning's Tennessean, the paper for which he once worked as a reporter. It carries a detailed map of his home state where George W Bush scored a clear victory. The Chicago Tribune reports another dramatic outcome of the polls: the first ever election of a dead man to the US senate: " The late Gov Mel Carnahan was victorious early Wednesday over Republican Sen John Ashcroft of Missouri. Carnahan's name stayed on the ballot in spite of his death last month. "Carnahan's triumph marks the first time a dead person has been elected to the US Senate. His widow, Jean, has agreed to accept an appointment to take his place. From the moment Carnahan's plane crashed on 16 October, nothing about this state's contest for the senate had been simple or predictable, nor would it be on election day." Columnist Steve Neal, writing in the Chicago Sun-Times, jumps the gun by discussing the likely administration to be put together by "president-elect George W Bush". He predicts that it will feature prominent members of a previous George Bush cabinet, including former army chief Colin Powell as Secretary of State. The Los Angeles Times reports the nailbiting last hours of the campaign: "With the race so taut, Gore continued campaigning relentlessly Tuesday night, even after polls closed in the east and midwest. Manning the phones from his hotel suite in Nashville, he joined his wife, Tipper, and Lieberman in calling radio stations in several states where ballots were still being cast. "Early in the evening, when several television networks called the vote in Florida, Michigan and Illinois for the vice-president, 'cheers went up around the room' in the Gores' suite, press secretary Douglas Hattaway said. The group took a brief dinner break, he said, then 'got back on the phones'." The Dallas Morning News, which staunchly backed Bush, is frustrated by the close finish, and gloomily reports that the crucial Florida result, hanging on a handful of postal votes, may prolong the agony: "Florida election law requires a vote recount if the margin of difference is less than one half of one percent. Several Florida counties still have absentee ballots to count and elections officials expect several thousand votes from overseas. Elections officials weren't sure how long it would take this time, but said it took 10 days in 1996 to count overseas absentee ballots." In the eye of the Florida psephological storm, the Miami Herald jumps both ways at once, reporting that Mr Bush led in the state, then saw his lead evaporate. The paper is breathless: "The result was astounding: The election of an American president after a campaign that inspired a remarkable nationwide turnout of voters now hinged on uncounted ballots from one precinct in Pompano Beach, a recount of some absentee ballots in Broward and Miami Dade counties, and, eventually, a legally mandated recount of the entire vote in Florida." The Herald's unofficial table of results shows Mr Bush leading Mr Gore in Florida by just 1784 votes out of nearly six million.

webTitle: Murray to host The Message

fields.headline: Murray to host The Message
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Woman's Hour host Jenni Murray is adding Radio 4 media show The Message to her presenting duties from January, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Woman's Hour host Jenni Murray is adding Radio 4 media show The Message to her presenting duties from January.

Ms Murray, who also presents Radio 4 current affairs series Turning World and has made occasional appearances on ITV afternoon show Live Talk, will take over from Alex Brodie.

She said: "I really like the way The Message challenges the media, and it is much easier to do that from Manchester where we aren't so caught up in the London media village."

The Message is produced out of the BBC's Oxford Road studios in Manchester by Dave Harvey. It goes out on Radio 4 at 4.30pm on Fridays.

webTitle: The US voting system: lessons from the past

fields.headline: The US voting system: lessons from the past
fields.standfirst: Al Gore could win most votes but lose the election. Derek Brown analyses two previous occasions in the 19th century when a similar situation occurred.
fields.trailText: Analysis: Al Gore could win most votes but lose the election. Derek Brown analyses two previous occasions in the 19th century when a similar situation occurred.
fields.body:
Whatever the final outcome of the Florida recount, it is clear that Al Gore has won a slender but clear majority of the popular vote.

But winning the vote doesn't qualify him automatically for the White House. That's because Americans don't choose their president - they choose the men and women who choose the president, in the electoral college.

The 538 members of the college are chosen in their home states, weighted by population and representation in Congress. Mighty California has 54 electoral votes. Delaware and several other tiddly states get just three each.

In most, but not all states, electors are obliged to respect the wishes of the broader electorate. As a further complication, there have been maverick electors who switched allegiance after the popular poll.

The last time a president was elected on a minority vote was in 1888, when incumbent Democrat Grover Cleveland was thwarted by Republican challenger Benjamin Harrison with the aid of New York's notorious Tammany Hall regime, which gerrymandered the state's 34 electoral college votes and delivered them to Harrison.

More notorious, however, was the outcome of the 1876 vote, in which Samuel Tilden, the Democrat governor of New York won a popular victory over Republican Rutherford Hayes, by 51% to 48%.

But Tilden fell just one vote short of victory in the electoral college. There ensued a long and undignified wrangle in Congress over the dubious validity of 20 of the electoral college votes.

It was eventually resolved in favour of Hayes, who was declared president in March 1877 - but not before the Democrats had extracted many valuable political concessions.

The Hayes-Tilden 'compromise' of 1877 is one of the more unsavoury episodes of US political history, and is often quoted in arguments for reform, or even abolition of, the electoral college.

But, although many Americans are offended by the idea that a candidate can win with fewer votes than a rival, they would almost certainly lose any vote on the issue.

The argument is as old as the union itself. The founding fathers, representatives of the original 13 former colonies, deliberately restricted the authority of the new federal power, to preserve the central idea of their new country as a federation of autonomous states.

Federal power, as embodied by the presidency, remains the object of undisguised suspicion and even hostility by many Americans.

They argue that a president armed with a popular mandate would be an inherent danger to their constitutional liberties.

webTitle: Marketing Week round-up

fields.headline: Marketing Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 9.
fields.trailText: Deutsche Telecom is considering launching new brands and services in the UK through its newly acquired subsidiary, One2One , the mobile telephone company.
fields.body:
Deutsche Telecom is considering launching new brands and services in the UK through its newly acquired subsidiary, One2One , the mobile telephone company.

Sophia Angelis , marketing manager at L'Oreal, has been hired by Brown Forman, the owner of Jack Daniels, as marketing director of its UK spirits division.

Sony is considering repositioning its original PlayStation as an entry-level machine aimed at younger game players after the launch of PlayStation 2 later this month.

Prudential Financial Services has poached Halifax online chief Jaz Faggu to head its newly created e-commerce division.

Scottish Courage Brands is launching a members-only internet club offering subscribers more than £200-worth of free beer in a bid to create brand loyalty.

The BBC has struck a deal with manufacturer Roberts Radio to feature the BBC World Service brand name on products for the first time.

Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO will retain its UK Volvo account in spite of Chrysler's decision to move its entire £1.25bn global advertising business into BBDO.

The Open University is understood to be reviewing its £5m advertising account as it prepares to appoint a new head of marketing.

LandRover has reduced its shortlist of pitching agencies to Grey Advertising and Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R.

Leagas Delaney has been sold to Envoy Communications.

Carat's boycott of Channel 5, which led the media agency to withdraw all advertising from the station, has collapsed after News International broke ranks and struck a deal to put Sunday Times ads back on air.

The Sun has put a celebrity-focused TV branding campaign into research which could feature Robbie Williams, Teddy Sheringham and Dennis Wise.

webTitle: MPs call for BBC to bring back Nine O'Clock News

fields.headline: MPs call for BBC to bring back Nine O'Clock News
fields.trailText: 10am: MPs from all three main political parties have condemned the BBC's decision to move the BBC1 Nine O'Clock News to 10pm, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
MPs from all three main political parties have condemned the BBC's decision to move the BBC1 Nine O'Clock News to 10pm.

The criticism of the controversial shift comes in a House of Commons early day motion published yesterday.

The EDM was sponsored by Labour's Kevin Barron, Conservative MP Ann Winterton and and Liberal Democrat Norman Baker.

The motion, which other MPs will be able to sign up to, "condemns the decision of the BBC's board of governors to move BBC1's Nine O'Clock News to 10pm one year ahead of schedule and without public consultation".

It goes on to state that the decision, and the move of Panorama to Sunday night, "represent a further marginalisation of news and current affairs on BBC1".

The EDM also calls on the BBC's board of governors to "reinstate the Nine O'Clock News on BBC1 with immediate effect".

An EDM, while having no direct impact on government policy, provides a lightning conductor for the strength of feeling in the House of Commons about an issue.

MPs have no direct power to force the BBC to backtrack on its news move. But, as culture secretary Chris Smith told the RTS autumn symposium last week, BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland and the governors must go before the Commons culture select committee and account for the corporation's performance in the past year following the publication of the annual report next summer.

Parliament will also have a key role to play in the renewal of the BBC's Charter and MPs are unlikely to forget the news move episode.

webTitle: T-Online profits hit by unmetered access

fields.headline: T-Online profits hit by unmetered access
fields.trailText: 2pm: Unmetered access is wreaking havoc among European internet service providers, with Germany's T-Online the latest victim. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Unmetered access is wreaking havoc among European internet service providers, with Germany's T-Online the latest victim.

Europe's largest ISP has sunk into the red after profits at the rudderless company were hit by a flat-rate billing scheme.

T-Online reported a pre-tax loss of E14.4m (£8.7m) for the first nine months of the year, against a profit of E14.2m (£8.6m) last year.

Some cheer was provided by the revenue figures, which soared 86% to E542.6m (£325m), but doubts remain about the ISP's ability to maintain a consistent source of income.

T-Online's Frankfurt-listed stock tumbled 5% on the results, falling to E22.30 (£14), compared with the E27 flotation price.

The company has been rocked by a series of boardroom resignations over the past few months, including the acrimonious departure of chairman Wolfgang Keuntje.

Mr Keuntje is rumoured to have left following disputes over strategy with Ron Sommers, the chairman of parent company Deutsche Telekom. The pair allegedly fell out over a failed bid for UK rival Freeserve.

Mr Sommers has drafted in right-hand man Detlev Buchal as acting boss, but has yet to recruit a permanent replacement. The company's chief financial officer and head of marketing have since followed Mr Keuntje out of the door.

T-Online is not alone in its problems, however, with UK companies AltaVista UK and LineOne ditching their unmetered services in the summer.

Freeserve and Breathe are sticking with their flat-rate schemes, but analysts doubt if the services will work as a long-term money-spinner.

Bob Kommers, internet analyst at ABN Amro, said: "Most of the French, German and British ISPs have pulled back their unmetered services, because they are not economically viable. They are much too expensive, and the companies cannot handle the weight of demand for access."

webTitle: US regulator demands fresh concessions from AOL/Time Warner

fields.headline: US regulator demands fresh concessions from AOL/Time Warner
fields.trailText: 11am: US regulators have demanded fresh concessions from AOL and Time Warner over internet cable access days before a decision is due on the merger. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
US regulators have demanded new concessions from AOL and Time Warner over internet cable access just days before a a final decision is due on the massive media merger.

Negotiators from the two companies and regulator the Federal Trade Commission are trying to thrash out a deal to guarantee rival internet service providers access to Time Warner's cable networks.

The talks, involving FTC anti-trust officials, come just days before a crucial vote by FTC members on Thursday on whether to approve or block the merger, according to a US newspaper report.

Some commission members are said to be insisting that the merger cannot be approved unless terms have been negotiated with at least one of AOL's rivals to provide internet access to Time Warner's cable systems.

Those commission members are urging their colleagues to go to court to block the deal unless the companies agree to the concession.

A spokesman for the companies is reported as saying they continue to make progress in negotiations and that the deal with be completed before the end of the year.

webTitle: Dead man walking: new senator elected from the grave

fields.headline: Dead man walking: new senator elected from the grave
fields.standfirst: As the still-running presidential contest continues to draw the most attention, Derek Brown looks at a Senate sideshow playing out in the state of Missouri
fields.trailText: As the still-running presidential contest continues to draw the most attention, Derek Brown looks at a Senate sideshow playing out in the state of Missouri.
fields.body:
The voters of Missouri have elected Governor Mel Carnahan to the US Senate - three weeks after he perished in a plane crash.

The late governor, a Democrat, scored a narrow victory over his living Republican challenger, incumbent Senator John Ashcroft. Their contest was both close and bitter. Mr Carnahan was a pugnacious liberal, while Mr Ashcroft was a passionate conservative. Both had won two terms as state governor.

Their long and vituperative rivalry ended when Mr Carnahan died, along with his son and an election aide, in a light aircraft crash on October 16. His death occurred too late for the ballot paper to be re-cast.

The new state governor, Roger Wilson, said that if Mr Carnahan won, his 66-year-old widow Jean would be appointed to serve Mr Carnahan's two-year term in the Senate. That is perfectly legal, though Republicans are incensed.

No candidate has ever before been posthumously elected to the Senate, though three dead candidates have previously won seats in the House of Representatives.

Mrs Carnahan will clearly be a formidable presence in the august second chamber, even without a popular mandate. In a telephoned message to hundreds of supporters in St Louis, she cited some illustrious precedents for her poignant situation.

"You have stayed the course; you have kept the faith; you have carried our hopes and dreams," she said. "Lincoln never saw his nation made whole again. Susan B Anthony never cast a vote. Martin Luther King never finished his mountaintop journey. My husband's journey was cut short, too. And for reasons we don't understand, the mantle has now fallen upon us."

webTitle: Confusion as Republicans put victory party on hold

fields.headline: Confusion as Republicans put victory party on hold
fields.standfirst:
Audio: Julian Borger with Bush (1min 46)

The celebrations of George W Bush's supporters proved premature, reports Julian Borger in Austin, Texas
fields.trailText: The celebrations of George W Bush's supporters proved premature, reports Julian Borger in Austin, Texas.
fields.body:
Amid Republican disbelief and anger, George W Bush's plans for a celebration in the Texas state capital were postponed in the early hours of this morning as a recount began in the intensely contested battlefield of Florida.

The emotions of Bush supporters veered from depression to euphoria to total confusion as they stood through the night in the cold and rain while conflicting projections and results emerged from Florida.

The state was first awarded to Vice-President Al Gore by the television networks and the pollsters. Then that projection was withdrawn less than an hour later. And at 1.15am the state, with its 25 votes in the electoral college, was awarded to Mr Bush, apparently giving him overall victory in the election.

By this time, many Republicans had begun to leave. It was cold, it was raining and it was late. But with the declaration of Mr Bush's victory, a shriek rose up from the stalwarts who had stayed behind.

Hundreds of people turned around and began to run back up Congress Avenue towards the State Capitol and arrived just in time to hear that not other had the Republicans retaken the White House, they had retained control of both the House of Representatives and the Senate. For many, the emotion was too intense and they began to weep, embracing strangers under the rain.

Rock music boomed out across the square, and the crowd readied itself for a victory address by the Texas governor. Yet the waiting stretched from minutes to hours as the rain continued to fall, and still no sign of Mr Bush.

The announcement that there would be a recount was met by stony silence and cries of bewilderment. Bush supporters have been distrustful of what they see as a liberally-biased media since the start of the campaign, and all the seesawing over the Florida count only went to reinforce those prejudices.

Don Evans, Mr Bush's campaign manager, appeared on the podium to make a short statement, stating the Bush camp's conviction that "we will prevail".

As election officials were recalled to their posts in Florida, Jamie Wilson, the executive director of the state's Republican party, reassured Bush loyalists that: "I am sure the recount will confirm that we've won Florida and the next president of the United States will be Governor Bush."

In the last hour before dawn, Republican officials reported that the putative US president had gone to bed to await developments. The rain kept falling and the remaining few thousand stalwarts still outside the pink granite capitol gave up and left for home, unsure what was going on.

webTitle: BBDO wins Nicorette global ad account

fields.headline: BBDO wins Nicorette global ad account
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: The BBDO network has picked up the £28m global Nicorette account, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The BBDO network has been charged with the task of weaning smokers off their habit after picking up the £28m global Nicorette account today.

The win comes swiftly after the company announced a review of the business out of the incumbent agency, BMP DDB, which has held the account for the last two years.

The DDB, BBDO and Saatchi & Saatchi networks all fought for the business.

BBDO will now work on a global campaign for the anti-smoking gum patches and inhaler brands that will run across Nicorette's main markets. These include the UK, northern Europe and Japan.

Pharmacia, Nicorette's parent company, works with other agencies across the US and Canada.

The media account for Nicorette held by Zenith Media has not been included in the review but sources say it may go up for pitch soon.

webTitle: LFF Review: State and Main

fields.headline: LFF Review: State and Main
fields.standfirst:
State and Main
London Film Festival
***
fields.trailText: "Communism's over? Huh! That's what they said about Warner Brothers in 1985!" Just a taste of the zappiest, snappiest dialogue available in the London Film Festival, and there's plenty more gags where that came from in David Mamet's State And Main, a light Capra-esque comedy which descants amusingly, if unsubstantially, on the theme of Hollywood Versus America.
fields.body:
"Communism's over? Huh! That's what they said about Warner Brothers in 1985!" Just a taste of the zappiest, snappiest dialogue available in the London Film Festival, and there's plenty more gags where that came from in David Mamet's State And Main, a light Capra-esque comedy which descants amusingly, if unsubstantially, on the theme of Hollywood Versus America.

William H Macy is a haggard film director strung out on his own nervous energy who turns up in a picturesque little town with his caravan of faintly unwholesome movie folk, including Bob Barrenger (Alec Baldwin), a louche leading man with a taste for underage girls. It turns out that they have been virtually run out of the last town they were in by creditors, so now they have to make their movie with whatever buildings happen to be around them.

Philip Seymour Hoffman is Joseph, a once promising dramatist, lured into writing the screenplay for this film and now driven to distraction by fanatical demands for rewrites from Macy and from Marty Rossen, the quicksilver-tempered producer: a very funny performance from David Paymer.

Hoffman (who is everywhere at the LFF this year) gives a performance which establishes him credibly as a romantic funny-valentine type leading man, as he spurns the sexual advances of leading lady Claire (Sarah Jessica Parker) in favour of the brainy bookstore owner Ann, nicely played by Rebecca Pidgeon with much more style and ease than in The Winslow Boy, David Mamet's unhappy and baffling excursion into British drawing room drama.

Hoffman's basso profundo voice is always at its most compelling when it slows right down to a 45rpm-single-played-at-33rpm drawl, indicating agonised indecision and introspection: the kind of semi-inchoate groan that he first treated us to in Todd Solondz's Happiness. We get some of this here, and some of his gamely perky persona, his attempt to get along and go along with whatever craziness the movie industry is going to dish out.

It wouldn't be a David Mamet film without some sort of deception and illusion and this duly arrives when Hoffman is forced to choose between his principles and his need to clamber up the Hollywood ladder.

As in his stage-play Speed-The-Plow, Mamet uses the wicked world of showbiz and the movies as the showcase for some fairly undemanding ethical dilemmas, but there is a lot of fun to be had here, and terrific performances from Hoffman, Macy and Paymer.

webTitle: LEAs not liable for bullying outside school gates, rules High Court

fields.headline: LEAs not liable for bullying outside school gates, rules High Court
fields.trailText: Local education authorities cannot be held responsible for bullying which takes place off school premises, even on a school bus, the High Court ruled today.
fields.body:
Local education authorities cannot be held responsible for bullying which takes place off school premises, even on a school bus, the High Court ruled today.

Mr Justice Garland rejected a claim for £75,000 in damages by Leah Bradford-Smart, who said she suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder as a result of West Sussex LEA's negligence.

Miss Bradford-Smart, now 19, claimed that she suffered "persistent and prolonged bullying" while a pupil at Ifield Middle School in Crawley between 1990 and 1993. She said she was chased around the playground, thrown against fences, suffered taunts, and that on one occasion was pushed into the road in front of a car as she waited for the school bus.

The LEA argued that there was very little, if any, sign that she was being bullied at the school and that she and her mother "greatly exaggerated" how often any such bullying was brought to the attention of the school. The judge was asked to rule on the issue of liability only.

He concluded: "Granted a school knows that a pupil is being bullied at home or on the way to and from school, it would not be practical let alone fair, just and reasonable, to impose upon it a greater duty than to take reasonable steps to prevent that bullying spilling over into the school."

"We are naturally very disappointed by the result," said Miss Bradford-Smart after the failure of the appeal. "However, our evidence was substantially accepted by the judge. The decision turned on whether the school had a duty which extended beyond the school gates - and on that point the judge found against us."

Miss Bradford-Smart's solicitor, Jack Rabinowicz, said: "The problem is that he has drawn a distinction between the school's responsibilities inside and outside the school gates. It seems to us that bullying is accepted as being very pernicious, very disruptive of school life, and to allow bullies to drag a pupil out of a school just seems to be a distinction which gives schools and bullies the green light to make things worse."

A spokeswoman for West Sussex county council said it was "very pleased" by the decision. "We have very effective anti-bullying policies in our schools, but that is not to say we are complacent." An Ofsted report in 1996 found that complaints of bullying were dealt with "promptly, firmly and sensibly."

Mr Justice Garland said it was generally accepted that a school owes a duty of care to a child on the school premises to safeguard physical well-being, "the duty being no greater than that of a parent of a large family". One of the themes that "underlay consideration of the evidence" in the case was that teachers regarded Mrs Bradford-Smart as supportive, sensible and not prone to exaggerate and Leah as a child who did not tell lies and who was generally well-behaved and co-operative.

He had no hesitation in finding that from July 1992 Leah was "seriously bullied at home and on the bus going to and from school".

He asked: "Is a school to be concerned with bullying only at the bus stop immediately outside the school gate, on the bus itself or arising from anti-social behaviour between families on a housing estate? A school's powers are limited to what might best be described as inquiry and counselling which may in certain circumstances exacerbate rather than ameliorate the situation."

He said: "I would regard the duty as going no further than to prevent the bullying actually happening inside the school; in other words, to take effective, defensive measures. If the school chooses, as a matter of judgment, to be pro-active then that is a matter of discretion, not obligation.

"In my judgment , a school cannot reasonably be expected to do more than to take reasonable steps to prevent a child being bullied while it is actually at the school." He had decided that Leah's class teacher did take reasonable steps to safeguard her while she was actually at school, ruling that accordingly the teenager's claim must fail.

webTitle: Brown to include fuel and pension concessions

fields.headline: Brown to include fuel and pension concessions
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown is expected to make concessions to fuel and pensions campaigners while keeping his reputation for prudence in his pre-budget report today.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown is expected to make concessions to fuel and pensions campaigners while keeping his reputation for prudence in his pre-budget report today.

The latest speculation about his eagerly awaited "mini-Budget" centred on plans to slash duty on ultra-low sulphur petrol. It is hoped that this will encourage motorists and oil companies to switch to the supposedly "greener" fuel.

Mr Brown is expected to announce a boost of at least £5 a week for single pensioners, and £8 a week for couples, and a freeze on fuel duty for conventional petrol and diesel.

He has also been tipped to appease truckers by levying a £1,500 charge on foreign drivers operating in Britain.

However, Mr Brown and the prime minister, Tony Blair, have both stressed that nothing will be done to jeopardise long-term economic stability by "blowing" any of the surplus billions in Treasury coffers to buy short term popularity.

The Bank of England governor, Sir Eddie George, has warned a big spending spree would lead to higher interest - and mortgage - rates.

MPs are eagerly awaiting Mr Brown's statement in the Commons at 3.30pm, which will set the scene for the next election. This morning, Mr Brown was briefing his cabinet colleagues on the report.

The report is supposed to lay the framework for next spring's full Budget. But more announcements than usual are expected today, with a general election widely forecast for next May.

Mr Blair has promised Mr Brown will put long-term economic stability "first, second and third". But the Tories have continued to press for at least a 3p cut in petrol and diesel duty.

Conservatives and Liberal Democrats claimed that any concessions on fuel or pensions would be reluctantly extracted from the chancellor.

Tory Treasury spokesman Oliver Letwin said: "I am sure Gordon Brown would rather not have to make this sort of statement at all.

"He has been dragged kicking and screaming to the altar to do something for pensioners and something for the people who drive."

Fuel protesters have argued for a 26p cut and threatened a repeat of September's campaign which left motorists panicking at the pumps, the NHS on "red alert" and supermarkets with dwindling food supplies if they are not satisfied with the government's actions by 13 November.

webTitle: Windies and England bosses hit wrong note

fields.headline: Windies and England bosses hit wrong note
fields.trailText: In terms of standing by your man, Hillary Rodham Clinton has nothing on Patrick Rousseau, the president of the West Indies cricket board. Not only does Brian Lara "not have a case to answer", about whether he accepted $40,000 to underperform in two one-day matches in India in 1994-95, he should sue. "I would," declared Rousseau, a former lawyer, in an extraordinarily strong response to the World Service's BBC Caribbean Report. "I don't believe a word of it. I'm pretty sure Brian had nothing to do with this character (MK Gupta)." Rousseau criticised the Indian authorities for "putting out such a poor set of statements", relying on the uncorroborated evidence of an illegal bookmaker. "Nonsense" was one of his milder descriptions of the document. Crucially, he added: "It's Sir Paul's job to mount an inquiry anyway. The WICB would only mount an inquiry if there's satisfactory evidence. I certainly don't consider those statements satisfactory evidence."
fields.body:
In terms of standing by your man, Hillary Rodham Clinton has nothing on Patrick Rousseau, the president of the West Indies cricket board. Not only does Brian Lara "not have a case to answer", about whether he accepted $40,000 to underperform in two one-day matches in India in 1994-95, he should sue. "I would," declared Rousseau, a former lawyer, in an extraordinarily strong response to the World Service's BBC Caribbean Report. "I don't believe a word of it. I'm pretty sure Brian had nothing to do with this character (MK Gupta)." Rousseau criticised the Indian authorities for "putting out such a poor set of statements", relying on the uncorroborated evidence of an illegal bookmaker. "Nonsense" was one of his milder descriptions of the document. Crucially, he added: "It's Sir Paul's job to mount an inquiry anyway. The WICB would only mount an inquiry if there's satisfactory evidence. I certainly don't consider those statements satisfactory evidence."

I hope Rousseau reflects on that and changes tack and tone. The report does have clear weaknesses, with its overreliance on what MK said and its straight reporting of it. Its quaint language (MK being telephonically introduced to this player and that) and sub-Bollywood detective prose does not help. But the mood music from the Windies supremo, and Lord MacLaurin, his opposite number on the England and Wales Cricket Board, has not struck the right note.

It's easy to kick the ball into an open goal, that is stick by their players in the face of unsubstantiated charges, but they should also give credit to the Indian investigators for trying get to the bottom of match-fixing, no matter how amateurish the effort appears. Many were similarly dismissive when the Indians first fingered Hansie Cronje, and look what happened. Rousseau and the West Indies team management in Australia are right to stick by Lara, and to presume him innocent. But like India, Pakistan and South Africa, they should have their own inquiry - they must be seen to be doing something.

Lord MacLaurin has been trying to clarify apparently contradictory statements about what should happen to players under suspicion. After appearing to suggest expulsion until the charges are investigated, he claims he was misunderstood. Co-operation is the key, he says, meaning a simple Q and A with a player. If he denies taking money from bookies for information or to fix matches, that's enough. That's OK by me. But it's amazing that MacLaurin should equate this sort of denial with a drugs test in athletics, as he did on BBC Radio on Sunday morning. A drugs test is scientific proof of cheating, even if the results are subjected to retesting, review and appeal. His answers suggest he hasn't properly thought the issue through. It's time he and Rousseau had a chat.

Alec Stewart? I recall the glitzy promotional launch of the World Cup last year, when the then England captain was taking questions from the media pack. In the middle of a tub-thumping speech talking up England's chances mostly for the benefit of the Fleet Street pack, I asked him for an assessment of the other teams and how he thought they'd do. The blue eyes registered a moment of surprise, he mumbled something about South Africa and India for all of 10 seconds, and then as if remembering he was there to help create the next day's Sun and Mirror headlines, he returned to his central theme - England could win the thing. A disappointing answer, but I understood. For Stewart, appearances count for an awful lot. This stain on his reputation must be killing him.

Seen in that light, the unwavering support of Lord MacLaurin and David Graveney makes sense. It goes further than Stewart's reputation for probity. In articulating England's vision, he was the most on-message captain of recent times, taking over after years of Mike Atherton's barely concealed disdain for the media. Stewie is English to his core and if anyone embodies traditional English values, he does. Yet he's no choirboy. He's not the sort of player who walks after edging it. It rarely occurred to him that he shouldn't be claiming catches that bumped or non-existent snicks. One of the images of the Barbados test two years ago was of him rubbing his forearm after edging an attempted hook to the keeper off Franklyn Rose.

None of this makes him a cheat, and with his word against Gupta's it's no contest. That Brian Lara is no choirboy is much more obvious. That it doesn't make him a croooked cricketer is equally true. He's accused of something far more serious, and given his year of turmoil, his suffering must be even more acute than Stewart's. In time we should see in both cases whether it's the pain of having a dark secret uncovered, or the pain of being falsely accused.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for six years and currently works as a broadcast journalist. To read his previous column, Say it ain't so Pat Rousseau, click here

It rarely occurred to him that he shouldn't be claiming catches that bumped or non-existent snicks. One of the images of the Barbados test two years ago was of him rubbing his forearm after edging an attempted hook to the keeper off Franklyn Rose. None of this makes him a cheat, and with his word against Gupta's it's no contest. That Brian Lara is no choirboy is much more obvious. That it doesn't make him a croooked cricketer is equally true. He's accused of something far more serious, and given his year of turmoil, his suffering must be even more acute than Stewart's. In time we should see in both cases whether it's the pain of having a dark secret uncovered, or the pain of being falsely accused. Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for six years and currently works as a broadcast journalist. To read his previous column, Say it ain't so Pat Rousseau, click here

webTitle: Knowledge Unlimited

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk. We'll do our best to answer them
fields.trailText: PUTTING IT ON YOUR SHIRT
fields.body:
PUTTING IT ON YOUR SHIRT

"You said that Liverpool were the first British club to have a shirt sponsor (Hitachi in 1979), but while Liverpool are doubtless the first professional club to be sponsored, I'm pretty sure Kettering beat them to it by a few years. This is not a wind-up. Maybe you can confirm it?" asks Jon Cudby.

Having spoken to Kettering club historian Mel Hopkins, Jon, we can indeed.

When Wolves striker Derek Dougan retired from football in the summer of 1975, he joined Southern League club Kettering Town as chief executive. Within a month of his appointment, he had brokered a "four-figure" deal with local firm Kettering Tyres, and in a SL game against Bath City on January 24 1976, Kettering became the first British club to run out with a company's name emblazoned on their shirts.

Sadly, the groundbreaking new strip would not get another run-out. Four days later, the FA predictably ordered the club to remove the new slogan, despite Dougan's claim that the ruling body's 1972 ban on sponsorship had not been put down in writing.

Characteristically, Dougan didn't take this body blow lying down. He cheekily changed the wording on the shirts to Kettering T, which he claimed stood for Town and had nothing whatsoever to do with Tyres. For a couple of heady months, the team played on under the new slogan.

Sure enough, however, Kettering were soon up before the FA, who in April ordered them to "remove the words Kettering T from their strip". The threat of a £1,000 fine was too much for such a small club, and the words were reluctantly removed.

There would be one final irony. Kettering didn't let the matter lie - after all, clubs like Bayern Munich had been coining it in on the continent for years - and so, with Derby and Bolton, they put forward a proposal to the FA regarding shirt sponsorship. But although the proposal was accepted on June 3 1977, Kettering could not find a sponsor for the upcoming season. Meanwhile, Derby players began that season running around in Saab shirts and Saab cars. Where's the justice?

MILLER TIME

"On American TV during the late Seventies / early Eighties, Miller Lite ran adverts with famous athletes endorsing their product," Tim McCarthy said last week. "The only football one I saw involved an English winger (possibly named Steve) talking about how he used to take out the trash with his feet when he was a kid. He then pours a bottle with his foot. Any idea who he was?"

The jury's out on this one, Tim. Initially we had a flood of emails from the States - well, alright, three - claiming that the star in question was Rodney Marsh, who was at the time playing in the NASL for Tampa Bay Rowdies. The author of one, Dan Jones, even went as far to say he remembers "booing every time it came on the telly".

However, Robin McMillan is not alone in thinking that the player in question was "probably Steve Hunt, who played with the New York Cosmos and was bought by Coventry. The players featured in these commercials had to have retired or moved overseas, which suggests this has to be the early Eighties."

QUICK QUESTION

"Who was the last English manager to win the league?" asks Brian Harrison. "As this makes him the most successful English manager in recent history, is this who we want as England manager?"

Allow us to take your points in order, Brian. 1) Howard Wilkinson (who led Leeds to the last-ever Football League championship in 1992); 2) No.

DO IT YOURSELF

A strange one from Peter Gunthorpe - he's sent us in a question and supplied us with the answer himself. But as it's an interesting one, here goes:

"I wondered if you know of a player in the Football League (as it was then) playing in a Second Division match for Side A v Side B one Saturday, then playing for Side C v Side D on the same ground the following week?"

"Jack Hodgson played for Grimsby against Rotherham at Belle Vue, Doncaster (Rotherham had a ban on playing at Millmoor). He was then transferred to Doncaster during the week and played his first game for his new club on the same ground that Saturday. I think it was 1948 or 1949."

We feel so redundant

SICK SHIRTS

The worst-ever kit rumpus rumbles on. "Look no further than Bournemouth's acid-induced nightmare away kit from the early Nineties. Purple, blue and green in a crazy potato-print pattern," chunders Andy Smith.

And Fraser Lees sounds even queasier. "While several unsavoury Celtic away kits have appeared over the last decade, unforgivable was the third strip which fleetingly revealed itself round about 1992," he writes.

"It was a colourful lime greenish number but decorated over the shoulder and chest with cascading speckles of white, lime green, dark green, tan and dark brown - resembling for all the world like someone had spewed over the shirt wearer. It was affectionately known amongst the support as the biryani."

At least Tom Morgan still has an appetite. "As if their name isn't comedic enough, South American team Sport Boys take to the field in a fetching frosted-pink kit," he explains.

"Therefore, brown Coventry vs Da Boys would be like two-thirds of a Neapolitan ice-cream: if the ref wore a Saffron-coloured kit it'd make up the holy ice-cream trinity."

CAN YOU HELP?

"Has anyone played for a First Division side in each of the big four European leagues (Italy, Spain, England, Germany)?" asks Paul Carek. "If so, who was the last to do it? Who was the most successful?"

"Who are the least successful side in the history of the Football League?" asks Bob Cole.

Anyone who knows can mail their answer to the.boss@theguardian.com. And you can use the same address to send your questions: we'll do our best to answer them.

webTitle: November 7 ratings

fields.headline: Queen of mean's ratings slip
fields.trailText: 1pm TV overnights: Anne Robinson's The Weakest Link may not prove the BBC1 ratings juggernaut the BBC was hoping for after last night's dip in viewing figures. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Anne Robinson's queen of mean act on The Weakest Link may have caught the media's imagination, but after last night's dip in viewing figures the quiz show may not prove the BBC1 ratings juggernaut the BBC was hoping for.

On the day the BBC went into PR overdrive by inviting a bunch of journalists to endure Ms Robinson's scathing put-downs, The Weakest Link was 1.2m viewers down on its debut last week, according to unofficial overnights.

The quiz show averaged 6.6m and a 28% share from 8.25pm; while last week it benefited from being scheduled between two editions of EastEnders, taking 7.8m and 32%.

The Weakest Link was up against The Bill and a 9pm news special on ITV. The Bill averaged 8.7m - a 37% share - from 8-9pm with a continuing storyline about DCI Meadows (Simon Rouse) investigating the murder of his ex-lover's son.

ITV's fifth flood news special averaged 8.9m and a 38% share.

Elsewhere last night, a lantern-jawed turn from Harrison Ford as a US president battling plane-hijacking Ruskie terrorists in hit movie Air Force One boosted Channel 5's ratings.

The terrestrial premiere of Air Force One drew an average audience of 3.3m and a 17% share over nearly 180 minutes from 9pm, undoubtedly taking viewers away from the other channels.

BBC1 drama The Sins dipped to 4.4m and a 19% share, compared with 6.6m and 28% a week ago, while the Ten O'Clock News slipped by half a million to 4.8m and 23%.

But Channel 4's The Real Paula Yates, which kicked off a new run of the biography series, still prospered on the eve of the inquest into her untimely death. The documentary averaged 3.4m and a 15% share from 9.30-10.30pm.

Earlier in the evening, BBC2's Home Front was the main beneficiary of Channel 4's ratings generosity in scheduling the Booker Prize over 60 minutes from 8pm.

Live coverage of the literary award ceremony averaged just 0.6m and a 3% share, 1.3m less than documentary Crash Detectives drew last week.

By contrast, Home Front was up by 1.1m on last week, to 3.3m and a 14% share across the same hour-long stretch.

webTitle: Leeds fan stable after stabbing

fields.headline: Leeds fan stable after stabbing
fields.trailText: A Leeds United fan is said to be in a stable condition today after suffering multiple stab wounds during a brawl in downtown Milan last night, ahead of the Yorskhire club's crucial Champions League match in the San Siro.
fields.body:
A Leeds United fan is said to be in a stable condition today after suffering multiple stab wounds during a brawl in downtown Milan last night, ahead of the Yorskhire club's crucial Champions League match in the San Siro.

The 31-year-old, who has not yet been named, is currently recovering in casualty at the Italian city's Fatebenefratelli hospital. Early reports claimed he had undergone surgery for a pierced bladder but club officials, who have visited him, say his injuries are not, as was first reported, life threatening.

United have maintained, however, that the man was not sold a match ticket by the club and was not on an officially recognised trip organised by them.

During Leeds' Uefa Cup campaign last year, two supporters, Kevin Speight and Christopher Loftus, were stabbed to death in Turkey before the side's match against Galatasaray.

Last night's incident sent a chilling reminder of that tragic evening, which was only seven months ago, to Ray Fell, chairman of the Leeds United Supporters' Association.

He said: "I'm rather shattered. After the deaths of two of our supporters earlier this year in Turkey I hoped it was something we would never have to go through again.

"We are continually looking to see what steps are being taken to prevent a repeat of events in Istanbul. You liaise with everybody but you can only do so much."

Over 6,000 supporters are expected to follow the club to Italy tonight for the Group H game which Leeds must get a point from if they are to guarantee their progress to the next stage of the competition.

It is the largest number of people to have followed the club abroad since their 1975 European cup final in Paris.

The Leeds chairman, Peter Ridsdale, said he felt drained by the news and was concerned that it did not affect the performance of the team.

He told Skysports.com: "So far we have tried to shield the team from the news - clearly when you travel you do not want to hear of incidents such as this."

webTitle: The new editor of WCM

fields.headline: The new editor of WCM
fields.trailText: Stephen Fay, former deputy editor of the Independent on Sunday, has been appointed the new editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. He replaces Tim de Lisle, who is taking charge of wisden.com, the cricket website which is about to undergo major expansion.
fields.body:
Stephen Fay, former deputy editor of the Independent on Sunday, has been appointed the new editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. He replaces Tim de Lisle, who is taking charge of wisden.com, the cricket website which is about to undergo major expansion.

Fay is a journalist with a rich range of experience. He has had two stints as deputy editor of the Independent on Sunday (acting as editor for three months). Before that he was, among other things, editor of Business magazine, and spent 20 years on the Sunday Times in jobs ranging from Washington correspondent to (up-market) gossip columnist. He has also written and co-authored seven books.

He has a lifelong love of cricket, dating back to watching Denis Compton and Don Bradman after the war - but only began writing about the game regularly seven years ago.

Wisden Cricket Monthly has won many plaudits since Tim de Lisle took over as editor in 1996 and made the magazine one of the most vibrant publications in sport. Last year, he beat off competition from many larger publications to be chosen as Special Interest magazine editor of the year.

"Although Stephen is 62, this appointment is really part of our youth policy," said Matthew Engel, Wisden's editor-in-chief. "He came late to cricket writing and so has retained his passion for the game and writes about it in a very fresh way. He isn't going to edit an elderly magazine.

"But his strong background in other fields is going to give WCM enormous authority on the great cricketing issues of the day, which now go beyond over-rates and bonus points. We have a lot of talented young contributors and staff at Wisden, and we hope Stephen will nurture them so he has a natural heir."

Steven Lynch, the magazine's deputy editor since 1985, is to move with Tim to take on an important executive role at wisden.com.

webTitle: Ericsson cuts ad shortlist to four

fields.headline: Ericsson cuts ad shortlist to four
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Ericsson has chopped the shortlist for its global ad account to four, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
One of the most fiercely contested advertising pitches this year moved a stage closer to completion this week as Ericsson chopped its shortlist of competitors to four.

BBDO, TBWA, Bartle Bogle Hegarty and the incumbent, Young & Rubicam, are all through to the next round of pitches for the mobile phone giant's £100m global consumer advertising business.

An appointment is expected at the end of the year.

A review was called last month when industry insiders said they believed Ericsson to be unhappy with Y&R's recent work. This included the company's long-running slogan, "Make Yourself Heard".

Y&R has handled the business since 1996, when it was the first global agency to be selected by Ericsson. Last year the company appointed Publicis to create a £33m global ad campaign for the business market.

News of the review follows months of turbulence in Ericsson's mobile phone division, which saw the company's shares plunge 16% at the beginning of last month.

Ericsson is the world's third-largest mobile phone company after Nokia and Motorola.

webTitle: Derbyshire crew cleared over tragedy

fields.headline: Derbyshire crew cleared over tragedy
fields.trailText: The captain and crew of the ill-fated bulk carrier Derbyshire were cleared today of any involvement in the sinking of the 160,000-tonne vessel.
fields.body:
The captain and crew of the ill-fated bulk carrier Derbyshire were cleared today of any involvement in the sinking of the 160,000-tonne vessel.

A second inquiry into the tragedy - in which all 42 crew and two of their wives lost their lives - refuted the findings of an earlier investigation which blamed the sinking on a badly-secured hatch cover.

Reporting its findings today, the latest inquiry, headed by a high court judge, put the blame for the disaster on inadequate hatch covers which bent and buckled when the vessel encountered 80ft waves in a Pacific typhoon off the coast of Japan in September 1980.

This allowed water to pour into the space above the cargo causing the vessel to plunge deeper, increasing the pressure on other hatch covers which burst and directly led to the massive ship sinking two-and-a-half miles to the bottom.

Mr Justice Colman concluded that minimum strength requirements laid down by international convention for massive ships such as the Derbyshire were "seriously deficient".

He called on the government to press "strongly and urgently" for new standards for hatch cover strength.

The judge said any amendment should be applicable not only to new ships but all existing bulk carriers because present hatch cover design "poses an unacceptable risk to the safety of those vessels and their crews".

Mr Justice Colman said the "tragedy and mystery" of the sinking of the largest British ship ever lost at sea began in 1980 when it disappeared without trace about 350 miles south east of Japan.

The four-year-old vessel was nearly three times the length of the playing area at Wembley stadium, considerably wider than the Titanic or the QE2 and manned by a competent and experienced master and crew, said the judge.

"Not surprisingly, the families of those who perished in this tragedy were extremely anxious to know what had caused such a catastrophic loss of life."

The first investigation took place between October 1987 and March 1988 and found that the ship was "probably overwhelmed by the forces of nature".

The Derbyshire Families Association pressed for an underwater survey but the exact location of the vessel was not known until the 1990s.

When the technology became available to conduct a survey two-and-a-half miles down, the assessors found from the photographic evidence that the loss had probably been caused by seawater entering the bow section.

"However, the disturbing aspect of this report was that the main reason for entry of seawater into the bosun's store in the first place was found to be the failure of the crew to secure the lid to the hatch on the foredeck," said the judge. "This conclusion clearly involved the imputation of serious negligence against the officers and crew. It was deeply upsetting to the families of those on board."

The report led the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, to call for a full reopening of the formal investigation.For the first time, it was to be held at the high court.

The Derbyshire Families Association had strongly criticised Oceanroutes, an agency which recommends sea routes and which was appointed by the ship's charterers, for failing in its duty to provide adequate information about the typhoon.

Mr Justice Colman said his report accepts that the message sent to the vessel by Oceanroutes during the height of the storm was "seriously deficient" in information but the agency was not negligent or at fault in failing to advise the master to alter course.

"It can therefore be concluded that the vessel's encounter with the most severe sea conditions of the typhoon arose without the fault either of those on board or of Oceanroutes."

Stephen Cantor, the families's solicitor, said: "We are very pleased that there has been complete exoneration and vindication of the crew  There has been a complete exoneration and vindication of the crew."

Paul Lambert, the chairman of the Derbyshire Family Association, who lost his 19-year-old brother, Peter, in the tragedy, said: "This is a vindication of the families and the decision by John Prescott to hold the second inquiry."

Anne Dowling, from Cornwall, whose father Ali Bujang died on the Derbyshire, said: "I am still in shock. We have finally got answers after 20 years.

Tony Santamera, national secretary of the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers, said: "The crew have been totally exonerated and that fact should be broadcast around the world."
