The four-year-old vessel was nearly three times the length of the playing area at Wembley stadium, considerably wider than the Titanic or the QE2 and manned by a competent and experienced master and crew, said the judge. "Not surprisingly, the families of those who perished in this tragedy were extremely anxious to know what had caused such a catastrophic loss of life." The first investigation took place between October 1987 and March 1988 and found that the ship was "probably overwhelmed by the forces of nature". The Derbyshire Families Association pressed for an underwater survey but the exact location of the vessel was not known until the 1990s. When the technology became available to conduct a survey two-and-a-half miles down, the assessors found from the photographic evidence that the loss had probably been caused by seawater entering the bow section. "However, the disturbing aspect of this report was that the main reason for entry of seawater into the bosun's store in the first place was found to be the failure of the crew to secure the lid to the hatch on the foredeck," said the judge. "This conclusion clearly involved the imputation of serious negligence against the officers and crew. It was deeply upsetting to the families of those on board." The report led the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, to call for a full reopening of the formal investigation.For the first time, it was to be held at the high court. The Derbyshire Families Association had strongly criticised Oceanroutes, an agency which recommends sea routes and which was appointed by the ship's charterers, for failing in its duty to provide adequate information about the typhoon. Mr Justice Colman said his report accepts that the message sent to the vessel by Oceanroutes during the height of the storm was "seriously deficient" in information but the agency was not negligent or at fault in failing to advise the master to alter course. "It can therefore be concluded that the vessel's encounter with the most severe sea conditions of the typhoon arose without the fault either of those on board or of Oceanroutes." Stephen Cantor, the families's solicitor, said: "We are very pleased that there has been complete exoneration and vindication of the crew  There has been a complete exoneration and vindication of the crew." Paul Lambert, the chairman of the Derbyshire Family Association, who lost his 19-year-old brother, Peter, in the tragedy, said: "This is a vindication of the families and the decision by John Prescott to hold the second inquiry." Anne Dowling, from Cornwall, whose father Ali Bujang died on the Derbyshire, said: "I am still in shock. We have finally got answers after 20 years. Tony Santamera, national secretary of the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers, said: "The crew have been totally exonerated and that fact should be broadcast around the world." webTitle: Britain prepares for a cooling of the 'special relationship'

fields.headline: Britain prepares for a cooling of the 'special relationship'
fields.standfirst: Political editor Michael White asks how much the recent close ties between Downing Street and the White House will be loosened by the US election result
fields.trailText: Political editor Michael White asks how much the recent close ties between Downing Street and the White House will be loosened by the US election result.
fields.body:
Hours before the US election night turned into even more of a cliffhanger than had been predicted, ministers and officials in Tony Blair's team were adjusting themselves to the prospect that George W Bush would be president - and putting a brave face on it.

"It will make no difference who wins," said one sophisticated analyst of US politics to whom the prime minister listens closely. "Bush has a lot of good people around him." Twelve hours later, Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, surfaced on radio and TV to say much the same.

"I congratulate George Bush if it is confirmed that he has won, and we look forward to working with him and keeping Britain as that unique bridge between America and Europe," said Mr Cook.

As for ideological differences, "I'm not the slightest worried," he added. "George Bush is firmly within the mainstream of American foreign policy, American tradition."

Similar soothing words came from Labour politicians on the election party circuit in London as the drama unfolded. In reality, the situation is far more delicate if Mr Bush's victory is confirmed, both in terms of party politics - the strange synergy between Clintonian Democrats and new Labour - and the practical calculations of day-to-day government.

It is not just that Mr Bush's brand of "compassionate conservatism" has won a convert in William Hague, it is also that, as an anti-intellectual Texan (despite that Yale education), he is actively suspicious of the "Third Way" politics that animated Blair and Bill Clinton to the extent that they actually attended conferences on the subject.

Business is business between leaders whose states have long-established common interests, but this pair were unusually close. Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher liked and admired each other, but they did not spend a lot of time talking on the phone as premier and president do.

Blair has been known to call the relationship "intense". The two leaders, both lawyers, both quick and clever modernisers with a shared interest in both the ideas and the packaging that win elections, also both have smart lawyer wives with distinct political personalities.

Cherie and Hillary were clearly comfy with each other too. Both had supressed their own political ambitions (until the Senate race).

Tory strategists will claim that a Bush victory signals a swing back to the right, to tougher stances on welfare and crime, to the low-tax years.

All such mood music which will make it easier for Mr Hague to campaign next year as a coming man.

Yet Blairites shrug off such talk. They point out that Hague is not the affable populist that George W made himself become. He has trapped himself on the right wing of the political spectrum, especially on the tax-and-spend issues where Blair and Gordon Brown will pin him down.

If vice-president Al Gore loses, they will murmur that it vindicates Blair's obsession with hanging on to the middle ground that Gore appeared to abandon.

That argument cuts both ways. By failing to inspire core voters - not least by choosing not to use Clinton's campaigning talents - the Goreites lost states, especially in the mid-west and south, which they might have won.

Green candidate Ralph Nader's campaign did not help, taking votes that otherwise would most likely have gone to Gore.

If Gore is belatedly confirmed as victor, the intensity of the "special relationship" (more special here than there) will be less, as will the personal warmth.

But Gore is a man that Downing St, the treasury and foreign office will be reasonably happy with in terms of personal relations (he is a policy wonk as fanatically committed to books and paperwork as Gordon Brown) and policy stances.

That translates as meaning that Gore understands foreign policy - especially the importance of Europe to the US's global interests - that he will, for example, not take US ground troops out of former Yugoslavia, as Bush aides have threatened to more than once. Chancellor Brown's "targeted tax cuts" strategy aimed at those in need will still find friends in Washington.

It is worth noting, however, that Clinton's personal keen interest in the Northern Ireland peace process cannot be replicated. But Gore is an environmentalist in the way Bill Clinton is not. There are losses and gains all round. What Belfast' politicians lose, Jerusalem's may gain.

As it happens, both contenders in the presidential race were committed to raising US defence spending. "Which European politician with any hope of winning an election would campaign on that slogan?" a despairing senior European official asked privately at the weekend.

Britain is America's most effective military ally, but Washington is increasingly unilateralist in its attitude to foreign policy decisions - impatient of Europe and the UN - and wants the EU to pull the kind of military weight it enjoys economically.

For every $3 the US spends on defence, the EU states spend $2, but - thanks to low-tech weapons and cheap conscript armies in key states (not Britain) - that buys only $1 worth of effectiveness.

Whoever wins, pressure on the allies to do more will intensify just as the US itself decides whether to go ahead with its new national missile defence system - which would protect only the US from what are said to be "rogue state" missile threats. Bush is more likely to go ahead than Gore.

Mr Cook's soothing words about the quality of the staff (and parents) at Mr Bush's disposal are true. They had better be.

Apart from Mexico, just across the Rio Grande, the Texas governor has only been out of the US three times, to Asia and the Middle East - never to Europe, even on holiday.

It is unsurprising that remarks by Mr Bush's foreign policy advisor, Professor Condoleeza Rice, about troop withdrawals from Kosovo have scared the allies.

But at a party level, a Bush win would shut down a steady source of ideas - from campaign tactics to welfare-to-work and "zero tolerance" - which has sustained New Labour strategists in search of new ideas. It is also a chilly reminder that a government can run a buoyant economy and still lose an election.

Win or lose, Gore didn't make enough of that, the Labour pundits will say. He allowed voters to take it for granted. It is not a mistake Mr Blair intends to make next year.

fields.standfirst: All today's gossip dresses up in body armour and heads for a day out at the Dome
fields.trailText: Barcelona are set to swoop for Leeds' duo Mark Viduka and Paul Robinson for a combined fee of £17m according to the Daily Star. The Catalan club will finance the deal, says the paper, by selling Frank De Boer, Jari Litmanen and Boudewijn Zenden.
fields.body:
Barcelona are set to swoop for Leeds' duo Mark Viduka and Paul Robinson for a combined fee of £17m according to the Daily Star. The Catalan club will finance the deal, says the paper, by selling Frank De Boer, Jari Litmanen and Boudewijn Zenden.

Another report in the Star claims the new England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson has put a £20m price-tag on his Lazio star Pavel Nedved, currently subject to the attention of Chelsea's Claudio Raineri. If a transfer went ahead the Blues would break the British transfer record they set in the summer when Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink moved to the Bridge. Meanwhile The Sun reveals that Jody Morris can leave the club for £5 million.

Newcastle have renewed their interest in Argentine defender Pablo Paz, currently with Tenerife. Teamtalk says that the South American impressed during a trial last month but manager Bobby Robson could not afford him at the time. Meanwhile the Mirror reports that the Magpies will release their£6m injury-prone defender Marcelino.

Roy Evans will arrive in Bradford today to act as Stuart McCall's temporary number two while Geoffrey Richmond decides upon a permanent fixture for the manager's position, according to the Mirror.

Marian Pahars is the latest striker to be linked with a move to Manchester City. The Latvian, currently employed by Southampton, is firmly in Joe Royle's mind says Teamtalk.

The Star reports that Coventry are hoping to capture Honduran Jorge Samuel Cabellero to join his fellow countrymen Ivan Guerrrero and Jairo Martinez at Highfield Road. However Planet football reports that West Ham, Middlesbrough, Coventry, Spurs and Newcastle are also in the hunt for his signature.

Meanwhile, according to the same Star, Colin Hendry is leaving the Sky Blues to replace the Charlton-bound Mark Fish at Bolton.

WBA boss Gary Megson is after Brentford midfielder Martin Rowlands, says Teamtalk. The Baggies manager will pay £1.5m for the man from Griffin Park.

webTitle: Belfast Telegraph wins website of the year award

fields.headline: Belfast Telegraph wins website of the year award
fields.trailText: 12am: The Belfast Telegraph has scooped the award for internet site of the year in the Newspaper Society's first ever new media awards, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Belfast Telegraph has scooped the award for internet site of the year in the Newspaper Society's first ever new media awards.

But significantly there were no entries for the category of "most commercially successful internet publisher".

The awards mark the first time that the society has awarded gongs for regional press internet sites.

But in the increasingly competitive world of regional publishing, no newspaper group was confident enough to enter the category that rewarded financial success.

Judges said the Belfast Telegraph site provided "great depth of content and numerous interactive features ensuring it remains at the forefront of technological development".

Other winners included Kent Messenger Group's Kentonline, which won the award for the best internet site from a weekly newspaper.

Cambridge Evening News's Cambridge News Online won the award for best innovation in digital publishing, while Eastern County Newspapers' pinkun.com won the best niche internet site award.

webTitle: The wagers of sin

fields.headline: The wagers of sin
fields.standfirst: James Richardson on a potential betting scandal in Italy that makes England players look positively respectable
fields.trailText: There's a betting scandal brewing in Italy that makes England players look positively respectable
fields.body:
Good news for jealous England fans: while the spectre of gambling threatens the soul of our national team, flash old continental Italian football has precious little to brag about. Right now in fact the world of calcio is facing the possibility of its biggest betting scandal for 15 years, and round these parts that's saying something.

At the heart of the story are Atalanta, Italy's Cinderella side. Newly promoted to the top division this summer, they'd managed to reach the very top of Serie A with just some home-grown talent, a sprinkling of veterans and a rookie coach. However their fairy-tale season now looks like turning grim.

Here's the deal, as they say at Bisham Abbey. On August 20th Atalanta played Serie B side Pistoiese in the Italian cup. The game finished 1-1, after Atalanta's had held a halftime lead. Italian bookmakers SNAI had quoted this combination at 11-1 and faced a payout of over a million pounds after a flurry of late bets. Sore losers, they contacted the Italian FA who, backed by Italy's police forces, immediately launched a low-key investigation.

Their findings look extremely damaging. Phone records show repeated contacts between players on the two teams on the eve of the match. Worse still, SNAI say their accounts show bets were placed by friends and relatives in some cases straight after receiving calls from the players. Eight players have now been named by the Italian FA in connection with the case; five from Pistoiese and three from Atalanta - including their biggest talent, Cristiano Doni. All eight have protested their innocence.

[Legal footnote: gambling is now legal in Italy even for football players, but a quick glance at the statute book confirms rigging matches to suit your wagers is not. The Italian FA calls it 'sporting fraud' and in this case they're pressing for the maximum penalty - a five year suspension from the game. They've fixed a trial date for the case for the 21st of November, until when they accused players are allowed to keep playing.]

"Many footballers bet," says Pistoiese's Massimo Allegri, a midfielder once tipped for great things, "but we're innocent of these charges. One phone call they've included was just a request to swap jerseys at the final whistle. It's ridiculous and nauseating. SNAI have some answering to do." "At least they still let us work," comments Cristiano Doni. "3-4 games will help me unload the tension."

What can happen now? In 1980 Italy's top division was hit by a major gambling scandals - among the results were relegation for Lazio and Milan, and a two year suspension from the game for Paolo Rossi, the future World Cup star. In 1985 Udinese and Lazio (again) had points deducted. This time round there's no suggestion of penalties for the clubs, although Atalanta would still be hit hard by a guilty sentence - two of the players are in their starting line-up, and Doni represents one of their biggest potential sales come summer. In the meantime, at least, the teams' on-field performances haven't suffered amid all the suspicion.

Could a SNAI defeat yet be on the cards? The odds aren't great but let's hope so anyway - with the bookmakers highlighting four or five more games from the last Serie B campaign they'd like investigated, this could otherwise become a rigging scandal to match the Good Ship Venus. Stand by for further news after the trial opens.

webTitle: Minister predicts jobs boom in creative industries

fields.headline: Minister predicts job boom in creative industries
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Film and broadcasting minister Janet Anderson has predicted a flood of new jobs in the creative industries, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Around 50,000 new jobs will be created in "creative industries" in the next three years, film and broadcasting minister Janet Anderson predicted today.

Advertising, TV and the performing arts will see a jobs boom extending to cities outside London including Manchester, Sheffield, Huddersfield and Birmingham.

Speaking at the London College of Fashion's Millennium Conference, Ms Anderson said: "The creative industries generate around £60bn of revenue each year and employ 1.4m people.

"The creativity of the British is one of our greatest strengths and this government is fully behind those who develop and make the most of this creativity to generate wealth and jobs.

She added that the creative industries are growing at a rate of 5% a year, twice the national average, growth that is not confined to the capital.

"We can realistically expect to see the creation of nearly 50,000 new jobs in the UK within these industries over the next three years.

"A majority of these will be skilled jobs - widening our skills base and equipping us as a nation to take the lead in the development and use of new, creative technologies."

webTitle: Yates verdict

fields.headline: Paula Yates: coroner's verdict
fields.trailText: 11.30pm: A London coroner today returned a verdict that Paula Yates died from non-dependent abuse of drugs after taking heroin.
fields.body:
A London coroner today returned a verdict that Paula Yates died from non-dependent abuse of drugs after taking heroin.

Dr Paul Knapman was speaking at the inquest into the former TV presenter's death on September 16 at Westminster Coroners Court.

Ms Yates's body was found in the bedroom of her house in Notting Hill, west London, by a friend, Josephine Fairley Sams.

Another friend, Belinda Brewin, told the coroner she went to see Ms Yates on September 16 and "could tell that she had been taking drugs".

webTitle: Thus reports further losses, but shares rise

fields.headline: Thus posts further losses but shares rise
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Telecoms outfit Thus is still down in the stock market dumps, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Beleaguered telecoms outfit Thus is still down in the stock market dumps despite getting a much-needed thumbs up for its latest results.

The owner of Demon internet reported more losses in its first-half results, but the figures were accompanied by some good news about the company's finances.

The company, which saw its shares pummelled when the tech bubble burst in the spring, said interim losses were £37.2m, against £61.2m last year.

But the shares rose 9p, or 11%, to 89p on the news that second-quarter sales had risen 5% to £53.3m.

Analysts also welcomed the appointment of John Maguire from Cable & Wireless as chief financial officer.

Controlling shareholder Scottish Power added to the good news by increasing the company's credit facility by £100m to £320m.

William Allan, Thus chief executive, said: "We remain confident that we are on track to achieve stronger revenue growth and improve performance in the second half."

Despite the attempts to soothe market concerns, the stock remains some way off its March high of 844.5p, following a blitz of post-bubble profit warnings.

Mr Allan added that the company was changing from a regional telecoms provider to a national player in the internet market.

However, Thus admitted that internet sales were flat at £37.3m, up a mere £100,000 from last year, due to a fall in subscribers.

webTitle: AOL rolls out unmetered internet access

fields.headline: AOL rolls out unmetered internet access nationwide
fields.standfirst:
Nov 8: Fresh AOL/Time Warner concessions
Sept 19: AOL launches unmetered internet access
fields.trailText:
11.15am: AOL has stayed kept its word and opened up its unmetered internet access service to the whole of the UK, writes Amy Vickers.
Nov 8: Fresh AOL/Time Warner concessions
Sept 19: AOL launches unmetered internet access
fields.body:
AOL has kept its word and opened up its unmetered internet access service to the whole of the UK.

The flat-rate service was initially only available to existing AOL members and cynics said at the time of launch that AOL might drag its heels on rolling out the service to non-members.

From Monday, consumers can pick up AOL Flat-rate CDs from any Asda supermarket, call a number or register for the call-free service for £14.99 per month at aol.co.uk.

Buoyed by public interest surrounding the flat-fee plan when it launched at the start of September, AOL claims that its overall UK membership has passed the landmark figure of 1m customers.

The extended roll-out coincides with the launch of AOL's new mobile offerings - a Wap service and SMS text messaging from a PC to a phone.

AOL UK managing director Karen Thomson said; "Today marks an historic turning point for the interactive medium in this country, as we at AOL UK are fulfilling our pledge to 'Stop the Clock' for UK consumers."

webTitle: Chaos and crisis serves American voters badly

fields.headline: Chaos and crisis serves American voters badly
fields.standfirst: With the outcome of the US presidential election resting on a tiny number of votes in Florida, Simon Tisdall examines the voting system that left the country on a political precipice
fields.trailText: With the outcome of the US presidential election resting on a tiny number of votes in Florida, Simon Tisdall examines the voting system that left the country on a political precipice.
fields.body:
The tumultuous and extraordinary confusion that enveloped the US presidential election this morning will certainly bring demands for a re-examination of the way Americans elects their leaders.

Although president Bill Clinton remains in charge of the country until January 20, there was no escaping the sense of deepening political crisis as the Democratic candidate, vice-president Al Gore, first conceded the contest to Republican George W Bush, and then retracted his concession.

Under scrutiny will be the first-past-the-post system that gives the candidate who wins the popular vote in any given state all that state's electoral college votes.

In Florida, for example, where a recount was under way, Mr Bush and Mr Gore effectively halved the vote between them. In a rational world, that would give them half each of Florida's college votes. But one fiftieth of a per cent looks likely to be enough not only to give the state to one of the candidate's but also, this year, the entire contest.

The electoral college itself may also come under review. The founding fathers of the US intended it as a fail-safe device to ensure that the country's government was insulated from the wilder vagaries of public opinion.

In other words, the framers of the Constitution did not entirely trust democracy. By creating a college of electors, they effectively hoped to keep control of the process.

In an era when democracy is deemed by the US to be the best governing system - not only for itself but the rest of the world - such considerations seem out-of-date. The US electorate is certainly better educated, better informed on the issues (when it wants to be), and more easily communicated with than at any time in the country's history.

The impact of the Greens' presidential candidate, Ralph Nader, on this year's result will also be carefully deconstructed. There is really no room in the US presidential election structure for third-party candidates, so dominant have the Democrats and Republicans become.

But it is palpably absurd that, in a country of about 260 million, only two shades of opinion can gain effective expression in its representative institutions. It would also appear fundamentally un-democratic for the Gore camp, as it did in this instance, to tell Nader supporters that their votes are wasted and will help Bush.

Although this may be exactly what has happened, this outcome cannot be blamed solely on Nader, but on a system that is so inflexible and outmoded that the will of the people may only be very imperfectly expressed.

Another post-mortem inquest will centre on polling methods. The exit polls are normally highly reliable, making it possible to project a national result from the morning's voting in just a few east coast states.

But that did not work this time. The exit polls gave Gore the victory in Florida, only to retract the verdict dramatically a short while later. This happened while people were still voting on the west coast. This premature "result' may thus have influenced voting in key swing states like Oregon and Washington, or even discouraged voters from turning out at all - because they believed it was all over.

The intrinsic imbalances within the electoral system may also be one reason why so many Americans do not bother to vote at all. Although turnout was reportedly up this time, probably 40% of eligible voters still boycotted the polls - perhaps because they believe the system does not and cannot reflect their opinions.

When the dust settles on the 2000 race, these and many other questions will come to the fore - including, perhaps, a move towards some form of proportional representation.

webTitle: Fay replaces De Lisle as Wisden editor

fields.headline: Fay replaces De Lisle as Wisden editor
fields.trailText: 11am: Former Independent on Sunday deputy editor Stephen Fay is replacing Tim De Lisle as editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Cricket writer and former Independent on Sunday deputy editor Stephen Fay is replacing Tim De Lisle as editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly (WCM).

Wisden editor-in-chief Matthew Engel said that despite the fact that Mr Fay is 62, the appointment was "part of our youth policy".

Mr Engel said Mr Fay's journalistic experience would "give WCM enormous authority on the great cricketing issues of the day, which now go beyond over-rates and bonus points".

In addition to two stints as deputy of the Independent on Sunday, Mr Fay spent 20 years on the Sunday Times where he was Washington Correspondent.

Mr De Lisle is moving to the magazine's website, Wisden.com, along with deputy editor Steven Lynch.

webTitle: Burger King sacks Lowe Lintas ad agency in US

fields.headline: Burger King sacks  US ad agency
fields.trailText: 11am: Burger King has sacked its advertising agency, Lowe Lintas, in the US, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Burger King has sacked its advertising agency, Lowe Lintas, in the US after claiming the advertising had failed to increase sales.

The world's second-biggest fast-food chain said yesterday that Lowe Lintas was now out of the running for its £265m US account.

Burger King began a review of its advertising in September after parent company Diageo decided to sell it. Burger King's sales have suffered over the past year, making it more difficult for Diageo to attract a buyer.

The restaurant chain said its UK account was not affected by the move. But the decision places a question mark over Lowe Lintas' hold on Burger King's £11m UK advertising account.

Mikel Durham, president of Burger King North America, said: "This is not just about a new campaign, but rather an entirely new way of approaching business and our consumers."

webTitle: A rollercoaster of a day in the Gore camp

fields.headline: A rollercoaster of a day in the Gore camp
fields.standfirst:
Duncan Campbell in Nashville, Tennessee reports on extraordinary scenes as the presidential victory hangs on a knife-edge

Special report: US election race
fields.trailText: Duncan Campbell in Nashville, Tennessee reports on extraordinary scenes as the presidential victory hangs on a knife-edge.Special report: US election race
fields.body:
There were extraordinary scenes in Nashville as Al Gore withdrew his concession of defeat in the presidential election at 2.45am after it became clear that the vote in Florida was so close that a recount was needed. Gore supporters and the media had been gathering in the War Memorial Plaza in anticipation of a sad farewell speech when gradually the news started emerging from members of the Gore team that Bush was ahead in Florida by only 1,200 out of nearly six million votes.

As the news was announced by CNN on the vast screen on the stage a loud cheer went out. Gore's aides, suddenly animated after being resigned to defeat, started briefing the media that a recount was mandatory when the margin of victory was so low. At 3.10 am, Bill Daley, Gore's campaign chairman, took to the stage to say: "I don't think there has ever been a night like this!" He went on to say that the margin of victory was so small that Mr Gore had telephoned Governor Bush to withdraw his earlier concession.

It had been a roller-coaster of a day with the mood in the Gore camp swinging with each new result. There was euphoria when CNN announced that Mr Gore had taken Florida, then high excitement as the favourable results for Michigan, Pennsylvania and Illinois came through. Suddenly the scenario seemed to be of a Gore victory and there were whoops, cheers and back-slappings as the Gore camp sensed that the White House was within their grasp.

Then came the disappointment for Gore of losing his own state of Tennessee and the nagging fears that victory was slipping away. But the real bombshell came with the news that Florida had not gone Gore's way after all and that the television pundits had miscalled it. The state was one of the essential building blocks for a Gore win and without it the sense of confidence was gone.

The mood changed again as other Gore states came in and frantic calculations were taking place in the downtown Sheraton hotel as Gore's teams still held out hopes that they might just nudge their way to the White House. But out in the War Memorial Plaza where the celebration had been planned, the mood was sombre. Only around 1,000 people - of what had been anticipated would be a 10,000-strong crowd - were present to wave goodbye to their candidate, or so they thought. Then came the latest bizarre twist in this most bizarre of elections.

webTitle: Punch editor hits back after Shayler fine

fields.headline: Punch editor hits back after Shayler fine
fields.standfirst: Punch fined £25,000 for contempt
fields.trailText:
10am: Punch editor James Steen speaks about the High Court's decision to fine his magazine for publication of an article by former spy David Shayler.
Punch fined £25,000 for contempt
fields.body:
Punch editor James Steen has spoken about how "upset" he is by the High Court's decision to fine his magazine for publication of an article by former spy David Shayler.

"It's a huge amount of money to pay when you basically feel you haven't done anything wrong", he told MediaGuardian.co.uk.

"I've gone up against the establishment and lost. A lot of people warned me that I couldn't win but I did trust my legal judgement."

But Mr Steen would not say whether the magazine - backed by Harrods owner Mohamed Fayed - would appeal against the judgement.

It is estimated that the total cost to Punch of the case, including costs for both sides, could come to over £150,000.

He added that the government had failed to prove that the Shayler article represented a threat to national security: the reason government lawyers claimed that the injunction had been imposed.

A crucial element in the judgement had been Punch's decision to publish - on its front cover - a letter from government lawyers warning the magazine that publication of the article would breach a 1997 injunction.

The judge said he believed the letter had been published to increase sales.

But Mr Steen claimed that after Punch received the letter, journalists had made the necessary changes to Mr Shayler's article to prevent breaches of national security.

"I agree that you can't go around breaking injunctions, but you have to look at the injunction on its merits," he added.

Freedom of speech campaigners condemned the ruling, but Index on Censorship's Rohan Jayasekera said the case could be good because the decision was so "perverse". He claimed the case "could be the last ruling of its kind that will be possible before the Human Rights Act really starts to kick in".

John Wadham, David Shayler's lawyer and director of human rights group Liberty, said " To fine an organisation when it was admitted that there was no damage to national security is an infringement of freedom of expression."

The Rugby Football Union is to open high street retail outlets and launch a travel firm in a bid to create a stronger brand identity for itself and explore commercial opportunities.

webTitle: Marconi shortlists four ad agencies for global account

fields.headline: Marconi shortlists four for £36m global account
fields.trailText: 8am: Marconi has culled the list of ad agencies competing for its £36m global account to four, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Technology giant Marconi has culled the number of ad agencies competing for its £36m global account to four.

Still in the running are Bates Worldwide, Grey Worldwide, Young & Rubicam and D'Arcy.

Following meetings with officials at Marconi's London headquarters last month, J Walter Thompson, M&C Saatchi, Bartle Bogle Hegarty and Leo Burnett have all been eliminated.

Marconi is seeking a global agency for its media and creative business as it seeks to reposition itself as a IT company.

In the past its advertising has been restricted to the defence and technology trade press. Now it wants to reach out to ordinary consumers and be seen as a general IT company.

Marconi is scheduled to host group briefings with the four finalists in the US later this month. Creative pitches are timed for mid-December with an appointment expected by Christmas.

In the past its advertising has been restricted to the defence and technology trade press. Now it wants to reach out to ordinary consumers and be seen as a general IT company. Marconi is scheduled to host group briefings with the four finalists in the US later this month. Creative pitches are timed for mid-December with an appointment expected by Christmas.

webTitle: VandeLinde to lead Warwick university

fields.headline: VandeLinde to lead Warwick university
fields.trailText: Warwick University has appointed Professor David VandeLinde as its next vice-chancellor. VandeLinde joins Warwick from Bath university where he has been vice-chancellor since 1992.
fields.body:
Warwick University has appointed Professor David VandeLinde as its next vice-chancellor. VandeLinde joins Warwick from Bath university where he has been vice-chancellor since 1992.

VandeLinde, born and educated in the US, is the latest in a series of senior appointments in UK universities this year. About half of the universities making up the 20 strong Russell group of elite research institutions are appointing new vice-chancellors.

"Warwick is now well established within the UK's 'Ivy League' and I look forward to the opportunity and challenge both professionally and personally to lead Warwick in becoming recognised as a world-class research university," said VandeLinde. He said that he would leave Bath in a "position of strength, well entrenched in the top ten rankings of the major UK league tables."

Rhys Williams, chairman of the Warwick university council said: "Higher education in the UK stands at a cross-roads. Universities face many challenges over the next five years: we need to find new sources of income, build Warwick's reputation as a truly international institution and take advantage of the tremendous opportunities for teaching and research from the IT revolution."

webTitle: Nick Hornby on his autistic son

fields.headline: About Nick's boy
fields.standfirst: Until now Nick Hornby has said very little about his autistic son. Matt Seaton hears about the stress, struggles and strange humour of life with Danny and the school which has changed everything.
fields.trailText: Until now Nick Hornby has said very little about his autistic son. Matt Seaton hears about the stress, struggles and strange humour of life with Danny and the school which has changed everything.
fields.body:
Nick Hornby attracts more than his share of envy. Perhaps this is inevitable for such a successful author, but there is also something about the artless, plain style of both the writer and his work that makes people think, "I wish I'd thought of that: I could have done that." The idea that someone might have a popular literary career founded on a memoir of being a football fan seems almost a provocation. And yet how many people would wish for his life if they knew how much it revolves around the needs of his autistic son Danny? If they had any idea of what life with an autistic child is like?

Hornby is just completing his third novel, but he has only ever written one brief newspaper article about Danny and autism. This week sees the publication of Speaking With the Angel, a collection of new short stories edited by Hornby. The line-up is stellar (Roddy Doyle, Helen Fielding, Robert Harris, Irvine Welsh, Zadie Smith . . .); the common theme that the stories are all first-person narratives. But the object of the collection is to raise money (£1 on every copy sold) for TreeHouse, the special school that Hornby and his ex-wife Virginia Bovell co-founded with several other parents of autistic children.

Besides contributing a story, Hornby has written an introduction which explains with eloquently suppressed anger why there is a need for schools like TreeHouse - because there is so little appropriate educational provision for the UK's 76,000 autistic children, or support for their families. And he describes in brief but telling detail a day in the life of not necessarily his own, but a typical family with an autistic kid:

"He sleeps five or six hours every night, in fact, which means that if he can be kept awake until, say, nine, then he will wake up at two or three. He is upset and frustrated, so he screams, and his parents, who have maybe slept three or four hours, feel a mixture of exhaustion and depression and panic - they live in a small flat, and the walls are thin, and they know that they are not the only ones who are disturbed on a nightly basis . . . It is six hours until one of them starts work (the other would like to work, but in the absence of any suitable school place for the child, it is not possible), by which time the child will have attempted to hurt himself by hitting himself hard and repeatedly on the head, and maybe thrown some food around, and refused to use the toilet and ended up soiling a carpet, and demanded in the only language he has at his disposal (one word, repeated with increasing force and volume) to go out to the park, even though it's pitch black outside . . ." It goes on. Hornby, you know, has been there.

We meet at a Turkish restaurant in Highbury, not far from his beloved Arsenal ground. He orders egg and chips and a mineral water, and lights up a Silk Cut.

"It seems to me a song about disability," he says, explaining how he borrowed the book's title from a track by Canadian singer-songwriter Ron Sexsmith. "It's almost an autistic trait - lots of staring up into the sky and off into the distance. There does seem to be a sort of communion with something that you can't see."

Danny was born in 1993. He was diagnosed with autism nearly five years ago, which is actually very young: the average age of diagnosis is nearer the age he is now, seven. This fact in itself means that many parents suffer an agony of anxiety and uncertainty about their child's developmental and behavioural problems before they even hear an official pronouncement of "autism".

"His birth was extremely difficult," Hornby says, "so I think we both suspect that his condition is in some way connected to that. Danny got stuck, and there was an emergency Caesarean. It was a scary night.

"When he was born he had a left-sided weakness. His head was down on one side, and he's got a droopy eye. Something seems to be affected down his left side, although most of the physical symptoms have been corrected except for the eye. I would imagine it would have been some sort of brain damage. And that the part of his brain that was affected would be the part that would result in autistic symptoms.

"Lots of parents whose kids are autistic suspect nothing until their kids are 15-18 months old. Because of Danny's birth difficulties, there had always been some slight worries about his development, but when he was 18 months he lost the language that he'd acquired more or less completely. He became almost catatonic. He didn't want to go out very much, and would not make eye-contact with anyone who wasn't me or his mum. There are phrases, little words that he had then which have still not come back.

So when did he and Virginia realise Danny was autistic?

"I think the word autism was floating about somewhere. I still remember it was something of a shock going for the first meeting in that we had a really bad time. We went to the health centre locally where there was a paediatric specialist. He was quite flustered. He looked at Danny - and at this stage we were still very tentative about what the problem was - and he suddenly said: 'Global development delay . . . don't really know . . . the hardest time is when he's five or six; he'll be much further behind the other kids . . .'

"It was all a million words a second and devastating information. That was the real shock day. But then it was a year after that that Danny was finally diagnosed autistic. By then it was no surprise: we had come to our own conclusions. It seemed fairly certain to us."

Autism is, as Hornby says, "a very, very wide term" - a spectrum condition: "It can be anything from not being able to recognise your own parents to being a bit funny when you're studying Maths at Oxford." Danny is probably somewhere towards the more severe end of that continuum, but each autistic child has particular characteristics, their own specific deficits of language acquisition and socialisation.

The common feature of autists is that they do not copy and therefore cannot learn as normal children do. Locked in their own private world, they are very sensitive about their personal space and ignore or actively repel attempts to engage with them. And, left to their own devices, autistic children often resort to extremely repetitive behaviour. TreeHouse's approach is a constant effort to break down the barriers autists erect around themselves, to socialise them seemingly despite themselves.

TreeHouse, which now looks after 20 children daily for an extended school year, uses a system imported from the US called Applied Behaviour Analysis (ABA). Hornby takes me to see it. In the newest class, one teacher seeks to get a child who cries and constantly turns away from him to follow a simple drill. Compliance is encouraged by lots of praise, rewards, cuddles and tickles. To witness the therapy you might think it utterly thankless and pointless; but the results are also evident. In an older class, the children are sitting around having a picture-book story read to them. In the context, astonishing progress.

"The process has gone far enough with Danny that he is beginning to spark a bit now," says Hornby. "He is discovering more toys. He does become bored more easily. We are definitely seeing the benefits." Danny even has a friend at TreeHouse: Toby. Until lately, this was inconceivable.

Another two schools, one in Wandsworth and another in Surrey, have just opened using the same system. Like TreeHouse, they have been voluntarily founded and are voluntarily funded. Five London boroughs now pay for children to attend TreeHouse, but before that few made much provision for autistic children. Hornby prefers not to be specific about the extent of his personal investment in the school, but he has signed a film deal for About a Boy and big publishing contract with Penguin "and TreeHouse has got a reasonable chunk of both of those".

TreeHouse, which is now housed in borrowed premises in Bloomsbury, began in a room in a library at Swiss Cottage in north London. Hornby quips: "It could almost be a figure of speech like 'a bull in a china shop': 'an autistic kid in a library'." Humour, the kind of deadpan black humour that Hornby likes, seems to be a survival strategy he has developed.

"There is a lot about autism that is very funny, and you'd have to be the parent of an autistic child to appreciate it," Hornby explains.

"Yesterday when I picked him up from school and we'd got back to the house, he had to come out again because we hadn't rung the doorbell. I don't know where that's come from. It's clearly something new that's just started, but it's done with such a neutral face that it's actually very funny."

Danny is doing well at school but, while there is no prognosis for autism, Hornby knows he has to be realistic about Danny's progress and his future: "Autism, more than any other condition, leaves the parents with the sense that there might suddenly one day be a breakthrough," he says. But he feels it is "unhealthy" to hold out too much hope of improvement, especially since autists seem to resist change.

"There are weird things like almost a constant need to be misunderstood," Hornby observes, "so that the language he has acquired, which is in itself obscure, he then changes subtly - as if you're understanding too much, which is an odd thing.

"'Tata' is his word for bread and peanut butter, but just about three or four weeks ago it's become 'Shasha', for no reason that I can fathom.

"There is a great temptation every now and then to say: 'Cut this out, Danny. You know and I know . . . The joke's over.' Really!"

The TreeHouse curriculum includes drama and PE: "I don't know what they do in drama," Hornby chuckles with rueful irony. "It always says on his report at the end of the day, 'Danny did very well in drama today.'"

But there hasn't been a school production yet? "Not as such. Nor indeed a school football team."

He jokes, but this must be a very real loss to him. "The only real way to survive is not to dwell on what isn't going to happen," he responds. "It is about living day to day with the pleasures I get from being with Dan.

"I think what kicks in is a sense of loyalty to him. In the same way that you'd be appalled by a parent obsessed with having a boy who wasn't really interested in having a girl. I think that sense of who he is takes over very quickly, and you think: 'OK, I've got a kid who doesn't want to play football, doesn't want to read, and that's my kid and I love my kid.' It would seem like a great act of disloyalty to him to wish he was some other way."

Yet the strain of bringing up an autistic child has exacted a price. Although he speaks to and sees Virginia every day because of Danny, the couple are now divorced. The pressure of looking after Danny was, Hornby concedes, "a huge part" of why the marriage broke down.

"Obviously there are other things as well, but you never know whether they would have actually counted for anything, had we not had this," he elaborates. "It's like a barium meal. It exposes immediately whatever flaws there are. You can imagine a lot of couples who stay married with the same flaws but they kind of rub along fine, and maybe they have another child, and there's not even the time to examine.

"Having Danny is like the stress of having a newborn permanently - that kind of disruption with a newborn's first weeks, and there's no change to that."

How happy is Hornby now? A pause. "Not thinking too far ahead is one trick," he says carefully. "Basically, each stage of Danny's life seems just about cope-able with if you've got the right systems in place . . . For anyone who has any kind of crisis to deal with of a permanent nature, then eventually things fall around it. And, yes, writing is a solace and an escape. But I think it ends up informing your work."

For all the struggle, anxiety and depression, I wonder, are there things that Hornby could be grateful for in the whole experience?

"Absolutely. I think in a way it makes you more intelligent about things, because you're faced with harder choices and more complicated problems. You end up thinking about what constitutes love, what constitutes being human, what makes someone happy - what makes Danny happy. There is much more sense of thinking about what you want your life to be."

 Speaking With the Angel is published by Penguin. On November 23 there will be an evening of readings from the book and music at the Hammersmith Palais, London in aid of TreeHouse. Rob Newman will compere and Teenage Fanclub will play a set. Tickets from £15 (inc £5 to TreeHouse) are available through www.ticketweb.co.uk or by calling 020 7771 2000.

webTitle: Tesco ad wins industry's top prize

fields.headline: Tesco ad wins industry's top prize
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Tesco's hugely successful "Dotty" campaign, starring Prunella Scales and Jane Horrocks, was voted the industry's favourite advert last night, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Tesco's hugely successful "Dotty" campaign, starring Prunella Scales and Jane Horrocks, was voted the industry's favourite advert last night.

The judges said the campaign had helped transformed Tesco's image from a "pile it high, sell it cheap" supermarket chain to one of the nation's most trusted brands.

Created by Lowe Lintas, the commercial was honoured with the industry's most prestigious award - the Grand Prix - at last night's Institute of Practitioners in Advertising's Effectiveness Awards dinner.

Lowe beat off six rival campaigns in the final "five star" shortlist of candidates. They included D'Arcy's reading and literacy campaign, BMP's Scoot.com campaign and Lowe's Stella Artois campaign.

The panel awarded Tesco the top prize after concluding that the company's advertising played an instrumental role in transforming its brand image.

The work was also deemed responsible for an extra £130m added to Tesco's bottom line over the past 10 years.

BMP DDB was voted Effectiveness Agency of the Year with declared billings of more than £100m. BMP earned the most points for its submissions in 2000 with each paper that it submitted making it onto the shortlist.

The agency scooped six prizes including a five star award for its campaign for Scoot.com, in the e-commerce/internet category and two four star awards for its work on Felix cat food and Arla Food's Lurpak.

The agency's work has credited with with securing an 11% rise in sales of Felix over the last five years. It also helped Lurpak overtake its rivals to become the number one brand in its market.

In addition, BMP picked up three star awards for Moneyextra and Terry's Chocolate Orange and a two star prize for PG Tips.

BDH TBWA was awarded Effectiveness Agency of the Year with declared billing of less than £100m. The Manchester-based agency's tally of awards included a five star award for its work on Henkel's Solvite and a four star award for Henkel's No More Nails brand.

The judges felt that both campaigns excelled with limited budgets. BDH received a three star award for Crown Paints, two stars for Freschetta pizza and one star for 1001 Mousse. Other five star awards went to D 'Arcy for its Reading & Literacy campaign for the Department for Education & Employment and Lowe Lintas for Stella Artois.

webTitle: Laxman saves Hyderabad, Jadeja bows out in style

fields.headline: Laxman saves Hyderabad, Jadeja bows out in style
fields.trailText: India
fields.body:
India

In the opening round of matches in the South Zone of the first-class Ranji Trophy, VVS Laxman almost single-handedly saved Hyderabad from a heavy defeat at the hands of Karnataka in Bangalore. After being asked to follow on with a first-innings deficit of 254, Hyderabad looked to be heading for defeat, but Laxman responded with an unbeaten 100 to steer his side towards a draw. Earlier Karnataka had amassed 545-9 declared in their first innings, thanks to 122 from wicketkeeper V Naidu and 92 from Sunil Joshi. webTitle: Blackserve closes down

fields.headline: Black website closes after two months
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Black community website Blackserve has thrown in the towel only two months after its high-profile launch, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Black community website Blackserve has shut down only two months after its high-profile launch.

The site was launched amid fanfare publicity in the summer by Paul Castro, former ad director at DoubleClick and part of the founding team of Kiss FM, and Simeon Quarrie, former chief operations officer of myISP.

The pair pledged to tackle the issue of poor quality black and ethnic media in the UK.

Susy Pote, an experienced presenter, journalist and producer from BBC Radio, was hired as news editor to shift the balance of black news coverage.

The idea was to tap into the £12bn potential of the black UK economy, but the site soon fell victim to the falling availability of dot.com venture capital.

Mr Castro has now left the company while Mr Quarrie remains, hoping to restructure the site and find some new funding.

In the meantime, the site has been shut down. All that remains is a note saying, "We are sorry but due to technical difficulties the blackserve site is not currently available. Please watch this space!".

Blackserve was set up by private funding.

Both founding partners were unavailable for comment.

Separately, health and beauty website Nutravida has been thrown a lifeline after signing a deal with London shop and catalogue operator Apotheke 20-20. The site, which shut down in September, will now sell a smaller range of products aimed at the premium market.

webTitle: It's personal, but Hillary heads for the Senate

fields.headline: It's personal, but Hillary heads for the Senate
fields.standfirst:
Republican postmortem begins as first lady confounds critics
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Republican postmortem begins as first lady confounds critics.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton was heading for a historic victory early today, capturing a seat in the US Senate as the first wife of a sitting president to win elected office, and flying in the face of considerable personal antipathy.

Early exit polls said she was eight points ahead of her opponent, the Republican congressman Rick Lazio, most of whose support appeared to have come from people who disliked her rather than approved of him. The race for one of New York's two seats in the 100-member assembly was therefore playing out as it had for the past six months, as a referendum on the 53-year-old first lady.

Daniel Patrick Moynihan, whose place Ms Clinton looked like taking in the Senate, said: "We're sending to the Senate not only the first lady of the land but she will be the first lady of New York."

But her influence in Washington was expected to be limited by the fact that her party's hopes of taking control of the Senate were slim. Before yesterday it was dominated 54-46 by the Republicans, meaning the Democrats needed a gain of five to take control.

Less than two years ago, Charles Rangel, who has represented Harlem in the Congress for 30 years, suggested to the first lady - on the rebound from the Lewinsky affair - that she might consider standing for the Senate. It seemed unlikely, but no more so than the route taken by Mr Moynihan, who started as a shoe-shine boy in Manhattan and became a social policy innovator in Washington, even if his legislative record is a good deal thinner than his reputation.

Mr Rangel said: "The contest has never been between Clinton and Lazio but between those who hate the Clintons and those who think she would be a great US senator."

"A good portion of [Lazio's] vote is simply against her and he's got nothing to do with it," said a pollster, Mickey Blum. "The people who are deciding this on the issues are Hillary Clinton voters. The people voting for him are saying more 'It's personal.' All along this has really been about her. You love her or you hate her."

Until last May the election was between two love-them-or-hate-them candidates. Then it was a title fight starring two caricatures: the presumptuous outsider who felt entitled to high office in return for her service to the president and the presidency versus Mayor Rudy Giuliani, the unsympathetic hero of the transformation of New York, the man who had eradicated much of the city's crime and elements of its unique personality in the process.

But Mr Giuliani, the tough guy knocked off course by health and marital problems, withdrew from the country's hottest race other than that for the presidency. In came Mr Lazio, 42, a member of the House of Representatives who was little known outside the state and with a profile not much more visible inside it.

Now there could be only one winner, the wife of the world's most powerful man and a president who is particularly popular in New York, which has a population loaded in favour of the Democrats. At least that was how it seemed until the first polls appeared and showed a core of voters who would elect anyone but Ms Clinton as she tried to style herself in the manner of both a less remote personality and a one-name celebrity such as Madonna.

Campaign mistakes

She was well aware of the antipathy with which the chauvinistic state greets those it perceives as carpetbaggers, and set out on a "listening tour" of the state, six months before making her candidature official.

Ms Clinton made plenty of campaigning mistakes at first. She acquired a previously undisclosed passion for the New York Yankees baseball team; she failed to tip a waitress at a diner; she struck a false note by lapsing into an unconvincing facsimile of the stereotypical cab-driver's accent during her nomination acceptance speech.

Gradually the gaffes receded and she solidified the support of crucial voting groups such as Jewish and black New Yorkers, balanced with a concerted effort to make herself more appealing to upstate New Yorkers by putting in appearances at even the most modest community events.

When Mr Lazio waved in her face a sheaf of papers during their first televised debate two months ago, attitudes shifted. At once he was no longer amiable but something of a bully and she went above 50% in the polls for the first time.

Ms Clinton's last direct involvement with the legislative process was early in her husband's first administration, when she took on the job of framing a universal health insurance system.

Her proposals were so complicated than even some professionals could not understand them and she was accused of being secretive and arrogant when experts tried to make a contribution.

Her plan never made it to the Congress, even though there was a Democratic majority at the time, and 43m Americans have no health insurance today. President Clinton blames himself for the failure of the initiative, saying he should not have cluttered the agenda by pursuing a free trade deal with Mexico at the same time.

Left tip

Ms Clinton started yesterday by voting with the president and their daughter, Chelsea, in Chappaqua, their adopted home town, 45 minutes north of New York city. Then they had breakfast in a deli, taking care to leave a tip.

She ended the night at a celebration in a midtown Manhattan hotel. Mr Lazio campaigned into the early evening, trying to persuade commuters at Grand Central terminal to give him a final lift. But already the recriminations were starting in the New York Republican party.

Libby Pataki, the wife of governor George Pataki, accused Mr Giuliani of being selfish for not pulling out of the senate race earlier. This, she said, had not given Mr Lazio - a protege of the governor - the opportunity to mount the strongest possible challenge. The mayor was "just jerking people around," she said.

webTitle: Sun man wins hacks' Weakest Link

fields.headline: Sun man wins hacks' Weakest Link
fields.standfirst: It was Jonathan Plunkett's moment of truth. The Oxford graduate who recently landed a job as The Sun's TV editor showed off his true colours in a journalists-only special edition of Anne Robinson's The Weakest Link. We reprint the highlights of this unrecorded edition.
fields.trailText: It was Jonathan Plunkett's moment of truth. The Oxford graduate who recently landed a job as the Sun's TV editor showed off his true colours in a journalists-only special edition of Anne Robinson's The Weakest Link. We reprint the highlights of this unrecorded edition.
fields.body:
It was Jonathan Plunkett's moment of truth. The Oxford graduate who recently landed a job as The Sun's TV editor showed off his true colours in a journalists-only special edition of Anne Robinson's The Weakest Link.

He saw off seven lesser rivals, including the Guardian's learned media correspondent, Matt Wells, The Independent's distinguished media and culture editor editor David Lister and the Mail feature writer Jane Kelly.

Here we reprint the highlights of this unrecorded edition, staged at the BBC's TV centre yesterday, including details of The Walk of Shame, the losers' tantrums and of course Ms Robinson's harshest put-downs.

Highlights of Round One

# Anne's comment to David Lister when he failed to define cornucopia - "Don't you use words like cornucopia on the Independent, David?" He replied: "Only in the headlines"
# Referred to Round One's £200 as "pathetic"
# Jane Kelly of the Mail voted off having got one question wrong: "Which film provided John Travolta with four UK top 20 hit singles in 1978?" The answer was Grease.
# Sharon Marshall, feature writer at the People, was the strongest link

Round Two

# Robinson haughtily asked the remaining people if they were sure of the rules because no one had banked any money.
# When asking contestants to vote for the weakest link, she shrilled: "Who is the most stupid of those left? Who is an embarrassment to their newspaper?"
# Anne said that this was the lowest second round in the history of the game

Round Three

# Anne asked who was "too dense" to stay? David Lister voted off
# Jonathan Plunkett got asked "Who is head of an Abbey" and he didn't know it was an abbott. When Anne asked him how he got it wrong he answered: "We only do vicars".

Round Four

# Matt Wells didn't know which US state was called the "Empire State" (Answer is New York, not Washington)
# Anne asked: "Who is even more of a dunce than the rest of you" - Claire Goldwin of the Mirror voted off.
# Anne asked Anjali Kwatra from The Express how long she had been in newspapers. AK answered: "One month", to which Anne replied by asking: "How long do you intend to stay in newspapers?"

Round Five

# "Whose knowledge is dismal and embarrassing?"
# A tie between Jonathan Plunkett and Caitlin Moran led to Anjali voting as the strongest link for Caitlin to do the Walk of Shame

Round Six

# "Who is too stupid to stay in the studio?"
# Matt Wells voted off. Robinson said it would give him more time to read
# Anjali studied Social and Political Science but got a question about Che Guevara wrong.

The final head-to-head between Anjali and Jon with Jon winning a final prize of £2,050, one of the lowest ever final prizes.

And here are some of the incorrect questions and answers:

Caitlin Moran, The Times
Caitlin answered a total of eight questions; five right and three wrong The three wrong were:
In maths, which has the greater volume - two pints or one litre? # Answered: two pints (Correct: one litre)
In history which American outlaw born in 1866 was the best known member of the Wild Bunch gang?
Answered: Butch Cassidy (Correct: Robert Leroy Parker)

Sharon Marshall, Sunday People
Answered three questions; one right and two wrong.
The wrong questions were:
Which British prime minister flew to Munich to meet Adolf Hitler in 1938? Answered: Churchill (Answer: Chamberlain).
Which English horror writer's first novel The Rats was published in 1974? Answered: Stephen King (Answer: James Herbert).

Claire Goldwin, The Mirror
Answered six
questions; three right and three wrong.
The three wrong questions were: In literature who wrote the novel 'Travels with My Aunt'?
Which British Monarch whilst Prince of Wales, married the Mrs Maria Fitzherbert?
In the animal kingdom frogs toads and newts belong to which vertebrates?

Jane Kelly, Mail
Answered one question and got it wrong - voted off first.

See above, Round One

Matt Wells
Answered 10 questions; seven right and three wrong.
In the animal kingdom what 'm' is the North American term for Elk?
In the radio series The Archers Sid Perks is the landlord of which pub?
Which US state is nicknamed the Empire State?. Answered Washington (answer New York).

Jonathan Plunkett, the Sun
Answered 18 questions in total including the head-to-head; 15 right and three wrong.
What "A" is the name given to the male head or superior of a monastery or abbey?
Which veteran entertainer uses the catchphrase, "I wanna tell you a story"?
What was the name of the spacecraft in which Yuri Gagarin became the first man in space?

David Lister, the Independent
Answered six questions; three right and three wrong.
The word cornucopia is another term for "The Horn of" what?"
In cookery, what 'm' is a small biscuit or cake made from ground almonds egg white and sugar?

Anjali Kwatra, Express
Answered 20 questions incuding the head to head; 11 right and nine wrong.
What kind of food are pitta and sourdough?
Which Queen, the wife of William IV, gave her nane to a major city in South Australia?
At which cricket test ground is there a Warwick Road end? Old Trafford or Trent Bridge?
What J is both a small British bird and a girl's name?
Which prominent figure of the Cuban revolution who first name is Ernesto, died in Bolivia in 1967?
In temperature what is the equivalent of 50 degrees F in celsius?
Which US president is traditionally supposed to have written his famous Gettysburg Address on the back of an envelope?
In literature, which character created by Muriel Spark aimed to make her girls the creme de la creme? Which animal has a male called a boar, a female called a sow, young called a cub and the group name a sleuth?

And the losers' comments from the Walk of Shame

Jane
Q: So how does it feel to be voted off The Weakest Link?
A: Pretty bad

Q: Who do think will be voted off next?
A: Might be Claire, she's losing her nerve.

Sharon
Q: How does it feel to be voted off?
A: I am burning with humiliation and shame.

Q: Why did you vote for Anjali?
A: I just wanted someone else to go.

Q: How did it feel to make the Walk of Shame?
A: It's longer than it looks.

Q: How does you feel?
A: Pretty stupid! Wish I'd listened to my history teacher.

Q: Who do you want to be voted off next?
A: Matt for that last comment.

Q: Do think its fair that you were voted off?
A: It's so harsh! Totally unfair just because of one little prime minister.

David
Q: How do you feel?
A: I feel aggrieved and hard done by, I got half of them right.

Q: Who do you think will be voted off next?
A: I think it will be Matt, because of the usual Guardian smugness and he banks rather than thinks about the questions

Q: Are you kicking yourself about that wrong answer?
A: yes particularly as I love macaroons.

Q: Who do you think will be next?
A: Caitlin because she is seven-and-a-half months pregnant and she can't stand up for much longer.

Claire
Q: How do you feel?
A: I feel deeply, deeply humiliated.

Q: Why did you vote off Caitlin?
A: To be honest I can't remember, I think she hesitated.

Q: How do you think you performed?
A: Pretty poor.

Q: Who do you think will win?
A: Matt may win, he's quite cunning.

Q: Who do you think will be next off?
A: Caitlin, because she hesitates.

Caitlin
Q: How do you feel?
A: Quite chuffed that I stayed so long.

Q: How do you feel about Anjali voting you off?
A: good to be sitting down, cheers!

Q: You weren't actually the Weakest Link, Matt was, how do you feel about that?
A: Well it make sense, having seen the show he's the sort of person people like - he's a cheeky chappie everybody loves him.

Q: Who do you think will be off next?
A: I think it'll be a grudge match between Anjali and Jon - well she's the strongest link but Matt is the cheeky chappie so that leaves Jon.

Matt
Q: You were the strongest link, but you were voted off, how do you feel?
A: Its a travesty of justice and an insult to my intelligence.

Q: Who would you least like to see win?
A: I would least like to see Jon, because retribution is an unattractive trait in anyone.

Q: Who do you think will win?
A: Jon may win because good never wins over evil.

Anjali
Q: How does it feel?
A: Congratulations to Jon. He deserves to win.

A: Might be Claire, she's losing her nerve. Sharon Q: How does it feel to be voted off? A: I am burning with humiliation and shame. Q: Why did you vote for Anjali? A: I just wanted someone else to go. Q: How did it feel to make the Walk of Shame? A: It's longer than it looks. Q: How does you feel? A: Pretty stupid! Wish I'd listened to my history teacher. webTitle: TV's most terrifying game show

fields.headline: 'Matt, you are the weakest link. Goodbye'
fields.standfirst: What is it like to appear on TV's most terrifying game show? Matt Wells took the plunge.
fields.trailText: What is it like to appear on TV's most terrifying game show? Matt Wells took the plunge.
fields.body:
Most retired reporters regale their grandchildren with tales of war and famine: I will be able to tell my family's offspring about the day I was insulted by the rudest woman on television. For, in studio four at BBC Television Centre yesterday, eight showbiz journalists and media correspondents - from the TV editor of the Sun to the culture editor of the Independent - were thrown into the bearpit that is Anne Robinson's hit new game show, The Weakest Link.

And even though I have done my fair share of war and famine (well, reporting the sink estates of Edinburgh), nothing prepared me for the sense of horror that descends when scary Anne spun her podium round and fixed me with that steely squint.

Sweat oozed from every pore, even before the game had started. There were the demon lights, the drilling eyes of the audience (the controllers of BBC1 and 2 and other assorted bigwigs) and the bank of cameras recording every flinch. Even though our version was not to be transmitted, it felt as if the world was looking in.

And Her. Standing by a dark curtain in the corner of the studio, she was difficult to spot at first. But there she was, the grand inquisitress, draped in black cloak, leather trousers and patent-leather heels (Armani, of course). When the floor manager's voice boomed, "Annie's on stage now," the faux friendly nickname fooled no one. Annie had got her gun and we were her targets.

I had a few seconds to settle myself as I was not first in line, but when Robinson's gimlet eyes came into view I felt all my acquired knowledge drain away. Perhaps it was her get-up, but I felt like a passive participant in someone else's fetishistic fantasy.

As the representative of a newspaper which has so publicly accused the country of dumbing down, I felt the ghost of the Guardian's founder, CP Scott, at my shoulder. "In the US," intoned Robinson grimly, "what colour ribbons are traditionally tied to trees to welcome someone back from a war?" Phew, that was easy. The song came into my head as I confidently declared, "Yellow."

Moments later she was facing me again: "In which northern English city is the Royal Armouries Museum?" Panic. I had never even heard of the Royal Armouries Museum, let alone know where it was. I blurted out the first northern town that came into my head: "Leeds." "Correct," said Anne.

This feat of guesswork filled me with confidence. I had got both my questions right and there was no way I was going out first. When the end of the round came it was time to vote someone off. For no reason in particular, I chose Claire Goldwin from the Mirror. Others were more shocked by the failure by the Daily Mail's Jane Kelly to name Grease as the film that provided John Travolta with four UK top 20 hit singles, and she was out. (That'll teach her for boasting that she had never watched the show.)

Few were spared the sharp end of Robinson's tongue. Berating the Independent's David Lister for failing to define cornucopia, she trilled: "Don't you use words like that on the Independent, David?" "Only in the headlines," replied a sheepish Lister. (Smart alec. He was out next.)

It's hard not to understand the success of this programme, whose teatime audience has been peaking at more than 5m on BBC2 this week, easily beating the channel's primetime output. Another 100 episodes have been commissioned and a "Champions' League" is running on BBC1. It has everything that makes great TV - teamwork, selfishness, voyeurism, sadism and humiliation. Each correct answer racks up the cash, but if you get one wrong and did not bank it before, you lose it all.

We were terrible at banking, and in the second round saved no money at all. "Are you sure of the rules?" Robinson demanded. When asking us to vote, she suggested: "Who is the most stupid of those left? Who is an embarrassment to their newspaper?" I thought it was the Sunday People's Sharon Marshall, who failed to name Neville Chamberlain as the prime minister who had appeased Hitler. "Working for a tabloid newspaper," I sneered, "is no excuse for not knowing elementary history." That was "typical Guardian smugness", said Lister in the post-match interview that every ousted contestant must endure.

My nadir came in round six, when - even though I had answered all my questions correctly - I was chosen for elimination by my two remaining rivals, the Sun and the Express. A tabloid conspiracy. Now it was my turn to endure the "walk of shame". Even though I had performed the best in that round, Annie turned to me and declared: "Matt, you are the weakest link." Compounding my sense of rejection, she turned away even before she got to the final, mocking "Goodbye!"

At the losers' interview, I was asked how it felt to be voted off despite having been the strongest. "It's a travesty of justice and an insult to my intelligence," I complained.

I could only console myself with the prediction of Rupert Murdoch, who once famously said that only three newspapers would survive in Britain - the Sun, the Mail and one broadsheet. If the Mail buys the Express, that maxim would appear to apply to The Weakest Link - and I'm sure CP Scott would have been proud that his creation had endured.

Oh yes, you want to know the identity of the victor. It was, of course, the Sun wot won it.

 The Weakest Link is on BBC2 at 5.15pm Monday to Friday, and on Tuesday and Thursday evenings on BBC1.

So, how would you have done?

1. In the US, what colour ribbons are traditionally tied to trees to welcome someone back from a war?

2. In which northern English city would you find the Royal Amouries Museum?

3. In nature, which flower has varieties called tiger and leopard?

4. In the animal kingdom, what M is the North American term for an elk?

5. Which US state is sometimes nicknamed the "Empire State"?

6. In The Archers, Sid Perks is the landlord of which pub?

7. Which vegetable is bought by the bulb and used by the clove?

8. In pop, which Beatles album shares its name with a gun?

9. What A is the medical term for a graze or minor skin wound?

10. What name is given to the left-hand side of a ship or aeroplane?

Answers

1. Yellow; 2. Leeds; 3. Lily; 4. Moose; 5. New York; 6. The Bull; 7. Garlic; 8. Revolver; 9. Abrasion; 10. Port

webTitle: Millions of Americans log on to follow elections

fields.headline: Millions of Americans log on to follow elections
fields.trailText: US news organisations broke internet records during the presidential election as millions of Americans logged on to find results and other details unavailable on television.
fields.body:
US news organisations broke internet records during the presidential election as millions of Americans logged on to find results and other details unavailable on television.

CNN estimated that 75m web pages had been viewed on its site on election day, breaking the previous record of 40m set on 12 October, the day after the second presidential debate and the day of a terrorist attack on the USS Cole.

Visitors to ABC news had viewed more than 23m web pages by Tuesday night, more than doubling the old record of 10 million set on 11 September 1998 when the site posted independent prosecutor Kenneth Starr's report to congress on President Bill Clinton's relationship with former intern Monica Lewinsky.

Fox News also reported records, but had no specific numbers. A visit is recorded whenever a user pulls up a new page or updates an old one. So someone frequently updating a page of election results would be counted multiple times.

"It's a huge win for the internet," said Merrill Brown, editor in chief of MSNBC.com, which projected a record 5m users for the day. "This is the largest event really in the... public affairs history of this medium."

The Wire, the news website for the Associated Press, also experienced heavy traffic.

"We were forced to add extra equipment to handle the load," said Mark Cardwell, executive producer for AP Digital. "We expect it to break all records."

One internet user, student Anthony Gill, found sites announcing some projections even faster, by a few seconds, than their television counterparts.

Several websites experienced delays because of the heavy traffic. Some sites took eight or more seconds to load, more than double the industry average of less than four seconds, according to Keynote, a company that measures internet performance.

The search engine Yahoo!, which had six times its normal traffic by early evening, said the bulk of its visitors had come for election returns.
