webTitle: Lakeside hosts text message ads trial

fields.headline: Lakeside hosts text message ads trial
fields.trailText: 8am: Essex shopping centre Lakeside is to host the world's first trial for text message ads delivered to shoppers' mobile phones. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The prospect will horrify Luddites and the noise-abatement society. It may even torment those who believe some things in life are better off free of advertising.

But this weekend Essex shopping centre Lakeside will be the centre of the world's first trial for localised text message adverts, delivered exclusively to shoppers via their mobile phones.

The service, called ZagMe, is being trialled initially at Lakeside with plans to extend it to Bluewater in January and then other shopping malls and popular high streets as the service takes off.

Some 150 retailers, including Pizza Hut, Debenhams, The Gap, Argos and Top Shop, have been signed up to provide timely SMS messages to people that have opted in for the ZagMe service.

Anyone who signs up for the service will be bleeped with special offers, product information and other promotions on their phones.

Retailers will send ZagMe a regular number of promotions that are then logged into a database and 'broadcast' at the appropriate times to shoppers who fit the appropriate demographic in the centre.

Promotions will be geared towards driving consumers into shops with special offers that expire after a certain period of time.

Bill Green, chief executive officer of ZagMe, admitted that some of the special offers could end up leading to 'controlled chaos' with people rushing to get to a store and redeem their offer within the half-an-hour given period.

He said retailers had been very keen to experiment with the service and that they were hoping to sign up thousands of users through field marketers at Lakeside.

ZagMe is also hoping its referral incentive scheme - where the referrer gets £5 in ZagPoints for every person they encourage to sign up - will boost the user numbers.

To incentivise shoppers to sign up in the first place, ZagMe is giving away £5-worth of ZagPoints, and 5p-worth of ZagPoints for every message received. These points can then be redeemed via the website, ZagMe.com, for pre-pay phone or store vouchers.

While the trial is open to anyone over the age of 16, it is expected that the key audience will be the under-25s.

ZagMe has been launched by SpotFlash, a new company specialising in wireless communication, in which Carphone Warehouse has an undisclosed stake.

webTitle: Budweiser seeks UK star for new TV ads

fields.headline: Budweiser trawls UK bars for new TV stars
fields.trailText: 8am: Budweiser has launched a nationwide search for a new star for its TV campaign, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Budweiser has launched a nationwide search for a new star for its next TV campaign.

The drinks giant, which has had sensational success with its "Whassup?" campaign, is trawling the pubs and bars in 12 UK cities.

Its current TV campaign has caught the imagination of children and adults everywhere, but it was imported directly from the US.

Now Budweiser is intent on creating something different in the run-up to Christmas to keep the public's appetite whetted.

The search for a new star will extend to 180 venues across 12 UK cities where real Bud drinkers will be filmed.

The campaign will be conducted over the next five weeks and five people from each bar will be selected to feature in a forthcoming TV and online campaign.

Lucy Cooke, brand manager at Budweiser, said: "As we continue to maximize the 'Whassup?' phenomena through an off and online campaign, not only are we allowing people to interact with the brand in an exciting way, we are also using the campaign as part of a planned and growing web presence in the UK."

Digital communications agency Circle.com will create the online campaign, while BMP DDB is handling the TV ads.

webTitle: Ant and Dec to quit the BBC

fields.headline: Ant and Dec to quit the BBC
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: BBC television's Saturday night entertainment line-up suffered a blow yesterday when the TV stars Ant and Dec quit the corporation.
fields.body:
BBC television's Saturday night entertainment line-up suffered a blow yesterday when the TV stars Ant and Dec quit the corporation.

ITV confirmed that it was developing a new prime-time show with the former pop singers, who already front the commercial network's hugely successful Saturday morning show, SM:TV Live.

They had also been presenting a game show, Friends Like These, for BBC1 on Saturday nights. It has enjoyed a successful run, drawing up to 7m viewers. It was highly regarded by BBC executives, including the new controller of BBC1, Lorraine Heggessey.

David Young, the BBC's head of light entertainment, said earlier this year that Ant and Dec could become huge BBC stars, and the corporation is thought to have considered offering the pair an exclusive deal.

But the BBC said that negotiations over a third series of Friends Like These have broken down. The ITV arrangement, which does not tie the pair to the network, is understood to be lucrative.

A BBC spokesman said: "It is a shame that negotiations with Ant and Dec for another series of Friends Like These next year have broken down. However, the door is always open for them to come back to the BBC."

The spokesman said the BBC would be making another series of Friends Like These but was looking for new presenters.

Anthony McPartlin, 24, and Declan Donnelly, 25, first appeared on television as PJ and Duncan in the Newcastle-based children's drama Byker Grove.

They left the show in 1994 to launch a musical career. In 1995 the BBC gave them their own programme and they have also worked on Channel 4 with their adult series Ant and Dec Unzipped.

Their popularity has soared recently with the success of SM:TV Live, which has been pulling in up to 2.5m viewers and a cult following among young adults, against just 1m for the BBC's rival Live and Kicking.

A spokeswoman for ITV said: "We are delighted to be working with Ant and Dec. They are enormously talented."

ITV has been winning the Saturday ratings war in the past few weeks, but BBC1, helped by Casualty and the national lottery draw, often beats its commercial rival.

webTitle: In the end it came down to sex, race and class

fields.headline: In the end it came down to sex, race and class
fields.standfirst: The voters: traditional constituencies held the key
fields.trailText: In the end it was not the men but the machines that did it. Despite the presidential candidates' expensive efforts to reach out to voters in the centre, it was their ability to motivate their core support that really counted. The unions and the black churches delivered for Mr Gore in industrial states such as Michigan and ethni cally-diverse areas; the Christian coalition and gun lobby backed Bush in the south and the mountain states.

The unions and the black churches delivered for Mr Gore in industrial states such as Michigan and ethni cally-diverse areas; the Christian coalition and gun lobby backed Bush in the south and the mountain states.

It may have been the most expensive presidential race in history. But the key determinant was not turnover but turnout. So strong were the numbers in Missouri that they kept the polls open to keep up with the demand. It was not how many of the undecided Gore or Bush could convince to come their way that mattered, but how many of those who had long ago made up their minds they could convince to come out and vote.

The key battle lines at the polls are the same as those in most other spheres of America - sex, race, class and religion. Bush scored well with men, whites, protestants and the rich while Gore triumphed among women, blacks, Hispanics, Jews and the poor. "[Blacks] were energised," said the Florida state Democratic party chairman, Bob Poe in one of the crucial states.

"|It was only up to us to get them mobilised and we did that, we got the job done."

Character certainly mattered. Voters looking for honesty and strong leadership went for Mr Bush, according to a poll based on interviews with almost 7,000 voters. Those seeking a candidate with experience and an understanding of complex issues went to Mr Gore. But ultimately the vast majority of voters remained loyal to the party rather than the person. Four out of five Clinton supporters from 1996 went for Mr Gore; Nine out of ten of those who backed Bob Dole supported Mr Bush.

African-American voters were vital to Democratic fortunes. The Democrats have only won an election once with a majority of white support - with Lyndon Johnson in 1964. They can rely on an overwhelming proportion of black votes, usually over 80%, but they cannot rely on them actually going to the polls.

It was a late switch by black voters in 1960 from Republi can to Democrat, lead in part by Martin Luther King's father, that was widely credited with handing victory to John F. Kennedy.

In recent times the trade union movement has also mobilised large numbers to vote for the Democrats. In Detroit, in the key swing state of Michigan, the unions negotiated a day off on election day so that they could canvas for Mr Gore.

The Christian coalition has proved equally crucial to Republican fortunes. Their anti-abortionist and anti-gay stance has galvanised many white voters, helping to turn the south from a Democratic stronghold during the sixties to a largely Republican bastion today. The National Rifle Association has proved equally loyal with its leader, Charlton Heston, campaigning in many key states.

The efforts of these interest groups and the two candidates' reliance on them left the campaigns with little room to manoeuvre. They did try. With a black woman as one of his main aides and General Colin Powell on the campaign trail, Mr Bush did all he could to show waverers that he was an inclusive Republican.

Mr Gore reached out to the middle classes, the elderly and the young. But in the end both were evenly divided among most age groups, Catholics and middle-income voters. Mr Gore did well with those who made $30,000 (£20,000) or less while Mr Bush lead among those who made $75,000.

The truism that brought Clinton to the White House in 1992 - "It's the economy stupid" - still held true. The most important issue for many voters was the economy, and those who picked that issue backed Mr Gore heavily. Taxes were another important issue and that group backed Mr Bush by an overwhelming margin.

But Clinton's legacy of sexual impropriety - two thirds said the current president will be remembered most for the Lewinsky affair - still hurt Mr Gore's chances. Just under half said Mr Clinton's scandals were important and most of them voted Bush. Those who thought it was very important backed him by six to one.

Mr Bush was backed by those who thought world affairs was the top issue, while Mr Gore was backed by those who thought healthcare and prescription drugs were top issues.

Two-thirds of voters felt the president was at least partially responsible for the strong economy and those people leaned toward Mr Gore.

The late revelation about Mr Bush's drink driving record did not help. But only one in four said it had made a difference to their vote.

webTitle: Republicans cling on to control of Congress

fields.headline: Republicans cling on to control of Congress
fields.standfirst: Special report: US election race
fields.trailText: Republicans appear on the way to extending their six-year reign in control of the Senate despite first lady Hillary Rodham Clinton's historic Senate victory in New York.
fields.body:
Republicans appear to be on the way to extending their six-year reign in control of the Senate despite first lady Hillary Rodham Clinton's historic Senate victory in New York.

To take control, Democrats will have to win all five Senate races that are still undecided.

In the race for the lower House of Representatives, Republicans and Democrats battled for control. Republicans gained seats in Virginia, Pennsylvania and New York, but surrendered one in Oklahoma.

By early Wednesday morning, Republicans had won three seats formerly held by Democrats, and were leading for six more.

Democrats had won one seat formerly in Republican hands, and were leading for six more. Democrats needed to gain eight seats to guarantee a majority in the House that convenes in January. Holding the majority in the Senate would give the Republicans their first eight-year stretch of Senate supremacy since the 1932 elections ended 14 years of unbroken Republican control.

Veteran Democratic senator Charles Robb of Virginia, Republican senator Rod Grams of Minnesota and William Roth, the long-time Delaware Republican, all were toppled from office.

Striking back for the Republicans, George Allen, the former governor of Virginia, ousted Robb after two terms in the Senate.

In Minnesota, the department store heir Mark Dayton used millions of his own money to defeat the conservative Grams, who served a low-profile single term and was beset by a divorce and other personal problems.

Perhaps the evening's most poignant drama involved the race for for Republican John Ashcroft's Missouri seat. Ashcroft's opponent, Democratic governor Mel Carnahan, died in plane crash in mid-October. His widow, Jean, said she would accept the new governor's offer to appoint her if her husband outpolled Ashcroft.

Democrats got a boost in New Jersey where Democrat Jon Corzine, after spending more than $60m of his own fortune, held onto a seat vacated by Democratic Sen. Frank Lautenberg.

Corzine, a former chief executive officer of Goldman Sachs, outspent four-term Republican representative Bob Franks by 10-1, making it the costliest two-candidate Senate race in history.

In Florida, Democrat Bill Nelson, the state's insurance commissioner, grabbed the seat of Republican senator Connie Mack, who is retiring.

But the former Republican representative John Ensign nabbed the Nevada Senate seat vacated by the retirement of Democratic senator Richard Bryan. Ensign, who narrowly lost a 1998 Senate bid, easily defeated Democrat Ed Bernstein.

Senator Joseph Lieberman, Al Gore's running mate, easily won re-election to his Connecticut Senate seat. But a Gore victory would make Lieberman vice-president, opening the door for a Republican to replace him in the Senate.

The congressional elections are important because of the key role Congress plays in policy making. Unlike a parliamentary system, the American system is one of separate powers divided between Congress and the president. Congress writes and must pass all laws before they go to the president.

webTitle: How Hillary vanquished Lazio

fields.headline: How Hillary vanquished Lazio
fields.standfirst: Special report: US election race
fields.trailText:
In the end, Hillary Clinton's opponent in the race for a seat in the United 
States Senate simply missed the media bus.
fields.body:
Hillary Rodham Clinton has triumphed in her historic quest to join the US Senate, defeating homegrown Republican Rick Lazio to become the only first lady ever elected to public office.

"You came out and said that issues and ideals matter," Clinton told a cheering crowd. In the wings, her husband, the president, watched and grinned.

"I am profoundly grateful to all of you for giving me the chance to serve you," she said. "I will do everything I can to be worthy of your faith and trust."

The campaign, which pitted her against a powerhouse New York City mayor and then a lesser-known Republican congressman, was the longest and costliest race in the state's history. It saw issues of character, place of birth, marital fidelity, and campaign finance collide with discussion of education, Social Security and the state's economy.

But Clinton herself - her activism, her issues, her president husband and her love-it-or-hate-it personality - proved to be the main issue in the campaign against Mr Lazio.

In the end, Rick Lazio simply missed the media bus. While the Republican Rick Lazio's campaign was uncertain about precisely what it might or might not be putting out on its net site, her's was firing out six rebuttals in the space of an hour during one of their televised debates.

And while Mrs Clinton was commanding the attention of the New York local cable news station - easier, of course, when you're famous - he was criticised for losing the contest for visibility by spending too much time upstate, far from the reach of the cameras.

Then there was the time he went out to meet and greet suburban voters on their way home from work at 5pm when they would actually arrive at the station an hour later.

The irony is that Mr Lazio fought and lost the battle on two main planks: first, he is not Mrs Clinton; second, he's from New York. The points overlap. Many people said they would not vote for her at any price, partly because they simply do not like her but also because she is an outsider.

The city of immigrants welcomes those from elsewhere as long as they know their place and their place, generally, is not to presume to be elected to the Senate 11 months after moving in. New Yorkers have a high opinion of themselves, one that extends to finding a candidate from among their own number.

Yet Mrs Clinton ran the more effective campaign, not least by having plenty of people from the state on her staff, while many of his came from other parts of the country.

Mr Lazio might be the real New Yorker, a breed that takes upon itself a know-it-all toughnesss, though this is a quality more remarked upon than observed. But when, during their first televised debate, the congressman from Long Island waved in her face a sheaf of papers about campaign finance, it was the turning point in the campaign.

Until that point it had been a referendum on Mrs Clinton: now polls showed that the electorate had filled in the blank page on Mr Lazio and what they drew was the image of a bully.

Previously, many women voters considered the Democratic candidate as anathema to them, someone who had stayed with her husband to further her ambition. Now enough recognised Mrs Clinton again as a victim, pushing her above 50 per cent for the first time.

The episode did nothing for the ideal of the strong, modern woman but it helped to put her in the Senate.

webTitle: Bush: Buoyant mood turns to disbelief

fields.headline: Buoyant mood turns to disbelief
fields.trailText: The George W Bush election headquarters scrambled last night to mobilise its supporters in the western states after its strategy to hold the eastern seaboard collapsed in the face of heavy turnout in urban Democratic strongholds.
fields.body:
The George W Bush election headquarters scrambled last night to mobilise its supporters in the western states after its strategy to hold the eastern seaboard collapsed in the face of heavy turnout in urban Democratic strongholds.

The Texan crowd which gathered on a chilly night outside the state capitol in Austin had come to celebrate but spent much of the evening biting their fingernails as Vice- President Al Gore scored victories in the eastern swing states.

"It's still OK. It's still OK," the compere at the rally told them, as he introduced one country and western singer after another. But for the Republican faithful, the loss of Florida, Michigan and Pennsylvania sunk in like body blows.

Carol and Stan TenEyck listened to the Pennsylvania result in silence. "That hurts," Carol said. "That's pretty bad."

Further bad news was to come. On big screens on each corner of the rally, Hillary Clinton's smiling face appeared - the Republican nemesis had just been confirmed in the New York Senate seat. The crowd booed heartily.

"I'm a bit nervous," Rose Beddingfield said. "I wouldn't like the Anti-Christ to be in the White House." She confirmed she was referring to Al Gore.

A moment of sweet revenge arrived with Mr Bush's win in the vice-president's home state, Tennessee, and hopes were once more buoyed.

The effort to counter the power of the unions and the black American vote in the great eastern cities, by relying on issue-oriented groups like the National Rifle Association and the anti-abortion movement had failed. Everything, it seemed, would depend on the west.

The Republican party chairman, Jim Nicholson, urged Republican voters to turn up in strength in western states, telling reporters: "It's not over 'til its over."

After news of defeats in Florida, Michigan and Pennsylvania, Governor Bush changed his plans and decided not to watch the rest of the results come in on a bank of television sets which had been set up in the Four Seasons Hotel in Austin. Instead, he went home to the governor's mansion with his parents.

"He preferred to be at home," Gordon Johndroe, a Bush spokesman said. "His own home was more relaxing."

Like speculators who had gambled everything on a single investment, Mr Bush and his backers had earlier assembled under torrential rain in Texas to discover if the most expensive campaign in US history had paid off.

At the centre of the action was Karl Rove, the Bush strategist, who shuttled between the campaign headquarters and the hotel armed with a notepad and a calculator for instant analysis of the shifting balance in the electoral college.

Exuding the studied opti mism which the Bush campaign had made its signature, Mr Rove predicted winning 320 of the 538 votes in the electoral college, which formally determines the presidency under the constitution.

His confidence, however, belied a nervous mood in the plush party headquarters. Some of the well-dressed staffers were actively discussing the possibility of winning the popular vote and narrowly losing the contest in the electoral college.

In that case, one said: "There should be pressure put on the delegates to reflect the national will."

All but two states - Maine and Nebraska - cast their votes in the electoral college on a winner-takes-all basis, but delegates have been known to defy the majority vote in their states and switch their vote.

Anticipating an agonisingly close finish, the Bush campaign set aside $80m for an effort in the last two weeks to mobilise its core supporters. Officials said 110m pamphlets had been posted and 62m phone calls had been made.

webTitle: Final west coast states hold key to election cliffhanger

fields.headline: Final west coast states hold key to election cliffhanger
fields.trailText: Al Gore and George W Bush were early this morning locked in the tightest head-to-head battle for the White House since the Kennedy-Nixon era.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Washington  Julian Borger  in Austin and  Duncan Campbell  in Nashville
fields.body:
Al Gore and George W Bush were early this morning locked in the tightest head-to-head battle for the White House since the Kennedy-Nixon era.

Both rivals captured important gains in back-and-forth swings of fortune in the vital battleground states as Democrats and Republican mobilised to the wire to capture every available vote in all 50 states.

Defying pundits who had mostly predicted a narrow Republican win, Mr Gore mounted a powerful all-night challenge to keep the White House in Democratic hands for a third term, winning Michigan and Pennsylvania, as well as taking Maine.

But Florida, declared a win for Gore on the basis of exit polls, was then early this morning declared too close to call as new polling information suggested a possible Bush victory.

On a night of extraordinary political excitement in the world's most important democracy, Hillary Clinton appeared to have made history by becoming the first president's wife to be elected to public office. Exit polls showed her capturing a New York Senate seat.

President Clinton was confident. He said: "I am the first president in history with a wife in the Senate and I like it."

Mr Bush was sweeping the South, including his own power base in Texas, but Mr Gore's strong early showing knocked Republicans back on their heels and meant Mr Bush had to win a long list of small and middle-ranking swing states if he was to win an election that had seemed to be his for the taking.

"It's going to be a long, late night," Mr Bush said in Austin. "Our people are still working like mad out there."

The Bush camp bitterly disputed the early media prediction that Florida had gone to Mr Gore and predicted that postal votes would push the state into the Bush column.

Mr Bush drew first blood in a pulsating evening of political drama by capturing Indiana, a traditional Republican state, and Kentucky, which voted for Mr Clinton in 1992 and 1996. Kentucky has voted for the winning candidate in every election from 1964.

Mr Bush then added to his total with early wins in Alabama, Georgia, Kansas, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Virginia and North and South Carolina. He also captured Nebraska, North and South Dakota and Wyoming.

But Mr Gore fought back strongly in the middle of the night with wins in Illinois, Maryland, Michigan, New Jersey, New York, Connecticut, Maryland and Vermont, giving him the initial advantage in the midwest swing states.

Then it was Mr Bush's turn to hit back, capturing the big midwest prize of Ohio, which frequently backs presidential winners, as well as Louisiana. Just after 2am Mr Bush won another psychologically important victory by capturing Mr Gore's home state of Tennessee.

That left Mr Gore's chances resting on victories in at least one of a group of hard-fought smaller states, including Iowa, Oregon, New Mexico and Wisconsin. US television networks called New Mexico for Mr Gore shortly before 3am.

Mr Clinton's original political base in Arkansas remained too close to call. Mr Bush's hopes of victory partly relied on a strong showing by the Green candidate, Ralph Nader, in traditionally Democratic states such as Minnesota, Wisconsin and the west coast states of Oregon and Washington. But Mr Gore captured Minnesota shortly after 2.30am.

In the battle for the Senate, Mrs Clinton fought an intense campaign against Republican Rick Lazio. Fifteen months af ter moving to New York, and with her husband at her side, Mrs Clinton was due to address cheering supporters in Manhattan in the early hours. Cheers rose from the crowd of Mrs Clinton's supporters gathered at the Grand Hyatt hotel in midtown Manhattan when the networks projected the first lady the winner, while isolated groans emanated from people watching the results on television monitors at Lazio's Roosevelt Hotel headquarters.

Democrats were also ahead in six swing Senate seats, and were losing to the Republicans in two others, suggesting that the Republicans may just retain control of the 100-seat body.

So close was the race for votes during the day that in a dramatic move yesterday afternoon, the Gore campaign hastily deployed top vote-getters and extra helpers into Pennsylvania and New Hampshire.

Mr Gore sent Jesse Jackson to Philadelphia, the main city in Pennsylvania, and asked Senator Edward Kennedy to deploy more than 100 extra trade union volunteers to stump for votes in New Hampshire.

Turnout was reported to be extremely high in several keenly contested areas, with well over 70% voting in Detroit and Miami.

A Fox News exit poll showed that Mr Gore made a strong challenge among undecided voters. Voters who had made up their minds in the past three days were divided two to one in favour of Mr Gore, the poll showed.
fields.bodyText: Al Gore and George W Bush were early this morning locked in the tightest head-to-head battle for the White House since the Kennedy-Nixon era. Both rivals captured important gains in back-and-forth swings of fortune in the vital battleground states as Democrats and Republican mobilised to the wire to capture every available vote in all 50 states. Defying pundits who had mostly predicted a narrow Republican win, Mr Gore mounted a powerful all-night challenge to keep the White House in Democratic hands for a third term, winning Michigan and Pennsylvania, as well as taking Maine. But Florida, declared a win for Gore on the basis of exit polls, was then early this morning declared too close to call as new polling information suggested a possible Bush victory. On a night of extraordinary political excitement in the world's most important democracy, Hillary Clinton appeared to have made history by becoming the first president's wife to be elected to public office. Exit polls showed her capturing a New York Senate seat. President Clinton was confident. He said: "I am the first president in history with a wife in the Senate and I like it." Mr Bush was sweeping the South, including his own power base in Texas, but Mr Gore's strong early showing knocked Republicans back on their heels and meant Mr Bush had to win a long list of small and middle-ranking swing states if he was to win an election that had seemed to be his for the taking. "It's going to be a long, late night," Mr Bush said in Austin. "Our people are still working like mad out there." The Bush camp bitterly disputed the early media prediction that Florida had gone to Mr Gore and predicted that postal votes would push the state into the Bush column. Mr Bush drew first blood in a pulsating evening of political drama by capturing Indiana, a traditional Republican state, and Kentucky, which voted for Mr Clinton in 1992 and 1996. Kentucky has voted for the winning candidate in every election from 1964. Mr Bush then added to his total with early wins in Alabama, Georgia, Kansas, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Virginia and North and South Carolina. He also captured Nebraska, North and South Dakota and Wyoming. But Mr Gore fought back strongly in the middle of the night with wins in Illinois, Maryland, Michigan, New Jersey, New York, Connecticut, Maryland and Vermont, giving him the initial advantage in the midwest swing states. Then it was Mr Bush's turn to hit back, capturing the big midwest prize of Ohio, which frequently backs presidential winners, as well as Louisiana. Just after 2am Mr Bush won another psychologically important victory by capturing Mr Gore's home state of Tennessee. That left Mr Gore's chances resting on victories in at least one of a group of hard-fought smaller states, including Iowa, Oregon, New Mexico and Wisconsin. US television networks called New Mexico for Mr Gore shortly before 3am. Mr Clinton's original political base in Arkansas remained too close to call. Mr Bush's hopes of victory partly relied on a strong showing by the Green candidate, Ralph Nader, in traditionally Democratic states such as Minnesota, Wisconsin and the west coast states of Oregon and Washington. But Mr Gore captured Minnesota shortly after 2.30am. In the battle for the Senate, Mrs Clinton fought an intense campaign against Republican Rick Lazio. Fifteen months af ter moving to New York, and with her husband at her side, Mrs Clinton was due to address cheering supporters in Manhattan in the early hours. Cheers rose from the crowd of Mrs Clinton's supporters gathered at the Grand Hyatt hotel in midtown Manhattan when the networks projected the first lady the winner, while isolated groans emanated from people watching the results on television monitors at Lazio's Roosevelt Hotel headquarters. Democrats were also ahead in six swing Senate seats, and were losing to the Republicans in two others, suggesting that the Republicans may just retain control of the 100-seat body. So close was the race for votes during the day that in a dramatic move yesterday afternoon, the Gore campaign hastily deployed top vote-getters and extra helpers into Pennsylvania and New Hampshire. Mr Gore sent Jesse Jackson to Philadelphia, the main city in Pennsylvania, and asked Senator Edward Kennedy to deploy more than 100 extra trade union volunteers to stump for votes in New Hampshire. Turnout was reported to be extremely high in several keenly contested areas, with well over 70% voting in Detroit and Miami. A Fox News exit poll showed that Mr Gore made a strong challenge among undecided voters. Voters who had made up their minds in the past three days were divided two to one in favour of Mr Gore, the poll showed.

webTitle: Weary teams pulled out all the stops

fields.headline: Weary teams pulled out all the stops
fields.standfirst: Gore  An extraordinary final sweep through 11 states
fields.trailText: The Democrats threw every effort into getting the vote out in key states as last night wore on. Rev Jesse Jackson was dispatched to Pennsylvania as exit polls indicated that George W Bush and Al Gore were neck and neck on 48% each.
fields.body:
The Democrats threw every effort into getting the vote out in key states as last night wore on. Rev Jesse Jackson was dispatched to Pennsylvania as exit polls indicated that George W Bush and Al Gore were neck and neck on 48% each.

The Democrats at their headquarters in Nashville claimed that "dirty tricks" were being played with their potential supporters. A conservative radio station in Florida was telling voters in this key state that Republicans were to vote on Tuesday and Democrats should vote on Wednesday. Polling, of course, was closing on Tuesday night.

A Democrat spokesman also claimed that the Republicans were playing the "race card" by warning voters in predominantly white areas that a vote for the Democrats could lead to the arrival of low income housing in their area.

The veteran Democrat senator, Edward Kennedy, was also asked to mobilise more than 100 activists in New Hampshire as both sides threw desperate efforts into getting the vote out.

Early on the Democrats had declared themselves pleased with the indication that there was going to be a high turnout of voters in the states that mattered most to them..

Mr Gore voted in his home town of Carthage, not far from Nashville, after an extraordinary sweep through 11 states, an indication of how tight the contest was seen to be right to the last moment.

His final campaign appearance before voting started was in Tampa, Florida, where he met a group of night-shift care workers at 4am. Florida was chosen for the last trip as a signal of how much he valued its votes. "It's not an accident that it's here in Tampa," Mr Gore, his eyes almost closed with weariness, told the workers, "because Florida may well be the state that decides this contest." George W Bush's brother Jeb is governor of the state.

As the votes began to come in under the sunny Tennessee skies, the Democrats' vice-presidential candidate, Joe Lieberman, and his wife arrived to watch the results with the Gores at a Nashville hotel. Then it was on to the War Memorial Plaza for the last of the hundreds of rallies of the campaign.

Confidence swelled through the evening as a string of key states which the Democrats need to win were announced as victories for Mr Gore. The Gores and Liebermans, dining together, leapt to their feet and embraced at news of their victory in Florida.

At his campaign headquarters, loud cheers greeted the news that Mr Gore had taken Pennsylvania. Mr Gore and Mr Lieberman began frantically phoning radio shows on the West Coast and in the mountain regions to persuade voters to get down to the polls, warning that the future of a woman's right to choose, and of the environment, depended on it.

Raucous celebration greeted the victory of Hillary Clinton in New York.

But the news that Mr Gore had lost his home state of Tennessee, while expected, was a blow, as local Democrats had promised him that he was in with a real chance. Only Woodrow Wilson has been elected president while losing his home state.

Doug Hattaway was meanwhile making final appeals on television to voters in Washington state, Oregon and California as well as Arizona, Colorado and New Mexico.

Earlier, Mr Gore's 100,000 volunteers had started phoning voters to get them down to the polls, and sending off the last of the 30m emails that have been sent throughout the campaign.

This has been the first internet election and the Democrats have made full use of it. The implications of reaching voters this way are enormous because it allows candidates to home in with very specific messages to groups.

webTitle: Wall Street millions buy victory

fields.headline: Wall Street millions buy victory
fields.standfirst:
Funding Banker spends record $60m on campaign
Special report: the US election
fields.trailText: A Wall Street millionaire won a seat in the United States senate early today after spending a record $60m of his own money to do it.
fields.body:
A Wall Street millionaire won a seat in the United States senate early today after spending a record $60m of his own money to do it. Jon Corzine, the 53-year-old former chairman of Goldman Sachs, won the New Jersey seat vacated by another Democratic multi-millionaire, Frank Lautenberg, who had served three terms and was retiring at the age of 76.

Mr Corzine spent at least $2m yesterday alone, including $75 a head on homeless people from nearby Philadelphia and recovering drug addicts employed to help get out the vote. The man defeated by Mr Corzine, Republican Bob Franks, had raised a relatively puny $6m and had to ride on the former presidential primary candidate John McCain's Straight Talk Express bus.

The campaign behind Mr Franks, 49, spent about $1m on encouraging turnout yesterday when their man appeared to be doing better than expected in the opinion polls.

But his hopes of winning were never going to be good after the Republicans decided to concentrate their resources on the ultimately failed campaign of Rick Lazio to prevent Hillary Clinton from winning a Senate seat from neighbouring New York.

Mr Corzine, who, unlike Mrs Clinton, has lived in the state he now represents for 25 years, left Goldman Sachs last year with a fortune estimated at $400m and was making his first attempt to win office.

webTitle: Referendum blow for Blair as backing for euro slips to 18%

fields.headline: Referendum blow for Blair as backing for euro slips to 18%
fields.standfirst:
ICM poll Labour voters increasingly hostile

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Pro-euro cabinet ministers fear Tony Blair will be unwilling to hold a referendum on joining the single currency if he wins a second term after the Guardian/ICM poll found support for the single currency has slumped to a record low of just 18%.
fields.body:
Pro-euro cabinet ministers fear Tony Blair will be unwilling to hold a referendum on joining the single currency if he wins a second term after the Guardian/ICM poll found support for the single currency has slumped to a record low of just 18%.

Fewer than one in every five adults said they would vote to replace the pound with the euro as opposition hit an all-time high of 71%.

The poll results dismayed euro campaigners and led to one prominent pro-single currency member of the government admitting Labour may be unable to fulfill its manifesto commitment. "We will promise a referendum before joining but governments only hold referendums they expect to win," said the minister. Support for the single currency has halved since February 1999, shortly after its launch, when 36% backed entry and was down three points on October this month to 18%.

Opposition has grown from 48% in March 1998 to 71% in November, up two points on October to produce an overwhelming 53% majority against - the highest since ICM started regular polling on the issue in February 1995.

The slump in support follows the Danish nej vote, two rescue missions to prop up the ailing money and Mr Blair's admission that even he would vote no if a referendum were held now.

Even Labour voters are increasingly hostile to the euro with 60% against and just 29% for. Tory leader William Hague on the other hand could rely, according to the poll, on 85% of Tories voting no in a referendum and only 10% for.

Yet there was a crumb of comfort for the prime minister. The proportion of voters who think the pound will be replaced by the euro within the next 10 years was down from 66% in January to 52% but that still represents more than half the electorate.

Pollster Nick Sparrow of ICM said the widening gap was partly down to Labour's decision to play down the issue ahead of the election. Even the most fervent cabinet supporter of the single currency, the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, has admitted a poll may now be some way off. Michael Heseltine, the former Tory deputy PM, will tomorrow claim thousands of jobs are at risk if Britain stays outside the euro. But he is in danger of becoming something of a lone voice.

Nick Herbert, chief executive of the anti-euro Business for Sterling group, said: "This is further evidence that it is going to be extremely difficult for the government to win a euro referendum when there is such a substantial poll lead to turn around."

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,001 adults aged 18 and over be telephone from November 3-5. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: The European ideal has been lost. We need to get it back

fields.headline: The European ideal has been lost. We need to get it back
fields.standfirst:
Europe must be rescued from the bureaucrats and the bankers
Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Vernon Bogdanor Europe must be rescued from the bureaucrats and the bankers
fields.body:
" A manacle chaining Europe." That is what Romano Prodi, president of the European Commission, has called the right of member states to veto European legislation, which Tony Blair, like his predecessors in Downing Street, is fighting to preserve. Prodi, however, wants to extend majority voting so as to secure the "ever closer union", which the treaty of Rome defined as the aim of European integration.

Since 1950, when the French foreign minister, Robert Schuman, proposed the creation of a European coal and steel community, British prime ministers have woefully underestimated the strength of the drive towards European integration on the continent. In Britain the hope now is that enlargement of the European Union will lead to dilution, a slowing-down of the pace of integration.

On the continent, by contrast, many political leaders believe that enlargement can be made compatible with a deepening of the community, a speeding-up of the integration process. In his "bombshell" speech in May, the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, proposed reforming the institutions of the union so that the tension between what he called "the communitarisation of economy and currency on the one hand and the lack of political and de mocratic structures on the other", could be resolved.

Fischer sought more majority voting, a further transfer of legislative power from the council to the European parliament, and the creation of a European senate, representing the parliaments of the member states.

The trouble is, however, that these institutional reforms fail to confront the fundamental problem facing Europe, the withdrawal of popular consent. Last year, fewer than half of the electorate voted in the Euro- elections. In Britain, as Charles Kennedy has pointed out, more people watched Big Brother, than bothered to vote for the European parliament. As the powers of the European parliament have increased, fewer and fewer people have been voting for it, turnout having fallen continuously since 1979.

Moreover, if survey evidence is to be believed, there is widespread hostility to the euro in many European countries, and especially in Germany and France. Yet, opposition to the euro has been led, not by the mainstream parties, but by extremists - former communists and the extreme right in Germany, the Front Nationale and the communists in France. Europe is beginning to create that most dangerous of all cleavages, one between the political class and the people.

This alienation will not be cured by more majority voting. For, as former British foreign secretary, Lord Howe, has pointed out, majority voting presumes a pre-existing sense of community. Most Europeans, however, see their national governments not as obstacles to their wishes, but as more representative than either the council of ministers or the European parliament, which are seen as part of a remote and even hostile superstructure. What is needed to combat this is not an alteration in the balance between European institutions, but an alteration in the balance between the institutions and the people.

The institutions of the European Union were designed in the 1950s, during an era of deference towards politics and political leaders. Then, the leaders led and the followers followed. Today, while the leaders may still be willing to lead, the followers are no longer willing to follow.

The ethos of the European Union is that of the French fourth republic, with key decisions being taken by non-elected and non- accountable commissioners, the equivalent of the French civil servants who kept the fourth republic afloat amidst a sea of unstable ministries. Perhaps Europe now needs the ethos of the French fifth republic, based on direct election of the executive and, as Commissioner Gunter Verheugen has proposed, use of the referendum to legitimise major decisions.

Giscard d'Estaing, the former French president, has long advocated that the president of the European Commission be directly elected. But this would require an amendment to the treaty of Rome, and is hardly practical politics at the present time.

An important first step, however, would be to activate article 158 of the treaty of Rome, which requires the president of the commission to enjoy "the confidence of the European parliament." So far, the parliament has been woefully supine in using this provision.

In 1994, a parliament with a left majority endorsed Jacques Santer, a Christian Democrat. In 1999, the governments of the member states agreed on Romano Prodi as Santer's successor, without even bothering to await the outcome of the Euro-elections.

In domestic elections, voters turn out to choose a parliament which will help decide the political leadership of their country as well as its policies. Why should anyone bother to vote for a Euro-pean parliament which fulfils neither of these functions?

If the president, and indeed the European commission as a whole, were to be genuinely res- ponsible to the European parliament, then there would be a real incentive for electors to vote for it. For they would genuinely be deciding upon their European future, upon whether they wished to live in a Europe led from the right or the left.

In 1950, Robert Schuman challenged Europeans to overcome the divisions of the past by embracing the European ideal. Today, Europe faces the challenge of rescuing that ideal from the bureaucrats and the bankers who have appropriated it. Can the democratic and constitutional forces of Europe confront that challenge with the same vigour and optimism as their predecessors did 50 years ago?

Vernon Bogdanor is professor of government at Oxford University. A new edition of his book, Devolution in the United Kingdom, will be published by Oxford University Press later this year.

Polly Toynbee's column will appear tomorrow.

webTitle: Police tell hauliers to scrap convoy

fields.headline: Police tell hauliers to scrap convoy
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Hauliers and farmers planning a convoy from Jarrow to London on Friday in protest at high fuel prices were last night on a collision course with police after chief constables said the action posed a danger to the public and should be called off.
fields.body:
Hauliers and farmers planning a convoy from Jarrow to London on Friday in protest at high fuel prices were last night on a collision course with police after chief constables said the action posed a danger to the public and should be called off.

Warning that the full force of the law would bear down on the demonstrators, Tony Burden, president of the Association of Chief Police Officers (ACPO), said the convoy - which would include tractors travelling at 20mph - was likely to create "major accidents" on motorways.

In another statement Northumbria police, which has responsibility for Jarrow and surrounding Tyneside, warned that prohibited vehicles, such as farm tractors, would not be allowed on motorways. "Every protester who intends to use a motorway or trunk road as part of their protest will be advised that they must neither form a convoy which could be inherently dangerous, nor travel at a dangerously low speed."

Mr Burden revealed that at a meeting with police in the north east on Monday night, leaders of the Peoples' Fuel Lobby had refused to call off the protest despite senior officers raising concerns about public safety.

He criticised their plans to go through areas badly affected by the current floods. "Not only are they impacting on public safety but they seem to be insensitive to those areas which are already suffering as a result of flooding," he said. "In relation to the convoy movements, there is no question in our mind that the tactic is dangerous and creates a danger to the public. It also creates a danger to the emer gency services." Fearing widespread disorder, Acpo is co-ordinating a national framework to deal with the protesters and a common policy to ensure that various forces interpret the law in the same way. It now seems clear that a slow moving convoy could well be regarded as an illegal obstruction of the highway.

Mr Burden said chief constables would be considering cancelling leave for officers and requiring some to work 12 hour shifts to help police the demonstration. "There will be positive policing to ensure that those convoys do not proceed down the motorway creating... danger in the way it did last time," he added. "This is a profoundly dangerous tactic which is likely to create major accidents on the motorway systems - therefore it is something the police do not support."

Craig Eley, a Tyneside haulier and member of the Peoples' Fuel Lobby, said the convoy from Jarrow to London would cause no more problems to road users than the "normal rush hour, Friday night traffic". He claimed police were joining the government in trying to scare the public into turning against the protesters. "We are not wanting to create massive havoc, but the protest is still going on."

 The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is expected to announce plans today for further price incentives to extend cleaner fuels, including proposed cuts in duty on ultra-low sulphur petrol.

The aim will be to offer ULSP at lower forecourt rates than other unleaded petrol. ULSP could be used in all cars that take unleaded petrol, and extend the life of catalytic converters.

In another statement Northumbria police, which has responsibility for Jarrow and surrounding Tyneside, warned that prohibited vehicles, such as farm tractors, would not be allowed on motorways. "Every protester who intends to use a motorway or trunk road as part of their protest will be advised that they must neither form a convoy which could be inherently dangerous, nor travel at a dangerously low speed." Mr Burden revealed that at a meeting with police in the north east on Monday night, leaders of the Peoples' Fuel Lobby had refused to call off the protest despite senior officers raising concerns about public safety. He criticised their plans to go through areas badly affected by the current floods. "Not only are they impacting on public safety but they seem to be insensitive to those areas which are already suffering as a result of flooding," he said. "In relation to the convoy movements, there is no question in our mind that the tactic is dangerous and creates a danger to the public. It also creates a danger to the emer gency services." Fearing widespread disorder, Acpo is co-ordinating a national framework to deal with the protesters and a common policy to ensure that various forces interpret the law in the same way. It now seems clear that a slow moving convoy could well be regarded as an illegal obstruction of the highway. Mr Burden said chief constables would be considering cancelling leave for officers and requiring some to work 12 hour shifts to help police the demonstration. "There will be positive policing to ensure that those convoys do not proceed down the motorway creating... danger in the way it did last time," he added. "This is a profoundly dangerous tactic which is likely to create major accidents on the motorway systems - therefore it is something the police do not support." Craig Eley, a Tyneside haulier and member of the Peoples' Fuel Lobby, said the convoy from Jarrow to London would cause no more problems to road users than the "normal rush hour, Friday night traffic". He claimed police were joining the government in trying to scare the public into turning against the protesters. "We are not wanting to create massive havoc, but the protest is still going on."  The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is expected to announce plans today for further price incentives to extend cleaner fuels, including proposed cuts in duty on ultra-low sulphur petrol. The aim will be to offer ULSP at lower forecourt rates than other unleaded petrol. ULSP could be used in all cars that take unleaded petrol, and extend the life of catalytic converters.

webTitle: Give clean fuel a break, says Peugeot

fields.headline: Give clean fuel a break, says Peugeot
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Tod Evans, the managing director of Peugeot UK, yesterday called for tax breaks to encourage use of diesel and LPG-powered cars, writes Nicholas Bannister .
fields.body:
Tod Evans, the managing director of Peugeot UK, yesterday called for tax breaks to encourage use of diesel and LPG-powered cars.

"We know we are being fleeced as an industry by fuel tax, vehicle excise duty and so on," he said. "We must concentrate on how government can change its fiscal policy to encourage ... fuel-efficient cars."

His comments at a Guardian motor industry lunch in London came on the eve of Gordon Brown's pre-Budget statement in which the chancellor is expected to give little to the anti-fuel tax lobby.

Mr Evans said environmentally friendly engine technologies, such as fuel cells, were being developed, but the government should encourage technologies already available.

"I have been telling government not to penalise short-term solutions such as diesel, which uses 30% less fuel, and LPG (Liquid Petroleum Gas)," he said.

The government had been told that manufacturers had been making great strides in removing harmful particulate emissions. The latest Peugeot diesel engines, for example, had a sensor which told the engine to burn the smuts containing the particulates and particulate filters which were automatically cleaned every 400 miles.

The car industry's relationship with government over the last five years had been "reasonably strained". Labour had been seen as anti-car, but that had changed with the approach of the general election.

Mr Evans also warned that the strong pound threatened inward investment in car manufacturing.

webTitle: BP posts record profits

fields.headline: BP posts record profits
fields.standfirst:
Chancellor expected to shift blame for forecourt price rises on to oil companies

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Trade unions and fuel campaigners renewed calls for a windfall tax on petrol companies yesterday, following news the booming price of crude oil helped BP Amoco almost double its profits to $3.8bn (£2.7bn) over the summer.
fields.body:
Trade unions and fuel campaigners renewed calls for a windfall tax on petrol companies yesterday, following news the booming price of crude oil helped BP Amoco almost double its profits to $3.8bn (£2.7bn) over the summer.

Surging earnings from exploration and production helped the company increase its third-quarter profits by 94%, although its garage forecourts business in Britain plunged $21m into the red due to September's fuel crisis.

The figures stepped up pressure on the oil industry ahead of today's Pre-Budget state ment. Chancellor Gordon Brown will try to shift the blame for high forecourt prices on to fuel suppliers by announcing a freeze on petrol taxes, although he is likely to stop short of a windfall levy on the oil companies. BP's record profits follow similar jumps in earnings from rivals Esso, Texaco and Exxon Mobil.

BP's chief executive Sir John Browne admitted he faced a tricky task in explaining to the public why the company was making so much money as consumers struggle to pay for fuel: "It would be unrealistic to suggest that my arguments would make them turn round and say 'that's all right then'."

However, he insisted that BP was a "taker, rather than a maker" of fuel prices, blaming rises on the Opec oil exporting nations and on government taxation.

Sir John added that BP could not unilaterally cut its forecourt prices without falling foul of pricing laws, which prevent big companies from squeezing their smaller rivals.

Union leaders were not satisfied and demanded government action. John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB, said oil companies were "making money hand over fist.

"If the government were to slap a windfall tax on all these companies, it would pay for 25p off a gallon of petrol as well as a £50 bonus for every pensioner this Christmas, he added.

Danny Carrigan, the AEEU's national officer for the North Sea, said: "There is clearly a case for the government to look at whether (the oil companies) are making excess profits."

Road haulage associations were also critical. Garry Russell, organiser of the Dump the Pump campaign, said: "I think this shows a huge flaw in the way fuel taxation is calibrated.

"I think the government should tax oil companies when prices are high. This would allow it to reduce consumer tax without losing revenue."

Oil prices have tripled over the last two years. But BP's deputy chief executive Rodney Chase said the group's profit margins from British petrol stations were "wafer-thin". He said the company makes just 1p profit on each litre it sells.

Sir John said he had few regrets about BP's handling of the fuel crisis, when its tanker drivers were allowed to stay at base to avoid "intimidation".

He said: "I think we looked after the physical aspects pretty well, although on the communications side we can always improve."

The crisis wiped out the company's usual profits of about $15m from domestic retailing, as it lost revenue and paid for extra shifts as its staff struggled to restore supplies.

webTitle: Fuel protesters: the fight continues

fields.headline: Fuel protesters: the fight continues
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2000
fields.trailText: Fuel tax protesters have reacted angrily to this afternoon's pre-budget statement by the chancellor.
fields.body:
Fuel tax protesters have reacted angrily to this afternoon's pre-budget statement by the chancellor.

Gordon Brown told the Commons that fuel duty frozen until April 2002. In addition, fuel duty on ultra-low sulphur diesel will be cut by 3p in next year's Budget.

Road tax will be scrapped for tractors, the chancellor said.

Five million motorists, those with 1500cc vehicles, will have cheaper driving licences from March 2001.

And Mr Brown spared oil companies an expected windfall tax on their profits.

Brynle Williams, the Welsh farmer at the forefront of the recent fuel protests, said there would be no return to blockade the oil refineries. But he described the measures in Mr Brown's speech as "an insult" to industry and the public.

"I believe the chancellor is trying to drive a wedge between the haulage industry, agriculture and the general public and I don't believe he is going to succeed," Mr Williams said.

"The general public will see through this for what it is. He has tried to seduce us with tokens like three pence off a litre, but it is not going to work ... This is a final slap in the face for the general public and Mr Brown is insulting our integrity."

Roy Masterson, a haulier who led the fuel blockades at Trafford Park in Manchester which paralysed the north-west, said Gordon Brown's statement was "very, very poor".

Mr Masterson, who owns nine lorries, said: "It goes nowhere to addressing the imbalance that the British people suffer in relation to the rest of Europe. Taxing foreign lorry drivers up to our level will not help manufacturing or the people of this country."

Mr Masterson welcomed the shake-up in the road tax system, but said: "The rally will go on to London and further talks will have to take place if he is going to make hauliers happy."

Ken Harvey, 50, who picketed at Cheshire's Stanlow oil refinery, the trigger for the nationwide fuel protests, said he did not think the chancellor had done enough for hauliers. Mr Harvey, who owns 22 lorries, said: "Fuel should be down 15p at least. I think the fight should go on."

But he did welcome a new tax for foreign lorry drivers. "I've been saying that for years. We have to pay tax when we go to Europe so they should have to pay it when they use our motorways."

The oil industry today welcomed Mr Brown's decision not to impose a windfall tax on the sector's spiralling profits.

There was speculation that the North sea industry would be hit with a windfall tax on the bumper profits caused by soaring oil prices. Earlier this month, Shell reported an 80% jump in its last quarter's profits to £2.24bn, while BP reported a record figure of £3.65bn.

Both firms had said the bumper profits were due to the soaring oil prices, which had prompted speculation a windfall tax would be imposed today by Mr Brown.

But Mr Brown confirmed today that there would be no new tax - and instead firms would be encouraged to invest their profits in the future of the industry.

The move was backed by the UK Offshore Operators Association, which represents oil firms and contractors. A spokeswoman said: "We have always been confident that the government understands fully the economics of the UK industry and the competition that it faces from other parts of the world for investment capital.

webTitle: Foreign lorries face £1,000 disc charge

fields.headline: Foreign lorries face £1,000 disc charge
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The government is to impose a Britdisc on foreign lorries as part of a package of measures designed to help Britain's road haulage industry weather the fuel crisis, Lord Macdonald, transport minister, indicated yesterday.
fields.body:
The government is to impose a Britdisc on foreign lorries as part of a package of measures designed to help Britain's road haulage industry weather the fuel crisis, Lord Macdonald, transport minister, indicated yesterday.

The disc or vignette, which would cost at least £1,000 per lorry, is likely to be announced by the chan cellor Gordon Brown in his pre-budget statement later today which will rule out any cut in fuel duty as demanded by protesters.

Lord Macdonald told the conference that the government had been examining the case for a Britdisc in talks within the road haulage forum and conceded that road haulage needed a package of measures to help it.

He admitted that thousands of small hauliers were losers as the industry underwent change, with low profit margins, a shortage of drivers and a squeeze by big UK transport companies and foreign competition.

The vignette, similar to the road permit required on many European roads, would make foreign hauliers in larger lorries "who do the most damage to our roads" make a contribution to the costs of repairing and renewing roads. The minister ruled out the 26.2p cut in fuel duty originally demanded by haulage protesters as required to bring the cost of diesel into line with European prices.

"I am well aware of the problems faced by hauliers and farmers which I believe we can address but not through an unrealistic and irresponsible 26p cut in fuel," he told delegates.

Lord Macdonald said a cut on that scale would cause an immediate rise in interest rates by pumping £12bn into the economy. It would force ministers to scale back on help for pensioners and bring deep cuts in spending on schools, hospitals and transport.

 Digby Jones, director general of the CBI, said high-earning executives should not be dubbed fat cats. There was nothing wrong with business leaders sharing in the prosperity they helped to create.

webTitle: Leader: Case for Euro not lost yet

fields.headline: Friendless, deserted
fields.standfirst:
But the case for the euro is not lost yet.

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will be comforted by Romano Prodi's endorsement of his vision of the EU as a super-power rather than a super-state.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will be comforted by Romano Prodi's endorsement of his vision of the EU as a super-power rather than a super-state. The president of the European Commission went out of his way at the CBI's annual conference to dismiss "scare stories about the creation of a centralised super-state". But that will not wipe away any of the embarrassment felt in Downing Street today as the euro sinks even lower in public esteem. The Guardian/ICM poll published today indicates that only 18% of electors want to join Europe's single currency now, compared with 36% only 20 months ago. Over half of all respondents (52%) still believe that Britain will eventually drop the pound and adopt the euro - but that too is down from a peak of 66%.

It is tempting to think that this does not matter because the Danish No vote and Mr Blair's admission that he too would not join the euro now have taken the issue out of practical politics at least for the next year or two. Except, of course, that the Conservatives - 85% of whom are against the euro, according to our poll - will not let it happen: they will do all they can to ensure that the euro comes up again and again during the election campaign to capitalise on what they perceive to be increasing euro- scepticism among voters.

Undoubtedly that exists. But the interesting thing is how far the politics of the euro are umbilically linked to its economics. It is no coincidence that the political unpopularity of the euro has closely tracked its unpopularity on the financial markets, where it is now trading about 30% below its recent high point. Most analysts, and the vast majority of politicians, believe that it is undervalued, though some have interpreted the European Central Bank's intervention in recent days as a move to prevent the euro falling even lower in the event of the US election producing a euphoric result for the markets - like a clean sweep of the presidency and both houses of Congress by the Republicans. Tinkering in the foreign exchange markets by the ECB in these circumstances would be like spitting in the wind. It will not do anything by itself unless it coincides with the event that Europe has been waiting for - the slowing down of the US economy.

If this happens, then it is easy to imagine a rosier scenario in which the main reason for the euro's woes - the vast flows of investment funds out of Europe and into America, caused by mergers and share investment - goes into reverse. The euro would become stronger, thereby boosting its poll ratings in Britain. This would encourage politicians to make more favourable noises which, in turn, would make people feel better about it. When the euro starts circulating in notes and coins (in 2002) everyone will be able to handle them on holiday. Suddenly, instead of being a theoretical bogeyman, the euro might become a rather pleasant vacation experience. In these circumstances, it is even possible to imagine the euro seeping into Britain as a parallel currency. Maybe in two or three years time the problem will not be that the euro is too weak, but that it is too strong. None of this is directly related to the underlying economic problems of joining the euro (such as Britain having to accept ECB-imposed interest rates irrespective of our economic circumstances). But it could have a big impact on the political conditions in which a re-elected Labour government might launch its pro-euro campaign. And, incidentally, any euros bought by the ECB at today's low level as part of its intervention strategy would then be sporting a very healthy profit.

webTitle: Citizen Clinton reflects as his enemies turn fire on Gore

fields.headline: Citizen Clinton reflects as his enemies turn fire on Gore
fields.standfirst:
End of an era Many are only too happy to see the back of him
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: End of an era Many are only too happy to see the back of him
fields.body:
Yesterday was the day Bill Clinton's enemies had been waiting for - or so they hoped - and the doyenne of Clinton-haters could hardly contain her excitement.

Lucianne Goldberg was the New York literary agent who advised Linda Tripp to tape her conversations with Monica Lewinsky to snare the president. She almost succeeded, but the failure of his impeachment has not diminished her thirst for the end of the Clinton era.

"Remember, oh bloodied ones, one vote is a landslide," she advised her troops yesterday as they chattered to one another over her website in the hope that George W Bush would win the White House.

Mr Clinton was a bit-part player in the 2000 election, but professed to be happy enough after casting his vote for Mr Gore and his wife. "I've had a great life and I've been very lucky."

He conceded yesterday that he felt a little bit wistful about being absent from the ballot for the first time in 26 years, but added: "I'm at peace with it - I'm just going to try to be a good citizen."

But the Clinton-haters were not at all at peace with him. For them there was only one reason to be involved in the election - to get rid of the man they call "the rapist".

"This is what we have worked so hard for, gang. The time has come," a Goldberg fan urged.

"I've just logged on our local TV station and checked their poll - Bush 51%, the vice rapist 37%. I know it's not scientific but it still made me smile. I'll bet the station is going nuts, they're so pro-rapist! Go W!" cut in Kathryn.

"Wild dogs could not stop me from voting these human piles of slime out of office," reported Cornhusker.

"With God's help, HELP is on the way," came another report.

"Just went and voted," reported Pat. "And the strangest thing, everyone leaving had huge smiles on their faces. Asked a lady why she was smiling and she said it was like cleaning your house to vote Bush. This is a lovely day for a thrashing."

"What a feeling to be in such great company with all these optimistic posters. Thank you for making this Christmas morning and the gift you've been waiting for is under the tree. YEEE HAAAA!" said Stratman.

It took Sukey to puncture some of the delirium. "Don't mean to turn sour, but just hope we are prepared emotionally if this whole election turns. I have to admit I'm a little concerned when I hear of all these lines at polling places. A huge turnout is almost always good news for the Dems."

But the mood of unshakeable Clinton-hatred was soon back in the shape of a message from Sulla. "I crawled uphill through broken glass on a stormy Tuesday. I cast my vote for Bush-Cheney with a big time smile on my face."

Lucianne Goldberg was the New York literary agent who advised Linda Tripp to tape her conversations with Monica Lewinsky to snare the president. She almost succeeded, but the failure of his impeachment has not diminished her thirst for the end of the Clinton era. "Remember, oh bloodied ones, one vote is a landslide," she advised her troops yesterday as they chattered to one another over her website in the hope that George W Bush would win the White House. Mr Clinton was a bit-part player in the 2000 election, but professed to be happy enough after casting his vote for Mr Gore and his wife. "I've had a great life and I've been very lucky." He conceded yesterday that he felt a little bit wistful about being absent from the ballot for the first time in 26 years, but added: "I'm at peace with it - I'm just going to try to be a good citizen." But the Clinton-haters were not at all at peace with him. For them there was only one reason to be involved in the election - to get rid of the man they call "the rapist". "This is what we have worked so hard for, gang. The time has come," a Goldberg fan urged. "I've just logged on our local TV station and checked their poll - Bush 51%, the vice rapist 37%. I know it's not scientific but it still made me smile. I'll bet the station is going nuts, they're so pro-rapist! Go W!" cut in Kathryn. "Wild dogs could not stop me from voting these human piles of slime out of office," reported Cornhusker. "With God's help, HELP is on the way," came another report. "Just went and voted," reported Pat. "And the strangest thing, everyone leaving had huge smiles on their faces. Asked a lady why she was smiling and she said it was like cleaning your house to vote Bush. This is a lovely day for a thrashing." "What a feeling to be in such great company with all these optimistic posters. Thank you for making this Christmas morning and the gift you've been waiting for is under the tree. YEEE HAAAA!" said Stratman. It took Sukey to puncture some of the delirium. "Don't mean to turn sour, but just hope we are prepared emotionally if this whole election turns. I have to admit I'm a little concerned when I hear of all these lines at polling places. A huge turnout is almost always good news for the Dems." But the mood of unshakeable Clinton-hatred was soon back in the shape of a message from Sulla. "I crawled uphill through broken glass on a stormy Tuesday. I cast my vote for Bush-Cheney with a big time smile on my face."

webTitle: Watford 1 - 3 Sheff Wed

fields.headline: Watford lose unbeaten run
fields.trailText: It was a big Tuesday for Wednesday. They showed outstanding sprit and opportunism to trash the final unbeaten record in all four divisions last night and leave Watford reeling.
fields.body:
It was not Wednesday that worried Graham Taylor so much as Tuesday. "We have been less than convincing on Tuesday nights and I am concerned about this game," said the Watford manager in advance. Not for the first time his team proved him right.

Clearly the league's last remaining unbeaten record had to fall some time and Taylor had picked up the runes about this particular game. It was one Tuesday too many for the First Division leaders as two second-half goals gave the visitors a surprise victory.

What is more Wednesday fully deserved it for an outstanding display of spirit and opportunism which demonstrated to their manager Paul Jewell that his hard work and angry words were getting through at long last. With this win his team leave the bottom three places well behind.

When the substitute Tommy Smith cancelled out a first-half own-goal from Richard Jobson, the Manchester City defender on loan to Watford where he began his career 18 years ago, there would not have been many inside Vicarage Road prepared to speculate that Wednesday would score the next goal.

Yet the home team had a problem dealing with their corners all night and when Terry Cooke swung the ball across there was the teenager Tony Crane, on only his second starting appearance, driving home a header.

Then, with seven minutes remaining, Alan Quinn produced a devastating burst down the left before squeezing his shot over the line.

"We were called Shambolic Sheffield after Saturday's display," said Jewell about the defeat at Crystal Palace which was a surprising way to follow up last week's success in the Sheffield derby. "I had a few harsh words with them and they have responded in the right fashion."

Wednesday's spirit was obvious from early on and the departure after 12 minutes of Gerald Sibon with a dislocated shoulder produced no disruption. On came Michele di Piedi and his energetic involvement exemplified his team's willingness to get involved.

An early Crane drive which drew a fine save from Espen Baardsen was a sign of things to come. Andy Booth struck the bar with a header and confidence grew.

Cooke's corner eight minutes before the interval brought defensive confusion and the ball bounced into the net off Jobson's forehead and at that moment Taylor began humming an old tune. "The Boomtown Rats didn't like Mondays," he said. "But for me the problem is with Tuesdays."

webTitle: Lyon and Valencia do just enough

fields.headline: Lyon and Valencia do just enough
fields.trailText: Pierre Laigle scored after two minutes to give Lyon a 1-0 win over Olympiakos last night and a place in the second phase of the Champions League.
fields.body:
Pierre Laigle scored after two minutes to give Lyon a 1-0 win over Olympiakos last night and a place in the second phase of the Champions League.

The French team's gamble of playing three strikers paid dividends as they edged the Greek side out on goal difference. Olympiakos will now drop down to the Uefa Cup.

Tony Vairelles crossed from the right and the midfielder Laigle headed home unmarked. Lyon also hit the woodwork twice in the second half.

Spain's Valencia claimed top spot in the group despite being held 1-1 at home by 10-man Heerenveen. Last season's runners-up opened the scoring after 10 minutes when a Libero Parri shot was deflected in by Diego Alonso. The Dutch equalised through Ronnie Venema seven minutes before half-time but were a man down for the final 33 minutes after Arjan Ebbinge was sent off. Spartak Moscow beat the below-strength European champions Real Madrid 1-0 in their Group A match with an own-goal from the Real midfielder Gérémi Njitap after 47 minutes. Both sides had already qualified for the next phase, Real secure in first place and Spartak second.

The other match in the group was a similarly lacklustre affair with Sporting Lisbon and Bayer Leverkusen playing out a goalless draw. The German club had already secured third place in the group and a place in the Uefa Cup.
