webTitle: Bush scores on honesty, Gore on understanding

fields.headline: Bush scores on honesty, Gore on understanding
fields.standfirst:
Choice between personality and experience
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Voters' split priorities reflected the tug-of-war between personality and experience  at the core of this campaign.
fields.body:
George W Bush got some strong backing from those voters who sought honesty and strong leadership in a candidate, exit polls said this morning, while Al Gore drew solid support from those who wanted experience and understanding of complex issues.

The voters' split priorities reflected the tug-of-war between personality and experience that has been at the core of this campaign.

Voters were interviewed last night and this morning as they left the polls by Voter News Service. Mr Gore led among women, blacks and Hispanics; Mr Bush among men and whites. Mr Bush led among parents; Mr Gore among non-parents, a larger group. The two candidates were matched fairly evenly among most age groups.

The Democrat led among those who made $30,000 or less a year while the Republican led among those who made $75,000 or more. They were evenly divided among middle-income voters. Mr Gore led among those who thought the issues were most important while Mr Bush led among those who valued personal qualities.

Both presidential candidates had strong support from their party bases and were splitting the independents about evenly, according to preliminary poll results. Mr Gore was getting four of five Clinton supporters from 1996 and Mr Bush was getting nine of 10 who voted for Bob Dole, the previous Republican candidate. Supporters of 1996 third-party candidate Ross Perot tilted toward Bush this time round.

The most important issue for many voters was the economy, and those who picked that issue backed Mr Gore heavily. Taxes were another important issue and that group backed Mr Bush by an overwhelming margin.

The Republican was also backed by those who thought that world affairs was the top issue, while the vice-president was backed by those who thought that healthcare and prescription drugs were important issues.

Two-thirds of voters felt that President Clinton was at least partially responsible for the strong state of the American economy and those people leaned towards the Gore camp.

Just under half of those questioned felt the president's scandals were important and they tilted heavily towards Mr Bush. Those who thought the scandals were very important backed Bush by six to one.

Both candidates were seen by voters as being good for education, an issue that has traditionally favoured the Democrats.

Voters who cared most about a candidate's honesty favoured Mr Bush and those who wanted a president with experience mostly sided with Mr Gore.

About one in four said reports that Mr Bush had been arrested in 1976 for drunken driving was important to their vote.

webTitle: Could it be Bush, Clinton, Bush, Clinton?

fields.headline: Could it be Bush, Clinton, Bush, Clinton?
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: As supporters of Hillary Clinton prepared for victory celebrations last night the question being whispered loudly among the American political classes was whether she would be seeking to return to the White House, this time as president in 2004.
fields.body:
As supporters of Hillary Clinton prepared for victory celebrations last night the question being whispered loudly among the American political classes was whether she would be seeking to return to the White House, this time as president in 2004.

When she was asked if her campaign to represent New York state was a prelude to a presidential race in four years' time, Ms Clinton denied it, laughed it off and then changed the subject.

But the speculation persists.

"I don't know if she'll run for president," said the veteran New York commentator John Hess. "The whole thing seems so preposterous I can hardly believe it. But then the two who ran this time are so preposterous - who would believe these two clowns would presume to be emperor of the free world?"

Sceptics who cannot believe that Ms Clinton would settle for a seat in the Senate say that her sights are clearly on bigger things. Dick Morris, who advised Bill Clinton in his successful 1996 campaign and who now spends much of his time as a Clinton baiter, said yesterday: "She runs for the Senate for only one reason: she wants to be president. From the beginning the subtext of the Clinton political operation was clear - she will follow him, just as the Kennedy brothers were to follow one another in order of seniority."

As the outcome of the presidential race still looked far from clear last night, there was even speculation that a Bush win this time could set the stage for an extraordinary Bush-Clinton-Bush-Clinton succession: George Bush Sr (1988-1992), Bill Clinton (1992-2000), George W Bush (2000-2004), Hillary Clinton (2004-).

For Mr Clinton, yesterday's events were bitter-sweet: as he exited stage left his wife looked set to enter stage right. He professed to be happy after casting his vote for his wife and Mr Gore. "I've had a great life and I've been very lucky," he said. He jested that he could not be dismissed as a lame-duck president until the formal handover of power in January. "I'll just keep quacking. I've got another 10 weeks to quack."

webTitle: Republicans forced to fight in the east

fields.headline: Republicans forced to fight in the east
fields.standfirst:
Florida proves tougher than expected
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Florida proves tougher than expected.
fields.body:
The Republican party leadership was last night scrambling to rally votes in the western states and the midwest after facing a much tougher fight than expected in the east.

Party officials at the Bush campaign headquarters in Austin said the battle was being fought one suburb at a time.

In one of the crucial swing states, Florida, a Democratic surge in the big urban areas along the east coast was answered by a last minute Republican push to mobilise traditionally more conservative voters in the Florida pan handle on the north-western corner of the state around the state capital of Tallahassee.

The panhandle is culturally much more a part of the deep south than the rest of Florida where much of the population has come from liberal industrial areas in the north-east to retire.

In key urban areas in the mid-west, the Republicans were relying on the National Rifle Association to counter the mobilising efforts of the pro- Democrat unions. The Bush camp was also putting its faith in absentee ballots in some of the key states, like Florida, Washington and Oregon, many of whom party official said would be cast by military personnel, traditionally sympathetic to the Republican cause.

The Republican party chairman, Jim Nicholson urged Republican voters to turn up in strength in western states, telling reporters: "It's not over 'til its over. "

Like speculators who had gambled everything on a single investment, Mr Bush and his backers assembled under torrential rain in Texas last night to discover if the most expensive campaign in US history had paid off.

Large-scale corporate contributors checked in alongside Republican heavyweights at the Four Seasons hotel in Austin where the Texas governor and his family awaited the early returns. At the centre of the action was Karl Rove, the Bush strategist, who predicted winning 320 of the 538 votes in the electoral college, which formally determines the presidency under the constitution.

"It's going to be a long night for the Gore campaign," he said, adding that his staff were watching Florida, Pennsylvania and West Virginia in the east for early indications of the result.

His confidence however belied a nervous mood in the plush party headquarters. The well-dressed staffers there were aware that they were on the brink of becoming the new US political elite, but some were actively discussing the possibility of winning the popular vote and narrowly losing the contest in the electoral college.

In that case, one said: "There should be pressure put on the delegates to reflect the national will."

All but two states - Maine and Nebraska - cast their votes in the electoral college on a winner-takes-all basis, but delegates have been known to defy the majority vote in their states and switch their vote.

Anticipating an agonisingly close finish, the Bush campaign set aside $80m for an effort in the last two weeks to mobilise its core supporters. Officials said 110m pamphlets had been posted and 62m phone calls had been made.

webTitle: Anchormen look for clues in late-night thriller

fields.headline: Anchormen look for clues in late-night thriller
fields.standfirst:
Stations chase viewers with guess work
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Comment, Gary Younge: Stations chase viewers with guess work
fields.body:
When news reached Washington DC on Monday that the Queen Mother had broken her collar bone the British press core feared the worst - that British royalty might finally wreak revenge on American democracy.

In the end David Dimbleby, James Naughtie, Jeremy Paxman and John Simpson were not to be disappointed. The Queen Mother was in relatively good health; the US elections were back on the top of the agenda. They were in the right place; the trouble is it was the wrong time. With America between five and nine hours behind, a race that would go down to the wire would leave them high on hypothesis and low on facts. So they spent the American afternoon talking to viewers in the late British evening about a result that most people on both sides of the Atlantic might not know until the early hours of the next morning.

So long as most Brits were awake they had nothing to say. But that did not stop them talking. They explained the workings of the electoral college; lectured on the fate of both Houses of Congress and evoked the ghosts of Nixon and Kennedy.

And then the guess work started. While most of California, the state with the largest number of electoral college votes, was still at lunch, John Simpson talked of early exit polls giving Gore an encouraging lead. Philippa Thomas in Austin started talking about the weather and ended up handing Florida and Michigan to Gore. Stephen Sackur said everything he knew had come with a health warning. Then went on to give Michigan, Florida and Pennsylvania to Gore and Tennessee and Arkansas to Bush.

It was the enduring formula for the evening. First they informed us that "it was too close to call". Then they called it. And then they reminded us to ignore everything they'd said.

Peter Snow, complete with an unfeasibly large graphics budget, was not to be outdone. He stood proudly in front of the equivalent of an electoral GameBoy as states flashed in red and blue behind him.

It had all the trappings of a thriller. The only problem was that neither the authors, the American public, nor the narrators in the news media had any idea whodunnit, why they had done it or what they had done. To help us understand we were introduced to several commentators not sufficiently important to be snapped up by American networks.

"We'll make of that what we can but it doesn't look like very much," said a characteristically pessimistic Paxman.

Then two states, Kentucky and Indiana - both safely in the Bush camp - declared that Bush had indeed won. The news added next to nothing to human knowledge but brought crucial colour to Snow's screen.

It was going to be a long night.

webTitle: CJD victim was 'devil for McDonald's'

fields.headline: Mother says CJD victim was 'devil for McDonald's'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: A 20-year-old woman who died from the human form of mad cow disease was a "devil for McDonald's" and ate Campbell's meatballs more than anyone else in her family, an inquest was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A 20-year-old woman who died from the human form of mad cow disease was a "devil for McDonald's" and ate Campbell's meatballs more than anyone else in her family, an inquest was told yesterday.

Kirsty Garven, a financial administration officer at Marks & Spencer, from Chester, died in July after showing symptoms of vCJD for a year.

The coroner at the inquest which looked into the deaths of three people from vCJD recorded a verdict of misadventure and said that the man and two women had died "unnatural deaths."

In the first inquest to be held since publication of the Phillips Report into the BSE crisis, Crewe coroner's court heard how Ms Garven, 20, Thomas Gemmel, 17, and Alison Thorpe, 25 - all residents of Cheshire - had died of the disease within two years of each other.

The first victim was Alison Thorpe from Macclesfield, who began showing symptoms of vCJD in 1997 but was not properly diagnosed until months before her death.

Doctors at Manchester Royal Infirmary believed she was suffering from anorexia. Her mother, Susan Hodge, eventually took her to see a specialist. She died at home in August, 1998.

Thomas Gemmel, from Northwich, was wrongly diagnosed with growing pains in May 1998, when he was 15. "He became very unstable and couldn't walk without two people holding him," his father, Robert Gemmel, told the inquest.

The inquest heard how Thomas, who died in February, had enjoyed a balanced diet of meat and vegetables.

But Kirsty Garven's mother said she was a "devil for McDonald's", and loved Campbell's meatballs more than anyone else in her family.

The 20-year-old showed symptoms of vCJD for a year before she died, the inquest heard. The first signs appeared during a holiday in Gran Canaria last year.

The coroner, Nicholas Rheinberg, said that all three had died "unnatural deaths" caused by vCJD from contaminated beef in the food chain.

Mrs Hodge complained that lack of health authority care had left the family to deal with her daughter's illness on their own.

Mr Rheinberg said the BSE enquiry had prompted the medical profession to implement a better system of care.

Kirsty Garven's mother, Jennifer, said: "We will never recover from this. Any family that has seen someone gradually deteriorate will never forget it."

Thomas Gemmel, from Northwich, was wrongly diagnosed with growing pains in May 1998, when he was 15. "He became very unstable and couldn't walk without two people holding him," his father, Robert Gemmel, told the inquest. The inquest heard how Thomas, who died in February, had enjoyed a balanced diet of meat and vegetables. But Kirsty Garven's mother said she was a "devil for McDonald's", and loved Campbell's meatballs more than anyone else in her family. The 20-year-old showed symptoms of vCJD for a year before she died, the inquest heard. The first signs appeared during a holiday in Gran Canaria last year. The coroner, Nicholas Rheinberg, said that all three had died "unnatural deaths" caused by vCJD from contaminated beef in the food chain. Mrs Hodge complained that lack of health authority care had left the family to deal with her daughter's illness on their own. Mr Rheinberg said the BSE enquiry had prompted the medical profession to implement a better system of care. Kirsty Garven's mother, Jennifer, said: "We will never recover from this. Any family that has seen someone gradually deteriorate will never forget it."

webTitle: Obituary: Ingrid, Queen Mother of Denmark

fields.headline: Ingrid, Queen Mother of Denmark
fields.standfirst: Much-loved Danish consort whose initiatives helped modernise the oldest royal family in Europe
fields.trailText: Queen Ingrid, the Queen Mother of Denmark, who has died aged 90, possessed a natural talent for one of the oddest jobs in the world. She helped modernise the royal family of her adopted homeland, the oldest royal house in Europe.
fields.body:
Queen Ingrid, the Queen Mother of Denmark, who has died aged 90, possessed a natural talent for one of the oddest jobs in the world. She helped modernise the royal family of her adopted homeland, the oldest royal house in Europe.

Queen Ingrid was the wife of King Frederik IX, ruler of Denmark from 1947 until 1972; the daughter of Crown Prince Gustaf VI Adolf of Sweden - who was that country's monarch from 1950 to 1973 - and Crown Princess Margaret, daughter of Queen Victoria's third son, the Duke of Connaught. The family she joined in the mid-1930s was stiff and unbending; the family she leaves provides Denmark with a monarchy supported by more than 90% of the population.

It was at the end of her husband's reign that a law on accession, approved in 1953 following a referendum, was enacted. It permitted women to take the throne of the king dom. Thus did Queen Ingrid's daughter, Queen Margrethe II, become the first female monarch of Denmark since Queen Margrethe I (1387-1412).

Ingrid herself was born at the royal castle in Stockholm. She grew up, with her four brothers, in a happy and, for the time, an open and relaxed family life. But in 1920, when she was 10, her beautiful, highly respected mother died. Observers suggested that Queen Ingrid's strong self-discipline was shaped by these young, rough years after that bereavement. In 1923, her father remarried, his bride being Britain's Lady Louise Mountbatten. The teenage Ingrid concentrated on her role as a dutiful royal daughter.

On May 24 1935, in Stockholm, she married her distant cousin, Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark. Two days later, they arrived in Copenhagen on the royal yacht Dannebrog.

Frederik was 11 years older than Ingrid. Unlike their Swedish counterparts, the Danish royal family lived at the royal castle as if it was a military barracks, without affection or charm. Everybody was afraid of the then monarch, King Christian X, who induced fear in his entourage; the exception was the new crown princess, whom he adored.

Slowly, Ingrid began to reinvent the Danish monarchy, but it was not easy. She mastered the difficult Danish language very quickly and established a coterie of friends and young relatives around herself and the crown prince. She redecorated the sombre palace and involved herself in charity work outside the castle. In April 1940, she gave birth to her first child, Princess (now Queen) Margrethe. In that month too, with the Danish armed forces facing the prospect of a blitz on the capital, the government accepted the reality of the Nazi occupation.

Ingrid - and indeed the entire royal family - took a remarkable position during the war, maintaining normality in an abnormal world. She rode her bicycle as usual, and pushed her pram around the streets of occupied Copenhagen. Part of an understanding with the Nazis was a hands-off policy towards Danish Jews. In 1943, as resistance mounted, the coalition government resigned and the Nazis began to detain Danish Jews. That October, as the result of a national effort more than 6,000 Danish Jews escaped to safety in Sweden.

In 1944, a second daughter, Princess Benedikte, was born. In 1946, a year before King Frederik's accession, the couple had their last child, Princess Anne-Marie, who, in 1964, married King Constantine of Greece.

It was by then clear that the new king and queen would never get a son. The result was the political initiative to change the law of succession, a move much due to the efforts of Queen Ingrid in her attempts to establish the Danish monarchy as a modern institution.

From her time as crown princess in the 1930s, through the death of her husband, the accession of her daughter - and in the years that followed - Queen Ingrid was the star of Danish royalty. Her daughter, Princess Benedikte, formulated the secret behind her mother's the outstanding success: "My mother finds that the thread to the past should not be cut, but it should neither keep us caught in the past."

It was in that spirit that Queen Ingrid democratised and renewed the court. She showed the Danes that the family in the palace may not have been ordinary, but that they were human. She also strongly supported her eldest daughter as she prepared for the daunting role of monarch. A woman with extraordinary willpower, judgment, flair and discipline, Ingrid kept a distance - yet retained her humour.

With that strong personality, no one could imagine her family getting stuck in the scandals and internal strife that afflicted other cousins and more distant European relatives. In 1997, she broke a hipbone and was confined to a wheelchair; in that year too, during the commemoration of her daughter's first 25 years as queen, she told Margrethe that, with her "two wonderful sons who would do their best for Dennmark", she could "safely close my eyes".

Queen Ingrid is survived by her three daughters, Queen Margrethe II, Princess Bene- dikte, Queen Anne-Marie of the Hellenes, 10 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.

 Ingrid, Queen Mother of Denmark (Ingrid Victoria Sofia Louise Margareta), born March 28 1910; died November 7 2000

webTitle: Obituary: Winston Grennan

fields.headline: Winston Grennan
fields.standfirst: Background musician with foreground players
fields.trailText: Winston Grennan, who has died of cancer aged 56, was one of Jamaica's outstanding drummers. He helped define rock steady, working on some of its biggest hits - including the Paragons' The Tide Is High, and Phyllis Dillon's Moonlight Lover - and was central to the emergence of reggae, playing on early Bob Marley and the Wailers' releases.
fields.body:
Winston Grennan, who has died of cancer aged 56, was one of Jamaica's outstanding drummers. He helped define rock steady, working on some of its biggest hits - including the Paragons' The Tide Is High, and Phyllis Dillon's Moonlight Lover - and was central to the emergence of reggae, playing on early Bob Marley and the Wailers' releases.

It was Grennan who can be seen behind Jimmy Cliff in the 1973 film, The Harder They Come. It was Grennan who provided the beat behind Max Romeo's Wet Dream. Later, he featured on Paul Simon's Mother And Child Reunion, and the Rolling Stones' Goat's Head Soup. He worked with Dizzy Gillespie, Marvin Gaye, the O'Jays and Aretha Franklin. He played on Cat Stevens' soundtrack for Harold And Maude (1971), and contributed a song to the soundtrack of Nine And A Half Weeks (1986).

Grennan developed for rock steady the one-drop rhythm that was marked by a prominent snare drum stroke on the third beat of every measure. It was this hard beat on the third, he explained, "that would cut the beat in half". His was a unique style, down to his placing of the cymbals behind, rather than in front of, his drum kit.

Grennan was born in Duckenfield, Jamaica. His father was a tailor and his mother worked in a general store. In the swing era of the 1930s and 1940s, six of his uncles played with the Scott Brothers, while another was trumpeter with Val Bennett's band. Grennan began drumming at junkanooos , or street carnivals, and accompanied street preachers on drums and percussion. His mother wanted him to be a doctor, and disputes about his career saw him ejected from the family home in 1959.

Moving to Kingston, he drummed in jazz groups with Trenton Spence, trumpeter Raymond Harper and trombonist Carl Masters. Low pay diverted him to Mexico, and a spell of professional boxing. Back in Jamaica, he briefly recorded vocals under the name of Winston Richards, toured with the comedy duo, Bim and Bam, and played piano in the Caribbeats backing band. At one performance, he replaced the absent drummer; he had no sticks, so cut them from a guava branch.

He recorded regularly with the Caribbeats and the Supersonics at Duke Reid's Treasure Isle studio. He tutored other drummers, including Lloyd "Tin Legs" Adams, Willie Stewart of Third World, Carlton Barrett of the Wailers, and Sly Dunbar.

When the Caribbeats disbanded, Grennan formed the Meditators, with saxophonist Roland Alphonso and bassist Vincent White, recording with keyboardist Jackie Mittoo at Studio One on early reggae material, such as Reggae In The Grass, a version of Hugh Masakela's Grazing In The Grass. He backed Desmond Dekker and the Melodians for producer Leslie Kong, and then drummed on hits by Judy Mowatt, Bob Andy and Marcia Griffiths for producer So nia Pottinger. Other work included the Rulers' Copasetic, for JJ Johnson, the Maytones' Funny Man, for Alvin Ranglin, and Derrick Morgan's Hold You. Other producers he worked with included Lee "Scratch" Perry, Clancy Eccles, Harry J, Derrick Harriott and Byron Lee.

It was in Sonny Bradshaw's band that Grennan backed Americans like Robin Kenyatta, Garland Jeffries, the Temptations, Dizzy Gillespie and Paul Simon, live in Jamaica. It was on Gillespie's suggestion that he moved to New Jersey in 1973, and began working for Gillespie, Kenyatta and Simon and the others. He toured Europe with jazz guitarist Eric Gale.

During the last decade, he fronted the Ska Rocks, releasing five albums. His move to America meant he was often overlooked in accounts of Jamaican music, but interviews he gave around the 1997 release of his Wash Over Gold changed the situation. By then, Grennan had developed what he called "Swegway", mixing ska, jazz and reggae.

Earlier this year, he moved to Nantucket, Massachusetts. He is survived by his wife, Ellie, and 11 children.

 Winston Grennan, musician, born September 16 1944; died October 27 2000

webTitle: Obituary: David Brower

fields.headline: David Brower
fields.standfirst: Environmental champion whose passion founded Friends of the Earth
fields.trailText: "We do not inherit the earth from our fathers, we are borrowing it from our children," proclaims a chiselled stone at the National Aquarium in Washington, ascribing the words to David Brower, the father of the modern conservation movement and its greatest, incorruptible crusader, who has died aged 88.
fields.body:
"We do not inherit the earth from our fathers, we are borrowing it from our children," proclaims a chiselled stone at the National Aquarium in Washington, ascribing the words to David Brower, the father of the modern conservation movement and its greatest, incorruptible crusader, who has died aged 88.

But it was typical of Brower's stormy trajectory that he later failed to recognise the sentiment as his own, putting down its appearance, in an interview, to being plied with a third Martini in a North Carolina bar by a journalist. By the end of his life, he took such a view to be uncharacteristically conservative: "We're not borrowing from our children, we're stealing from them - and it's not even considered to be a crime."

Twice nominated for a Nobel Peace Prize, Brower founded Friends of the Earth, after being ejected from the Sierra Club, an organisation which had originally been set up for hikers in America but which, under his leadership, became a powerful environmental group.

He kept dams out of the Grand Canyon; helped create the Redwood national park; pushed through the landmark Wilderness Act, which set aside millions of acres of US public land, establishing the concept of keeping the countryside pristine; and stopped oil and timber corporations having the run of Alaska. Throughout, he maintained his vision in the face of an American environmental movement increasingly drawn to the corridors of power through lobbying and politicking in Washington.

Brower was born in Berkeley, California, when there were no bridges to obstruct the view through San Francisco Bay to the Pacific, and the surrounding hills were untouched. His father was an academic, but his mother went blind when her son was seven. Helping her see, he recalled, sharpened his own appreciation of the natural surroundings.

After high school, he entered the University of California, Berkeley, in 1930 to study entomology, but left to become a mountaineer. He made 70 first ascents of the perpendicular granite rocks of Yosemite park, where he established 19 new routes, and scaled the 12,000ft-high mountains of California's Sierra Nevada. He was an instructor in the US 10th Mountain Division, and, during the second world war, served as a combat-intelligence officer in Italy, where he won the Bronze Medal.

When Brower joined the Sierra Club in 1933, it was an elite institution with just 2,000 members. He was elected to the board in 1942, and on returning from war service, edited the club magazine. In 1952, he became executive director, and built the club into a political force, raising its membership to 77,000 by the 1960s, and pioneering the use of films and journalism to put across the ecological argument. During his regime, politicians stopped and listened when the Sierra Club took a position.

But in 1963, Brower failed to save Glen Canyon, in his view "the most beautiful place on earth, no exception". It was a deep narrow ravine in the northern Arizona desert, with wondrously shaped rock walls, cascading waterfalls, bowers of ferns, quiet pools and Indian inscriptions. However, the club's board voted to support a compromise development plan, and it was dammed. Eventually, the rising waters of the river in the canyon's bottom obliterated its wonders for ever.

Renowned for his almost mystical ability to return to the fray after defeat (John McPhee's 1990 book on him was entitled Encounters With The Archdruid), Brower was spurred on by this reverse to more intense opposition to the construction of several proposed dams in the Grand Canyon. In 1966, the Sierra Club took out huge advertisements in major American newspapers asking people to save the canyon from being flooded "for profit". The next day, the US Internal Revenue Service revoked the club's tax exemptions, available only if it kept out of political activities. But this insensitivity boomeranged in headlines across the country. Brower recalled: "People who didn't know whether they loved the Grand Canyon sure knew whether or not they loved the IRS."

When Floyd Dominy, the government official in charge of dam-building, declared that the canyon "lakes" (reservoirs) created by the dams would enable people to see the walls better from boats, Brower ran an ad saying: "Should we also flood the Sistine Chapel so tourists can get nearer the ceiling?" Within 12 months, he and his supporters had won.

Yet only two years later, in 1969, Brower was out. The argument in the Sierra Club was ostensibly about a series of unsold coffee-table books he had commissioned as part of his strategy of showing off nature's wonders to encourage preservation. But central to the dispute was the club's accommodation of corporate interests, Brower having made enemies of members on immigration issues, and on notions, held by some, that came close to eugenics.

The same year, Brower formed the more radical Friends of the Earth (FoE), which incorporated opposition to nuclear weapons as a green issue - something the Sierrra Club had declined to embrace. A motto he never needed to go back on was his "think globally, act locally", coined for FoE. But by 1984, the organisation was in debt and the staff were rebelling. In 1986, when the board tried to move their headquarters to Washington, Brower resigned and went to work with the San Francisco-based Earth Island Institute, which he had formed in 1982. It has had major achievements in preserving wildlife, such as sea turtles and dolphins.

Last year, Brower withdrew at the last minute from the election to become president of the Sierra Club, and wrote a conciliatory letter about the need for unity. But he could not resist quoting Isaiah about the club and its corporate dealmakers: "Thou hast multiplied the nation, but not increased the joy."

It was the joy of an unspoilt world to which Brower devoted his long life. He leaves his wife, Anne, three sons and a daughter.

 David Ross Brower, environmental campaigner, born July 1 1912; died November 5 2000

webTitle: England look for winning formula

fields.headline: England look for winning formula
fields.standfirst: Today's match gives Hussain a final chance to tune his Test thoughts
fields.trailText: Today's match will give Nasser Hussain a final chance to tune his thoughts ahead of the first Test, writes Mike Selvey.
fields.body:
Suddenly the first Test is looming and England have only four more days in the middle to get things sorted before travelling down to Lahore on Sunday. And if Nasser Hussain ever needed to fit a quart into a pint pot, now is the time.

In the match against the North West Frontier Province Governor's XI starting here today the England captain needs to do the following: ensure that all seven of the batsmen who will almost certainly play next week are fit and in form; likewise all his key pace bowlers, at the same time giving both his spinners the chance to get valuable overs behind them in order to establish rhythm and confidence; and make sure Alec Stewart is not about to crack under the strain of the allegations that have surrounded him this past week.

Yesterday, sitting by the pool in the team's hotel here, Hussain was upbeat about Eng land's prospects while insisting that no inferences concerning next week's line-up could be drawn from today's selection.

He subsequently became a high-profile whistleblower for a while, offering evidence to all inquiries, specifically on Pakistan and Indian players but adding the unsubstantiated opinion that match-fixing was widespread internationally.

He had nothing further to say yesterday except that he had lost a career because of his stance and was now trying to rebuild it at 32. Helping him here are three others with Test experience in Wajahatullah Wasti, who made a century in each innings of his second Test, Mohammad Hussain, a left-arm spinner, and Kabir Khan, a fast-medium left-armer.

webTitle: Bengali Tigers roaring to go

fields.headline: Bengali Tigers roaring to go
fields.trailText: As Bangladesh step on to the Test stage, Paul Weaver reports on how the country's manic love of cricket should soon earn it credilibity on the pitch.
fields.body:
Cricket is giving off such a whiff of halitosis at the moment that the dear old game offends the olfactory senses. The pong of corruption is as pungent as all that tear gas in Rawalpindi recently.

But on Friday we get some air freshener: Bangladesh will play India in a one-off Test match in Dhaka, a sacred ceremony on the Ganges delta that will anoint the 10th full member of the International Cricket Council.

Bangladesh is more famous in Britain for its curries than its cricketers. In last year's World Cup match in Edinburgh they only just managed a narrow, white-knuckle win over Scotland, whose cricketers are an even softer touch than its footballers.

But this small country, which was not so much born as torn bloodily from the womb during the civil war in Pakistan almost three decades ago, is potty about cricket. And old worries that the relative short stature of Bengalis might hamper their cricket progress have already been ridiculed.

A nation of 125m people and 100,000 cricketers has been waiting for this moment since its creation, for its cricket traditions were already rich. Cricket has been popular around Dhaka since the abortive Sepoy rebellion against the British in 1857. And this former capital of East Pakistan was a Test venue in the 1950s and 1960s.

Since independence the cricket establishment has always recognised the country's enthusiasm, especially at a time when world Test-match attendances have been in decline. Only India can claim a more passionate following. When they won Test status in the summer they staged a five-day celebration party.

The rest of Asia has always been eager to embrace Bangladesh. So have Australia and South Africa, though England always seemed a little sniffy about the idea. The country who were bottom of the world rankings only last year should have clamoured for the inclusion of a team they could be certain of beating. For the time being, at least.

The concern that the currency of the Test game might be devalued is a noble one. But there is a stronger cricket culture in Bangledesh than there ever was in Zimbabwe, whose side have declined since they won Test status eight years ago. The potential in Bangladesh, where India's players arrived yesterday, is immeasurable, and this should outweigh the quality-control argument. Even league matches pack out the stadiums here.

The most vivid colours in last year's World Cup were, essentially, Asian. India provided the most memorable batting and Pakistan the fizziest bowling. But in Chelmsford, Dublin, Edinburgh, Chester-le-Street and Northampton the following for the Bangladesh side often took the breath away. And the eardrums.

We had whistles, drums, face paint, wildly waving flags and jumping Bengali Tigers from the Bangla Army. They danced the Soul Limbo during the interval in Chelmsford and swarmed over the ground after the win over Pakistan in Northampton, the upset of the tournament.

This was the Bengali Tigers' first victory over a Test country and only the fourth such win by an ICC associate member in the World Cup. Unfortunately Bangladesh's virgin soldiers have been dragged into the betting and match-fixing scandal before they have played a single Test.

That 62-run win over Pakistan, which helped them win their promotion, has been the subject of increasingly cynical speculation ever since, and some will claim that they are capable of winning only a fixed game.

Like Zimbabwe and Sri Lanka they will have to win a series before they are taken seriously. But the established cricket powers, England included, should cash in on the easy runs and wickets while they can. With this following, Bangladesh will not be soft touches for long.

webTitle: Leeds fan recovering in hospital

fields.headline: Leeds fan recovering in hospital
fields.body: A Leeds fan who suffered a pierced bladder during a brawl in Milan last night is today recovering in hospital and said to be stable. The 31-year-old, whose name has been withheld, was in the city ahead of tonight's crucial match against AC Milan in the Champions League where Leeds have to draw to be certain of progressing in the competition. The incident comes just seven months after Leeds fans Kevin Speight and Christopher Loftus were stabbed to death in Turkey before the club's Uefa Cup tie against Galatasaray. Peter Ridsdale, the club chairman said the incident left him feeling drained.

webTitle: Rangers lack the will to win in Europe

fields.headline: Rangers lack the will to win in Europe
fields.trailText: Rangers' heart-breaking exit from the Champions League this year can be attributed to various causes.
fields.body:
Rangers' heart-breaking exit from the Champions League this year can be attributed to various causes.

The club have suffered a horrendous injury crisis which, at times, has left manager Dick Advocaat with up to nine first-team players unavailable for selection at one time. Then there has been the rumoured unrest at Ibrox that led to Lorenzo Amoruso being stripped of the captaincy, followed swiftly by Advocaat's denial that the decision was forced on him by his own players.

And, of course, you can't account for the kind of howlers that Amoroso committed to provide Marco Simone with the equaliser last night.

Advocaat said after the game that he "needed a bit of luck" and then described his side's relegation to Uefa's second-string competition as "understandable", considering the tribulations that this season has brought.

What Gers supporters are finding less understandable is their feelings of déjà vu when the Champions League group stages are concluded each season. The club's greatest achievement in Europe is still the Cup Winners' Cup final victory over Dynamo Moscow in 1972. The Ibrox faithful are now in their 28th year of hurt and stories of injury crises, bad luck and "losing to the better side on the night" must be wearing a thin.

Advocaat brought an air of expectation to the club when he took over from Walter Smith in 1998. It wasn't that Smith was unpopular at Rangers - far from it - but many fans believed he lacked the tactical acumen to succeed in Europe. Advocaat's years at PSV Eindhoven, Twente Enschede and as Holland coach, supporters believed, had primed him for a European conquest.

But Advocaat seems to have lost his way at Glasgow. His decision-making is becoming increasingly erratic as the club has suffered setbacks in both domestic and European competitions. Last night he left Tugay Kerimoglu out of the starting eleven, a player who has had a calming influence over the Rangers' midfield in recent weeks. His gamble on Michael Mols appeared justified when the Dutchman scored but, as expected, he did not last the distance and Tugay replaced him after 55 minutes.

So Dick has not been so clever recently. But blaming him, or sacking him is not the long-term solution to the club's problem. Glasgow's footballing powerhouses - Rangers and Celtic - joining another league as soon as possible, however, is.

In August, David Murray said he was fully behind a proposed Atlantic League, which would involve Rangers and Celtic joining sides from Portugal, Holland, Belgium and Scandanavia in a Uefa-sanctioned alternative to domestic competitions.

The hope was to start such a competition in 2003, but that is looking increasingly unlikely as other European sides have delayed backing the project. They are not in as serious a situation as Rangers.

By simply substituting their league and FA Cup for this Atlantic League will not be enough. They need to play in a regular league against top quality sides. The argument still exists for a British league. Last weekend's fixtures in the English and Scottish leagues prove the point.

Rangers prepared for last night's game against Monaco, who have a strong European pedigree, by hammering St Mirren, who do not, 7-1 in the Scottish Premier League. The result was a welcome one for the Blues, and particularly for Kenny Miller who scored five, but the game was a world away from the challenge they faced last night.

Leeds United, on the other hand, faced Liverpool at the weekend ahead of tonight's clash with AC Milan. Regardless of the drama of the game itself, the fact is that Liverpool, despite their own struggles at the very top level in recent seasons, remain a far more intimidating opposition than St Mirren.

As players have been telling us for quite a few seasons now, there are no easy games in the Premiership. David O'Leary, a strong believer in that philosophy, can sympathise with Advocaat's injury-list tales of woe. Should Leeds get knocked out of the Champions League tonight, he is likely to conclude, as Advocaat did, that such a result is "understandable".

Yet Leeds' performances in their first Champions League season have impressed more than the Scottish side's, chiefly because of the resolve they have displayed against unquestionably superior sides such as Milan and Barcelona, particularly with most of the first team resting up in the treatment room.

This can be attributed to their rigorous Premiership schedule. While many still argue that the demands of the league can fatigue players and indeed be the cause of injury lists such as O'Leary's, those that do play are regularly involved in matches that require immense stamina, both mental and physical.

It is true that Amoroso's defensive aberration last night pales into insignificance against those of Gary Neville last season, who seemed to be compiling a collection for his own video on sale this Christmas - but the Premiership's top teams now appear to have acquired the endurance that these tough European games demand.

It seems Rangers' perennial departure from the Champions League comes complete with a string of mumbled excuses and forlorn wishes of what might have been these days. After 43 years without a European trophy, they almost seem to accept their fate in Europe without a fuss.

It is unlikely that Sir Alex Ferguson will be as "understanding" as Advocaat if Manchester United crash out of the competition tonight.

Dick Advocaat and his troops have got to learn to be more uncompromising if they are to succeed at this level. That will come by playing sides that are led by men as uncompromising as Alex Ferguson.

webTitle: Indian bookie 'made 70 calls in a day' to Jadeja

fields.headline: Indian bookie 'made 70 calls in a day' to Jadeja
fields.trailText: An Indian newspaper has published records that reveal heavy mobile phone traffic between a bookamker and former Test batsman Ajay Jadeja.
fields.body:
An Indian newspaper has published records of heavy mobile phone traffic allegedly between a bookmaker and Ajay Jadeja, the former Test batsman suspended by the Indian cricket board after he was named in the Central Bureau of Investigation report on match-fixing last week.

India's Telegraph gave details of what it claimed were calls made to and from Jadeja by Ramesh Gupta, one of several illegal bookmakers named in the report, during New Zealand's tour to India last year.

The paper says that on November 13, the day before New Zealand beat India in Guwahati to level the one-day series at 2-2, Gupta (also known as Uttamchand) made 48 calls to Jadeja's mobile phone.

Then, the day before India clinched the series by winning in New Delhi on November 17, the bookmaker made 55 calls to Jadeja. He did not play but on match day was in the dressing room with his team-mates and received 31 calls.

The paper, which also published what it said were Jadeja's and Gupta's mobile phone numbers, said the bulk of the calls - generally to Jadeja rather than by him - were made on the eve of matches.

Gupta has been linked to his namesake Mukesh, another Indian bookmaker who told the CBI he had offered money to several Indian and foreign players, including the former England captain Alec Stewart.

According to the records, Gupta made 70 calls to Jadeja on the day before the series' second one-day international, in Hyderabad on November 8, following that with 33 calls on match day. On October 28, a day before the third Test in Ahmedabad, Gupta made 24 calls to Jadeja. On the first day of the match the cricketer received 13 calls, then 62 on the second day and 30 on the third.

Jadeja has told Indian match investigators that Gupta is a "fan" and a "well-wisher" and that there is nothing suspicious about his links with him.

Meanwhile, Brian Lara opened the West Indies tour of Australia with a run-a-ball century after what he described as a "tough week" in which he figured in the CBI report. Lara, who has denied the allegations of the bookmaker MK Gupta that he was paid £26,000 to underperform, flayed the Australian Board Chairman's XI attack in the traditional curtain-raiser at Lilac Hill, near Perth, as he and Sherwin Campbell (111) took the tourists to 276 for two from their 50 overs before the match was rained off.

webTitle: Fourth time lucky for Atwood in Booker prize

fields.headline: Fourth time lucky for Atwood in Booker prize
fields.standfirst:
Canadian was bookies' favourite but beat off strong competition for £21,000 award

Booker Prize 2000
fields.trailText: Margaret Atwood's bad luck as a veteran "handmaid" of the Booker prize - three times nominated but never receiving the garland - changed triumphantly last night when she was declared this year's winner.
fields.body:
Margaret Atwood's bad luck as a veteran "handmaid" of the Booker prize - three times nominated but never receiving the garland - changed triumphantly last night when she was declared this year's winner.

The Canadian writer's novel The Blind Assassin beat stories by former prizewinner, the Japanese-born British author Kazuo Ishiguro, and books by four other authors. In one of the tightest contests in recent years, Atwood, 60, won £21,000 and a probable fortune in extra sales.

Atwood's spiritual detective story about love, betrayal and violence in a Toronto industrial and political dynasty was the bookmakers' favourite at 9-4. But it came under heavy pressure from the 11-4 second favourite, Ishiguro's elegy of loss and displacement, When We Were Orphans.

Atwood, a multiple award winner elsewhere in the world, was Booker-shortlisted for The Handmaid's Tale (1986), Cat's Eye (1989) and Alias Grace (1996). She has written more than 30 books of fiction, poetry and critical essays and lives in Toronto.

While this year's chairman of the judges, Simon Jenkins, stressed in advance that the Booker is not a "lifetime achievement" award, last night's decision for Atwood will be seen as having an element of that.

Other eminent or famous novelists whose new books failed even to reach this year's shortlist include Muriel Spark, Doris Lessing, JG Ballard, Julian Barnes, Fay Weldon, AS Byatt, Michael Ondaatje and Zadie Smith, whose novel White Teeth was shortlisted for the Orange Prize.

All six shortlisted novels carry the clearest hallmarks of millennial literary fashion in novel writing. Most strikingly, all are largely interior monologues. Only Matthew Kneale's The English Passengers comes near to telling a straightforward chronological story - and this is set out in 20 monologues or documents. The other five deploy flashbacks and almost constant time lapses.

Four use detective story devices to unravel the sources of a trauma or acts of violence. Two of the three north American novels, Atwood's The Blind Assassin and Michael Collins's The Keepers of Truth, throw up a still more striking coincidence. In each, the central figure is the grandchild of a dominating businessman whose successors have presided over the de-industrialisation of their cities and the advent of a consumerist fast-food civilisation which is haunted by its own emptiness.

The prize has been called the equivalent for a novelist of winning the national lottery. The 1989 winner, Ishiguro's The Remains of the Day, sold more than 1m copies and was turned into a successful Merchant-Ivory film. Last year's winner, JM Coetzee's Disgrace, is claimed by the prize organisers to have sold 150,000 copies in paperback.

Small effect
But this year the claimed "Booker effect" - the boost supposedly given to sales as the contest warms up - has been slight. Iziguro's sales, 8,408 when the shortlist was disclosed last month, had by last night risen to just 9,360 copies.

In mid-October combined sales for Trezza Azzopardi's The Hiding Place, Brian O'Doherty's The Deposition of Father McGreevy and Collins totalled a mere 553. Last night their combined total was only up to 2,560; sales of Collins's The Keepers of Truth - picked by three out of four Observer critics on Sunday as the novel that deserved to win - had risen from 184 to a paltry 370.

Kneale's place on the shortlist pushed his sales up by just over 400 copies. The exception was Atwood, who gained 6,180 on her October figure of 1,069, mainly because her book was new in the shops.

Judges, headed by the journalist Simon Jenkins, were Roy Foster, professor of Irish history at Oxford, historical fiction author Rose Tremain, the Sunday Times literary editor Caroline Gascoigne, and television presenter Mariella Frostrup.

An extract from The Blind Assassin

Ten days after the war ended, my sister Laura drove a car off a bridge. The bridge was being repaired: she went right through the Danger sign. The car fell a hundred feet into the ravine, smashing through the treetops feathery with new leaves, then burst into flames and rolled down into the shallow creek at the bottom.

Chunks of the bridge fell on top of it. Nothing much was left of her but charred smithereens.

I was informed of the accident by a policeman: the car was mine, and they'd traced the licence. His tone was respectful: no doubt he recognized Richard's name. He said the tires may have caught on a streetcar track or the brakes may have failed, but he also felt bound to inform me that two witnesses - a retired lawyer and a bank teller, dependable people - had claimed to have seen the whole thing. They'd said Laura had turned the car sharply and deliberately, and had plunged off the bridge with no more fuss than stepping off a curb. They'd noticed her hands on the wheel because of the white gloves she'd been wearing.

It wasn't the brakes, I thought. She had her reasons. Not that they were ever the same as anybody else's reasons. She was completely ruthless in that way.

"I suppose you want someone to identify her," I said. "I'll come down as soon as I can." I could hear the calmness of my own voice, as if from a distance. In reality I could barely get the words out; my mouth was numb, my entire face was rigid with pain. I felt as if I'd been to the dentist. I was furious with Laura for what she'd done, but also with the policeman for implying that she'd done it. A hot wind was blowing around my head, the strands of my hair lifting and swirling in it, like ink spilled in water.

"I'm afraid there will be an inquest, Mrs. Griffen," he said.

"Naturally," I said. "But it was an accident. My sister was never a good driver."

webTitle: Atwood wins Booker prize

fields.headline: Atwood wins Booker prize
fields.standfirst: Booker Prize 2000
fields.trailText: The Canadian novelist Margaret Atwood last night emerged victorious from a closely fought battle for this year's Booker prize.
fields.body:
The Canadian novelist Margaret Atwood last night emerged victorious from a closely fought battle for this year's Booker prize.

Atwood won the £21,000 prize for her tenth novel, The Blind Assassin, beating five other shortlisted authors.

This year's competition was regarded as unprecedented because there was initially no clear favourite.

The prize administrator, Martyn Goff, said: "In 30 years, there hasn't previously been a time when I have felt unable to forecast a winner. This year any of the six could win."

A total of 120 books were submitted for consideration in April. After six months the panel announced a shortlist which included three little-known authors, one of them a first novelist.

Announcing the winner at a ceremony at London's Guildhall last night, Simon Jenkins, chairman of the judges, said: "The Blind Assassin is a complex book that works on many different levels. Far reaching, dramatic and structurally superb, it demonstrates Atwood's immense emotional range, as well as her poet's eye for both telling detail and psychological truth.

"The book demonstrates the mature pessimism of age and does so brilliantly."

Ms Atwood said in a brief speech of thanks at the awards ceremony: "This is not just about one book. Somewhere out there is an unknown writer who will write the next Booker prize winner."

The novel features the elderly Iris Chase Griffen reviewing her life and, in particular, her relationship with her sister Laura, whose premature death in the 1940s affords her iconic status as the author of a scandalous novel.

webTitle: World will be watching Tayside derby

fields.headline: World will be watching Tayside derby
fields.trailText: Dundee's short trip to Dundee United's Tannadice on Saturday will be seen by millions of viewers in South America and Australasia, and it's all down to Claudio Caniggia.
fields.body:
The Tayside derby will be seen by millions of viewers in South America and Australasia this weekend.

Dundee's short trip to Dundee United's Tannadice on Saturday is to be broadcast live by ESPN to Australia and New Zealand, and will be shown later in South America and the West Indies.

The arrival of the Argentine Claudio Caniggia at Dens Park has sparked the worldwide interest. Dundee sold 1,300 of their 5,000 allocated tickets within three hours of them going on sale.

Scotland players have a £400,000 incentive to reach the World Cup finals. The Scottish Football Association has agreed to split that sum among the squad if they qualify for Japan and Korea in 2002. Added to that is a £300 match fee plus £300 for every point won during qualification.

The Celtic midfielder Paul Lambert will be out of action until the new year after picking up a knock in the 1-0 win at Kilmarnock on Sunday.

webTitle: United poised to offer Carr a new direction

fields.headline: United poised to offer Carr a new direction
fields.trailText: Man Utd are set to offer Steve Carr the chance to swap the trials of life at Tottenham for a new career at Old Trafford.
fields.body:
Manchester United are set to offer Steve Carr the chance to swap the trials of life at Tottenham for a new career at Old Trafford.

Sir Alex Ferguson, the United manager, is monitoring Carr's situation at White Hart Lane and it is understood United have already made inquiries with the player's representatives. Carr has been increasingly disillusioned with Tottenham's perceived lack of ambition and what he claims is an unwillingness to reward his impressive form with a more lucrative contract.

The Republic of Ireland international, regarded as the finest right-back in the Premiership, will meet the Spurs director of football David Pleat today for what Carr describes as "make-or-break talks" and unless his demands are met it seems certain he will be seeking new employers.

Middlesbrough sank further into trouble yesterday when their £7m training complex was flooded. Half a dozen pitches were under water after the Tees burst its banks, leaving only the gym intact.

Bolton's defender Mark Fish will return to the Premiership after agreeing to join Charlton for about £850,000.

The 26-year-old South African international will join Alan Curbishley's squad subject to a work permit being granted. Fish has been refusing to sign an improved contract offer since September.

Bolton's manager Sam Allardyce said: "It is disappointing but Mark Fish's recent performances have shown everyone he doesn't want to be here. The situation meant I had to act and I did that by moving him on as quickly as I could."

The United States international goalkeeper Brad Friedel has completed his move to Blackburn Rovers after being given a free transfer by Liverpool. He had not played for Liverpool since October last year and was forced to leave Anfield after failing to play enough games to earn a new work permit.

George Weah, the former world footballer of the year who left Manchester City under a cloud last month, is to take over as captain at his new club Marseille. He will replace Patrick Blondeau as captain with the French First Division club who, unlike City, are in the relegation zone.

Nicolas Anelka is unhappy with life again. The French striker's new club Paris Saint-Germain have suffered back-to-back defeats and the eternal malcontent has called for a complete overhaul of their midfield.

"I think it's time to react because we are going to end up losing everything," said Anelka on his website. "When you look at it, our problem midfield is not new. We don't have a playmaker and with only one defensive midfielder in Pete [Luccin], it's impossible."

webTitle: Leader: The drugs tsar has jumped to conclusions

fields.headline: Through the wrong gate
fields.standfirst:
The drugs tsar has jumped to conclusions

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Yesterday, the drug tsar became an overt politician. Drawing himself up to his full former chief constable's height, Keith Hellawell told a press conference assembled for his second annual report that he was now convinced that cannabis was "a gateway drug".
fields.body:
Beware of shroud wavers. Be doubly wary when the issue involved is the highly controversial - and complex - issue of drug control. Yesterday, the drug tsar became an overt politician. Drawing himself up to his full former chief constable's height, Keith Hellawell told a press conference assembled for his second annual report that he was now convinced that cannabis was "a gateway drug". He said he had always been reluctant to use the term. But he was now convinced by a new study of drug-taking habits in New Zealand. It concluded, he claimed, that young people who smoked a joint once a week were 60 times more likely to progress to harder drugs. He went on: "The pro-legalisers who have said that cannabis isn't a gateway drug will have to look at this hard and long."

To be fair to the tsar, the new study is not one of those snapshot surveys showing that a large majority of hard drug users had earlier used cannabis. These prove nothing, but are regularly misin terpreted by commentators who fail to draw a distinction between an association and a causal relation. Such surveys cannot prove causality. They ignore the huge proportion of cannabis users who never take up hard drugs. The new study is "longitudinal" in the jargon, following young people from birth to the age of 21. It has been carried out by well-respected social scientists. It is full of caveats as well as extremely esoteric statistical analysis. It does not state what the tsar implied: that if you use cannabis you will invariably progress to regular addictive hard drugs. It emphasises "harder" not "hard" drugs. The long list includes prescription drugs and magic mushrooms. Hard drugs, including heroin and cocaine, accounted for mere 4%. Even then, it was not suggesting this was an addictive move, but merely an initial taste. Mo Mowlam, the drugs minister, was right to be more sceptical. But then she, unlike the tsar, is a social scientist and more ready to resist Tony Blair's hard line.

They ignore the huge proportion of cannabis users who never take up hard drugs. The new study is "longitudinal" in the jargon, following young people from birth to the age of 21. It has been carried out by well-respected social scientists. It is full of caveats as well as extremely esoteric statistical analysis. It does not state what the tsar implied: that if you use cannabis you will invariably progress to regular addictive hard drugs. It emphasises "harder" not "hard" drugs. The long list includes prescription drugs and magic mushrooms. Hard drugs, including heroin and cocaine, accounted for mere 4%. Even then, it was not suggesting this was an addictive move, but merely an initial taste. Mo Mowlam, the drugs minister, was right to be more sceptical. But then she, unlike the tsar, is a social scientist and more ready to resist Tony Blair's hard line.

webTitle: Leader: Austria should ditch Haider

fields.headline: No place for Mr Haider
fields.standfirst:
Austria would do better to ditch him
Special report: the Austrian far right in power
fields.trailText: It is bad form to kick a man when he is down but an exception may be made for Jörg Haider.
fields.body:
It is bad form to kick a man when he is down but an exception may be made for Jörg Haider. The Carinthian casuist was at his poisonous worst at a recent rally, declaring that Austria has no need of "any artificially induced multicultural society" and warning that Vienna could become "a city of immigrants". A year after elections that brought his far-right Freedom party to power, this dangerous, dissembling booby and his slab-sided cronies have proved to be an even bigger embarrassment than predicted.

Mr Haider's poll success provoked a bitter breach with the EU and Israel and the quarantining of Wolfgang Schüssel's coalition. Despite last September's unwise decision to lift the sanctions unconditionally, an extraordinary stand-off persists with blood-brother Germany. In Berlin, Chancellor Gerhard Schröder pursues a personal boycott. In Paris, President Jacques Chirac still smarts over Mr Haider's repeated comparisons of him with Napoleon. In Vienna, meanwhile, no fewer than three of the six Freedom party ministers have resigned or been sacked and another, the justice minister who was formerly Mr Haider's lawyer, may be next in the firing line. The party is up to its neck in a scandal over alleged illegal purloining of confidential police files on rival politicians, reporters, artists and academics. The pixilated Mr Haider claims this is all a plot to get him, that documents have been "manipulated", and that the allegations emanate from "the sick minds of a few journalists". But Vienna's state prosecutor has taken a more level-headed view, opening an inquiry that may lead to criminal charges. Mr Haider's bodyguard is among those helping police with their inquiries. Piling on the misery, the Haiderite vote in recent elections in Styria tumbled to 12.7%, against 27% nationally last year. Some say, without irony, that this is because the Freedom party in government has forsaken its "principles". More likely it is because it is now seen as untrustworthy and damaging to Austria.

Whether Robin Cook was wise to visit Vienna last month while these people still help run the country is an open question. But the foreign secretary was correct in saying that Austria occupies a pivotal place in an enlarging, democratic Europe. The sooner it washes its hands of Mr Haider the better. He is overdue for a comeuppance and down on his luck: an opportune moment for Mr Schüssel and all fair-minded people to put the boot in.

webTitle: Hillary set for victory

fields.headline: Hillary set for victory
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton was heading for a historic victory in her battle to capture one of New York's two Senate seats early today. Exit polls put her eight points clear of her opponent, the Republican congressman Rick Lazio.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton was heading for a historic victory in her battle to capture one of New York's two Senate seats early today. Exit polls put her eight points clear of her opponent, the Republican congressman Rick Lazio.

If she succeeds, the 53-year-old first lady will be the first wife of a sitting president to win elected office.

Mr Lazio was seen as the underdog in the race, but Mrs Clinton had to fight off a series of highly personalised attacks.

The race was one of the costliest Senate campaigns in history, with the candidates spending $78m (£54m) by the middle of last month.

webTitle: Wheen's world

fields.headline: Jack takes a liberty too far
fields.standfirst: Francis Wheen on: MI5's Operation Fat Bloke * How asterisks speak louder than words.
fields.trailText: Francis Wheen on: MI5's Operation Fat Bloke * How asterisks speak louder than words.
fields.body:
On being told that President Coolidge had died, Dorothy Parker asked: "How could they tell?" The same can be said of next week's fuel protest. Just suppose that militant farmers and hauliers do succeed in "disrupting" the country: how will anyone notice the difference? Thanks to Railtrack and the rain gods, much of the nation is already at a standstill anyway. Yet Jack Straw has now accused the fuel-tax campaigners of "threatening the lives of others and trying to put the whole of our economy and society at risk".

There is a case to be made for keeping petrol taxes high. But why embellish it with hyperbole and palpable fibs? Tony Blair was at it again last weekend, claiming that any reduction in fuel duty would mean cuts in schools 'n' hospitals. Does he think that people are too dim to notice Gordon's bulging budget surplus? Besides, what price the chancellor's famous "prudence" if he can fund public services only by taxing all motorists - rich and poor, the countess and her cleaner - at a rate of 72 pence in the pound?

Honest Jack Straw is no better. "Peaceful protest is an important right in any functioning democracy," he told the Commons last week. "However, the behaviour of some protesters [in September] did create a climate in which the managers and the drivers themselves judged that it was unsafe to allow normal operations to continue . . . I am placing in the library of the House a detailed log of 180 incidents of intimidation recorded by the oil companies." When Ann Widdecombe asked how many people had been arrested during this crime wave, Straw was forced to come clean: "I think it was about two."

To Labour MPs, of course, the lack of prosecutions does not exonerate the pickets but proves that they were in cahoots with the police. Sounding remarkably like Sir Bufton Tufton, Dale Campbell-Savours declared that disruptive protests - whether by peace campaigners, environmentalists or anyone else - must never be tolerated. "There would be chaos. It is a matter now of who runs Britain." (This echoes the question put by Ted Heath in February 1974, during another period of chaos: "Who governs Britain?" To which the voters replied: "Clearly not you, matey.")

Bridget Prentice MP was even more bellicose, demanding an assurance that "the courts will take the full panoply of the criminal law into account when anyone disrupts our civilised society".

Dennis Skinner, with his customary irony, has contrasted the police's "touchy-feely and sensitive" behaviour two months ago with their brutal conduct towards pickets in the miners' strike. But the irony's on him. If, as he implies, the government is entitled to unleash a blitzkrieg against demonstrators of whom it happens to disapprove - "fat blokes", in Steve Bell's contemptuous shorthand - then the pass has been sold. These liberals and lefties will be in no position to complain when similar tactics are used against people who are protesting against the construction of a new bypass or the export of live veal calves.

In a magazine article four years ago, the former chief constable, John Alderson, warned that British policing had been "poisoned" by methods first used in Northern Ireland and the miners' strike of 1984-8. The dangerous blurring of the distinction between terrorism and civil disobedience was exemplified by the murky role of MI5 and Special Branch in Margaret Thatcher's war against the National Union of Mineworkers.

Lo and behold, the cloak-and-dagger mob is up to its old tricks again - but this time without a murmur of protest from civil libertarians. An apparently well-sourced story in the Observer has revealed that after the September blockade Straw ordered "one of the biggest undercover operations against non-terrorist targets in Britain for 20 years. Every local police force's Special Branch began to gather intelligence on the leaders of the protests . . . Dossiers were compiled of activists' police records, finances and political views. Many were put under 'soft' surveillance". Meanwhile, undercover operatives from MI5 began infiltrating the pressure groups and exploiting "divisions within the activists".

Straw was asked about his spooks' antics last week. "There are," he replied sternly, "no circumstances in which a home secretary will tell the House which actions of particular groups are being investigated . . . I have ensured that all the law enforcement agencies properly observe the strictly laid-down requirements of the law, and I shall continue to do so."

In the absence of further details, I turn to an official booklet issued by MI5 earlier this year. In a section headed "Myths and Misunderstandings", it flatly denies that the security service ever infiltrated or investigated pressure groups such as the NUM or CND. Its only political targets have been "subversives" who intend to overthrow democracy by violent means, but "the subversive threat to parliamentary democracy in the UK is now negligible and the service accordingly has no current investigations in this area".

So how does MI5 justify its surveillance of the fat blokes? A clue can be found in the booklet's preface, written by Straw, which summarises the service's duties thus: "Countering the threats of terrorism and espionage which endanger our society, and the spread of weapons of mass destruction, which presents a global threat. More recently the service's skills have been harnessed in support of the law enforcement agencies in tackling serious crime."

Since even Straw doesn't pretend that Welsh farmers and Essex lorry drivers are secretly building nuclear weapons, we must assume that they are instead engaged in "serious crime". But we must also assume that his diligent sleuths have found no evidence of it: if they had, it would have been pre-emptively leaked without delay to discredit the protest.

As it is, the best that government spin doctors can manage is a non-attributable allegation that some of the ringleaders run "million-pound haulage companies". At the same time, however, Alastair Campbell and press officers at the Department of Trade and Industry have encouraged friendly journalists to investigate the "business background" of the dairy farmer David Handley, chairman of the People's Fuel Lobby. Because of BSE and falling milk prices, Handley is almost £50,000 in debt and has a number of county court judgments against him.

Shock, horror! The Daily Mirror promptly denounced Handley as a "dangerous fool". So he may be; but, er, doesn't his financial plight rather contradict the suggestion that fuel-tax campaigners are all bloated plutocrats? If Downing Street has to resort to character assassination in the hope of making our flesh creep, it might at least try to synchronise its smears.

How asterisks speak louder than words.

Is it a surrealist manifesto? Is it a postmodernist joke? No, it's the annual report of parliament's intelligence and security committee (ISC), published last Thursday.

According to Jack Straw, the ISC's "detailed and careful work" keeps MI5 and MI6 under "effective external scrutiny". Here's an example: "We believe that the UK needs to be *** to ensure that the UK remains ***." There follow nine detailed and careful paragraphs, each of which consists of three asterisks and nothing else, after which the committee concludes: "We believe the UK cannot afford not to be involved in this work." An interview with the head of MI5 is equally revealing: "The director general of the security service confirmed that next year was going to be difficult. He had ***, ***, ***." Mumps, measles and rubella?

Turning to intelligence failures in the Kosovo campaign, the ISC pulls no punches: "GCHQ did comment that ***, ***, ***. The committee is concerned that ***, ***. The foreign secretary stated that '***'." Wise words, Cookie.

Tom King, the absurd chairman of this preposterous committee, was asked if the blizzard of asterisks suggest that the secret state is becoming even more secretive. Not at all, he replied cheerfully: it just goes to show how much more information we are being given.

Readers who find the Booker short list a bit tame should buy a copy of his comic masterpiece without delay, at the bargain price of £8.95 (about 1p per asterisk). Why not get a few extra for your friends? It's the year's most original Christmas present - and a guaranteed hangover cure.

webTitle: RMC cuts jobs to halt slide

fields.headline: RMC cuts jobs to halt slide
fields.trailText: RMC, the cement and aggregates group, is cutting 1,000 jobs, it said yesterday, as the firm struggles to reverse its fall in profits and share price.
fields.body:
RMC, the cement and aggregates group, is cutting 1,000 jobs, it said yesterday, as the firm struggles to reverse its fall in profits and share price.

The group, which is on the point of concluding the sale of its Great Mills do-it-yourself chain, also said that it was running ahead of its target of reducing costs by £40m a year. It now expects to save £50m a year, and to eliminate losses by January next year.

RMC has seen its share price slide by a third, following the fall in profits last year and its £896m takeover of cement maker Rugby Group in January this year. The market has also been worried about the time taken to find a buyer for Great Mills which was put up for sale in July.

The RMC board, which is hoping to get at least £300m for Great Mills, said yesterday that negotiations with a potential purchaser of the retail business were far advanced.

Sources close to the talks expect a deal to be struck within days. Duke Street Capital, the venture capital firm, is widely thought to be the buyer.

Job losses will be spread around the world. About 180 jobs will go in Britain, including some at the group's international head office.

Its German operations will bear the brunt, with the loss of 400 jobs. The group said that most of those affected had al ready gone. The group is planning a one-off charge of £60m this year to cover the redundancy and other rationalisation costs needed to deliver the £50m a year savings. The savings figure does not include £30m a year benefits from the integration of the Rugby operations.

The board said the review had already led to a streamlined and simplified management structure. The closures of its ready mixed cement businesses in Indonesia and Ytong, its lightweight concrete operation in Florida, were under way and should be completed by the year end.

The group, which aims to concentrate on heavy building materials, is planning to sell non-core activities. Analysts estimate that these further disposals will raise about £50m. In addition the group is expected to raise further funds through an accelerated property disposal programme.

RMC also intends to sell the US joinery business it acquired when it took over Rugby, though the board stressed that it would only be sold when "an appropriate value" was achieved.

The board said that the group's strong international positions in heavy building materials offered "the best opportunity to deliver improving returns to shareholders".

RMC shares, which were worth 872p a year ago before the slide set in, yesterday closed 18p higher at 610p.

webTitle: New £100m stadium unveiled by Arsenal

fields.headline: New £100m stadium unveiled by Arsenal
fields.trailText: Arsenal yesterday unveiled plans for their new stadium and announced that the old ground will be turned into an upmarket housing estate.
fields.body:
Arsenal yesterday unveiled plans for their new stadium and announced that the old ground will be turned into an upmarket housing estate.

The new stadium at Ashburton Grove, Islington, north London is less than 500 yards from the existing Highbury stadium and will be a four-tier complex with museum, shops, restaurant, bars and a hotel.

Meanwhile Highbury will not be entirely demolished. The ground's famous marble hall entrance will remain intact and act as the entrance for a luxury-flat complex formed from the listed east and west stands. Two new housing developments incorporating flats and mews housing, together with light industrial units, will replace the existing north and south stands, and the notoriously narrow pitch will become a landscape garden and children's playground.

Planning applications for the new stadium and redevelopment of the old one were yesterday lodged with the London Borough of Islington, the area's local authority.

The new stadium, which will cost £100m and have a capacity of 60,000, has been designed by the architects HOK Sport, who are also behind Sydney's Olympic stadium and the new Wembley stadium.

Arsenal, who were founded in south London in 1886, hope to get the go-ahead for construction by next spring and aim to make 2004-05 their first season at the new stadium.

The club are unlikely to face opposition to developing the site as it has been derelict for almost 20 years. Islington council has already indicated that it is prepared to recommend compulsory purchase of any property necessary.

The club director Ken Friar said: "The new stadium will be a stunning addition to the area and will provide a landmark building of which everyone can be proud."
