webTitle: Keegan to sue over gambling claim

fields.headline: Keegan to sue over gambling claim
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan is to take legal action against the News of the World over allegations that he played a central role in gambling with his players.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan last night instructed his solicitors to begin legal proceedings against the News of the World after it alleged that as England coach he had taken a central role in gambling with his players.

Keegan, who has maintained a studious silence since his resignation as coach after last month's defeat by Germany, is seeking a full retraction and apology for the article, which appeared under the headline "Keegan's £40,000 bet shame".

Peter Carter-Ruck and partners, Keegan's legal advisers, said: "Mr Keegan utterly refutes the allegations and is determined to take whatever action may be necessary to defend his reputation.

"A letter has been sent to the News of the World by Peter Carter-Ruck and partners today in advance of legal action against the newspaper."

Hayley Barlow, a spokeswoman for the newspaper, said: "The News of the World report into Kevin Keegan's gambling activities with members of the England football squad resulted from a thorough investigation. The News of the World is satisfied with its facts and stands by its story."

If the matter goes to court it is conceivable that Keegan will call England players to give evidence for him.

Earlier in the day the Football Association's chief executive Adam Crozier tried to draw a line under the public dismantling of Keegan's methods.

webTitle: Norwich 1 - 0 Birmingham

fields.headline: Forbes' riches too much for Birmingham
fields.trailText: Captain David Holdsworth was sent off as Birmingham dropped further behind in the race for automatic promotion.
fields.body:
A rare goal by Norwich City's midfielder Adrian Forbes left Birmingham City lagging further behind in the race for one of the First Division's automatic promotion places.

To compound a miserable night for Trevor Francis's team the captain David Holdsworth was sent off for violent conduct 10 minutes from time after he elbowed the Norwich substitute Adrian Coote.

For Norwich, Forbes's first goal in more than a year and only his second ever at Carrow Road maintains Bryan Hamilton's side's recent improvement.

Yet although they have lost only one of their last six games, Norwich have continued to look shaky at home. The £6m sale of Craig Bellamy to Coventry followed by the departure of Tony Cottee to Barnet has not helped. Cottee's exit to cut his managerial teeth at Underhill has resulted in Hamilton using the midfielder Lee Marshall as a makeshift striker alongside Iwan Roberts.

All of which did not augur well, especially as Norwich were up against opponents not noted for defensive charity on their travels. But they wasted little time in putting the visitors' defensive solidity to the test. Only two minutes had gone when the midfielder Scott Parker bypassed the Blues centre backs but was denied by a timely challenge from Michael Johnson.

With the Birmingham keeper Ian Bennett opting to punch everything, a legacy perhaps of his blunder that cost his side victory against Bolton on Saturday, the visitors' defence lacked its normal assurance. There was also a lack of confidence at the other end as Blues, harried and hustled by the hosts' purposeful midfielders, presented little threat to Andy Marshall's goal.

Norwich finally scored the goal their first-half enterprise had threatened in stoppage- time when Forbes, seemingly presenting little danger on the right of the City penalty area, volleyed a loose ball across Bennett and into the roof of his net.

Francis preferred the more muscular attributes of Geoff Horsfield to the lightweight skills of Mark Burchill in the second half, sending on his record signing to unsettle the home defence.

Despite the change it was Norwich who came closer to scoring when Holdsworth miscued a defensive header 10 minutes after the interval. It fell to Roberts who, one on one with Bennett, fired wastefully wide. At the other end the Birmingham strikers continued to labour, with Michael Johnson coming closest when he tested Andy Marshall with a fierce left-foot drive.

webTitle: Pass notes

fields.headline: Pass notes
fields.standfirst: No: 1757 Charles Darwin
fields.trailText: No: 1757 Charles Darwin
fields.body:
Age: A fossil, basically.

Mesozoic? Victorian, actually: 1809-82.

Occupation: Naturalist.

Pioneering nudist? Do you own a dictionary?

Appearance: Old bloke with a beard.

Perfect. Put him on a banknote. The Bank of England has done just that. He is to adorn the new forgery-proof £10 note.

Forgery-proof? Maybe not totally, but it comes with all manner of holograms to make life tricky for counterfeiters.

Who has Darwin replaced? Charles Dickens.

Wasn't he another bloke with a beard? Wispier.

The Bank of England seems rather keen on blokes with beards. They resent that slur. "You do not have to be a hirsute male to appear on a banknote," says a spokeswoman. "Is the Queen a hirsute male?"

So apart from reigning monarchs, who does get to appear on banknotes? Brits who have made a "lifetime's contribution" to the arts or sciences.

Why did Dickens get the chop? Balance. The composer Edward Elgar replaced electrical engineer Michael Faraday on the £20 note last year, and the science lobby had to be placated.

Hard times for writers? They're all of a twist.

So what did Darwin do to get on a tenner? A feckless medical student and trainee vicar, he was shipped off at 22 on a five-year voyage to South America on board the Beagle. There he discovered his vocation as scientist and, eureka, the theory of evolution by natural selection. Wrote Origin of Species and The Descent of Man, exploding creationism and producing the Victorian crisis of faith.

That (plus the beard) is enough to get him on a banknote? Well, he has a greater claim than Sir John Houblon, who graces the £50.

Sir John is . . . ? A banker.

And who gets to choose the note-ables? The ruling court of the Bank of England.

What a lot of bankers. Quite.

webTitle: Shakhtar Donetsk 3 - 0 Arsenal

fields.headline: Timid Gunners are caught cold
fields.standfirst: Atelkin 35, Vorobei 57, Bielik 66
fields.trailText: Arsenal left everyone in little doubt that they would rather have stayed in London as they produced a spineless, if meaningless, display to end their Group B campaign.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger had admitted his players were less than keen to make this journey and that much was plain to see last night. Outfought and outplayed this was a spineless, if meaningless, end to Arsenal's Group B campaign.

They go into Friday's second-phase draw in any event and, to the delight of the locals, Shakhtar Donetsk will continue their European adventure in the Uefa Cup. The Ukranian side played with a real verve so sorely lacking from Arsenal that the crowd must have wondered whether Wenger had been joking when he said he would give them a shot or two of vodka to help them through the cold.

With the temperature freezing, the wind blowing and top spot in the group guaranteed, Arsenal could doubtless think of a few places they would rather have been than in south-east Ukraine. Watching reruns of Derby against West Ham in an igloo might even have been among them.

Wenger's players, five of whom wore gloves and most of whom must have wished for longjohns, at least had an incentive to run hard in order to keep warm. And the fact that this modern, exposed stadium was full to its 32,000 capacity provided a lively atmosphere for a visiting side stronger than many had expected.

Shakhtar Donetsk, of course, had every reason to go for a win. They knew they would qualify for the Uefa Cup if they matched or bettered whatever result Sparta Prague managed at home to Lazio - the Czechs in fact lost 1-0. The key for them was not being caught out by the pace of Thierry Henry and Sylvain Wiltord, with Nwankwo Kanu lurking behind that front pair.

Shakhtar began positively and enjoyed the majority of possession, though without initially threatening to break an Arsenal defence which featured Matthew Upson at its centre and Stuart Taylor making only his second first-team appearance in goal.

When Taylor was called on for the first time, after almost 20 minutes, he showed no sign of nerves. The 19-year-old has trained with the full England squad at Kevin Keegan's invitation and plunged impressively to his left to push wide a shot by Dainius Gleveckas after the impressive Alexei Bakharev had crossed from the right.

Although Wiltord sent one effort over the bar from near the edge of the area shortly afterwards and had another ruled out for offside after being set up again by Henry, they were rare Arsenal counter-attacks of substance, and Gleveckas's chance seemed to galvanise a determined, skilful Shakhtar side.

It was no great surprise when they made the breakthrough in the 35th minute. Anatoliy Tymoshchuk's long ball caught out Martin Keown and left Sergei Atelkin bearing down on goal to finish via the post.

Keown, scorer of two vital late goals in the win against Shakhtar at Highbury, had joked before the game that the locals think he is a centre-forward. Their suspicions must have been confirmed by this error, and the wild celebrations were almost disbelieving after a 3-0 defeat here by Lazio and only a narrow win over Sparta Prague. Mexican waves were soon under way.

The 50 or so Arsenal fans who had made the 3,500-mile round-trip must have hoped for better in the second half. Wenger's players did begin with a little more purpose but the midfield was clearly lacking the drive of Patrick Vieira, who was left in England, with Nelson Vivas an unconvincing and out-of-place stand-in.

A clear chance did arrive not long after the interval, when a neat step-over by Ashley Cole allowed Lauren space on the left-hand side of the area. But his shot lacked the power to test Yuri Virt.

Instead it was Taylor who was soon picking the ball out of his net at the other end. Vivas conceded a free-kick just outside his penalty area in the 57th minute and the highly rated Ukraine striker Andriy Vorobei curled his shot over the wall and into the right corner.

Having scored that one, Vorobei set up the third, crossing from the right for the substitute to Olexiy Bielik to volley in as Keown failed to intercept. For Arsenal the flight home could not come fast enough.

Shakhtar Donetsk (4-4-2): Virt; Starostyak, Okoronkwo, Popov, Gleveckas; Zubov, Tymoshchuk, Bakharev, Abramov (Aliuta, 78); Atelkin (Bielik, 52min), Vorobei (Savu, 86).

Arsenal (4-4-2): Taylor; Dixon, Keown, Upson, Cole; Parlour (Vernazza, 72), Kanu, Vivas, Lauren; Wiltord, Henry (Ljungberg, 62) .

Referee: K Fisker (Denmark).

webTitle: Ferguson aims to extend home run

fields.headline: Ferguson aims to extend home run
fields.trailText: Alex Ferguson is confident that his players' fine home form this season will bring the victory that will take them through to the second round tonight.
fields.body:
Manchester United's chances of reaching the next round of the Champions League tonight will depend on their resisting the temptation to play chicken with Kiev. Old Trafford would prefer a cakewalk to a cliffhanger.

The situation is simplicity itself. United have to defeat Dynamo Kiev to go through and the Ukrainians need to beat Sir Alex Ferguson's team to finish third in Group G and enter the Uefa Cup. In that event United would be level on points with Dynamo but behind them on head-to-heads, having drawn 0-0 in Kiev.

A draw would send Anderlecht and PSV Eindhoven, who lead United by two points and meet in the Netherlands tonight, into the second group stage. United would be sure of a Uefa Cup place but that would be poor consolation.

Having been drawn in what appeared to be one of the easier groups United would not be in this position but for defeats away to PSV and Anderlecht. Now Ferguson is putting his faith in his side's home form and the present preponderance of home victories in the Champions League.

"Our performances at home have given me confidence that the players can handle it tomorrow," the United manager said yesterday. "On these occasions you've got to trust them and they haven't let themselves or me down very often."

With Roy Keane fit after a hamstring injury and David Beckham and Ryan Giggs in awesome form Manchester United should triumph this evening, with Teddy Sheringham their most likely match-winner. Yet Ferguson still has problems in defence, with Ronny Johnsen kept out by an ankle problem and Jaap Stam recovering from an achilles operation, and in midfield he will be without the suspended Paul Scholes.

Scholes it was who three weeks ago swiftly repaired the damage with an outstanding goal after United, having outplayed PSV at Old Trafford, found themselves being held to 1-1 with little more than a quarter of an hour remaining. Nicky Butt will be a sound replacement alongside Keane but only if he has recovered from a foot injury.

Kiev, quick on the break with a lot of pace on the flanks, are likely to test Phil Neville and Denis Irwin, Ferguson's most likely choices at full-back. They are not the force they were before Andrei Shevchenko and Sergei Rebrov joined Milan and Tottenham respectively but their coach, Valery Lobanovsky, will not have given up the notion of achieving a surprise tonight despite his gloomy observation that "even steel engines get tired, let alone human beings".

Ferguson, however, remains chipper about his team's chances. "They've been fantastically consistent over a number of years," he stressed, "and this game will hold no fears for them."

Manchester United (probable): Barthez; P Neville, Brown, G Neville, Irwin; Beckham, Keane, Butt, Giggs; Cole, Sheringham.

Dynamo Kiev (probable): Shovkovsky; Bodnar, Holovko, Vashchyuk, Dmitrulin; Khatskevich, Kaladze, Belkevich, Nesmachny; Shatskikh, Demetradze.

Referee : C Colombo (France).

webTitle: High street banks scramble for advice

fields.headline: High street banks scramble for advice
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A scramble to appoint new investment banking advisers is expected this week as Abbey National and Bank of Scotland try to resume negotiations about a potential marriage.
fields.body:
A scramble to appoint new investment banking advisers is expected this week as Abbey National and Bank of Scotland try to resume negotiations about a potential marriage.

Their so far ill-fated attempts to agree terms under which they might merge continued to prompt speculation last night that Barclays, Lloyds TSB and even National Australia Bank might be prepared to wade into the contest.

City sources believe that Barclays might appoint Goldman Sachs to offer advice on any potential bid, while Lloyds TSB could turn to JP Morgan. National Australia Bank is said to be using Lazard and Merrill Lynch. None of the banks would comment. CSFB is advising BoS while Warburg and Lehman are advising Abbey National.

Speculation about the future ownership structure of the high street banks mounted last night after Bank of Scotland said its chairman, Sir John Shaw, had received a phone call from Lord Tugendhat, the chairman of Abbey National, about a possible meeting.

BoS said last night: "Sir John will be writing tomorrow in response (to the phone call).

"Any exchanges between ourselves and Abbey will be conducted directly and not in the media".

Abbey said: "Both sides have been in touch today and will be progressing on this."

webTitle: Opera review: Guildhall Opera

fields.headline: British premiere for Massenet
fields.standfirst:
Guildhall opera
Guildhall School of Music and Drama, London
****
fields.trailText:
Guildhall opera
Guildhall School of Music and Drama, London
****
fields.body:
It's typical of the enterprise of the Guildhall School's opera department that its latest production, a triple bill, should include a British premiere and a work that has rarely, if ever, been seen on stage before.

Debussy's "lyric scene" L'Enfant Prodigue - a fascinating score that reveals both where his music came from and where it was heading - wasn't intended for the opera house at all: it was the piece that won the composer the Prix de Rome in 1884, while he was studying with Massenet. Here though it is staged, with a good deal of conviction, alongside two of his teacher's one-acters.

Massenet's Le Portrait de Manon was designed in 1894 as a sequel to his most famous opera, and has never been seen in Britain before. The plot is thin and contrived: the now mature Des Grieux continues to hark back remorsefully to his affair with Manon, and the tragedy of her death, until he manages to exorcise her memory thanks to his nephew Jean and the woman he wants to marry, Aurore, who reminds Des Grieux inescapably of Manon. If it's an excuse for a trawl through some of the famous themes of the earlier opera, it does so pleasantly and undemandingly enough.

La Navarraise, though, could hardly be more different. It was Massenet's shot at doing verismo, composed in 1901 in the wake of the success of Mascagni's Cavalleria Rusticana, and he shows that he can do it just as lustily and loudly as any of his Italian contemporaries.

Further performances tonight and Friday. Box office: 020-7628 2571.

webTitle: Salaries for new lawyers

fields.headline: So much, so young
fields.standfirst:
Salaries for new lawyers have gone into overdrive, catapulting some graduates from student poverty to £60,000 a year. But how do they handle the shock of sudden wealth? And can any of them really be worth it?

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Salaries for new lawyers have gone into overdrive, catapulting some graduates from student poverty to £60,000 a year. But how do they handle the shock of sudden wealth? And can any of them really be worth it?
fields.body:
Anyone who has ever read or watched The Firm - or indeed any other John Grisham blockbuster - will know only too well that top American law firms routinely offer their fresh, straight-out-of-law-school new recruits company BMWs, stratospheric bonuses and fat-cat salaries. Alas, anyone who has ever read John Grisham thoroughly will also know that such absurdly glittering packages come with a high price tag: often the ritual sacrifice of one's evenings, morals, personal relationships and blood pressure.

We may like to think it couldn't happen here - not on the same scale, anyway - but now it has. Last week came the news that two of London's top law firms are to offer their newly-qualified recruits a starting salary of £42,000 - probably enough to make many feel decidedly nauseous. It certainly isn't bad for a first pay cheque - and in fact Allen & Overy and Linklaters, the two solicitors' firms in question, know only too well that even this sum might not be enough to lure the most talented new legal brains to their doors.

Increasingly, salaries of £50,000, even £60,000 and above are needed: not bad for a new recruit with little experience of law beyond the correct use of Tipp-Ex and how to carry a box of files from one office to another. Hyperinflation is the order of the day: graduate salaries have been rising at the rate of 30% for the past three years. The reason: stiff competition from aggressive American firms such as Dewey Ballantine and Sullivan & Cromwell.

Take Adam Ross, a freshly-minted lawyer with a US company based in London, who earns, as he puts it, "in excess of 50k, plus bonus". He says: "I must admit, the money was a big factor in my choosing to go with an American firm. One minute I was scrabbling around as a trainee with student loans to pay off and growing credit card debts. Overnight, I've been able to go out and buy a home cinema system, an MP3 mini-jukebox and I'm looking at buying an Audi. This may sound shallow, but having money for the first time does make me feel good about myself, and I can't see that ever wearing off."

But does he enjoy the work? "To be honest, a lot of it is just drudge work and, yes, the hours and the personalities in my office can both be tough. It's tempting to go and get completely trashed after work. Among my peers, drugs are usual, too. When I watched This Life, I thought all that stuff with the lines of coke was an exaggeration. But it's really not."

Sadly for the envious and less well- paid, money really can buy happiness, says Professor Andrew Oswald, a psychologist at Warwick University who has studied the links between bank balances and emotions. "There's no question. In my studies across Europe, money does appear to make people happier," he says. But that is only half the story. "In the workplace, money is a more complex issue. Merely being well-paid does not guarantee happiness. Long commutes, difficult bosses and overcrowded offices cancel out the effect of financial incentives . . . The happiest group of all workers, regardless of salary, are the self-employed."

The ratcheting up of competition for new graduates means top firms are driven to greater and greater lengths to woo their prey. James Norton-Jones, currently being sponsored through his law conversion degree by City firm Herbert Smith, says the situation at Oxford has become absurd. "There's such one-upmanship among firms - not just law firms but merchant banks and IT firms, too - to host the most lavish receptions. The Randolph Hotel used to be the top spot; now that seems dull. Cocktails at Freuds is seen as the most desirable place now. I was rung up out of the blue by a bank asking if I'd be interested in a job. Never in my life had I expressed an interest in banking - they targeted me because I was captain of the college boat club. If you run anything at all, they want to see you."

But they had started on Norton-Jones long before Oxford. "I first made contact with Herbert Smith when they came to our school [Winchester]. I always knew I was going to be a lawyer but I wanted to go with a firm that offered a decent starting package. They are also paying my fees and giving me £5,000 living allowance."

Many of the highest paid new graduates certainly work for their salaries. And being paid so well, Adam Ross says, imposes an added burden. "It's about supply and demand - that's why we're being paid funny money. They know they have to do that to get us. But my God, we do earn it. I don't mind - there's plenty of time to party later."

Law firms are unwilling to comment on their salary policies, but the hyperinflation shows no signs of slowing. "There is currently a big shortage of lawyers," says Gill Jones of legal recruitment consultants Taylor Root, who monitor salaries in the profession. "Firms have become more mobile, which means they are losing staff to the US, Europe and Asia. And during the last recession, loads of people were made redundant, so we're still trying to catch up with the shortfall. The salary levels might seem high, but I think pound per pound, lawyers work much harder than merchant bankers or management consultants. There's no guarantee that they will eventually make it to being a partner, and the stress in these City law firms is phenomenal."

Generous pay packets are used to justify a climate in which "people going into law are expected to put their lives on hold," Jones says. "Many firms are short-staffed. You are expected to work round-the-clock, evenings and weekends, and, although firms are now being forced to be more supportive of new recruits, if you get put in with an arrogant, difficult boss, your life can be made a misery. I frequently see young people cracking up under the stress."

It may take an effort to summon much sympathy for the £60k brigade - but a Law Society study last week supports Jones's argument, showing that one in five trainee solicitors claims to have been bullied.

It's not just law. Absurdly high starting pay has long been the norm in information technology, management consultancy and banking. Andersen Consulting recently announced a package of £10,000 "golden hellos", on top of more than adequate salaries, to attract new staff.

Richard Halkett was lured into a management training programme by Lloyds-TSB. "They rang me while I was still a student, I think because I was president of my college," he says. His starting salary was in the high 20s - nothing in comparison with those offered by many law firms, but still far above average for the sector, and it was supplemented by a four-figure, interest-free loan.

But Halkett soon found that, despite the luxury of going from student loan to decent pay cheque, he wasn't happy. "It wasn't for me. I couldn't get my head around having to achieve things in the nine-to-five time frame when I'd been used to writing essays when I felt like it," he says. "After six months I left and am now running a dot.com start-up for academics." He has seen many of his contemporaries seduced by fat starter salaries and thinks many of them are making a big mistake. "When you leave university, your needs aren't that great. You don't have expensive tastes, you usually don't have dependants, why do you need all that money? There's plenty of time to do that later."

In any case, can any newly-qualified recruit really be worth £100,000, or even £50,000? "No, of course not," Gill Jones says, with refreshing candour. "But the market dictates these levels and that's where we're at at the moment. If you're looking at law, the hours these people work are horrendous. If you totalled up the hours put in by someone who's earning under £70,000, maybe qualified for three years, you'd find they weren't earning significantly more than their PA."

webTitle: Art review: Dexter Dalwood

fields.headline: Dexter Dalwood
fields.standfirst:
Gagosian Gallery, London
*
fields.trailText:
Gagosian Gallery, London
*
fields.body:
Painters today, by and large, are whores in a marketplace characterised by ignorance. They are complicit in the marginalisation of their art because they appear only too eager to supply some- thing with just the right mix of irony, retro chic and figurative familiarity to look good in a collector's beach house in Malibu.

Dalwood paints rooms he imagines would suit celebrities from Bill Gates to Mikhail Gorbachev. The paintings are in knowing bad taste. Here is Kurt Cobain's Greenhouse, where the Nirvana star shot himself. Let's buy that for the boardroom, it'll define us as a young company. Or what about the drained concrete pit from which we look up at an English country house in Brian Jones' Swimming Pool? Rock'n'roll suicides, cult deaths, Waco before the FBI attack, all imagined with consummate banality.

Dalwood's earlier pictures were small, and some of them at least gave the illusion of being made with sincerity. Now his paintings are big, but lack the presence to go with their size. They are flimsy, sad things. The walls could have been more authoritatively hung with posters.

So why has Dalwood got a show at the London branch of the prestigious art dealer Gagosian? Dalwood was nobody until he was taken up by Charles Saatchi and promoted as one of Saatchi's so-called New Neurotic Realists. Now Dalwood has this big commercial show. Wow. No one can doubt Saatchi's influence on contemporary art.

A painter like Dalwood is just what the art market needs. He has a bit of attitude, but not too much. His paintings are not going to break anyone's brain, but they make the people who buy them feel clever and sophisticated. Some people say painting is back. If this is what they mean by painting, I hope it goes away again soon.

Until November 18. Details: 020-7292 8222.

webTitle: Pop review: Petit Vodo

fields.headline: Petit Vodo
fields.body:
One-man bands are normally associated with bygone eras or buskers - the ability to play guitar while clattering cymbals attached to your knees is a little-appreciated art form - but no one has told Petit Vodo. So with an harmonica wrapped around his neck, guitar under one arm, drumsticks in both hands, he's merrily creating havoc with tradition.

Vodo, a guise adopted by Bordeaux native Sebastien Chevalier, has the soul of a Delta blues man and the dexterity of a 20-strong brass band. So it's surprising that the diminutive figure lugging instruments on stage is the genius in question. Slight doesn't describe the 5ft nothing musician, whose only concession to making the transition from roadie to star is to don orange-tinted glasses and a hat with flaps.

"I am French," he proclaims, a sample of a moaning woman set to cut-beats and backward loops behind him. "I wanna play my blues, I wanna play my rock'n'roll." And rock he does. Vodo obviously has a penchant for Bo Diddley and he's just as enamoured with Jon Spencer - his loudspeaker-sounding vocals and screams of pent-up delight the most obvious affectations - and the Kinks.

Big Like That sees him at his most versatile, playing heavy guitar riffs with one hand, keeping the beat going with drum and cymbal combo with the other. Then there's the harmonica, evoking the power of Bob Dylan, fired by a passion of his own as his left leg frantically keeps time.

After releasing the album 69 Stereo Vox, his capacity to astonish and entertain has just seen him complete a five-date tour of Britain and tonight he works through any remaining demons. It's an exhilarating, if tiring, ride - the intensely controlled performance outweighing the showmanship.

Originally a drummer who combines Beck tendencies with lecturing in art, Vodo appears to be indulging in an avant-garde musical statement, while still playing a good tune. Drumming on the microphones surrounding him, using a drumstick to play slide guitar and masterfully tapping and blowing into a steel kettle, he's a man possessed.

The kettle is integral to Spam Cow, a lo-fi epic as discordant trumpet meets looped humming sounds, Vodo coiling himself around an old-fashioned microphone, standing on a speaker to reach it. He cackles and yells demonically, his voice throaty and sleazy. We're left not just admiring the talent but caught up in his vision.

webTitle: Sir Eddie warns that tax cuts would bring higher interest rates

fields.headline: Sir Eddie warns that tax cuts would bring higher interest rates
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sir Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, delivered a strong warning yesterday that over-generous tax cuts or further big increases in public spending in today's pre-Budget report would trigger higher interest rates.
fields.body:
Sir Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, delivered a strong warning yesterday that over-generous tax cuts or further big increases in public spending in today's pre-Budget report would trigger higher interest rates.

Rejecting calls from exporters for specific measures to reduce the value of the pound, Sir Eddie said that the economy was running at almost full capacity and a further tightening in monetary policy could not be ruled out.

He added that inflation would start to rise unless there was a slowdown in the rate of private sector demand growth to prevent a further deteriora tion in the trade balance and accommodate "the public sector expenditure growth which the chancellor has already announced, not to mention whatever he may be planning to announce tomorrow".

Speaking to the CBI annual conference in Birmingham, Sir Eddie said: "There are signs that this slowdown in private sector demand growth may be beginning to happen, but that is certainly not assured - and over-generous tax cuts would not help.

"I must tell you that I am surprised by the billions of pounds that some commentators have suggested the chancellor could safely give away."

Sir Eddie said Britain's long period of economic expansion could continue provided there was low and stable inflation, fiscal prudence and supply-side flexibility.

However, he added that he was aware that many business leaders - struggling with the impact of the strong pound - would conclude that he was "living on a different planet".

Beneath the surface of the encouraging macroeconomic data, there was a serious imbalance between those parts of Britain doing very well - including services and hi-tech manufacturing - and those parts facing the toughest conditions that they could remember.

He said globalisation was one reason for the disparity between sectors, but added that the strength of the pound had also been a key factor. "There is no doubt that some of these effects have been aggravated by exaggerated changes in foreign exchange rates - including the progressive weakening of the euro," he said.

"That is a particular problem for the UK because of the relatively large proportion of our economy exposed to competition from the eurozone.

"Even as a central banker I can understand why many euro-exposed businesses feel hard done by."

webTitle: Buzz words

fields.headline: Buzz words
fields.standfirst:
On the appeal of adrenalin.

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: On the appeal of adrenalin.
fields.body:
Once upon a time, it was only metal that could be stressed out. Now, it seems as if most workers are feeling the strain. Survey after survey shows that a growing proportion of the workforce is feeling "stressed".

Stress is described by some as a "21st-century plague"; by others as weak-minded nonsense fuelled by a self-serving community of therapists and counsellors. Stress is in danger of becoming one of those words - along with empowerment and creativity - that is made worthless through distortion and overuse.

It is certainly the case that each survey on stress seems to outdo the last - but this may not indicate a real rise. The trouble with surveys is that they influence each other. People get surveyed on how they feel about something, the results are plastered across the papers, then another set of people who have read the articles are surveyed on the same subject. Surveyitis sets in.

In the case of stress, it is now so well-known that anyone who is anyone is stressed, that any one of us will tell the clipboard-wielding pollster that, yes, we are, too. Once stress became a precondition of having an important job, the number of people reporting it shot up.

So there is no "stress epidemic" in Britain's workplace - but there are stressful jobs. Being a casualty doctor, or police officer, or rape counsellor are all "stressful" jobs - in the real sense of being hugely demanding and requiring serious support. Many low-skilled service sector jobs are also in the stressed camp, but for different reasons. At least docs and cops have power. It has long been established in the psychological literature that lack of power or control causes mental distress at work. The boss may be the one who claims to be stressed, but the real victims are likely to be thetelesales operatives.

Publilius, the Roman slave turned entertainer, said: "The height of misery is to depend on another man's will." This is never more true than when the man in question is a rude customer. If you want this kind of stress, forget advertising or banking: try McDonald's, in any city centre, at midnight on a Saturday.

Of course the people whose mental health is really hit by work are those who are out of it. Unemployment is where the highest price is paid. As a trade unionist once said: "The trouble with unemployment is you never get a day off."

These examples of real stress are lost in the tidal wave of the stuff reported to be sweeping across offices everywhere. What does it mean for a young doctor to say he or she is stressed, when marketing executives who have to work late on a presentation place themselves in the same category?

Some of these office workers may simply hate their jobs and dub the problem stress. People who love their jobs use the term in a different way, or refuse the label altogether. As one participant in a Channel 4 programme, The Joy of Stress, put it: "It is hard work, but it's a buzz." Most people want activity. Hate your job? It's stressful. Love your job? It's a buzz.

There are plenty of us who deliberately put ourselves under pressure, knowing that we excel when the adrenalin is in full flood, knowing that pressure wins prizes. The writer James Thurber, after having 20 stories rejected by the New Yorker, was asked by his wife one afternoon in 1927 if he wasn't "ruining those stories by spending so much time on them" and advised to set an alarm clock to ring in 45 minutes and finish it in that time. Thurber did just that, sent off his piece - and received a $40 cheque.

Eggs over squeezy

Just in case you are suffering from a nasty bout of hurry sickness, or time famine, an idea from flametree.co.uk, the work/life website. If you are one of those people who puts on a tie or your make-up during the journey to work, there is a product just for you. Breakaway Foods, a US firm, is now marketing food in a toothpaste-style tube. Think of the time you waste using cutlery or waiting for someone to cook! Simply squeeze away! Top of the paste taste list is . . . scrambled eggs and sausage.

 Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society. Contact him at rreeves@indsoc.co.uk.

webTitle: Art review:  Conor McFeely

fields.headline: Conor McFeely
fields.standfirst:
Mappin Art Gallery, Sheffield
****
fields.trailText:
Mappin Art Gallery, Sheffield
****
fields.body:
It just shows what you can do with next to nothing. Conor McFeely's Ink Mathematics is an installation of torn paper and tube lights that, at first sight, look as if they've been scattered around the gallery walls and floors willy-nilly. Believe it or not, it's a great achievement to make an exhibition look as if it has just been dumped there.

Such seemingly arbitrary composition is actually the result of painstaking artifice. You can tell because it gives you the creeps. It looks odd, awkward, something other than art as you know it. Maybe it's not art at all, but, like the innovative sculptural scrapwork of Joseph Beuys, a form of affective magic.

But, unlike Beuys's eco-shamanism, McFeely's perverse brand of hocus-pocus appears to be up to no good. The brief statement on the gallery wall claims that the work "explores the related subjects of fire and arson... the state of arousal sparked by them".

McFeely's materials are perspex, thermoplastic, ultraviolet, black lights, bundles of firelighters and rolls of paper treated with invisible ink. The light is not the light of this world. It bleaches everything out, turns everything negative.

The scrappiness and sparseness of the assembled objects give extraordinary, evocative significance to the occasional fragments of anonymous texts. Next to a photocopied image of a moonlit doorway and amid a pile of screwed-up paper embedded in spills of dried plaster, we read: "I am made out of water. You wouldn't know it, because I have it bound in... Not only do we have to walk around without being absorbed by the ground but we also have to earn our livings."

So what is McFeely up to? Is he some kind of displaced anarchist-electrician? A 21st-century electro-alchemist? Common sense is slipping away, serendipitous signs are everywhere and the ordinary world is ready to explode. McFeely's just an artist, but he's a good one.

Until January 7. Details: 0114-278 2600.

webTitle: World music review: Yat-Kha

fields.headline: Throat singers of the wild frontier
fields.standfirst:
Yat-Kha/ Sainkho Namtchylak
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
****/**
fields.trailText:
Yat-Kha/ Sainkho Namtchylak

Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
****/**
fields.body:
Way out on the borders of Siberia and Western Mongolia there's an area of mountains, steppes, reindeer, horses and singers who make the most extraordinary noises on the planet. Like Mali or Madagascar before it, the Republic of Tuva has suddenly become famous because of its music, and this bizarre double bill showed how the ancient and eerie art of Tuvan "throat singing" has collided with western pop and the avant garde to remarkable effect.

First off, and by far the best, were the latest line-up of the Tuvan rock band, Yat-Kha. Now a five-piece with a girl singer included in their line-up, these unexpected heroes of last year's Womad festival showed how they have survived a year in which they have been feted by world music audiences and signed to Paddy Moloney's now sadly defunct Wicklow Records.

They have got better, playing their updated treatment of local songs about "horses and girls" with passion, obvious enjoyment and a sense of danger, easing from patches of controlled discord to bursts of wild guitar work to show their sense of dynamics, and then bringing in traditional instruments that looked like early cellos and had names like the igil and doshpular.

They looked like a throw-back to the psychedelic 1960s, with their long hair and velvet shirts, and sounded like nothing on earth, with the two male singers switching from almost-conventional sounds to impossibly low growls and what sounded like weird industrial buzzing effects.

Yat-Kha are strange, but strangely accessible. Some of the songs had unexpected echoes of Celtic dance tunes, then veered off to eastern, at times almost Chinese-sounding, influences. The band speak little English but their leader, Albert Kuvezin, has developed a fine sense of dry humour. "They call this Tuvan throat singing, but I've never heard a human sing without using their throats - ha!" he announced. He finished a song about a Tuvan cowboy fooled by a girl from the frozen north (she beats his horse by riding a reindeer across the ice) with a question to the audience: "Can you ride? I can hear that you can't. Ha!"

They were an impossible act to follow, as headliner Sainkho Namtchylak was to discover. She's been working outside Tuva for a while, in Russia and then the west, collaborating with the likes of Evan Parker and building a reputation on the experimental jazz circuit. Now, with Tuvan music in fashion, she seems to have lost direction. She came on with shaved head, white face and flowing white dress and acted out the songs by wandering around the stage, often with her head in her hands. She, too, had an extraordinary voice but her material sounded strangely dated.

Partly this was the fault of her backing band, with acoustic guitars, double-bass and Tuvan traditional instruments, dominated by an infuriating sound-effects man who added anything from bird-song to pre-recorded rhythm tracks. There was a sub-Tom Waits clanking blues that almost worked, as did a couple of gentle ballads, but she was trying too hard to shock. Yat-Kha had already done that, with exuberance and charm.

Yat-Kha and Sainkho Namtchylak play the Sir Jack Lyons Concert Hall, University of York (01904 432439), tonight, then tour.
